column2: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank appear to have benefited as hedge funds shift their prime-brokerage business in a "flight to quality."
Carl C. Icahn has hit a bump along the hedge-fund road.

The head of Morgan Stanley's commodities trading shop is stepping down, The New York Post reported. John Shapiro, who helped launch Morgan's energy-trading operation, has told executives he plans to retire at the end of the year.
Microsoft and Yahoo have been holding separate talks with other potential media partners after their negotiations with each other broke down, Reuters reported citing unnamed sources.

Bain Capital, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Silver Lake and the buyout arm of Goldman Sachs are among the private equity funds that have made it to the next round of bidding for a significant stake in the mobile services unit of China's Huawei, The Financial Times reported, citing people familiar with the auction.

Landmark Communicationsis expected to announce the sale of The Weather Channel to a group made up of NBC Universal, Blackstone Group and Bain Capital within two days, Reuters reported citing unnamed sources.
The Belgian-Dutch financial services group Fortis will sell about 10 percent of ABN Amro's Dutch operations to Deutsche Bank for 709 million euros ($1.12 billion).
As companies like Taylor Wimpey are forced to abandon necessary fundraising efforts, some analysts told The Telegraph that the equity markets are being rocked by the worst conditions in 20 years.
From The Onion:
Morgan Stanley will sell half its remaining stake in MSCI, a company best known for its international stock indexes that went public last year, for about $850 million, The Financial Times reported.

AMR's American Airlines, British Airways and Iberia are gearing up to apply for antitrust immunity in order to form a joint venture that could create a trans-Atlantic aviation giant, The Financial Times reported.
What's on the minds of deal-makers in these tough times?

In a bid to repair its reputation following a 40 percent loss on its $1 billion Endeavour Fund, Endeavour Capital will launch a new fund with a little help from Barclays, The Wall Street Journal reported citing people familiar with the matter.

Premier Investments may drop its A$809 million ($778 million) hostile takeover bid for Australian specialty clothing retailer Just Group after the latter cut earnings forecasts, Bloomberg News reported.

Airbus's former chief executive, Gustav Humbert, has been placed under formal investigation as part of a probe into allegations of insider trading at European aerospace group EADS, a Paris judicial source told Reuters on Wednesday.

Energy Recovery, July's first initial public offering, spiced up a generally barren market for new stocks on Wednesday. Shares of the company, which makes devices used in water desalination, were priced at $8.50 apiece, near the high end of the expected range of $7 to $9. They rose to $10 on the Nasdaq.
BHP Billiton said on Thursday that U.S. antitrust authorities had largely cleared its effort to acquire rival Rio Tinto for $170 billion.
More of your user-generated comedy (send via the comment link below):
Youku.com has secured $30 million in a financing round led by Maverick Capital, Variety reported. One of China's leading online video sites, it will use the funding for expansion.

In a high-stakes case of sibling rivalry, a consortium led by Indian billionaire Anil Ambani is considering taking a majority stake in South African mobile operator MTN to help thwart a potential legal challenge to the deal from his brother, Mukesh Ambani, The Financial Times reported.
In a deal that will eliminate a legal tussle, International Business Machines has agreed to buy Platform Solutions. The move also removes a potential competitor for I.B.M.'s mainframe business.
Taylor Nelson Sofres has rejected a fourth unsolicited takeover offer from WPP Group. Taylor, the British market-research company, previously agreed to merge with Germany's GfK, Bloomberg News said.

Federal prosecutors have dropped criminal charges against a former executive at AIG Global Investment in connection with a supposed scheme to bribe Azerbaijan officials over the privatization of the State Oil Company of the Azerbaijan Republic.

In a sign of apparent backpedaling by officials here, the Russian government said on Wednesday that it would expedite work permits for the chief executive of a BP joint venture, and five other senior staff members.

SK C&C, a provider of information technology services that is part of Korea's SK conglomerate, has withdrawn its initial public offering, citing weak stock market conditions. The choppy markets have contributed to a sharp decline in the volume of new listings across Asia in the first half, Finance Asia reported.

Two more firms shelved plans for initial public offerings in Asia, adding further gloom to a market which recently showed signs of a revival after a dismal start to the year. The news comes on the heels of the shelving of Korea's SK C&C's potential $1.2 billion I.P.O. due to averse market conditions.

Hedge fund Highbridge Capital Management is attempting to raise $1 billion for a fund focused on buying bank assets that have been pummeled by the credit crisis, The New York Post reported citing an unnamed investor who was considering committing funds.

ForeScout Technologies has raised $8 million from previous investors, Venture Beat reported. The firm makes a security platform combining clientless network access control and intrusion prevention, and saw 80 percent growth last year.
Drake & Scull International plans to raise $326 million for regional expansion and acquisitions from a Dubai initial public share sale this month, Bloomberg News reported.

Flipping through the coming weekend's Book Review, you'll find a quadrant of faces - two pairs, each featuring a mug shot and a present-day photograph. The images are from "Breach of Peace: Portraits of the 1961 Mississippi Freedom Riders," by Eric Etheridge (Atlas, $45), a book chronicling a remarkable moment in civil rights history that merits a few more words than the 30 we were able to give it in print.
Today's vocabulary lesson, from Wikipedia:

About 60 percent of the units in the Trump Soho in New York City have been sold, Ivanka Trump told the London Times last week for an article headlined, "Trump kids bet on rich Europeans to back New York hotel/condo."
When a family in Rotterdam needed more space, there was nowhere to go but up.
Katie Hoff set an American record in the 200-meter individual medley and Michael Phelps won the 200-meter butterfly at the United States Olympic trials.
It could be a version of the "Harry and Louise" television commercial that helped kill Hillary Rodham Clinton's health care plan in 1994, only this time, it will be in favor of reform.
Location: Reno, Nev.
No matter how much you train in the heat, it will never be easy, athletes and researchers say.
“The Wackness” makes a good-faith effort to steer clear of coming-of-age story clichés, and succeeds and fails in roughly equal measure.
For years, Northrop Grumman, a leading military contractor, kept a Web page about the three employees held hostage in Colombia, who were freed on Wednesday.

When an international sports court upheld doping charges against Floyd Landis this week, reaffirming his disqualification as the 2006 Tour de France winner, it was a reminder of the dark cloud that still hovers over cycling as this year’s Tour begins on Saturday. That cloud hovers even over its past champions. "I know already now that I’m not going to miss being in the race," says Johan Bruyneel, the hard-driving and strategic Belgian-born team director whose U.S. Postal Service and Discovery Channel teams won the Tour de France eight times in the last nine years. "That’s a feeling I’ve had for the last three years. It basically wasn’t fun anymore. The fun was winning the race, not being in the race.".

The parade of a sports team through Manhattan is supposed to mean something. The Canyon of Heroes is the dream of any athlete who plays here. Players who have been shredded by the news media and booed by the fans know that, if they can get through it all, there’s that reward awaiting them. If you can make it there, it’s all worth it. We save our parades for cultural celebrations, athletes and war heroes. That sounds about right.
Lawyers for Brian McNamee, Roger Clemens's former trainer, asked a court to dismiss the defamation suit the former Yankees pitcher filed against their client.

Leanness doesn’t come easy, even for Olympians, if the results of a recent survey of their weight control strategies are any indication - and male athletes deal with their weight issues more poorly than women.

The Red Sox face this Yankees in a four-game series starting tonight, but in an odd twist it turns out to be Boston’s second-most important series of the week. The Red Sox just finished three game s with the Tampa Bay Rays, the team with the best record in baseball and one they’ve been chasing in the standings for most of the season. Does Tampa’s ascendency steal any of the luster of the Boston-New York rivalry?.
By JOHN BRANT.
The Mets lost a two-run lead in the eighth inning and again failed to muster a comeback, losing to the Cardinals in a game where the chances for victory were there for the Mets' taking.
A federal judge said that the wiretapping law established by Congress was the “exclusive” means for the president to eavesdrop on Americans, ruling out presidential authority to override that law.
Jason Giambi hit a grand slam and drove in a season-best six runs, Alex Rodriguez added a three-run shot and the host Yankees pounded the Texas Rangers.
Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee sprinter from South Africa, finished well outside the Olympic qualifying time in his first able-bodied race in nearly a year.
Zach Scruggs, son of the Mississippi lawyer Richard F. Scruggs, was sentenced to 14 months in prison for his part in a scheme to bribe a judge.
The United States Supreme Court rejected an effort by victims of a deadly refinery explosion to block a plea deal between the plant’s owner, BP P.L.C., and prosecutors.
Massachusetts will invest in renewable energy and require utility companies to obtain energy from sources other than fossil fuels under a new measure.
The Pentagon’s inspector general, Claude M. Kicklighter, is resigning after just over a year in the job.
Luis Castillo and Jerry Manuel are wondering whether it is Castillo’s strained hip flexor will put him on the disabled list.
Officials unveiled the prototype of the first American coin with readable Braille characters.
The lawyer for Tim Donaghy, the disgraced former N.B.A. referee, wants a retired federal agent to testify in court about information Donaghy provided the government.
Pitcher Joe Saunders matched Brandon Webb for the major league lead with his 12th win, fueling the Los Angeles Angels 7-4 victory against the Oakland Athletics.
The graphics chip maker warned on Wednesday that revenue and gross margin would miss analysts’ estimates, sending its shares down 25 percent in late trading.
The Marks & Spencer Group said sales had dropped the most since 2005 and ousted Steven Esom, its top food executive, after his unit had the worst quarter in at least a decade.
Australian retail sales rose in May at the fastest rate in six months. Sales increased 0.7 percent from April, the Bureau of Statistics said.
Deutsche Bank says it expects to have a profitable second-quarter despite market uncertainty and the wavering global economy when its results are reported July 31.
The Belgian-Dutch financial services group Fortis will sell about 10 percent of ABN Amro’s Dutch operations to Deutsche Bank for 709 million euros ($1.12 billion).
French authorities filed preliminary charges against a former chief executive of Airbus, Gustav Humbert, in an investigation into reported insider trading.
Alfredo Amezaga hit a go-ahead, two-run homer to lead the Marlins defeat of the Nationals.
The state comptroller said that his office had uncovered numerous instances of child care centers in New York City misspending public funds.
A Bronx judge has entered a $930,000 civil judgment against a bookkeeper who stole from a Riverdale prep school and is now serving time in state prison for grand larceny.
The city of Seattle and the SuperSonics reached a last-minute settlement before a judge was to rule in their KeyArena lease dispute.
A strike by concrete-truck drivers has all but halted work at scores of sites, from the Freedom Tower at ground zero to modest apartment buildings.
Bush administration officials knew that an oil company with close ties to President Bush planned to sign an oil deal with the Kurdistan government, counter to U.S. policy.
Hank Steinbrenner, the team’s co-chairman, aired his frustrations with the team’s anemic offense in an interview on Wednesday.
Higher gas prices and tolls seem to be reducing the number of cars clogging New York City’s streets.
The decision to eliminate more than one-sixth of the newsroom staff and publish 15 percent fewer pages is the deepest of a series of cuts at the Tribune Company as it tries to stay afloat.
After the deaths of two immigrant detainees, a review of the cases prompted recommendations for faster reporting of deaths and better sharing of information.
The New York Times won three Gerald Loeb Awards for reporting on subjects that ranged from the rural factories of China to the rarefied boardrooms of Wall Street.
METRO.
The boy, Misael Fuentes, was rescued along with seven members of his family from an apartment fire in Brooklyn early Tuesday.
Some of the most important decisions came on 5-to-4 votes — a stark reminder that the court is just one justice away from solidifying a far-right majority.
Katie Hoff and Natalie Coughlin, both of whom have set a world record in the United States Olympic trials, had a rare showdown in the 200-meter I.M. Wednesday.
Detroit automakers will temporarily lay off upward of 25,000 workers this year, but are still obligated to pay them more than half of their take-home wages.
An ex-convict who spent more than three years in the Illinois State Prison for aggravated robbery is said to have killed eight people indiscriminately.
Sean Avery, the controversial forward, signed a four-year, $15.5 million contract with the Dallas Stars on Wednesday.
President Lech Kaczynski of Poland said in an interview that he would sign the Lisbon Treaty to strengthen the European Union only if Ireland approved it in a new referendum.
Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the Hezbollah leader, confirmed that the group would hand over two captured Israeli soldiers in exchange for five Lebanese prisoners in Israel.
Judges at the International Criminal Court ordered the release of Thomas Lubanga, a former Congolese militia leader, saying that he could not get a fair trial.
The world of St.-Émilion wine was thrown into turmoil when a local court ruled that the latest reclassification of these Bordeaux wines, made in 2006, was not impartial and should be annulled.
Nascar fans are famous for traveling long distances to watch races, but with gas at $4 a gallon, or higher, they are being forced to rethink their travel plans.
Technogym, an exercise equipment maker, is expanding its reach to countries with few health clubs, in a strategy to survive an economic downturn in the United States.
President Bush called for Congress to renew his global AIDS initiative and urged other nations to live up to their promises to fight poverty and disease on the continent.
The story of the tiny St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church and its efforts to rebuild is a microcosm of the troubled effort to reconstruct the World Trade Center.
Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but people briefed on it said it was worth as much as $150 million.
Companies ripping off taxpayers in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars may never be fully prosecuted unless Congress does more to go after war profiteers.
Jailing and criminalizing young Americans causes a lot more crime than it prevents. Congress should update and reauthorize the 1974 law on juvenile justice.
Urban decline is dragging down Connecticut. The local governments need to work together to shape a new vision for the state’s cities.
The decision to expedite work permits for the six staff members of a BP joint venture was a sign of apparent backpedaling by the Russian government.
Two rock climbers, Hans Florine and Yuji Hirayama, broke the record for the fastest ascent of a 2,900-foot wall in Yosemite.
When the Red Sox arrive at Yankee Stadium on Thursday to begin a four-game series, both teams will be chasing the Tampa Bay Rays, who are in first place.
Orders to American factories grew by the smallest amount in three months in May, reflecting slumping demand for autos, heavy machinery and steel.
Federal prosecutors dropped criminal charges against David B. Pinkerton in connection with a supposed scheme to bribe Azerbaijan officials.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton visited storm-damaged orchards in upstate New York as she transitioned back from being a presidential candidate.
Dogs and their owners weighed in on Leona Helmsley’s secret earmark of up to $8 billion of her real estate fortune for the care and welfare of dogs.
Tubs of Kozy Shack rice and chocolate puddings are now being sold at Shea Stadium alongside the hot dogs and giant pretzels, and are being included in children’s meals at the ballpark.
After four decades in New York City, a tiny and quiet Roman Catholic order is moving to Mexico.
A fire that’s been burning for 11 days intensified, prompting a mandatory evacuation of the coastal retreat.
The president of a New Jersey company that owns the dump truck that crashed in Chinatown last week has been charged with unlicensed collection of trade waste.
Jason Barlett knocked in two runs to cap off a six-run seventh inning as Tampa Bay rallied past visiting Boston to complete a three game sweep.
The comely, country fashions sported by Texas polygamists while fighting to regain custody of their children are now available in youth sizes on the Web.
Under increasing public pressure, the federal government lifted a freeze on new solar projects, barely a month after it was put into effect.
Senators Barack Obama and John McCain are at odds over a California ballot initiative that would amend the state’s Constitution to ban same-sex marriage.
Regulators in the state say Trans World Assurance violated rules adopted in 2007 to prevent the sale of misleading or unsuitable life insurance policies to military personnel.
Summer is a great time to catch up on your reading. You might even be able to look up books available at your library with the WorldCat database.
How do I create a slide show on a DVD that combines stills and brief movies from a digital camera?
It seems easy enough to add images into a Microsoft Word file, but how can these graphics be pasted down so that they do not slip all over the place when text is added?
The United States military said there were no serious injuries when the UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter was brought down south of Afghanistan’s capital.
The particle research laboratory at the center of a budget showdown in Congress will resume work, allaying some fears of long-term damage to basic research in the United States.
The Roman Catholic bishop of Richmond, Va., apologized after workers from a Catholic organization helped a teenager in its care have an abortion.
An accountant started a fictitious company to embezzle millions of dollars from his employer, Tishman Construction, prosecutors said.
Dr. Seamans was NASA’s nuts-and-bolts manager of the Apollo moon-landing program, later serving as the first administrator of the federal energy research agency.
As the state lurches toward a new era of natural gas production in upstate New York, oil and gas law are becoming important things to grasp.
Brett Favre dismissed an ESPN report that he is considering coming out of retirement, saying “it’s all rumor.”
European Union residents would be able to receive most health care treatment anywhere in the 27-nation bloc without prior authorization under a proposal published on Wednesday.
Mr. Pont was a football-coaching lifer who was best remembered for taking Indiana University to its first bowl game in 1968.
As the celebrations begin in Canada and the United States, the people of North America are heirs to two great ideas: Thomas Jefferson’s — and Samuel de Champlain’s.
Americans would come to regard the Statue of Liberty as a beacon for immigrants. The French have always related it to their complex struggle for liberty.
Childhood lead poisoning declined by 15 percent last year, reaching the lowest rate ever recorded in New York City.
The United Steelworkers signed a merger agreement with the largest labor organization in Britain and Ireland to create what union leaders said would be the world’s first global union.
The handcuffs may not be coming off cellphone owners, but they are getting looser.
A Brooklyn judge has ordered the removal of a metal fence that separates the Red Hook Recreation Area from the Henry Street Basin.
Only a few weeks ago the Japanese government finally, and unexpectedly, recognized the Ainu, who live on Japan’s northernmost island, as an “indigenous people.”
Even something as straightforward as buying a new television — a mere display, the ads wink — spawns a salivating beast of Ethernet, HDMI and surround-sound tentacles.
NEW YORK.
American Airlines said it expects to cut nearly 7,000 jobs, about 8 percent of its work force, by the end of 2008, as it reduces flights and grounds aircraft due to high fuel prices.
It was bound to happen sooner or later: Generation X nostalgia and modern technology have come together in the “Knight Rider” Global Positioning System from Mio Technology.
The Imation Atom works with Windows, Apple and Linux computers, and it lets users protect data with a password and split the storage space into multiple virtual “drives.”
Crude oil closed at $143.57 a barrel, another record, sending shudders through financial markets already worried about the prospect of a global economic slowdown.
To the Editor:.
Linda Dodwell, an intrepid motorcyclist, adventurer and artist, built a compound in California that was inspired by her solo ride across the Australian outback.

“America’s Got Talent” raised NBC’s ratings on Tuesday as 12 million viewers tuned in to the talent competition from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. NBC led the night over all by a small margin, finishing third in the 8 p.m. time slot with “Celebrity Family Feud” (7 million), behind ABC’s “Wipeout” (9.4 million) and CBS’s “NCIS” repeat (8 million). CBS ranked second for the night in total viewers with “48 Hours Mystery” at 9 (7.6 million) and a “Without a Trace” rerun at 10 (6.7 million), but among adults 18 to 49 the network finished last. ABC and Fox shared second place in that demographic. Fox earned the night’s highest ratings in that age group with “Hell’s Kitchen” at 9, although the show drew a modest audience with 7.9 million total viewers. Fox struggled during the 8 p.m. hour, however, with “The Moment of Truth” (4.6 million). ABC’s ratings dropped off following “Wipeout,” as the network garnered 6.3 million at 9 for “I Survived a Japanese Game Show” and 5.7 million at 10 for “Primetime.”.
After two and a half months of talks Actors’ Equity Association reached a tentative agreement with the Broadway League, averting a strike.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will feature classical music and rock in its concert series this fall. In addition to Itzhak Perlman, above left, the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra playing Saint-Saëns’s “Carnival of the Animals” and the farewell season of the Guarneri String Quartet, artists including Patti Smith, above right, Richie Havens and Lesley Gore will be featured. Music from Mali, Mexico, Spain and Turkey will also be performed.
The Wilmette Theater hopes to come to the rescue of a beleaguered production of “Ragtime.”

Shakira, above, has become the latest pop star to leave a major record company for Live Nation, the international touring giant that has begun signing marquee names for lucrative all-purpose contracts. After months of speculation Shakira, the 31-year-old Colombian singer of Lebanese descent who is a strong international touring draw, has signed a 10-year deal that encompasses tours, recordings, sponsorship and merchandise. Neither Shakira’s representatives nor Live Nation would disclose the value of the deal, but people close to the negotiations, who spoke anonymously because they were not authorized to discuss them, said that depending on Shakira’s performance over the 10 years, it would probably be worth $70 million to $100 million. Shakira’s contract with Epic Records calls for three more albums — one in English, one in Spanish and a compilation — but the touring and other rights of the Live Nation deal would begin immediately.

Employees at the free weekly The Village Voice avoided a strike by agreeing to a three-year contract Wednesday morning with Village Voice Media. “We got a deal 3 o’clock this morning,” said Tom Robbins, a Voice columnist and shop steward for the United Auto Workers Local 2110. “We won a good victory for unions.” He added that the contract did not require union members to pay any portion of the premiums of their health care, and it also calls for a raise. The contract was unanimously ratified by the membership on Wednesday morning. “We had a celebratory drink of a little Scotch,” Mr. Robbins said, “and then went home.”.

The American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry said that NBC should end “The Baby Borrowers,” a reality television show that separates babies and toddlers from their parents and places them temporarily with teenage strangers. “A child’s sense of security should not be gambled with,” said Robert Hendren, the president of the academy. NBC has said that the “Baby Borrowers” is a social experiment that can educate teenagers on the responsibilities of parenting. The parents are able to monitor their children through video cameras.

After a big opening, Coldplay’s new album, “Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends” (Capitol), lost two thirds of its sales in its second week out, but it is still the No. 1 album in the country, selling 249,000 more copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Lil Wayne’s “Tha Carter III” (Cash Money/Universal) was No. 2 with 209,000, and Disney’s “Camp Rock” soundtrack, with the teenage stars Demi Lovato and the Jonas Brothers, was No. 3 with 169,000 sales. The new Mötley Crüe album, “Saints of Los Angeles” (Mötley), opened at No. 4 with 99,000, and Three 6 Mafia’s new “Last 2 Walk” (Hypnotize Minds/Columbia) bowed at No. 5 with 77,000. Shinedown’s new release, “The Sound of Madness” (Atlantic), was No. 8 with 50,000 sales.

The actress Tatum O’Neal, below, who was arrested in June on a charge of cocaine possession, pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct in Manhattan on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. Judge Elisa Koenderman of Manhattan Criminal Court ordered Ms. O’Neal, 44, to spend two half-day sessions in a drug treatment program and pay a $95 fee. If she follows through, the case will be dismissed.
The Nokia N78 cellphone has a built-in FM transmitter that allows you to share your favorite whale-call-based dance tracks with the group over the home stereo or car radio.
Nikon’s D700, priced at $2,995, packs the considerable abilities of the company’s hefty $5,000 flagship, the D3, into a more svelte 2.2-pound device.
EyeClops Night Vision goggles use infrared L.E.D.’s that shine a wide beam of infrared light up to 50 feet away.
G-Unit’s show at the Nokia Theater on Tuesday night figured to be full of tumult, but instead 50 Cent and the remaining members of G-Unit were on their best behavior.
The world’s best cyclists are cooped up in small French hotels, anxiously awaiting the start of the race. They have been preparing to suffer for the past six months.
On Tuesday night the old songs were as precise and galvanizing as ever. And the Feelies were their old, undemonstrative selves onstage.
The creative director of Barneys New York shopped for house gifts that would suit the hypothetical characters described in his new book.
Zimbabwe’s opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, rejected the African Union’s call for talks with Robert Mugabe, citing continuing government-backed violence.
Francis Menotti broke a long silence on Wednesday and accused Italian politicians of callously throwing him out of the festival founded by his father, the composer Gian Carlo Menotti.
In London, the Treasury secretary called for a new regulatory system that would allow even large financial institutions to fail without risking a wider market collapse.
A change in home life, as much as in career, seems to appeal to a new breed of back-to-the-landers: former urban professionals.

The European Team Championships finished in Pau, France, last Saturday.

An Illinois man thought to be responsible for the deaths of eight people in Illinois and Missouri made a brief court appearance and was ordered held on a charge of murder.

By day, Lesley Higgins works as a compliance director on Gov. David Paterson’s campaign staff. But Thursday night, she’ll be competing for a spot on the 2008 Olympic team in steeplechase.

Chinese wrestler Luo Meng tested positive for a diuretic, a drug that could be used to rid the body of performance-enhancing substances.

The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about doctors who remunerate patients for posting recommendations or videos of their procedures on the Internet, misstated the affiliation of Dr. Kathy Faber-Langendoen, a professor of bioethics and medicine who said that she sees nothing wrong in patients’ voluntarily surrendering their privacy for a doctor’s discount. She is with the SUNY Upstate Medical University in Syracuse, not SUNY in Syracuse.

Large tomato-red ceramic pots filled with boxwood line the gravel path to the entrance of Berns Fry Ltd., above left, an antiques shop just opened in Bridgehampton, N.Y. Inside, furnishings in beige and white play off earth-tone walls.

Cole Kelly took turns hiking with his sons, Jack, 2 years old, and Luke, 10 months, in 4 new carriers. He also tested a more economical four-year-old carrier that has remained popular despite not having been updated.
Designers seem to be having more fun than usual playing up denim pieces in their collections.
This summer, a new generation of pocket-size gadgets offer anyone willing to spend $129.99 or more a way to use the Global Positioning System to track the people, pets and possessions they love.

In 2004, when the Rev. Uwem Akpan applied to the graduate program in creative writing at the University of Michigan, his folder attracted a lot of attention. He was both a Nigerian and a Jesuit priest, and the program was unused to applicants from either category. And though Father Akpan's talent was abundantly evident, if a little raw, Eileen Pollack, the director of the program, recalled recently, there was some hesitation on the part of the admissions committee. ''There were discussions about having a priest be part of workshops where students would be writing about sex and drugs,'' Ms. Pollack said. But in the end Father Akpan was admitted, and he endeared himself, Ms. Pollack recalled, by showing up on the first day of class wearing a University of Michigan sweatshirt. ''Everyone loved him,'' she said. ''It turned out he had had more experience of the dark side of the world than all the other students put together.''

Funeral services will be held on July 3 at 10:30am at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, NJ. MASON--Jonathan, of Wellington, FL and Southampton, NY died at his home in Wellington on Sunday, June 22nd. He was 92. The son of Alexander Taylor Mason and Susanne McKee Lee, Jonathan was born February 19th, 1916 in New York City. A graduate of the Hotchkiss School and Princeton University Class of 1938, he later served with Army intelligence during World War Two. After working with Bache and Company on Wall Street, he helped launch the Japan Fund in 1962, the first closed end fund to invest in Japanese stocks, and served as its longtime Chairman. He also served on the boards of the Japan Society, Asia Society, International House and the US-Japan Foundation. Jonathan is survived by his loving wife of 22 years, Natsuki Nakayama Mason; his two sons, Alexander Mason of Owings Mills, MD and Southampton, NY and Anthony Mason of Rye, NY; and five grandchildren: Taylor, Christopher, Emily, Olivia and Nicholas A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, August 23rd at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in Southampton.

LANG--Theresa. The staff of the Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Center for Research and Education at the New York Hospital Queens deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend, Theresa Lang. We are grateful for her dedication to alleviating human suffering, and her generosity and vision that led to the creation of the Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Center for Research and Education. Her warmth, wit, charm and commitment will always be remembered. We extend our condolences to her husband Eugene, and to the entire family. Phyllis August, M.D., Theresa Lang Director Karen Hultberg, Administrative Director Daniel Lorber, M.D., Associate Director Staff of The Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Center for Research and Education LANG--Theresa. It is with tremendous sadness that the entire New York Hospital Queens family mourns the passing of Theresa Lang, a longtime member of our hospital's Board of Trustees, charter member and past president of our Women's Auxiliary, and hospital volunteer. Mrs. Lang's dedication to hospital service began during WWII, when she served as a Red Cross volunteer nurse aid. It was then that she laid the foundation for a lifelong commitment to advancing health care accessibility and enhancing the health services available for the people in the borough where she grew up--Queens. Mrs. Lang and her husband, Eugene, helped New York Hospital Queens establish several significant programs, including The Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Community Health Education Center in 1984, which later evolved to become The Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Center for Research and Education in 1998. It is due to their generosity and keen vision for the future, that the Lang Research Center now serves as a national model of excellence for a research center established at a community hospital. Other hospital programs that were founded with the assistance of Mrs. Lang include: The Theresa Lang Children's Ambulatory Center in 1997, the Theresa Lang Pediatric Emergency and Trauma Center in 2001, and the endowment of the Theresa Lang Directorship for the Lang Research Center in 2007. For her enduring commitment to community health care, Mrs. Lang was presented New York Hospital Queens' highest honor, the Pacesetter Award, in 1996. Over the years she was a mentor and friend to the many people with whom she worked--the Board of Trustees, the Women's Auxiliary, hospital administrators, physicians and employees. Undeniably, Mrs. Lang's leadership has had a significant impact upon the hospital's programs that are available today for the people of Queens. On behalf of all of our trustees, administration, clinical leadership and medical staff, employees, volunteers and auxilians, we offer our condolences to her family, including her beloved husband, Eugene, her children Jane, Stephen and David, her eight grandchildren, and five greatgrandchildren. George F. Heinrich, M.D. Chairman Stephen S. Mills President and Chief Executive Officer, New York Hospital Queens LANG--Theresa. The trustees, faculty, students, and staff of The Rockefeller University community deeply mourn the loss of our cherished friend Theresa Lang, an esteemed member of the Board of Trustees for more than two decades. Terry Lang joined The Rockefeller University Council in 1984 and was elected to the Board in 1986. She was named an honorary member of the staff of The Rockefeller University Hospital, in recognition of her leadership as chairman of the Board's Hospital Committee. The Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Professorship, which Terry's beloved husband established in her honor, reflects their shared passion for scientific inquiry and belief that basic research can provide answers to the unsolved questions of human health and disease. Terry will be remembered for her numerous philanthropic and pro bono activities, including her service to hospital patients and their families as a volunteer in several New York medical institutions. She put into action her conviction that there is a natural kinship between biomedical science and medical care, and that each has much to learn from the other. As a philanthropist, as a knowledgeable advocate for physicians and their patients, as a dedicated trustee, and as an exemplary wife and mother, Terry made the world a better place. She will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences are sent to Gene; their children, Jane, David, and Stephen; and her entire family. Paul Nurse, President Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Barry Coller, Physician-in-Chief Jules Hirsch and Attallah Kappas, Physicians-in-Chief Emeriti Jeffrey Ravetch, Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Professor LANG--Theresa. The Board of Directors and share holders of Fifth 912 Corp., 912 Fifth Avenue, mourn the passing of Theresa Lang, beloved wife of fellow board member Eugene Lang and wish to express their condolences to the family. Board of Directors LANG--Theresa, died peacefully in her sleep on June 30, 2008 in her New York home. Beloved wife for more than 62 years of Eugene M. Lang, she was the adored mother of and survived by, her children Jane, David and Stephen, their spouses Paul, Belinda (former) and Kristina; by her grandchildren Lucy, Daniel, Noah, Grace, Jessica, Benjamin, Joanna and Jacob; by her great - grandchildren Maitlynne, Alexander, Teddy, Thomas and Erin; by her great-nieces Charlotte, Lily and Daisy; by her sister-inlaw Barbara; and by many dear friends. Theresa-Terry as she was known-was a rare human being. Kind, sincere and generous, she represented the nobility of compassionate service, the sterling qualities of friendship and the profound meaning of family. Daughter of Albert and Lucy Volmar, she was born in 1918 in Greenpoint, NYC. She graduated from Jamaica High School in 1936 and, in 1997, at the age of 79, she graduated from Marymount-Manhattan College with a B.A. to which, as a Trustee of the college, she added an honorary L.H.D. degree early this year. The Theresa Lang Theater and the Theresa Lang Scholarship fund at MarymountManhattan will continue to recognize her cherished college relationship. Terry's lifelong commitment to volunteer service began in 1942, when employed as an executive secretary in a Long Island aircraft parts factory, she volunteered to serve as a nurse's aid on evenings and weekends at the Queens General Hospital, After the war, she transferred her voluntarism to the New York Hospital-Queens (then the Booth Memorial Hospital) and continued her service, uninterrupted by her marriage to Eugene in early 1946, throughout her life. She joined the hospital's Women's Auxiliary, became its president and since 1975, a hospital Trustee. This lifetime relationship is memorialized by the NYH-Q's Theresa Lang Emergency Pediatric Clinic, Ambulatory Pediatric Clinic, Auditorium and Center for Research and Education. In 1975, Terry joined the New York City Visiting Committee of the United Hospital fund, became its chair and, in 2008, was named Hospital Trustee of the Year. In 1986, she became a Trustee of Rockefeller University and chaired its Hospital Committee. She also served on the Boards of he New York City Opera, Roundabout Theater, and the Hunter College Foundation. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. Family will receive friends on Wednesday 6:30-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday at 10am at St. Jean Baptiste Catholic Church, Lexington Ave. at E. 76th St. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Center for Research and Education at the New York Hospital-Queens or the Theresa Lang Scholarship Fund at MarymountManhattan College. LANG--Theresa. We mourn the passing of our founding member, past president and beloved friend. The Women's Auxiliary of NY Hospital Queens

France's system of using sweeping arrests and aggressive interrogations and prosecutions to combat terrorism prevents suspects from receiving a fair trial, a human rights group said. A report by Human Rights Watch said that the practices resulted in too many arrests and convictions based on scanty evidence. It said the much-used charge of ''criminal association in relation to a terrorist undertaking'' was so sweeping that it allowed the authorities to arrest and interrogate many people even when they had nothing to do with suspected terrorist activity. The Justice Ministry defended the country's counterterrorism strategy but said there would be no official comment on the report itself.

ROBBINS--Louise, nee Louise Severance Nash, at Greenwich, CT. Died June 30, 2008, aged 80. Much loved mother of Anne, Julia and Nash and grandmother of Phebe and Helen. HIKING with backpacking gear is a matter of balancing weight and necessity. Add a baby and the equation gets complicated. ''You want a pack that will allow you to also pack in other items besides the child, or your hiking partner will get stuck with a very heavy load,'' said Tim Hauserman, the author of ''Monsters in the Woods: Backpacking With Children.''

Seamans Jr., NASA's nuts-and-bolts manager of the Apollo moon-landing program, who later served as secretary of the Air Force and then as the first administrator of the federal energy research agency, died Saturday at his home in Beverly Farms, Mass. He was 89. The cause was a heart attack, his son Joseph said.

The Service Employees International Union has two million members and substantial resources -- more than $75 million for political efforts between now and November -- and it is planning to use them on Senator Barack Obama's behalf in states that have not been traditional battlegrounds. Colorado, North Carolina and Virginia will see an infusion of the union's money and staff members, said Anna Burger, the union's secretary-treasurer. The strategy appears to dovetail with the Obama campaign's plans to compete in those states, all of which President Bush won in 2004.

SAPIR--Isidore, 93, died peacefully on Tuesday at home in West Palm Beach, comforted by family after suffering from a stroke. A good and wise man, he was loved by all who knew him and served as a role model for his family. His children, Robert (Jeri), Glenn (Nancy), Donald (Janet), Marlene (Tom) and Eric (Vivian), twelve grandchildren and five great-grandchildren will miss his loving kindness, jokes and gin rummy games. Rena (nee Goldfield), the love of his life and wife of 60 years, predeceased him. He was the youngest of seven children, and only his brother Harry survives. Born in NYC, he attended Townsend Harris H.S., C.C.N.Y. and Brooklyn Law, before serving as a captain in the Army Signal Corps during WWII. He built a thriving solo law practice and later served as general counsel and director of American Mayflower Life Insurance Co. and its successor, Genworth Financial. A longtime resident of Yonkers and Putnam Valley, NY, he retired to Florida in 1979. A supporter of Israel and Jewish philanthropies, he was past president of Midchester Jewish Center in Yonkers and Golden Lakes Temple in West Palm Beach. A service at Beth El Cemetery, Oradell, NJ, will be held today at 11am.

SIMON DOONAN, the creative director of Barneys New York, was dressed in a style reflecting the ideas in his newest book, ''Eccentric Glamour: Creating an Insanely More Fabulous You.'' In it, he creates three personality types: the flighty, exotic gypsy; the super-confident socialite; and the on-the-edge existentialist, and suggests that anyone who is tired of the ordinary should make the leap to eccentric glamour by cultivating one of those styles.

Charles Lloyd was responsible for a ton of words at the New York Society for Ethical Culture on Saturday night. At the outset of his JVC Jazz Festival concert he called up Charles Simic, the poet laureate of the United States, who read a handful of nocturnal poems. Later, for a second encore, Mr. Lloyd recited passages from the Bhagavad-Gita over a gentle drone. And during the pauses between songs he was a torrent of allusive patter, drawing on a fount of vintage hipster recollections. None of this is standard practice for a jazz performance. But then Mr. Lloyd, a tenor saxophonist and flutist, isn't a standard jazz musician, if such a thing exists. His career has been a curious study in elusiveness and fluctuation; Mr. Simic touched upon some of those cryptic qualities as he read a poem called ''Two for Charles Lloyd.'' (''Voice of solitude,'' he said. ''Voice of insomnia.'') But Mr. Lloyd, 70, gave his restlessness a tactile embodiment. His playing was vital enough to dispel any need for explanation.

The rest of the season will show what effect, if any, Joe Girardi's heated team meeting has on the Yankees. Girardi tries to project a calm exterior, rarely admitting to any kind of shortcoming by his team or players. But there is a toughness to Girardi, and he showed the team his ornery side in a half-hour meeting after Thursday's 7-0 loss.

Nebraska Beef Ltd. is expanding a recall announced this week to include all 5.3 million pounds of meat produced for ground beef from May 16 to June 26. The company’s products have been linked to an outbreak of E. coli affecting 40 people in Michigan and Ohio. Some products were sold by Kroger, which has recalled ground beef products in more than 20 states because the meat may have been contaminated. The company said Monday that beef involved in the original recall went to Nebraska, Colorado, Illinois, Michigan, New York, Pennsylvania and Texas. Thursday’s release did not specify whether the beef now being recalled went to additional states.

A doctor whose Wichita clinic is one of the nation’s few providers of late-term abortions was not indicted at the end of a six-month investigation on Wednesday by a citizen-initiated grand jury, an unusual practice allowed in only a handful of states. The jurors said their investigation into the clinic of the doctor, George Tiller, right, did not yield sufficient evidence of a crime, but they noted that a review of medical records “revealed a number of questionable late-term abortions” that might not have met a common interpretation of the words in state law, which limits abortions of viable fetuses to pregnant women who would otherwise face “substantial and irreversible impairment of a major bodily function.” The jury was convened after abortion opponents collected signatures to prompt the investigation.

Two lawyers accused of defrauding their clients in a diet-drug settlement of $65 million were sent back to jail, after a jury in Covington deadlocked and a federal judge declared a mistrial. The jury considered the case against the lawyers, William Gallion and Shirley Cunningham Jr., for eight days, and twice in two days sent out notes indicating it was stumped. A third defendant, Melbourne Mills Jr., was acquitted this week. All faced a single charge of conspiracy to commit wire fraud. The case has been watched in the horse racing industry because Mr. Gallion and Mr. Cunningham are part-owners of the 2007 Horse of the Year, Curlin. Prosecutors said they planned to request and schedule a new trial in the next two months. The lawyers were accused of keeping millions of dollars that should have gone to plaintiffs in a $200 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit over the diet drug fen-phen.

A federal jury convicted the former top accountant at the Cleveland Catholic Diocese of tax charges, but acquitted him of more serious charges related to kickback accusations. The jury in the trial of the man, Joseph H. Smith, 51, had been deliberating for nearly two weeks. The prosecution portrayed Mr. Smith as a manipulator who arranged $785,000 in kickbacks and secret payments because he felt he was underpaid. He was acquitted of more serious charges of mail fraud related to the alleged kickbacks, but convicted of six tax-related charges. A judge had earlier dismissed money laundering charges. Sentencing was set for Oct. 3. He faces a maximum of 20 years in prison.
It was a challenge for Manager Joe Girardi to keep his composure after the Yankees’ lifeless loss to Boston, in which Jon Lester, the Red Sox’ starter, was magnificent in a five-hit shutout.

Conor Jackson hit a winning two-run single Thursday as the Arizona Diamondbacks rallied from a five-run deficit in the ninth inning to defeat the visiting Milwaukee Brewers, 6-5.

A United Nations appeals court in The Hague cleared the former commander of Bosnian Muslim forces in Srebrenica, Naser Oric, left, of war crimes against Serbs. Mr. Oric, 41, a hero to Bosnian Muslims but vilified by Serbs, had been sentenced in 2006 to two years in prison by the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia for crimes committed by his forces during Bosnia’s 1992-95 war. The appeals court said prosecutors had failed to prove a link between him and the crimes committed by his subordinates.

TAIYO ONORATO/NICO KREBS: 'THE WHOLE SHEBANG' Marcel Broodthaers's ''Museum of Modern Art, Department of Eagles,'' that textbook example of postmodernism, seems to have inspired this installation by a pair of Swiss artists better known for their photography. But where Mr. Broodthaers created a fictitious museum department from a single, powerful symbol, Mr. Onorato and Mr. Krebs offer a series of oddities and one-liners. Thirty-two crudely fashioned, quasi-representational assemblages are displayed on pedestals throughout the black-walled gallery. Included are a brown paper teepee covered with peace signs, a laptop computer made of Styrofoam and painted silver, an urn oozing a Play-Doh-like substance and a small figure urinating on a cracked mirror. Birds appear to be a theme, perhaps in deference to Mr. Broodthaers: one is roasted on a spit, and another is covered with white droppings.

Rubyfruit Bar and Grill, a well-known lesbian bar and restaurant that opened in 1994 in the West Village, will soon close as a result of higher rents and the dispersal of the gay and lesbian community to other parts of the city, like Brooklyn. ''Back then in 1994 there wasn't this liberation yet for lesbian women, so it became a haven with private, intimate dinners, great wines, a place to hold hands and feel comfortable being out and having dinner,'' said Rubyfruit's owner, Debra C. Fierro, who announced her decision last weekend. ''Here we are in 2008, where they no longer need to have their own place. It's kind of a good thing, I guess.''

BARRY HARRIS TRIO The bebop piano trio, once a staple of the New York jazz landscape, has become something of a rare sighting in recent seasons. Blame changing tastes or the march of time; either way it's hard not to wonder how Bill Charlap, a revivalist in his early 40s, came to assume the mantle of torchbearer. Many of the best living pianists from previous generations have slackened the pace or relinquished their fixation on the style. Barry Harris, above, ranks high among the prominent exceptions, which is one reason to take note of his engagement at the Village Vanguard next week. At 78, he's still a bebop pianist of the first order, with a style both sparkling and self-assured. And his loyalties have never wavered: his most recent album, ''Live From New York Vol. One'' (Lineage), was released two years ago with a track listing that includes bop chestnuts like ''Star Eyes,'' ''A Night in Tunisia'' and ''Woody 'n' You.''

THE FIFTH OF JULY When the oohing and aahing, not to mention the eating, are over, it might be time for a holiday reality check. In New York reminders of the War for Independence are everywhere, of course, and several events on Saturday deliver jolts from the past. On his ''Revolution in the Streets'' walking tour, Frederick Cookinham focuses on the plots and conspiracies percolating before the war. The stops include Pearl Street, near Maiden Lane, home to one Hercules Mulligan, a friend of Alexander Hamilton's. Mulligan was questioned by the British several times but never arrested even though he was, in fact, a spy. Fittingly for an incipient fashion capital, his clothing shop was the scene of the crime: that's where he gleaned tidbits from his Redcoat customers. (11 a.m., meeting at Fraunces Tavern, Pearl and Broad Streets, Lower Manhattan, 917-607-9019, centurywalkingtours.com; $20.)

MEYER--Dr. Douglas. The New York Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy mourns the tragic and untimely passing of one of its members, Dr. Douglas Meyer. Dr. Meyer was a graduate of NYU and Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, completed his residency in Internal Medicine at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, and a gastroenterology fellowship at Montefiore Medical Center. He received additional training in hepatology, and worked at Beth Israel Medical Center since 2003. He was known for his compassion, his intelligence, his unyielding dedication to his patients, his smile and his goodnatured way. He was always caring, sensitive, and giving. He will be greatly missed by the Society and by his patients. The Society extends its heartfelt sympathy to Dr. Meyer's family.

RAPOPORT--Vitaly, died on June 10, 2008 at the age of 71 in Cresskill, NJ. Vitaly was an exceptionally talented writer, historian and scholar. With his encyclopedic knowledge in many fields, he was a true Renaissance man. His friends and family will forever remember him for his big heart, uncompromising conscience, quick wit and infinite kindness. Vitaly's death is an irreparable loss to all his friends in Russia, France, Germany and the United States. Kathy R-Milyutina and Nick Rapoport

'DAMN YANKEES' Since 1994 New York City Center's Encores! series has celebrated lesser-known musicals like ''Face the Music'' and ''Juno'' through concert readings. Last year Encores! added its first summer show, a better-known musical in a fully staged production for a longer run, presenting ''Gypsy.'' Clearly the experiment paid off: ''Gypsy'' reopened on Broadway in March and recently won three Tony Awards. The people at Encores! are smartly gearing up for another summer show, ''Damn Yankees.'' ''I wanted to do something equally exciting but very different,'' said Jack Viertel, the series's artistic director. Based on the novel ''The Year the Yankees Lost the Pennant'' by Douglass Wallop, ''Damn Yankees'' is a Faustian tale about Joe Boyd (P. J. Benjamin), the ultimate baseball fan, who sells his soul to the Devil (Sean Hayes, in his New York stage debut) to be transformed into the young slugger Joe Hardy (Cheyenne Jackson) and help the Washington Senators beat those ''damn Yankees.'' (Serious Yankee fans beware: The point here is for the Bronx Bombers to lose.) The Devil is aided by his sexy assistant Lola, played by Jane Krakowski, right with Mr. Jackson, of NBC's ''30 Rock.''

Edmar Castañeda is a virtuoso, and a modern jazz musician in that he collects different musical languages of the New World and melts them together, fusing them with swing and improvisation. But he also does the same thing with instrumental approaches: he borrows the technique and sound of several other instruments and applies them to his own, which is a harp. He can turn a harp into a bass, a guitar, a piano and a hand drum. Of course, that's not meant literally, but it's not meant metaphorically either. Mr. Castañeda, now based in New York City, comes from Bogotá, Colombia, and his instrument is specifically the arpa llanero, used in joropo, the music of the plains of Colombia and Venezuela. It's midsize and wooden framed, with 32 strings, and at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday he had it amplified with electronic pickups -- one for the bass range, one for the rest, with the wires connected to two different amplifiers. He leads an unusual trio: harp, trombone (Marshall Gilkes) and drums (David Silliman). But then, any jazz group led by a harpist would be unusual.

High-Water Mark On July 3, 2007, just as New York's financial elite were packing up early and heading to summer haunts in the Hamptons, Blackstone announced a $26 billion buyout of Hilton Hotels. The credit markets had already begun to fray at that point, and after Hilton, the parade of huge private equity deals came to a halt. Remarkably, Blackstone found enough financing to take Hilton private, even as the credit squeeze locked up the leveraged loan market. By October, the deal was done.
FOR CHILDREN

LANG--Theresa. It is with tremendous sadness that the entire New York Hospital Queens family mourns the passing of Theresa Lang, a longtime member of our hospital's Board of Trustees, charter member and past president of our Women's Auxiliary, and hospital volunteer. Mrs. Lang's dedication to hospital service began during WWII, when she served as a Red Cross volunteer nurse aid. It was then that she laid the foundation for a lifelong commitment to advancing health care accessibility and enhancing the health services available for the people in the borough where she grew up--Queens. Mrs. Lang and her husband, Eugene, helped New York Hospital Queens establish several significant programs, including The Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Community Health Education Center in 1984, which later evolved to become The Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Center for Research and Education in 1998. It is due to their generosity and keen vision for the future, that the Lang Research Center now serves as a national model of excellence for a research center established at a community hospital. Other hospital programs that were founded with the assistance of Mrs. Lang include: The Theresa Lang Children's Ambulatory Center in 1997, the Theresa Lang Pediatric Emergency and Trauma Center in 2001, and the endowment of the Theresa Lang Directorship for the Lang Research Center in 2007. For her enduring commitment to community health care, Mrs. Lang was presented New York Hospital Queens' highest honor, the Pacesetter Award, in 1996. Over the years she was a mentor and friend to the many people with whom she worked--the Board of Trustees, the Women's Auxiliary, hospital administrators, physicians and employees. Undeniably, Mrs. Lang's leadership has had a significant impact upon the hospital's programs that are available today for the people of Queens. On behalf of all of our trustees, administration, clinical leadership and medical staff, employees, volunteers and auxilians, we offer our condolences to her family, including her beloved husband, Eugene, her children Jane, Stephen and David, her eight grandchildren, and five greatgrandchildren. George F. Heinrich, M.D. Chairman Stephen S. Mills President and Chief Executive Officer, New York Hospital Queens LANG--Theresa. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of Theresa Lang, beloved wife of our longtime friend and supporter, Eugene Lang. Theresa cared deeply about the League's work and supported our efforts to promote Catholic-Jewish relations. We extend our sincerest condolences to Eugene and the entire family. Glen S. Lewy, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER Any chance to see Nina Ananiashvili and Angel Corella, above center, dance together should not be missed, but Monday's performance of ''Giselle,'' which opens American Ballet Theater's final week of the spring season, has a special resonance. The company announced last month that the singular Ms. Ananiashvili, a principal since 1993, will retire from Ballet Theater next year. She plans to continue dancing with the State Ballet of Georgia (she has been its artistic director since 2004) and in various international guest appearances, but she will be sorely missed in Ballet Theater's storybook repertory. She is especially powerful as Giselle, using her flowing lines, theatrical presence and nuanced musicality to full effect. Catch her while you can. While Ms. Ananiashvili's storied performing career is winding down, other stars are rising. At the Wednesday matinee of ''Giselle,'' David Hallberg will make his debut as Albrecht, opposite Irina Dvorovenko in the title role. Technically and musically, Mr. Hallberg is a marvel of classical purity. But this young principal is still finding his way as an actor, and it should be fascinating to watch him navigate this tragic love story.

My Sunday column argues for a Truth Commission, with subpoena power, to investigate torture, improper detention and other abuses in the aftermath of 9/11. This should not be a bipartisan commission with Democrats and Republicans, like the 9/11 Commission, but rather a non-partisan commission with prominent figures who don't have strong party ties. I would welcome a strong representation of generals, admirals and intelligence figures, along with leaders from law and other fields. Perhaps Sandra Day O'Connor or Brent Scowcroft could chair it.

A housing market in shambles, inflation at the highest level in years and signs that the economy is headed for, or already in, recession. Sound familiar? The British economy, like its counterpart across the Atlantic, has fallen on hard times, and in many ways the experience appears to be mirroring that in the United States. Indeed, the run last September on a British mortgage lender, Northern Rock, was one event that helped to embed the term ''credit crisis'' firmly into the global consciousness.

LEVIN--Tom, Ph.D, died peacefully on July 4, 2008 at the age of 84. He was passionate, charismatic, a humanitarian, and had a unique intellect. Sailor, poet, author, romantic, social advocate, civil rights activist and an idealistic pragmatist. Marine Veteran of WWII, psychologist, psychoanalyst, founder and first director of the Child Development group of Mississippi, Assistant Professor of Psychiatry and Project Director of the Health Careers Program at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, UN liaison for the World Association of Psychosocial Rehabilitation. First graduating class of National Psychological Association of Psychoanalyst (NPAP), original member of American Group Psychotherapy Association. Beloved husband (Ronny Diamond), loving father of Erica (Bob Zurer), Jed Levin (Patti Jeppson), Kate Levin, Clem Levin (Diane), Natasha Page-Levin (Eric Schnabel), stepfather of Jason Samuels (Stephanie). Grandfather of Micah and Emma Zurer, Alexae and Nina Levin, Astrid Schnabel and Carter Samuels. He was ''someone who mattered''. Services will be Wednesday July 9, 2008 at 1:30. Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10024.

SHERMAN--Richard S., 80, of Las Vegas via the Bronx and Los Angeles, passed away July 2. He is survived by wife, Linda, daughter, Andrea and son, Robert. Basketball player, lawyer, record executive, and world class deli eater. He just couldn't take the Knicks losing anymore.

FAIRSTEIN--Alice Atwell, of Mount Vernon, New York, known also as Bobbie, died on July 3, 2008. Born April 17, 1920 to James and Ida Atwell, she was a 1941 graduate of the Mount Vernon Hospital School of Nursing and served as a U.S. Navy nurse during World War II. In 1943 she married her beloved husband, the late Samuel Johnson Fairstein, a Fellow of the American College of Anesthesiology and Chief of Anesthesiology at Mount Vernon Hospital from 1957 to 1984. In 1965, Alice joined the staff of Louise Wise Services of Manhattan, where she was a supervising pediatric nurse, participating in the care of thousands of infants and children until the agency closed in 2004. In 1976, she received her B.A. degree from the College of New Rochelle. She will be remembered for her skilled nursing care and compassion, her wise counsel to friends of all ages, and the great spirit of joy with which she lived her very full life. Alice loved being a wife, mother and grandmother above all else. She is survived by her son and daughter-inlaw, Guy and Marisa Fairstein of White Plains, her daughter and son-in-law Linda Fairstein and Justin Feldman of Manhattan, grandchildren Lisa and Marc Fairstein, surrogate son David Braunstein, nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews, and scores of devoted friends. Visitation at McGrath's Funeral Home, Bronxville, New York on Sunday, July 6, 2-4pm. Service at McGrath's on Monday, July 7 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Safe Horizon, 2 Lafayette Street, New York, New York 10007, for the Alice Fairstein Pediatric Care Fund created in her honor at Manhattan's first Child Advocacy Center, to be dedicated in October 2008.

An article today in Sunday Business about missed opportunities to reduce America’s dependence on imported oil refers to a 1990 effort by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, to block higher mileage requirements for vehicles and notes that Mr. Helms did not return calls seeking comment. FISCH--Stephen Allen, born to Abraham and Alice Fisch in New York on December 17, 1924, died in New York on June 27, 2008. Beloved brother of Genivieve Hewitt (Richard), Richard Fisch (Ebba), and Nancy Fish (Scott Perry); cherished cousin of Jerome Fisch (Lorraine); Remembered by nieces Liz Gadon, Kate Meyer, Natasha Silver, and Viktoria Fisch; nephews John Fisch, Abraham Fisch, Peter Fisch, Light Silver, and by two grandnieces and six grandnephews. Stephen graduated from The Franklin School and was honorably discharged from the Merchant Marines. Throughout his life, Stephen spoke fondly of his memories of extended stays in England, Japan, and Norway. As a result of his travels, Stephen had an open mind and a keen interest in foreign cultures enjoying Sushi in Manhattan ahead of any family member. Stephen was an ardent Yankee fan and a World War II buff. He could recite by heart the speeches of Winston Churchill and President Roosevelt. He studied voice and sang the scores of Oklahoma and many other Broadway shows; In his last decade while a resident at The Bronx Rehabilitation Center, Stephen was the first to sign up for outings to Yankee games, Broadway shows, and Belmont Racetrack. To all who knew him, Stephen always spoke frankly and will be remembered as a true gentleman.

QUALE--John C. The attorneys and staff at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the loss of our partner and friend, John C. Quale, age 61, who died on Sunday, June 29. A prominent Washington, DC lawyer and nationally recognized authority in communications law, Mr. Quale will be greatly missed by our firm and our clients. Mr. Quale, who suffered from bladder cancer, founded the Bladder Cancer Advocacy Network with his wife, Diane Zipursky Quale. Mr. Quale is survived by his wife and five children: Jane Harris Vergnani, Virginia Quale, John Quale, Rachel Goldman and Alisa Goldman.

Three days ago, Senator Barack Obama said he had not been clear enough in explaining his Iraq policy. On Saturday, there was a different rationale. The confusion was not his fault, Mr. Obama said, but rather that of the news media for seizing on three words he uttered in Fargo, N.D., when he suggested he would be open to ''refine my policies.''

The pilot program, SFpark, is aimed at reducing the number of drivers searching for curbside parking by installing multispace meters in close to 25 percent of the city's approximately 24,000 metered spaces.

GOLDSTEIN--Theodora. July 10, 1918-June 26, 2008. Born in New York to Anna and Meyer Nitzberg, Theo (Teddy) graduated from Hunter College and worked in the biochemistry lab of Nobel Prize winner, Severo Ochoa at NYU. She met the love of her life, Dr. Robert Goldstein, while he was a resident in medicine there. They married in 1941 and she continued to work in the lab while he was overseas as a Navy medical officer. When he returned in 1945, they moved to Boston where she was active in progressive politics, chairing the Massachusetts state committee for Henry Wallace's 1948 bid for president on the Progressive Party ticket. As a result of these activities and her unwavering commitment to peace and social justice, she was called before the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1953. Her fiery defense of the first amendment right to freedom of association in that hearing was a major news story in Washington, DC and Boston. The family moved to New York in 1961 where Bob took a position as Professor of Medicine at New York Medical College. After several years as a homemaker, she went to work as a computer systems analyst until her retirement in the early 1980s. After Bob's retirement they moved to Seattle in 2002. She is survived by her sister Bernice, by her two children, Richard (Nanette) and Erika (Jim) and four grandchildren, Cody, Amelia, Maggie and Kate, and by her loving and devoted husband, Bob. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Alzheimer's Disease Research Center at the University of Washington.

Roger Lowenstein's article (June 15) failed to present all the facts of the trade debate. Lowenstein paints the trade debate as a battle between protectionists and pragmatists. If only the debate over trade policy -- or health policy or foreign policy or monetary policy or education policy -- were that simple.

THE NUMBER of American and coalition troops who died in Afghanistan last month, the highest monthly toll since the American-led invasion began in 2001. BEHIND THE NUMBER The violence is the latest evidence of a strengthening Taliban insurgency that has menaced NATO forces and reclaimed some southern and eastern parts of the country. The death toll spiked even as the number of foreign troops in Afghanistan -- including 32,000 Americans -- approaches its highest level since 2001. But that many not be enough. The former senior commander there, Gen. Dan K. McNeill, last month called Afghanistan an ''under-resourced war.''

SLIDE SHOW: After 2,000 Years, Zadar Still Seduces Located on the northern Dalmatian coast, Zadar, Croatia, may be the country's most underrated destination. The city has a youthful zeal, a rich architectural history and a non-euro economy that's easy on the dollar. The Old Town, left, is a 100-acre peninsula with a pedestrian-only, fishbone layout. Zadar is seeking heritage-site status for its historic center from Unesco. nytimes.com/travel

SKOLNICK--Rand. The Bailey House Board of Directors, our dedicated staff, and the men, women and children living with HIV/AIDS in New York City who Bailey House serves and houses mourn with overwhelming sadness the loss of our friend, champion and fellow board member Rand Skolnick. A fierce, loyal and generous advocate for homeless people living with HIV/AIDS, Rand's humanity, wisdom, humor and love will forever be our guide and standard. We extend our deepest condolences to Connie and Allen and the entire Skolnick family who made Rand's cause their own; even as our hearts are breaking, we are awed by your courage and comforted by your grace. We witnessed with joy the great and everlasting love that Rand and Terrence shared. In the darkest, coldest hours Terrence, you lifted all of us up so we could see by the bright, warm light of your love for Rand. And Rand, our darling Rand, we honor you, we miss you terribly and we will always, always love you.

MOTT--Stewart R. A memorial service for Stewart Rawlings Mott, the avant garde philanthropist and political activist who died at age 70 on June 12th will be held from 34:30pm on July 9th at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY. Senator GeorgeMcGovern, Cora Weiss, Russell Hemenway, National Director of NCEC and the Hon. Alex Scott, former Premier of Bermuda will speak on his life and works. Reception will be held at Synod Hall from 5-7:30pm. Open to all friends and acquaintances of Stewart Mott. Donations can be made to the ''Stewart R. Mott Constitutional Defender's Fund'' at the Fund for Constitutional Government, 122 Maryland Avenue, NE, Washington, DC, 20002; the ''Stewart R. Mott Fund'' at the Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation, 322 Fourth Street, NE, Washington, DC 20002; and ''The Apple Tree Fund'' at Planned Parenthood Federation of America, 434 West 33rd Street, New York, NY 10001. For further information please contact: Conrad Martin, Director, Stewart Mott Charitable Trust: 202 546-3732 conrad@srmtrust.org.

Most people focus on the beauty and glamour of the period setting, or the smoking/drinking/sexism that seems so ancient and yet is so recent, but the greatness of ''Mad Men'' (Alex Witchel, June 22) is that people are and always will be people. You can watch a Jane Austen adaptation or a Merchant-Ivory drama and get caught up in the costumes and paraphernalia, but in truth, the fascination lies in how little is different: We still hope and long, deceive and get caught. When the newlywed Pete Campbell (Vincent Kartheiser) says he thought marriage would be magical, but instead his wife is ''just another stranger,'' he is not some 1960 period oddity; he is speaking to all of our childish desires for fulfillment without effort. The characters of ''Mad Men'' are flawed, confused and compelling. Just like real people (but better-looking). DEBORAH LIPP Nanuet, N.Y. Ah, yes, I remember the ad agencies of the 1960s. For me and other African-Americans who were turned away by them, ''Mad Men'' isn't so fictitious. Armed with a degree from the University of Chicago, I knocked on door after door, and the excuse I heard most often was, ''Our clients might object.'' I wound up writing copy for the Sears catalog. HOSEA L. MARTIN Chicago The depiction in ''Mad Men'' of the dynamics between men (the bosses) and women (the secretaries) reflects the reality of being female during the years leading up to the women's-liberation movement. The offices I worked in as a young woman were rife with sexism, racism and anti-Semitism. Women were touched and leered at, and the only visible African-Americans were relegated to being the elevator operators and cleaning people. The highlight of each program for me, however, is seeing the Drapers eating off the same plates that I did as a child in the 1950s and early '60s. Nothing sets the time and place better than that. MIRIAM KAPLAN PICKETT New Milford, N.J.

PURA--Thomas R., 54, of Bedford Hills, New York, and Los Angeles, California, died unexpectedly on July 1, 2008 in Los Angeles. Tom grew up in Salinas, California. One of five boys raised by a single mother, Nancy Pura, Tom was an accomplished student and athlete. Every summer from elementary school to college, Tom worked in the Salinas lettuce fields. Although Tom was drafted by the Kansas City Royals after high school, he chose to accept a scholarship from Harvard. There his baseball experience culminated in pitching for Harvard in the College World Series. After beginning his Wall Street career at Lehman Brothers, Tom joined Salomon Brothers where he became its youngest ever managing director. In 1986 Goldman Sachs hired Tom as a partner in Fixed Income where he was a co-head of Liquid Capital Markets. Lisa Endlich in her book ''Goldman Sachs: The Culture of Success'', described Tom as ''a hard driving trader who would be widely emulated. A contender in the annual 'Iron Man' Triathlon, he would bring to the department a new intensity and a risky style of trading that was bolder and more aggressive than anything Goldman Sachs fixed income had ever seen.'' Since retiring from Goldman Sachs in 1993, Tom's priority has been his family. Tom took great pride in his daughter, Jennifer, now a senior at Wellesley, and his son, T.J., a nationally ranked junior tennis player. Tom recently produced ''50,000 Balls,'' a documentary on junior tennis which premiered in June at the Newport International Tennis Hall of Fame. Surviving Tom are his wife, Sara Weinheimer Pura; daughter, Jennifer Laura Pura; son, Thomas Jason Pura; two stepsons, Eugene and Adam DiBenedetto; mother, Nancy Pura; and four brothers, Roger (San Antonio, TX), William (Tampa Bay, FL), Michael (Stamford, CT), and Peter (Troy, NY). Tom will be remembered for his commitment to his family and friends, his generosity, his competitive spirit, his passion for life, and his loyalty to and encouragement of others. A memorial service is planned for later this month in Manhattan. Details will be made public when available. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to: Partnership for After School Education (PASE), 120 Broadway, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10271 or Harlem Junior Tennis and Education Program, 140 West 143rd Street, New York, NY 10037.

OUTPOSTS Last week, almost 1,000 jobs were eliminated in the American newspaper industry, making it perhaps the bloodiest week yet of a year where many papers are fighting for their lives. You read about the great names -- The Baltimore Sun, The Boston Globe, The San Jose Mercury News -- as if reading the obituary page. Even rich cities like San Francisco can no longer support a profitable daily paper. Columnists, reporters, editors, cartoonists and photographers who brought to life the daily narrative of a city or region have been swept aside. What started as layoffs and buyouts is edging toward closures and bankruptcies.

McCLINTOCK--William T. (Bill), died peacefully on June 17, 2008, at age 95, in Medford, Oregon. His three daughters Julie McClintock, Mary Kadarauch and Bonnie Cohen, and his son William T. McClintock, Jr., his eight grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren vividly remember him as an energetic, determined and dignified man, a student of art, architecture and history, and as a loving husband to June Dunn. He called his marriage of 66 years to June ''the number-one achievement of my life.'' An Austin scholar from Northwestern University, he started his career at Booz, Allen and Hamilton in Chicago before joining Rohm and Haas Chemical Company, Philadelphia, where he was for many years Financial Vice President. Bill worked to establish the Old York Road Ice Skating Rink, and was the main force behind the financing and construction of International House, a residence next to the University of Pennsylvania for students from all over the world. He and the family became active members of the Society of Friends in 1954. Bill and June moved to Pebble Beach, CA, where they enjoyed an active life with their friends for 30 years golfing and dancing. Bill took up water colors and contributed to preserving open space in the Del Monte Forest. They moved to Medford, OR in 2002 near lifelong friends. Bill was a gifted raconteur who wrote a memoir at age 93 of a year-long trip he and his brother Bob made to Europe in 1934. He wrote, ''It was clear from the beginning that the greatest pleasure of the trip would be the two of us taking it together.'' His entire family will miss him and will remember the great pleasure he took in living. Contributions to his memory may be made to Abington Meeting, 520 Meeting House Rd., Jenkintown, PA 19046.

Campbell Jr. of New York City and Jean E. (Mrs. Roy) Peterson of Oxford, NY.
