NARKISS--Professor Bezalel, passed Sunday June 29, 2008. The Center for Jewish Art Jerusalem and New York mourns the loss of its founder and leader. He was the outstanding world figure in his field, a prolific writer, scholar, and world authority in Jewish Art. He founded the journal of Jewish Art. He was awarded the Israel prize in Art History for his multi faceted role in preserving the rich, artistic heritage of the Jewish people. He was a senior fellow at Harvard, Princeton and lecturer at Brown University and the National Gallery, Washington, DC. Our sincere condolences to his companion, professor Aliza Cohen Mushlin and to his family. Memorials can be sent to the Center for Jewish Art, 1676 Lawrence Road, Mohegan Lake, NY 10547.

FAIRSTEIN--Alice Atwell, of Mount Vernon, New York, known also as Bobbie, died on July 3, 2008. Born April 17, 1920 to James and Ida Atwell, she was a 1941 graduate of the Mount Vernon Hospital School of Nursing and served as a U.S. Navy nurse during World War II. In 1943 she married her beloved husband, the late Samuel Johnson Fairstein, a Fellow of the American College of Anesthesiology and Chief of Anesthesiology at Mount Vernon Hospital from 1957 to 1984. In 1965, Alice joined the staff of Louise Wise Services of Manhattan, where she was a supervising pediatric nurse, participating in the care of thousands of infants and children until the agency closed in 2004. In 1976, she received her B.A. degree from the College of New Rochelle. She will be remembered for her skilled nursing care and compassion, her wise counsel to friends of all ages, and the great spirit of joy with which she lived her very full life. Alice loved being a wife, mother and grandmother above all else. She is survived by her son and daughter-inlaw, Guy and Marisa Fairstein of White Plains, her daughter and son-in-law Linda Fairstein and Justin Feldman of Manhattan, grandchildren Lisa and Marc Fairstein, surrogate son David Braunstein, nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews, and scores of devoted friends. Visitation at McGrath's Funeral Home, Bronxville, New York on Sunday, July 6, 2-4pm. Service at McGrath's on Monday, July 7 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Safe Horizon, 2 Lafayette Street, New York, New York 10007, for the Alice Fairstein Pediatric Care Fund created in her honor at Manhattan's first Child Advocacy Center, to be dedicated in October 2008.

STURMAN--Helen Armsburg was born in New York City the 29th of November 1906 and died the 23rd of June 2008 in Croton-on-Hudson where she has resided for the past 12 years. She was preceded in death by her husband, Sam, her parents William and Fannie Armsburg (nee Schoenberg) and a sister, Pearl Willis. She leaves behind her son Morris Bernard Nachman of Venice, California, her granddaughter Alessandra Fil Picasso Novak of Portland, Oregon and a great-granddaughter Anyanka Sofia. She was a sportswear buyer for major New York department stores including Lord & Taylor and the founder of the Women's Sportswear Buyers Club. Born at the beginning of the 20th century, she lived a long and fruitful life, and gave much to many. She was loved, will be lovingly remembered and dearly missed. IT seems as though the only time you hear about car companies fudging horsepower numbers, it's when they're busted advertising more beans than are actually present in the under-hood burrito. Mazda got in trouble for exaggerating the 2001 Miata's power output. Ford had to recall the 1999 SVT Mustang Cobra when owners realized its motor fell about 20 horsepower short of its official numbers. I have a theory on where all those phantom ponies went: They're under the hood of the new Nissan GT-R.

MASON--Jonathan, of Wellington, FL and Southampton, NY died at his home in Wellington on Sunday, June 22nd. He was 92. The son of Alexander Taylor Mason and Susanne McKee Lee, Jonathan was born February 19th, 1916 in New York City. A graduate of the Hotchkiss School and Princeton University Class of 1938, he later served with Army intelligence during World War Two. After working with Bache and Company on Wall Street, he helped launch the Japan Fund in 1962, the first closed end fund to invest in Japanese stocks, and served as its longtime Chairman. He also served on the boards of the Japan Society, Asia Society, International House and the US-Japan Foundation. Jonathan is survived by his loving wife of 22 years, Natsuki Nakayama Mason; his two sons, Alexander Mason of Owings Mills, MD and Southampton, NY and Anthony Mason of Rye, NY; and five grandchildren: Taylor, Christopher, Emily, Olivia and Nicholas A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, August 23rd at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in Southampton.

LIEBER--Eric, Producer, passed away on Wednesday, July 2, 2008 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. Lieber has worked in television for more than 30 years. He has been the Executive Producer of programs for ABC, NBC, CBS, FOX and PBS. He has produced the talk-show series of Dick Cavett, Mike Douglas and Sammy Davis, Jr. Among his other producer credits are: ''Omnibus,'' ''Musical Comedy Tonight,'' ''The AFI Salute to Henry Fonda,'' and ''The Secret Files of J. Edgar Hoover.'' In 1976, he served as television consultant to Chairman Robert S. Strauss for the Democratic National Convention in New York. He was also the creator and Executive Producer of the long-running dating show ''Love Connection.'' He has won two Emmys and a Peabody Award. He is survived by his wife Peggy; daughter, Christine and granddaughter Rachel. Memorial services will be held at a later date, please do not send any flowers. It would be appreciated, if you care to make donations, that they are directed to: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

BERK--Mortimer S., died early in the morning on June 30th in San Diego, California. He was 96. Born and raised in Philadelphia, he was a track star at Germantown High School and was invited to try out for the 1936 Olympic team as a quarter miler. He moved to New York City as a young man and, with his father Max Berk and brother Harold Berk, founded the Berkray Corporation, which soon became one of the world's largest producers of men's outerwear at the time. He married Regina I. Clark in 1940. They retired to San Diego in 1984 where Regina died in 1994. Mort Berk was a strong-willed and courageous man who lived and died on his own terms. He will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his children, Richard, Leslie, and Wendy, by his grandchildren Rachel, Michael, Meredith, Emily and Stephanie, and by his greatgrandchildren Seth and Sonja.

EXPERIENCING ART IN THE ROUND, MAY 11, 2008 Claire Mathieu, 25, a researcher for an architecture studio in Paris, touches ''Cloud Gate,'' a sculpture by Anish Kapoor in Millennium Park. ''My boyfriend and I were really surprised by Chicago. We had started with a tour of the East Coast, hitting Washington, New York and Boston, then on to Chicago, where we spent three days. We knew that it was a city that was very rich in architecture, but we didn't know it was such a great city for contemporary art and for culture. I go abroad fairly often, about two big trips a year. I travel to understand the world and to understand other people -- to understand what's going on, to understand the television news. If I stay in my country, I only have myself as a reference, with my French opinions. If I never travel, I can't understand why other people don't think like I do. So I travel for that, and because I love to see different things. I love to discover places I don't know, to meet people I don't know and talk with them.'' As told to Austin Considine

PECHTER--Morton H., November 13, 1922 -June 24, 2008, a business tycoon and later Hall of Fame Underwater Photographer, adventure sports photojournalist, writer and book author passed away peacefully from respiratory failure. Morton Pechter was the last remaining member of the original Pechter Baking Company and Harrison Baking Company, wellknown for its Jewish Rye Bread and other baked goods products, serving the New York, New England, New Jersey, Pennsylvania area. The specialty of dark and heavy breads, pumpernickel and rye, and assorted bagels and pastries proved popular and the concern prospered. The bakery grew to over 1000 employees with hundreds of delivery trucks. Serving at various times as President, Treasurer and Secretary he was a brilliant, energetic, practical, motivating, detail oriented force ensuring the company's success. Starting with horsedrawn delivery trucks, they were one of the first commercial companies to change to the Edison Electric Truck. Thomas Alva Edison was present to give a personal send-off when the first of these trucks was put into service. Pechter's was also wellknown for its ''kosher for Passover'' line of products. Store shelves were filled with their ''kosher'' items at holiday time. Jews and non-Jews alike devoured their delicious Passover macaroons and chocolate nut brownies. Pechter was a graduate of Dartmouth College, Class of 1943, the Tuck School, 1944 and Harvard Business School. He served in the Army in WWII. In later years, when the Pechter Baking Company had been sold, Pechter turned to SCUBA diving and underwater photography, first as a hobby and later as a profession. His professional life as a photographer grew and he wrote and photographed for hundreds of magazines, joining the masthead designation on many. He became the ''Official Photographer'' for the SCUBA Industry for over 25 years; for over 16 years he was the ''Official Photographer'' for the Chris Evert Tennis Charities; for eight years for the Delray International Tennis Championships; for four years for the Air & Sea Show in Ft. Lauderdale, FL and was the photographer for ''Raffi on Broadway'' and several other Broadway productions. As a professional photographer, writer, SCUBA diver and lecturer, he photographed and wrote about the world's top tennis professionals, searched for sunken archeological and lost treasures, photographed the magnificent reefs, jumped from helicopters, flew in hot air balloons and gliders and investigated the deep ocean. He authored and photographed an award winning book, ''What's In The Deep?'' that was a ''Reading Rainbow'' designated book. It was the first children's book ever done with actual underwater photos rather than illustrations. Pechter's book is a science text in libraries and classrooms throughout the U.S. He also produced and photographed an instructional, photographic flyer for the Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta. His photos appeared on many calendars and covers of magazines. He was recognized as an outstanding underwater photojournalist by New York Times art critic David Shirey, who stated that Pechter's photos ''reflect a technique, a specialized expertise and an aesthetic authority that gives us a new understanding of underwater photography.'' His many awards include: the 2003 NOGI for Distinguished Service from AUAS; the 2008 Diver of the Year from Beneath the Sea; Director's Award from the Balloon Federation of America; the Photographer of the Year from USCA. He was given recognition and honored by the United Nations Environment Programme, recognized by the U.S. Navy as an Honorary Deep Sea Diver, and awarded the ''Rambo'' underwater diver from the Police Department. He was honored with election to the SSI Platinum Pro 5000 group in recognition of making over 5000 SCUBA dives and his work within the industry. The North American Travel Writers Association (NATJA) awarded him top honors for several of his published pieces. He was elected a Fellow National member in the prestigious Explorers Club for his contribution to scientific knowledge in the field of geographical exploration. Pechter has been the featured speaker on several television productions, among them a special television production about sea and space including Michael Collins, the command module pilot for the first landing on the moon. Some of the more memorable TV shows he helped to film were Mr. Rogers Neighborhood, Kim Alexis for Good Morning America, Al Roker for the Today Show and Hugh Downs for 20/20. He was a founder of the Long Island Science Museum and its Executive Vice President. His photos and articles have appeared in Life, Time, Newsweek and Forbes Magazine. Pechter was a longtime member of Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, Long Island and a member of the Board of Trustees, sang in the choir and served as Cantor on many occasions. He was a charter member of DEMA, a member of the American Society of Media Photographers, the National Association of Press Photographers and the North American Travel Writers Association. He was a Life member of the National Marine Educators Association, a Founding member of the Historical Diving Society, a Fellow in the Academy of Underwater Arts & Sciences and a Fellow in the Explorers Club. Pechter had the unique ability to instill in others the same excitement and enthusiasm for life's wonders that he had. His obvious delight for the world beneath the sea was nurtured by his deep commitment to conservation and preservation of the underwater wilderness. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Alese, and his children; Dr. Stuart and Madeline Pechter, Dr. Richard and Robin Pechter, Dr. Jay and Roxanne Pechter, Juris Dr. Todd and Christine Pechter and his grandchildren, Nelson, Wyatt, Joseph, William, Patricia and Diana.

An independent group that has been critical of Senator Barack Obama is preparing an initial $1.5 million television advertising campaign over the next two weeks in battleground states promoting what it deems the success of the troop buildup in Iraq. The campaign by the Vets for Freedom, a nonprofit advocacy organization for veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan, appears to be the first major independent effort benefiting Senator John McCain.

Helene Romeo, a dietitian, and Sherene De Palma, a former corporate lawyer, have joined forces to create Near and Natural, a charming market and cafe in Bedford Village that is as organic as is practicably possible. Also busy raising seven children under the age of 12, the young mothers are on a mission to stock their shelves with delicious, nutritious food that has traveled a minimum number of miles to get there -- and to educate the public about a new model for eating. With its paned windows, ocean-blue floors and buttercup-yellow walls, Near and Natural is a modern riff on an old-fashioned grocery, offering staples, dairy products, meats, produce and a changing roster of prepared foods. There are crumbly cranberry-orange scones ($3 each) and richly brewed fair-trade coffee ($1.85 a cup) from Gorilla roasters in Brooklyn; wonderful sandwiches, including the Bedford Village Club ($8.25, made with Applegate natural turkey and bacon); the Cluck 'n' Russian ($7.99, made with an organic chicken cutlet and spicy Russian dressing); and the Sandwich of the Sea ($8.95, made with locally smoked salmon); a bountiful salad bar with add-ons like local goat cheese and candied nuts; and perhaps the best lemon squares on earth ($3.25 each, from Wild Hive Farms, a mill and bakery in Dutchess County).

O'NEILL--Cornelia Rockwell. Longtime Greens Farms, CT resident Cornelia (Connie) Rockwell O'Neill died on May 31. She was 88. A Minnesota native and the oldest of three sisters, Connie attended Smith College and the University of Minnesota. She served as an officer in the OSS in WWII. Following OSS training at ''the farm'' outside Washington, DC, she was stationed in London, and near the end of the war, in Paris. While in Paris, Connie witnessed French General Charles de Gaulle's triumphant march on the Champs E'lysee as that city was liberated from the Nazis. Before her assignment in the European Theatre, Connie met and fell in love with Bridgeport, CT born Charles O'Neill who went on to oversee the training and assigning of OSS recruited agents from various ''Joe Houses'' in North Africa and France. Because of operational security concerns, communication between Connie and Charles as to whereabouts and well being had to be undertaken through a code they concocted based on favorite poems. The couple was married in the American Cathedral in Paris, on August 10, 1945, some three months after V.E. Day. After the war, Connie and Charles moved to Laguna Beach and Santa Monica, CA where Charles worked as a writer in the film and TV business. Their first son Bracken was born in California, followed by three more boys -Denis, Christopher and Trevor, all of whom were born following the couple's return to Connecticut. Fluent in French and an accomplished piano player, Connie was active in her great friend Ruth Steinkraus Cohen's U.N. Hospitality Program in Westport, CT. In the 1960s and 1970s she hosted Thanksgiving and other holiday dinners for dozens of U.N. Representatives at her Turkey Hill home (one of whom later turned out to be a member of the KGB; it was unclear if he was aware his hosts were a pair of former OSS operatives). Connie had an ear for and a great love of good music. In the 1960s she was approached by a Westport friend to invest in a Broadway-bound musical. After playing the sheet music for herself, she agreed to invest a modest amount of money in a show which became ''Man of La Mancha.'' (A year later, one of the producers asked her to invest in his next musical featuring the same creative team. Connie played the sheet music and passed. Sometime later, that show opened and closed in one night). As a child in Minnesota, Connie enjoyed many summers at family cabins on Isle Royale, and later on the north shore of Lake Superior. Her father, Harvard S. Rockwell, was a grain elevator engineer, an amateur organ recitalist and bridge expert. Other Rockwell relatives were early discoverers and developers of the Mesabi Range as well as property owners in what is now the Boundary Waters wilderness region of Minnesota. More distant relatives were cofounders of Carleton College in Northfield, Minnesota. Connie raised her four boys in the 1950s and 1960s, chaperoned an endless string of little league and pee wee hockey seasons, and enjoyed sailing at the Pequot Yacht Club in Southport, CT. Over the years she hosted countless dinners for friends she and Charles knew from the often overlapping worlds of the OSS, entertaining, politics and literature. Visitors to Turkey Hill relished Connie's homegrown sorrel soup and the seafood dishes she prepared with freshly harvested clams and mussels from Long Island Sound -as much as the inevitably spirited conversations. Gardening -both for season vegetables and for the beds of beautiful irises, roses and peonies that ringed her Turkey Hill home -was a passion Connie enjoyed throughout her life, right up to this spring's lilacs. Her love of books and things literary led her to take a part-time job at the Pequot Library in Southport, CT, where she continued to make new friends with her intelligence, curiosity and keen sense of humor. Husband Charles died in 1997. Son Trevor succumbed to cancer in 2007. Sister Rowena Rockwell Langworthy predeceased her by a few months. Connie is survived by her sister Jean Rockwell Anderson, three sons, Bracken, of Fairfield, CT, Denis of Beverly Hills, CA, and Christopher, of Winston-Salem, NC, nine grandchildren, and numerous nieces and nephews. A private memorial service will be held in August. One of Connie's favorite stories about her wartime service was how as a 25 year-old OSS Lieutenant on a warm Paris spring day, she decided -with two girlfriends -to flaut military regulations and take a lunchtime stroll down the Champs E'lysee carrying rather than wearing their helmets. Arm in arm they marched, three representatives of what has been called this country's ''Greatest Generations,'' the sun in their faces (and on Connie's auburn hair), the war about to end, their lives stretching before them...only to slow down apprehensively when they spotted a couple of senior American officers strolling toward them. Technically out of uniform, they were busted -or not, as it turned out -by General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Commander of all Allied Forces in the European Theatre, and General Omar Bradley, both of whom greeted the young women with proper military salutes and broad smiles.

Noah Feldman's informative article (June 22) ignores a crucial historical fact that explains much about Western Europe's current dilemma with its Muslim immigrants. Great Britain, France and the Netherlands, until after World War II, ruled large colonial empires, concentrated in Africa and Asia, that included many Muslim subjects. These people, the ancestors of today's ''outsiders,'' did not ask to become colonials but were brought up learning the language and culture of their mother countries, abandoning much of their own culture for that of the mother country. For example, many of the far-flung countries once under British rule are now English-speaking and play cricket. That their descendants want to live in the mother country should be no surprise.

As Tara Parker-Pope reports in today's Times, the American Academy of Pediatrics (A.A.P.) is recommending that doctors take an aggressive approach to monitoring the cholesterol levels of children as young as age 2 if they are overweight, have a family history of high cholesterol, or have other risk factors for heart disease. The A.A.P. also is recommending that doctors treat kids as young as 8 years old with cholesterol-lowering drugs called statins.

BAGHDAD -- On July 4th, in a former Saddam-era palace in Baghdad, 1,200 soldiers and marines took part in the largest mass re-enlistment in the history of the United States military. Sports Illustrated recently published the results of a poll taken among 495 major-league baseball players. The question was "Who is the most overrated player in baseball?" and the winner, with 10 percent of the vote, was Derek Jeter. Barry Zito - he's not overrated, just overpaid - came in second, followed by J.D. Drew, Alex Rodriguez and Kevin Youkilis. Rounding out the top 10 were David Wright, Mark Prior, Andruw Jones, Curt Schilling and Juan Pierre. I'm a Mets fan and I like Wright a lot, but I have no problem with his being on this list. He can suffer through a monthlong slump and few people seem to notice; when José Reyes has a bad game, the yahoos at Shea and on local sports radio treat him like the second coming of Vince Coleman.

Last week, a former Mossad official began his column for The Forward, "What Kind of Interviewer Confuses Hamas and Hummus?" The answer, he soon revealed, was one that has built a reputation for fooling people just like him. Sacha Baron Cohen, the actor behind Borat, had struck again in a different disguise: Bruno, a gay Austrian fashion expert. Until May 2009, when Universal reportedly plans to release the film, there's a strikingly similar combination of comedy, Mideast violence and the appetizing dip in Adam Sandler's "You Don't Mess With the Zohan." It has "more hummus-based humor than you might have thought possible," according to A.O. Scott of The New York Times. Have these two comedians found the key to laughing about such a sensitive subject?

Dan Patrick, who left ESPN last year to create his own syndicated radio program and write a column for Sports Illustrated, will join NBC Sports where he will be reunited with Keith Olbermann to call the N.F.L. highlights on "Football Night in America." The weekend brought good news for the Beijing Games organizers, as Japanese Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda announced that he, like U.S. President George W. Bush, would attend the Olympic opening ceremonies next month. Fukuda will be the first Japanese prime minister to attend an opening ceremony overseas since Noboru Takeshita was present for the start of the Seoul Games in 1988, a significant decision at the time, given the charged history between Japan and Korea going back to the first half of the 20th century.

Vote for Al Franken and save television comedy: Michael Kinsley dedicates his column in The Washington Post to Al Franken's Senate race in Minnesota. Franken, a former comedy writer, has been criticized by Republicans in Minnesota for, among other things, "a 1995 magazine article describing Franken as proposing rude, unfunny jokes about rape at a Saturday Night Live staff meeting; a 2000 article in Playboy fantasizing about three-way sex with robots (or something); an ungallant crack about women in Afghanistan (a place Franken has visited repeatedly with the U.S.O.); and so on," Kinsley writes.
The funny thing is that the essential ludicrousness of this guy was plain to see all along.

Chimurenga is a lively literary magazine started in Cape Town in 2002 by Ntone Edjabe, a literary scenester and DJ originally from Cameroon. At the Cape Town Book Fair last month, Chimurenga unveiled a new web project, Chimurenga Library, a compendium of literary magazines, mostly from across Africa, including African Film (Nigeria), Chief Priest Say (Fela Kuti's newspaper columns from Nigeria), Ecrans d'Afrique (Burkina Faso), Lamalif (Morocco), Mfumu'eto (Congo), Moto (Zimbabwe). The collaborative project, in which authors and general readers add their own comments about each magazine, is an ingenious use of the Web on a continent where millions are illiterate.

The Q&A column in Science Times on Tuesday, about the differences in nutritional value between fresh fruits and dried fruits, misstated the quantities of fresh and dried apricots and grapes and raisins that were being compared in the list of individual nutrients. They were a full cup of each kind of fruit, not a full cup of fresh fruit and a half-cup of dried fruit. (A half-cup of dried fruit is considered the equivalent of a full cup of fresh fruit only in the general recommendation for eating two cups of fresh fruit each day.

8 P.M. (TCM) ELVIS MITCHELL: UNDER THE INFLUENCE Mr. Mitchell, a former film critic for The New York Times, chats with celebrity guests about the films that influenced them. The series begins with his interview with the director Sydney Pollack, who died May 26. ''I'll tell you the thing that makes a film director happiest,'' Mr. Pollack (above left with Mr. Mitchell) says, ''is a film living on for a while.'' The interview, taped last summer, is followed at 8:30 by a screening of ''Tootsie'' (1982), which earned Mr. Pollack an Oscar nomination for best director. It is followed at 11 by Vincente Minnelli's ''American in Paris'' (1951), one of the films that affected Mr. Pollack. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELORETTE By now fans know that DeAnna Pappas is engaged. But did she choose Jason, an account executive and father of a 3-year-old? Or was it Jesse, a professional snowboarder who sometimes acts as if he's a 3-year-old? The answer is revealed in this season finale, but first the men must meet Ms. Pappas's family -- at the same time. And then, just when things seem like smooth sailing, one of the bachelors she dumped shows up to meet them on Grand Bahama Island.

GOLD--Steven A. The world has lost a great thinker, a company has lost a great leader, a family has lost a wonderful father and caring husband, and the community has lost a great friend. Steven A. Gold, 53, of Guilford, CT passed away on the morning of July 4. He was Founder and CEO of GraphLogic Inc., a cutting edge software company in Branford, CT. Dr. Gold was an accomplished inventor with a keen vision and quick wit. His visionary invention for a fully integrated web-based development environment PointDragon is positioned to become the platform of choice for the newest wave in computing technology, cloud computing. Steve Gold was born and raised in New York City where he attended Stuyvesant High School. Steve went on to Yale University where he majored in computer science. He continued his studies at Yale; eventually earning his Masters Degree and a Doctor of Philosophy in 1995, both in computer science. Dr. Gold is survived by his wife June, two children, Robert and Julie Pellegrini and their significant others; Jennifer Dermanci and Eric Steinlauf. He is also survived by a brother, Michael Gold, three sisters-inlaw, Joan Adams, Janet Faust, and Judy Boutin, and a brother-in-law, Joe Boutin. Steve also leaves one niece, seven nephews, three greatnieces, and two great-nephews. Steve loved being with his extended family; his wit, friendship and brilliant mind will be missed by family, friends, co-workers, research peers, and business associates alike. A service will be held at the Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church Street, Guilford, CT on Tuesday, July 8, at 11am. A local interment will immediately follow. Donations may be sent to the Yale University Computer Science Department through the Graduate School of Arts & Sciences portal at http://yaletomorrow.yale.edu/ give--online. Please specify your gift to go to the computer science department, in memory of Steven A. Gold. www.GuilfordFuneralHome .com

LEVIN--Tom, Ph.D, died peacefully on July 4, 2008 at the age of 84. He was passionate, charismatic, a humanitarian, and had a unique intellect. Sailor, poet, author, romantic, social advocate, civil rights activist and an idealistic pragmatist. Marine Veteran of WWII, psychologist, psychoanalyst, founder and first director of the Child Development group of Mississippi, Assistant Professor of Psychiatry and Project Director of the Health Careers Program at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, UN liaison for the World Association of Psychosocial Rehabilitation. First graduating class of National Psychological Association of Psychoanalyst (NPAP), original member of American Group Psychotherapy Association. Beloved husband (Ronny Diamond), loving father of Erica (Bob Zurer), Jed Levin (Patti Jeppson), Kate Levin, Clem Levin (Diane), Natasha Page-Levin (Eric Schnabel), stepfather of Jason Samuels (Stephanie). Grandfather of Micah and Emma Zurer, Alexae and Nina Levin, Astrid Schnabel and Carter Samuels. He was ''someone who mattered''. Services will be Wednesday July 9, 2008 at 1:30. Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10024.

SKOLNICK--Rand. The Bailey House Board of Directors, our dedicated staff, and the men, women and children living with HIV/AIDS in New York City who Bailey House serves and houses mourn with overwhelming sadness the loss of our friend, champion and fellow board member Rand Skolnick. A fierce, loyal and generous advocate for homeless people living with HIV/AIDS, Rand's humanity, wisdom, humor and love will forever be our guide and standard. We extend our deepest condolences to Connie and Allen and the entire Skolnick family who made Rand's cause their own; even as our hearts are breaking, we are awed by your courage and comforted by your grace. We witnessed with joy the great and everlasting love that Rand and Terrence shared. In the darkest, coldest hours Terrence, you lifted all of us up so we could see by the bright, warm light of your love for Rand. And Rand, our darling Rand, we honor you, we miss you terribly and we will always, always love you.

Fresenius, the giant German maker of dialysis services and products, said Monday that it would buy APP Pharmaceuticals for about $4.6 billion including debt, giving it control of one of the biggest makers of generic injectable drugs. Under the terms of the deal, Fresenius will pay $23 a share for APP, a 29 percent premium over APP's closing stock price on Thursday.

JOHN MELLENCAMP ''Life Death Love and Freedom'' (Hear Music) John Mellencamp, 56, is feeling his age and then some on ''Life Death Love and Freedom.'' It's an album presented like a deathbed testament: bleak, solitary, bluesy and unbowed. In ''Don't Need This Body'' Mr. Mellencamp sings, ''All I got left is a headful of memories/And a thought of my upcoming death,'' and that just about sums up the album.

New York’s municipal elections may be more than a year away, but try telling that to those who get hit up for campaign donations, David W. Chen writes. Already, 146 people have announced that they are running for city office in 2009, well above the previous record of 103 set in 2001, according to the Campaign Finance Board. And because the candidates must collect donations early to qualify for matching funds from the city, they are trying to amass cash before everyone flees the city for vacation in August.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has been slow to increase weekday bus service even as ridership has surged over the last decade, resulting in jam-packed buses that often have to pass waiting riders without stopping because they simply cannot accommodate more passengers, according to a report released on Tuesday by the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group for transit riders.

Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, as this recent cover of Toast -- I mean Coast -- magazine attests. The version on the left was cooked up for the Spring 2007 cover of T Living by an all-star crew including photographer Miles Aldridge, food stylist Susan Spungen and set designer Stefan Beckman, who were asked to create their version of a beachy picnic, cocktail rings and all. (Credit also goes to the model, Anja Rubik, who was a good sport about pretending to eat for an hour.) The Californified cover on the right has all the fixings, but it is odd that a West Coast magazine would have a sadder tomato -- especially since T's shoot took place in February. Coast, if you really want to reflect Orange County's finer lifestyle, we challenge you to recreate the Spring 2006 cover that got nixed at the last minute: a milkmaid and a dead chicken.

There will be a total solar eclipse on August 1, 2008, and one of the best places on the planet to view it is in northern China, near the Mongolian border. There are many travel organizations offering solar eclipse tours. Can you recommend a few?

When it comes to age and fertility, women fear a "biological clock" and are urged to have children early. But men are rarely given the same advice and often don't worry about fertility when postponing marriage and children.

"NBC said its marathon coverage of the men's Wimbledon Championships tennis final generated its best overnight ratings for the event in eight years with a 4.5 rating/12 share," Broadcasting & Cable reports.

While rumor-mongering has long been a stock in trade on Wall Street, the new era of virtually untraceable communication has added fuel to the gossip fire, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

When sports-related assets go up for sale, institutional investors traditionally stay on the sidelines -- but that may be slowly changing, Investment Dealers' Digest writes in an article in its latest issue. The story comes as Tribune is seeking buyers for the Chicago Cubs and the Pittsburgh Steelers are reportedly on the block as well.

Not long ago Dr. Joanne Lynn, a geriatrician who pulls no punches in her frequent critiques of America's sorry system of end-of-life care, looked out from the dais of a Washington, D.C., ballroom at a sea of middle-aged faces: health policymakers, legislative staff, advocates for the aged and for family caregivers -- an audience of experts.

Ambac Financial Group said it has enough funds to meet obligations, but if its ratings are cut too far below current levels, it may have to use assets from a regulated subsidiary to pay off its obligations.

New recommendations from the American Academy of Pediatrics that some children as young as age 8 be given cholesterol-lowering drugs have stirred a furious debate among pediatricians.

If the recent deals for Bell Canada and The Weather Channel mark the return of the leveraged buyout, it is a "curiously muted one," The Financial Times wrote.

The Pittsburgh Steelers, one of the top National Football League franchises, has quietly been shopped to potential buyers as the five sons of the team's founder and their heirs tussle over its future.
JP Morgan Chase's chief executive, Jamie Dimon, said U.S. regulators should investigate whether people betting on Bear Stearns' stock falling deliberately brought down the investment bank.

Hedge funds are on a hiring binge, taking advantage of cutbacks at investment banks. Star traders, senior executives and whole teams have been recruited by funds recently as they look to capitalize on the banks' woes for their own expansion, The Financial Times reports.

Warren Buffett has given away 512,169 Class B shares of Berkshire Hathaway stock to three charitable foundations, in keeping with his plan to give away the bulk of his fortune, The Associated Press reported.

The mortgage lender IndyMac Bancorp, struggling to raise capital to stay in business, said Monday it had stopped accepting new loan submissions in its main mortgage lending divisions and planned to cut 3,800 jobs, or more than half of its work force, The Associated Press reported.

Vueling and Clickair, two Spanish airlines, agreed to merge Monday, Reuters reported, citing a source close to the situation. The deal still must be approved by the boards of Vueling and Iberia, which controls Clickair, the source told Reuters.
The Carlyle Group will make its first investment in China this year via an $87 million investment in privately owned Chinese chemical company Sinorgchem, Finance Asia reported.
Thermage and Reliant Technologies have agreed to merge in a cash-and-stock transaction worth about $95 million, The San Jose Mercury News reported.

The war of words between Reliance Industries and Reliance Communications may be jeopardizing Reliance Communications' hopes of a merger with mobile operator MTN, The Wall Street Journal reported. MTN said it would issue a statement Tuesday morning regarding the Reliance talks, according to Bloomberg News.
Olympus Partners has acquired Ann's House of Nuts, The Daily Deal reported. The private equity firm did not release terms of the deal.

UBS has received a license to operate in Saudi Arabia and will offer investment banking, asset management and wealth management services there. Further, it will more than double its investment banking team in the Middle East by the end of the year, The Financial Times reported.
The Russian partners in BP's joint venture tried to fire the chief executive at a board meeting on Monday, but they were outvoted by directors nominated from the British side.

Sinosteel took a big step closer to acquiring the Australian iron ore prospector Midwest on Tuesday, with Midwest's directors lining up to sell their shares after a merger with Murchison Metals Group collapsed.

Warburg Pincus' $800 million investment in troubled insurer MBIA -- greeted with applause on Wall Street when first announced -- is now proving troublesome. The New York Post reported that Warbug's most recent quarterly performance report reveals it took a $215 million writedown on its MBIA stake.

Macquarie Group is encouraging Korean investors find U.S. targets after acquiring Giuliani Capital Advisors. John Walker, chairman of Macquarie's Korea unit, told Bloomberg News that the bank is focusing on Korea-U.S. cross-border transactions.

Energy pricing agency Platts has put Lehman Brothers under a temporary review that effectively excludes it from trading benchmark-setting oil contracts, Reuters reported citing unnamed sources on Monday.
In yet another sign of the tightening I.P.O. market, GeoVera Insurance Holdings has canceled its planned initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.
UTI Asset Management has deferred plans to launch an initial public offering, sources told Reuters. India's No. 4 mutual fund firm made the decision after falling stocks hit investor sentiment.

A dispute between brother and sister Winnie and Stanley Ho will lead a Hong Kong court to decide whether a stock market listing of casino operator Sociedade de Jogos de Macau can go ahead, Reuters reported.

Stephen Brodsky will step down as president of CHX Holdings, parent company of the Chicago Stock Exchange, The Chicago Tribune reported. Mr. Brodsky will be joining private equity firm Vernon & Park Capital as managing director.
CVC Capital Partners has opened a Beijing office and appointed former Goldman Sachs executive Zhu Wei to head it, FinanceAsia reported.

Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Company and MTM Capital Partners, have launched a $1.5 billion fund to be used for investments in projects to capture natural gas, The Khaleej Times reported.

Mantara, a financial software provider, has raised $5.8 million from Silicon Valley investor Mohr Davidow Ventures along with Australian firms Southern Cross Venture Partners Management, CM Capital Investments, and Tivsco.

The Mets won three of four games this series against the team they have spent most of the season chasing, and reached a modest milestone: a record of 45-44.

The former Minnesota Vikings defensive lineman Darrion Scott pleaded guilty to child endangerment for putting a plastic bag over the head of his 2-year-old son. Scott pleaded guilty to the gross misdemeanor as jury selection was scheduled to begin in his trial. Scott’s lawyer, Joe Friedberg, said the other charges would be dismissed when Scott is sentenced July 24. Friedberg said Scott said he had no intent to injure the boy. Scott’s plea was to an amended child endangerment count — not the original one that accused him of keeping a loaded, unsecured handgun in his nightstand, where a 2-year-old could reach it. Scott could face a maximum penalty of a year in jail and a $3,000 fine.
A Miami Beach man pleaded not guilty to charges of defrauding the Pentagon under a contract to supply ammunition to forces in Afghanistan.
A climber collapsed and died on the summit of Mount McKinley, officials at Denali National Park said.
Tropical Storm Bertha has strengthened to become the Atlantic season’s first hurricane.

Habitat for Humanity International has reached a settlement with its San Antonio affiliate, which filed a lawsuit in January over an agreement that the organization was imposing on its 1,600 local chapters.
The adoption of a woman by her lesbian partner 17 years ago in Maine has been annulled, and the woman has filed an appeal in the State Supreme Court.
C. C. Sabathia joined Johan Santana and Eric Gagné as temptations that Brian Cashman resisted, all in the name of rebuilding the Yankees’ foundation.
Workers at the headquarters of Viterra, a Canadian grain handler, went on strike to protest the company’s decision to enforce a contract offer that had been voted down by union employees.
Canadian consumer confidence slumped to its lowest level in nearly 13 years in June as a result of the surge in gasoline prices and concern about future economic conditions.
Reliance Industries, India’s biggest company, plans to sign an agreement to jointly explore for oil and natural gas with Peru’s state oil company, a government official said.
A European Parliament committee voted to give national regulators the power to force dominant telephone companies to open their networks.
Stock in Embraer rose the most in more than eight months as the company overcame production problems and increased second-quarter deliveries by 44 percent.

The British government said it would slow down the introduction of biofuels to address concerns that switching the use of land for biofuels could exacerbate climate change.
A British police department reached an agreement with the parents of Madeleine McCann to provide them with information about her disappearance.

The former Minnesota Vikings defensive lineman Darrion Scott pleaded guilty to child endangerment for putting a plastic bag over the head of his 2-year-old son. Scott pleaded guilty to the gross misdemeanor as jury selection was scheduled to begin in his trial. Scott’s lawyer, Joe Friedberg, said the other charges would be dismissed when Scott is sentenced July 24. Friedberg said Scott said he had no intent to injure the boy. Scott’s plea was to an amended child endangerment count — not the original one that accused him of keeping a loaded, unsecured handgun in his nightstand, where a 2-year-old could reach it. Scott could face a maximum penalty of a year in jail and a $3,000 fine.

The former University of Connecticut standout Shea Ralph will return to Storrs as an assistant coach of the women’s team. Ralph was captain of the Huskies when they won the 2000 national championship. She finished her college career eighth on UConn’s career scoring list and in the top 10 in assists, steals and field goal percentage. The W.N.B.A.’s Utah Starzz chose Ralph in the 2001 draft, but a knee injury cut short her professional career. She served the past five seasons as assistant coach at Pittsburgh.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about Soho Rep’s 2008-9 season referred incorrectly to the first production, “Blasted,” by Sarah Kane. It will be the New York premiere of the play, not the American premiere.

Todd Bertuzzi, best remembered for an on-ice attack from behind on Colorado’s Steve Moore in 2004, signed a contract with the Calgary Flames. Bertuzzi, 33, scored 14 goals and had 26 assists with the Anaheim Ducks last season but was released so the Ducks could re-sign the restricted free agent Corey Perry. Bertuzzi had signed a two-year, $8 million deal with Anaheim last summer. A two-time All-Star, Bertuzzi’s best season was in 2002-3, when he scored a career-high 46 goals with the Vancouver Canucks.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about negotiations over a security agreement between Iraq and the United States, under which private security contractors would no longer be immune from Iraqi law, gave an outdated name for a private security contractor with a reputation in Iraq for excessive force. It is Blackwater Worldwide, not Blackwater USA. (The error also appeared in an article last Tuesday and has appeared in at least seven other articles since the contractor disclosed on Oct. 22, 2007, that it had changed its name.).

An article on Thursday about a generational change in professors at American colleges and universities omitted a source of income for the University of Wisconsin, which is experiencing financial pressures, as are many colleges and universities. In addition to money from the State Legislature and from donations, foundations, federal research grants and corporations, the university also receives money from tuition.

An obituary on Friday about Jules Tygiel, a baseball historian noted for his writing on the role of Jackie Robinson in integrating baseball, referred incorrectly to the game Robinson played on April 18, 1946. It was his first game in what had been segregated white professional baseball, not his first pro game.
An article on Friday about shopping for antiques in the mid-Hudson Valley misspelled the surname of the owner of the Village Antique Center in Hyde Park, N.Y. She is Rose Gaches, not Graches.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Saturday about The Washington Post’s hiring of a classical music critic, Anne Midgette, omitted credit for the source of the information and quotation from Ms. Midgette. It was MusicalAmerica.com.

Because of an editing error, an obituary last Tuesday about Kenneth Macke, who headed the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the forerunner of the retail giant Target, misstated the disposition of the retail chain Mervyn’s when Target sold it and another chain, Marshall Field, in 2004. Target sold nine Mervyn’s store sites along with Marshall Field to the May Company in June 2004; it did not sell the entire Mervyn’s chain to May. (Target sold Mervyn’s in July 2004 to a consortium of several businesses.).

A credit for a photo illustration of James P. Evans, a physician and molecular biologist, which accompanied an interview last Tuesday, omitted an explanation of how the image was created. It was a composite image, in which a photograph of Dr. Evans was superimposed over a photo image of his tie, which carried a double-helix design. Both pictures were taken by Karen Tam for The New York Times, but Ms. Tam was not involved in creating the composite image.

The Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the relationship of Fox News with reporters who cover it, misidentified the owner of TV Guide. It is the Macrovision Solutions Corporation, not the News Corporation, which completed the magazine’s sale to Macrovision in May.
The synchro platform team of the 15-year-olds Hayley Ishimatsu and Mary Beth Dunnichay will join a veteran United States Olympic diving team.

Ronaldinho and Robinho will try to lead Brazil to its first Olympic gold medal in soccer in Beijing. The 18-player team was announced Monday by its coach, Dunga, 15 days before the squad is scheduled to begin preparation for the Games. The Olympics is the only significant title Brazil, a five-time World Cup champion, has not won.

The new Madame Tussauds museum in Berlin said a wax figure of Adolf Hitler whose head was ripped off would be put back on display once it is repaired, Agence France-Press reported. On Saturday, just after the museum opened, a former police officer evaded security guards and tore the head off the figure, which depicts Hitler looking grim and defeated seated behind a desk in a re-creation of his bunker. The incident has attracted widespread news coverage and commentary, including accusations that the museum’s decision to include a Hitler figure was in bad taste and was made only to generate publicity. A spokeswoman for Madame Tussauds told the news agency the statue would return to its place in the museum’s history section as soon as possible. “Adolf Hitler represents a defining moment in German history that cannot be denied,” she said, adding that the display was created “with sensitivity and respect.” The 41-year-old who was arrested, identified only as Frank L., told reporters that he came up with the idea over drinks with friends, who dared him to do it; he said he now regretted it. “I did not do it for money, nor for fame,” he told the online edition of the newspaper Die Welt (welt.de), “though I suppose I will now be famous for a while.”.

More than 8,000 photographs taken by Stanley Tretick, a photojournalist who chronicled the Kennedy White House and who died in 1999, are now available online. The photo archive of Mr. Tretick’s work, at stanleytretick.com, was created by the writer Kitty Kelley, a close friend of the photographer’s and the legal representative of his estate, which is making the work available to historians and libraries and for sale to collectors. During the Kennedy years Mr. Tretick was given special access to the family. One of his most famous pictures shows John Kennedy Jr. as a toddler playing under his father’s desk in the Oval Office, above. The photo was taken a month before President Kennedy was assassinated. Later Mr. Tretick became close to Senator Robert F. Kennedy and covered his presidential campaign in 1968. He covered the Senate Watergate hearings and shot stills for many films, including “All the President’s Men,” “Reds” and “The Candidate.”.

The Osbourne family, which helped invent the genre of celebrity-reality television on MTV six years ago, now wants to try its hand at reviving the variety show format. Ozzy and Sharon Osbourne, above, and their children Jack and Kelly are set to host six episodes of an hourlong variety show for Fox, the network said on Monday. The episodes could include musical performances, comedy skits, games and taped segments, reminiscent of classic variety shows like “The Sonny and Cher Variety Hour.” The four broadcast networks each bid for the Osbourne project, which will be produced by FremantleMedia North America. Mike Darnell, the president of alternative programming for Fox, said he believed that variety shows were primed for a comeback. Mr. Osbourne, who rose to fame as the lead singer for Black Sabbath in the 1970s, starred alongside his family on “The Osbournes” from 2002 to 2005. Ms. Osbourne is currently a judge on the NBC summer competition “America’s Got Talent.”.

Ringo Starr, above, held a surprise “peace and love” party on a Chicago sidewalk on Monday to celebrate his 68th birthday, Reuters reported. “What could be wrong?” he said. “Peace and Love. What a great birthday gift. It’s a happening.” The event, which had sparse advance publicity, was held outside the Hard Rock Hotel in Chicago. “I saw it in the paper, left my sister’s house and came down here,” said Joyce McDaniels, who was visiting from Winton, Calif. She emerged from the crowd holding a chocolate cupcake, slightly mauled. “I saw a Beatle. That’s all I needed.”.

An appeals court has ordered a retrial for seven artists who hacked into a Czech television weather broadcast to show a fake nuclear explosion in the Czech mountains, The Associated Press reported. Members of the Ztohoven art group, based in Prague, admitted tampering with equipment so that viewers watching a live shot of the Krkonose Mountains in June last year saw a flash of bright light and a mushroom cloud rising on the horizon. In March the artists were acquitted of spreading false information, but the state prosecutor appealed the verdict. An appeals court in Hradec Kralove overturned the decision last week in a ruling made public on Monday, said Michal Strnad, a court spokesman. The court ordered a new trial but did not yet set a date. If found guilty, the artists face maximum jail terms of three years. The group claimed its project wanted to show how reality could be manipulated by the media. Czech Television called such stunts improper and said they could incite panic.

For the third consecutive Sunday, NBC led in the ratings among adults 18 to 49, thanks to coverage of the Olympic trials, followed by “Dateline.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two broadcasts gave NBC a slight edge over ABC for the night in the 18-to-49 set, but neither fared especially well in total viewers. The Olympic hopefuls attracted just 5.7 million viewers from 7 to 9, while “Dateline” earned 7.4 million from 9 to 11. Meanwhile, a two-hour “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” from 8 to 10 (6.5 million) buoyed ABC’s all-repeat lineup. ABC finished second in the 18-to-49 set but third in total viewers behind CBS, once again the night’s most-watched network. CBS drew the largest audiences early in the night with “60 Minutes” at 7 (8.1 million) and “Million Dollar Password” at 8 (7.5 million). A rerun of CBS’s “Cold Case” at 9 brought 6.8 million viewers, while “Numb3rs” at 10 had 5.7 million. With reruns of its animated comedy lineup, Fox finished a distant fourth in total viewers but third, ahead of CBS, in the 18-to-49 set.
Manhattan Theater Club said that Brian Murray would join the cast of its coming Broadway production of “To Be or Not to Be.”

The owner of the house in Hong Kong where Bruce Lee lived before his death in 1973 has announced plans to turn the building, above, into a museum dedicated to Lee, the martial arts movie star, giving in to public outcry that the home not be sold, Reuters reported. The two-story, 5,600-square-foot town house is in the Kowloon area of Hong Kong. Yu Panglin, 86, a real estate tycoon and prominent philanthropist, had put the house up for sale but told reporters on Monday that he had decided to donate the property to Hong Kong’s government for use as a museum.

EMI, the music company that was bought by the private equity firm Terra Firma last year for about $6.4 billion, has hired Elio Leoni-Sceti, 42, to be the chief executive of its recorded music division, the company said on Monday. Mr. Leoni-Sceti, who will take over on Oct. 1 as the chief executive of EMI Music, is the latest in a string of recruits from outside the music business. The company, which has sustained heavy losses in recent years, releases music by the Beatles, Coldplay, Norah Jones and others. Born in Rome, Mr. Leoni-Sceti currently serves as an executive vice president at Reckitt Benckiser, which owns brands including Lysol and Woolite. In an interview on Monday, he said he believed that understanding music consumers was crucial to turning around the company. “Understanding where they will need music in the future, where they will go, how they will interact with it,” Mr. Leoni-Sceti said, “and try to position the company so that you are there first.”.

BENDICK--Robert L., died on June 22, 2008, at home in Guildford, CT. Born in NYC in 1917, he was a decorated WWII veteran, a pioneer of early television news, Co-producer of ''This is Cinerama'', Director of the ''Today Show'', ''Wide Wide World'' and many other documentary television programs and educational films. He was the loving husband for 67 years of children's book author and illustrator, Jeanne Bendick.

LYNCH--Cornelius J., 81, of Cedar Grove, NJ, died Sunday, July 6th. Funeral Services Friday 9:30am from Shook's Cedar Grove Funeral Home 486 Pompton Avenue, Cedar Grove, New Jersey. www.shookscedargrove .com. For details call 973239-1489. Born in New York City, moved to Cedar Grove 50 years ago. WWII US Army veteran. Alumni of Fordham University and Fordham Law School. Admitted to the Bar of NY State and member of the Supreme Court of the State of NY. In 1987 he retired as the Deputy Director of the World Trade Dept. of the Port Authority of NY/NJ after 34 years. Responsible for leasing the World Trade Center. After his retirement worked for Silverstein Properties as Senior VP, leasing 7 World Trade Center. Past President of BOMA NY. Surviving are his wife Eileen (Walsh) Lynch, three daughters Eileen Weinstein, Patricia Wlazlo and Maureen Lynch-Jacobs and six grandchildren.

Throughout his life Rand worked diligently in the health food industry building his family business, Solgar Vitamin and Herb Company into a household name for those who demanded integrity and high quality in nutrasutical. He will be remembered as a wonderful son and brother, loving husband, honest businessman and great friend to so many. Most of all, he will always be remembered for his ability to remain humble throughout his all too short life. From the beginning of his career until his death, Rand was an avid philanthropist. In the end, people were Rand's greatest joy. Services were held at Riverside Memorial Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Rand's Foundation, The Palette Fund at P.O. Box 865, Lynbrook, NY, 11563.

An airplane chartered by the Obama campaign for a flight from Midway Airport in Chicago to Charlotte, N.C., made a precautionary landing in St. Louis on Monday morning because of a mechanical problem that interfered with the pilots' ability to control the plane's pitch, said Midwest Airlines, the operator. President Lee Myung-bak dismissed three ministers in a cabinet reshuffle intended to restore public trust in his four-month-old government, which has been shaken by weeks of large protests. The ministers of agriculture, health and education, who were replaced, have been under fire as South Koreans rallied almost daily against the government's decision to lift a ban on beef imported from the United States. The initial protests, set off by fears of mad cow disease, quickly evolved into a broader expression of grievances against Mr. Lee's policies on education, the economy and other issues.

REESE--Louis Garfield III. Born July 21, 1949. Died June 29, 2008 (5:34 Montana time). Child of Pete and Lou, husband, father, friend, brother, mentor, Louie, visionary, uncle, loyal business partner, Big Lou, lover of nature, man of impossibly high standards, tender hearted, enthusiastic but terrible singer, great fly fisherman, notorious delegator, doer of deals, rough around the edges, dreamer of dreams, Daddy... Survived by wife Susan (so proud to share his name), daughter Katie, son Beau, daughter McKenzie, father-in-law Walter, adopted family Ginnie and Jeff McCorkle and Baby Cameron. He loves his family, his friends, his work, his house, his garden, the Madison River, Hawaiian shirts, making fudge, giving advice and more advice -wanted or unwanted, Thanksgiving, structuring a complex real estate deal on a paper napkin, skinny dipping, The Ashram, bonfires in the yard, crying freely, speaking Spanish, his children's most special friends, Warren Zevon, Restvedt beef jerky, Cuban cigars, big diamonds, wild flowers, Christmas morning, marking his territory, howling at the moon, chaos, Yellowstone Park, Hawaii, passing on ridiculous cures, old diesel Mercedes, letting Grady bring in the morning paper and saving a busted deal when no one else could. We will miss your big hands, your generous heart, your unending sense of integrity, your superb snuggling, your stories and your pushing us all to be more than what we ever think we can be. We love you. We miss you. We honor you. We won't see your likes again. In lieu of flowers, please make any donations to: Lou Reese Madison River Conservation Fund, c/o The Dallas Foundation, 900 Jackson St., Suite 705, Dallas TX 75202. To donate online and share your memories, please visit: madisonriverfund.org.

WITKIN--George J., DDS. Beloved alumnus, Professor Emeritus of Periodontics, and benefactor, died on June 9th after a long illness. He was 92. A graduate of NYU College of Dentistry Class of 1942, George was associated with the College for over 30 years, as a Professor and Chairman of the Department of Periodontology, Assistant Dean, Associate Dean, and Interim Dean. George was an excellent teacher who mentored numerous students and was widely respected for his clinical expertise. George served in World War II and was proud of his contribution to our country. For over 50 years, he also practiced privately in offices at Rockefeller Center. He is survived by his beloved wife Ann, daughter Georgia, son Roy and grandchildren. In 2006, he and Ann donated a gift to his alma matter which was recognized with the establishment of the Dr. George and Ann Witkin Graduate Center for Clinical Excellence. The gift represented the profound love and respect that George and Ann Witkin had for one another and for the NYU College of Dentistry. George's memory and legacy are assured a lasting place of honor at his alma mater and in the hearts of all who loved him. Charles N. Bertolami, DDS, DMedSc Herman Robert Fox Dean NYU College of Dentistry

Howard Wolfson, who was a top strategist for the presidential campaign of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, is going where some Democrats were unwilling to go during the early days of the election season: the Fox News Channel. The network is expected to announce as early as Tuesday that it has signed Mr. Wolfson as a contributor who will appear regularly on its programs.

One of Africa's most infamous soldiers of fortune, Simon Mann, was sentenced to 34 years in prison for his role in an elaborate but failed plot to overthrow the government of Equatorial Guinea, an oil-rich country that is about the size of Maryland. Mr. Mann, a flamboyant member of Britain's upper crust, admitted his role in the plot, but claimed that he was merely carrying out the wishes of more powerful backers. He was arrested in 2004 in Zimbabwe after meeting a plane headed for Equatorial Guinea loaded with 80 mercenaries and a stockpile of weapons. He had served part of a seven-year sentence for weapons trafficking in Zimbabwe, but was eventually extradited to Equatorial Guinea, where he was convicted last month for trying to overthrow the government.

For years, the Allen & Company media conference in Sun Valley, Ida. was a time for media moguls to kick back, talk with their fellow executives — and maybe even strike a deal.

In a matter of a few hours, the center of power in the media industry has shifted from Los Angeles and New York to a tony resort town in Idaho. Current and former executives of some of the world’s largest media groups rolled into Sun Valley on Tuesday and Wednesday to attend Allen & Company‘s annual conference, peeking through car windows as they prepared for what promises to be an extended, high-powered schmoozefest.
At Sun Valley, it appears that everyone wants to be Jeff Zucker’s friend.
Will Yahoo eventually get sold to Microsoft? And if so, for how much?
The annual Sun Valley conference has always been a place for established moguls — media barons such as Rupert Murdoch or John Malone are regulars on the guest list.

For devotees of Allen & Company‘s annual confab who like to keep up with the official doings here in Sun Valley, we’ve procured an official schedule — against the wishes of the event’s organizers — for your information andperhaps even your amusement.
Greetings from Sun Valley!

A man scaled the front of the New York Times building in Midtown Manhattan in the predawn darkness early Wednesday — the third time in six weeks that a climber had scaled the one-year-old skyscraper, which is sheathed in thin ceramic rods. After staying on the building for about four hours, the man surrendered to police officers and was arrested around 5:20 a.m.Unlike the two previous climbers, this one — identified as David Malone, an activist who studies Al Qaeda — did not try to make his way to the roof. Instead, he unfurled a banner around the fifth floor of the 52-story building, before climbing a few more stories. Several hours elapsed during which the police appeared to alternate between trying to go after the man and waiting for him to surrender.
The government of Abu Dhabi bought a 90 percent stake in the landmark Chrysler Building on Tuesday for $800 million from German investors and Tishman Speyer Properties.

Railroad cars are filled with passengers listening to iPods, typing on laptops and talking on cellphones. Buying a ticket onboard, though, is usually a pretty analog affair: Conductors punch holes in multicolored sheets called “duplexes,” separate the back page from the front page, and collect coins and bills from passengers in return.

My Thursday column asks: Is genocide really that bad? Perhaps not surprisingly, I think it is. Sure, lots more people may die from disease or chaos and banditry, but genocide seems to me the ultimate human crime and thus deserves a top priority response.

The closing line of Senator John McCain's most recent advertisement - "Don't hope for a better life; vote for one" - is supposed to be a dig at Senator Barack Obama's mantra of hope. But the line is hardly original; as the liberal blog Talking Points Memo noted this week, the slogan was also used in a spot for the Conservative Party of Margaret Thatcher in the late 1970s.

It appears the Rich Rodriguez-West Virginia drama may be coming to a close. Rodriguez, the former Mountaineers coach, and his current employer, Michigan, agreed to share the $4 million buyout that West Virginia had stipulated as part of the contract extension he signed with the university in late 2006. The extension, which was to run through 2014, was signed after Rodriguez's brief flirtation with Alabama, which eventually hired Nick Saban. Michigan will take on $2.5 million of the buyout and Rodriguez the remaining $1.5 million, which he will pay in three $500,000 installments beginning in 2010.

The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. In this installment, Joerg Koch, the editor in chief of the Berlin-based art and culture magazine 032c, shares a few of his style essentials. The current summer issue has just hit newsstands over here in the States and features sharp-eyed editorial content, including a conversation between the architects Jacques Herzog and Rem Koolhas and a selection of 20 years of Martin Margiela press curated by the notoriously press-shy designer himself. If in Berlin, make sure to check out the Museum Store, 032c's new concept retail/art space in collaboration with the German industrial designer Konstantin Grcic. For more information, e-mail office@032c.com.

Judge Richard A. Posner has just published a new book. That's not news. What would be news is if he hadn't just published a new book. Over his distinguished career, he has produced more than 40 books, and that's not counting new editions of old ones. He's also written numerous articles, monographs and book reviews - I stopped counting when I reached 150 and saw that I still had 20 pages of listings to go. This productivity is remarkable by itself, but even more remarkable is the high quality of Posner's work. He is one of our most influential legal minds and one of our most prominent public intellectuals.

About three years ago, Bucharest experienced a revolution that was entirely ignored by the international community. Granted, the coup was not as dramatic as Romania's 1989 revolution, in which Nicolae Ceausescu, the Communist dictator who had brutally mismanaged this Black Sea nation for more than two decades, was deposed and executed. Nor was it as momentous as when the country joined the European Union in 2007, along with Bulgaria, its neighbor to the south.

A blind trust run by New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg is willing to pay between $4.5 billion and $5 billion to buy Merrill Lynch's 20 percent stake in Bloomberg L.P., The New York Post reported citing unidentified sources.

American private equity firms raised $132.7 billion across 185 funds in the first six months of the year, according to a report by Dow Jones Private Equity Analyst, The Washington Business Journal reported.

An important source of profits for private equity groups in Europe has been cut off due to the credit crunch by eliminating the option to add new debt to companies they own solely to pay themselves a dividend, The Financial Times reported.
Britain had the worst performance among the world's four biggest private equity markets last year, The Financial Times reported citing research published on Wednesday by Ernst & Young.

WPP Group, the advertising and marketing company, said Wednesday that it had made a hostile bid for the British market research company Taylor Nelson Sofres, aiming to upset that company's plans to merge with a rival, GfK.

Four months after embarking on a search for directors with financial expertise, Citigroup is close to announcing that the dean of the Harvard Business School will join its board, The New York Times reported citing several people briefed on the search.

A federal judge on Tuesday sentenced Mark Lay, chief executive and founder of the now defunct MDL Capital Management, to 12 years in prison on fraud charges related to the loss of $216 million in a hedge fund at the state agency for injured workers.

Time is running out for IndyMac Bancorp, one of the faded darlings of the subprime era. On Tuesday, IndyMac, one of the nation's largest independent mortgage lenders, faced what amounted to a run on the bank. As depositors rushed to withdraw money, IndyMac's share price, already in a free fall, spiraled even lower.

Federal prosecutors are investigating whether two former Credit Suisse brokers lied to investors about how they placed their money into short-term securities, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

Hedge funds have suffered their worst first-half since at least 1990 as the credit crunch took a heavy toll on some managers, MarketWatch reported citing data compiled by industry tracker Hedge Fund Research.
The Carlyle Group has appointed David Balint director of its Asia leveraged finance group, FinanceAsia reported. Mr. Balint will manage Carlyle's investment strategy in Australia and New Zealand.

Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country's financial industry.
Software developer Xeround has closed its second round of financing with an additional $16 million, The Seattle Times reported.

MTN has agreed to extend exclusive talks with Reliance Communications stemming, for now, speculation that the deal might fall apart due to a case of sibling rivalry inside Reliance, The Financial Times reported.
BuzzFeed has received $3.5 million in its first round of funding, CNet News reported. The start-up trend-tracking site tracks and delivers the most viewed content on the Internet.

Alliance & Leicester is close to Alan Gillespie as its chairman, a move could help stabilize the bank in the near term amid fears that it could face further upset from the credit crisis, The Financial Times reported.
Hong Kong's High Court has dismissed a lawsuit by Winnie Ho challenging the legality of the $493 million initial public offering of her brother's SJM Holdings, Bloomerg News reported.
Razgulay Group will aim raise as much as $233 million in a sale of new shares to repay debt and buy farmland and machinery, Bloomerg News reported.

A front-page picture caption on June 26 describing an 11-month-old boy whose legs were in casts stated that his legs were broken and that his mother said the injuries were caused by an episode of state-sponsored violence in Zimbabwe. After the picture and an accompanying article that also described the injuries were published, The New York Times took the boy to a medical clinic in Harare for help. When the casts were removed, medical workers there discovered the boy had club feet. Doctors said on Monday that X-rays of the baby’s legs showed no evidence of bone fractures.

The fourth season finale of “The Bachelorette” helped lift ABC to No. 1 for the night over all on Monday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two-hour conclusion of the reality dating series, a spin-off of “The Bachelor,” attracted 9.5 million viewers, leading during both the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots. A “Bachelorette” special, “After the Final Rose,” won the 10 p.m. hour with 10 million viewers. Fox and CBS tied for second place on the night. Fox broadcast repeats of “Bones” at 8 (6.5 million) and “House” at 9 (7.9 million), while CBS earned solid ratings from reruns of its comedy lineup followed by “CSI: Miami” at 10 (8.4 million). NBC was fourth with “American Gladiators” at 8 and “Nashville Star” at 9, both of which drew 5.3 million viewers, fewer than NBC’s “Dateline” at 10 (6 million).

More than 60 looted artifacts, including gold and emeralds, were returned to the Colombian government Tuesday in Miami by United States officials. The artifacts, one shown left and some of which date as far back as 500 B.C., were seized in 2005 by United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the Broward County Sheriff’s Office from an Italian citizen, Ugo Bagnato, 66, who was living in south Florida and smuggled them into the country. The United States Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of Florida prosecuted Mr. Bagnato, who pleaded guilty to the sale and receipt of stolen goods and served 17 months in prison before being deported, officials said.

The Los Angeles County Museum of Art said it had acquired one of the most significant private collections of Oceanic art assembled in the 20th century. The collection, a piece of which is shown above, will be exhibited next February and focuses on art from Polynesia and Melanesia. It includes objects like a rare 18th-century Hawaiian drum collected by Capt. James Cook in 1778, an Easter Islands dance paddle and a hermaphrodite ancestor figure. The museum, which declined to name the previous owner, said the acquisition had substantially broadened its permanent collection. “In our efforts to become a truly world museum with a Los Angeles point of view, acquiring art of the Pacific islands is essential, and this acquisition is a landmark event,” said Michael Govan, the museum’s director.

The Washington Ballet has hired Russell P. Allen of the Orlando Ballet as its new executive director, The Washington Post reported. Mr. Allen will begin the job on Sept. 2, taking over from Kay Kendall, the president of the ballet’s board, who stepped into the post temporarily after Jason Palmquist resigned in February 2007. Not including interim officials, Mr. Allen will be the ballet’s fourth top administrator since 1999.
