The Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, which has been closed to the public since March for a continuing renovation and expansion, said it had reopened its main galleries to the public through Aug. 29. The galleries, on the second and third floors, feature the museum’s core exhibition exploring how moving images are made, marketed and exhibited. The galleries will be open Tuesdays through Thursdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and Fridays from 10 a.m. to 6:30 p.m., with free admission after 4 p.m. The museum is expected to fully reopen in late 2009 or early 2010.

Less than a week after its deal with Shakira was confirmed, the music giant Live Nation said Tuesday it had signed the Canadian rock band Nickelback to a long-term worldwide contract for recordings, touring, merchandise and other rights. Nickelback, whose hits include “How You Remind Me” and “Photograph,” has sold more than 26 million albums around the world. The contract will cover three touring and album cycles, with an option for a fourth, according to the announcement. People close to the negotiations, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss the details, said the deal was worth $50 million to $70 million. By signing Nickelback, Live Nation, whose main business is concert promotion, took another step toward expanding its role at the center of the music industry, the traditional province of record labels. Nickelback is the fourth act to sign a so-called multiple rights or “360” deal, and the company said it planned to sign up four to six acts within a year. Besides Shakira, deals have been made with Madonna and Jay-Z.

“World News,” the evening newscast on ABC, received its lowest measured ratings last week, according to Nielsen Media Research. The newscast, anchored by Charles Gibson, averaged 6.9 million viewers for the week of June 30, ranking second to “NBC Nightly News,” which attracted 7.4 million. The third-place “CBS Evening News” averaged 5.6 million. The audience was ABC’s lowest since Nielsen introduced its people meter ratings system in 1987. The record is largely symbolic, as it occurred in a traditionally low-rated week leading up to the holiday. (July 4 was excluded from the averages of the three newscasts.) But it underscored the declines that evening newscasts are experiencing more broadly. Three times this year, the CBS newscast set new lows in ratings among total viewers. For the last two weeks, “World News” has set new lows in the 25- to 54-year-old demographic that advertisers covet.

The producer of the hit reality series “Survivor” and “The Apprentice” has been sued by his former business partner, The Los Angeles Times reported. Conrad Riggs filed the lawsuit against Mark Burnett on Monday, contending that Mr. Burnett owed him more than $70 million for his contributions to their joint efforts. The two met in the 1990s when Mr. Burnett was trying to pitch an idea for a show that eventually became “Survivor.” Mr. Riggs then worked for Walt Disney and helped Mr. Burnett with contacts in the industry, and later helped arrange deals. The lawsuit says Mr. Burnett broke an agreement to pay Mr. Riggs 10 percent of his profits from several television series. Mr. Burnett’s office said late Monday that he was traveling and could not be reached for comment.

A beloved literary institution on Martha’s Vineyard, the Bunch of Grapes Bookstore, suffered serious damage over the Fourth of July weekend when a fire broke out at an adjacent cafe, Publishers Weekly reported. The bookstore’s owners said the store would remain closed for the “foreseeable future.” Founded in 1975 by a former nurse in the town of Vineyard Haven, the independent bookstore has long been a gathering place for notable writers and book lovers. Katherine Fergason, the store’s manager, told Publishers Weekly that the building was still structurally sound, though the books on the first floor were destroyed. “Right now we don’t really know enough to say what will happen,” Ms. Fergason said, adding: “Obviously we miss the store very much. It almost feels like we watched an old friend die.”.

The United States and regional powers will resume talks with North Korea on Thursday about ending its nuclear weapons programs, a South Korean envoy said. The six-nation talks, the first in nine months, will concentrate on verifying North Korea's account of its nuclear program and on expediting the disabling of its main nuclear complex in return for fuel shipments. North Korea has delayed removing spent fuel rods, a source of plutonium, from its main reactor, saying the nations have been slow to provide promised fuel.

KOPPELMAN--Brenda. Remembering you with love. Judi, Andy, Brian & Stefani Marcus KOPPELMAN--Brenda. To my brave and beautiful Bunny, I will always treasure our much too short time together. Your legacy will live on in your incredible family, and you will always be in my heart. XOXO Ellyn KOPPELMAN--Brenda (Bunny), of Roslyn Harbor, died July 8th, 2008, after a stoic fight against pancreatic cancer. Until the end, her warmth and laughter were only surpassed by her intelligence, kindness, generosity and love for her family. Her husband, Charles; children, Brian, Stacy and Jennifer; daughter-in-law, Amy; sonsin-law, Keith and David; and grandchildren, Sophie, Sam, Harrison, Ruthie, Jacob, Anna and Raquel already miss her immensely. Bunny was at the center of our lives, gave her all to all of us each and every day, and never stopped trying to protect, counsel, love and spoil the lot of us. She was One of The Great Ones and we just cannot believe she's gone. Services Wednesday, July 9, 2008, 1pm at Temple Sinai of Roslyn, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn, New York.

CLEVELAND--Robert Gran, retired Foreign Service officer, died Monday, June 30 in Washington, DC. He was 97. From 1947 to 1970, he served in Bucharest, Paris, Sydney, Bangkok and Belgrade. From 1970 to 1977, he was President of Meridian House International, promoting international educational and cultural exchanges. He served on the boards of the American Foreign Service Association; Meridian International Center; the Diplomatic and Consular Officers Retired (DACOR) Bacon House Foundation; the Evening Star Broadcasting Company; the Washington Hospital Center Medlantic Research Institute; and the Textile Museum. He leaves his wife of 64 years, Mary Manning Cleveland; three children: Polly Cleveland (New York, NY), Frances Cleveland (Boulder Creek, CA) and David Cleveland (New York, NY); six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to the DACOR Foundation, providing scholarships to students of foreign affairs. (www.dacorbacon.org).

She is survived by her husband, Alan Leibowitz, son and daughter-in-law, David and Mayumi Leibowitz, daughter and son-in-law, Sandra and Glenn Rodney, all of Johns Creek, GA, brothers, John Henry Falk, Ft. She graduated from Scarsdale High School, Rider University, and Nova University. She served the Alper JCC in Miami for 29 years. Her legacy of enthusiasm and zeal for life will be greatly missed. Helene supported numerous organizations and charities: Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation, Chabad of Alpharetta, Chabad of Kendall, Alper JCC to name a few.

Malia and Sasha Obama, the daughters of Senator Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, have been seen in the background on election nights and during a handful of campaign stops in the last 18 months. But interviews? Strictly off limits -- until now. The girls made their television debut on ''Access Hollywood,'' in a segment taped last week in Montana; the first of the four-part interview was shown on Tuesday. Their appearance, sitting alongside their parents, was a sharp departure from how other presidential candidates have handled media requests for their children. (Chelsea Clinton still declines interviews.)

NARKISS--Bezalel. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the passing of Professor Emeritus Bezalel Narkiss. Professor Narkiss, who held the Nicolas Landau Chair in Art History at The Hebrew University, was a founder of its Department of Art History and Center for Jewish Art. A beloved and well-respected international expert in the field, he was awarded the Israel Prize in Art History for his lifetime achievements. We extend our sympathies to his family and friends. May his memory be for a blessing. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem President Menachem Magidor American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, Chairman of the Board George A. Schieren, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

DeVITO di PORRIASA-Marchese Lino, on July 7, 2008. Loving husband of Ilona and devoted father of Elisa. Cherished by his many loving family members and friends. Funeral service Friday 10am at St. Patrick's Cathedral (Our Lady Chapel) 51 St. and Fifth Ave. Services entrusted to Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel.

SKOLNICK--Rand. American Friends of The Hebrew University is deeply saddened by the passing of Rand Skolnick, beloved son of Allen and Connie Skolnick. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the entire Skolnick family. May the Skolnicks be comforted among the mourners of Zion. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, Chairman of the Board George A. Schieren, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director Martin E. Karlinsky, Pres., Greater NY Region Jacqueline S. Glodstein, Executive Director, Greater NY Region SKOLNICK--Rand Harlan, passed away peacefully at his summer home in New Hope, PA on July 4th, 2008. Surrounded by his longtime partner Terrence Meck and family, Rand succumbed to his battle with pancreatic cancer. He was 50 years old. Throughout his life Rand worked diligently in the health food industry building his family business, Solgar Vitamin and Herb Company into a household name for those who demanded integrity and high quality in nutrasutical. He will be remembered as a wonderful son and brother, loving husband, honest businessman and great friend to so many. Most of all, he will always be remembered for his ability to remain humble throughout his all too short life. From the beginning of his career until his death, Rand was an avid philanthropist. In the end, people were Rand's greatest joy. Services were held at Riverside Memorial Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Rand's Foundation, The Palette Fund at P.O. Box 865, Lynbrook, NY, 11563.

REESE--Louis Garfield III. Born July 21, 1949. Died June 29, 2008 (5:34 Montana time). Child of Pete and Lou, husband, father, friend, brother, mentor, Louie, visionary, uncle, loyal business partner, Big Lou, lover of nature, man of impossibly high standards, tender hearted, enthusiastic but terrible singer, great fly fisherman, notorious delegator, doer of deals, rough around the edges, dreamer of dreams, Daddy... Survived by wife Susan (so proud to share his name), daughter Katie, son Beau, daughter McKenzie, father-in-law Walter, adopted family Ginnie and Jeff McCorkle and Baby Cameron. He loves his family, his friends, his work, his house, his garden, the Madison River, Hawaiian shirts, making fudge, giving advice and more advice -wanted or unwanted, Thanksgiving, structuring a complex real estate deal on a paper napkin, skinny dipping, The Ashram, bonfires in the yard, crying freely, speaking Spanish, his children's most special friends, Warren Zevon, Restvedt beef jerky, Cuban cigars, big diamonds, wild flowers, Christmas morning, marking his territory, howling at the moon, chaos, Yellowstone Park, Hawaii, passing on ridiculous cures, old diesel Mercedes, letting Grady bring in the morning paper and saving a busted deal when no one else could. We will miss your big hands, your generous heart, your unending sense of integrity, your superb snuggling, your stories and your pushing us all to be more than what we ever think we can be. We love you. We miss you. We honor you. We won't see your likes again. In lieu of flowers, please make any donations to: Lou Reese Madison River Conservation Fund, c/o The Dallas Foundation, 900 Jackson St., Suite 705, Dallas TX 75202. To donate online and share your memories, please visit: madisonriverfund.org.

The Guardian has a fascinating story on how an unseen trove of Franz Kafka's papers may finally come to light, following the death of the woman who'd held onto them for years, refusing to let scholars have a look. The cache, which reportedly includes documents, letters and personal effects, has been sitting in the Tel Aviv home of Esther Hoffe, a former secretary of Kafka's great friend and executor, Max Brod. (Brod was the guy who didn't heed Kafka's orders that he burn the Czech-German author's papers after his death in 1924.) Since Brod himself died in 1968, Hoffe has driven scholars bananas with her refusal to relinquish the material. And now that she just died at age 101, they thought they might finally get some insights into the final years of Kafka's life. But not necessarily. ...

With or without the threat of human-caused climate disruption, it's clear the world lacks the menu of energy options it will require to avoid trouble as the human population heads toward 9 billion people (more or less), all seeking a decent life. The definition of decent life, of course, depends on who's doing the defining. But clearly such a life would not necessarily include children being required to walk two hours a day to collect firewood or a bucket of potable water (instead of, say, going to school or helping plant a crop or just being a kid). Needless to say, a decent life also does not necessarily require three cars, 5,000 square feet of house, and 100,000 frequent-flier miles a year.

O.K., it's an official trend. Three people have now climbed the Times Building. But where, agents and editors, is the book proposal? Surely we have not exhausted the market for anthologies of original essays that tell us way too much about personal experiences of love, hate, sex, divorce, money, swearing, eating (or not), you name it. So where is "Why I Climb: Scaling the Times Building and All the Shocking Things I Spied Through the Windows"? One or two more attempts, and the project's golden. The $19 billion merger of Activision and Vivendi Games has ignited speculation that the merged company could now set its sights on Take-Two Interactive Software, which has been fending off a $2 billion hostile takeover attempt by Electronic Arts.
Bank of America is primed to assume all debt of the former Countrywide Financial, independent research firm CreditSights said, a move that would alleviate worries of Countrywide bondholders.

Clarium Capital Management, the $6.4 billion fund founded by Peter Thiel in 2002, returned a 57.9 percent at the end of June, according to performance data obtained by The New York Post. The company is now on track for one of its best years ever.

Sir Ronald Cohen, co-founder of Apax Partners, is backing the management buyout of ABN Amro's former hedge fund arm a mere two and a half years after the Dutch bank bought the business, The Financial Times reported.

New York-based hedge fund Sandelman Partners, which manages about $4 billion of assets, told investors in its largest fund that they cannot have their money back soon, The Wall Street Journal said on Thursday.
Challenge Games has received $4.5 million from Sequoia Capital and announced a multi-year licensing deal with MLB Advanced Media, the interactive media and Internet company of Major League Baseball.
China's securities regulator intends next Monday to review an application for a Shanghai initial public offering. by Great Wall Motor, which could raise up to $82 million, Reuters reported.

Politics | Would Mark Twain have been a critic of waterboarding? You bet, says Roy Blount Jr. in an essay. In 1902, Twain wrote of "the torturing of Filipinos by the awful 'water-cure.'" So it's not just sarcastic social comics like Stewart and Colbert who are in Twain's debt. His influence was such that he was "our original superstar." -- Time
HSBC has appointed Hitendra Dave head of global markets for India, FinanceAsia reported.
French police on Wednesday detained an executive of EADS, the parent of Airbus, as part of an insider trading probe, according to his attorney.
German thin-film solar cell manufacturer Sulfurcell closed on a $133.7 million round, which was led by Intel Capital with a $37.7 million contribution.
Dimdim, an open-source Web conferencing provider, has raised $6 million in Series B funding, according to media reports.

Steve Wynn is mulling a secondary listing for his casino and hotel group in Hong Kong, MarketWatch said, citing a media report. The move could raise as much as $3 billion and would likely be the largest listing on the Hong Kong bourse this year.
Macquarie Group and Seek will invest a combined $105 million in Zhaopin, owner of China's third-biggest recruitment Web site, Bloomberg News reported.
Man Group has reported a 6.6 percent rise in assets under management to $79.5 billion in the past three months, Bloomberg reported.
Novartis has taken a majority stake in Speedel Holding and offered to buy the rest in a deal valuing the company at 1.01 billion Swiss francs ($980 million), Bloomberg News reported.
Cracked.com asked its readers to draw historical events as if depicted by 5-year-olds. Here's some of what they came up with:

Aired Wednesday night on NBC: The Democratic Party announced this week that Barack Obama will give his acceptance speech at an 80,000-seat stadium and that they will not serve fried food at the Democratic convention. Which begs the question: Where are they going to find 80,000 Americans who don't eat fried food?
More of your "late night" humor (send via the comment link below):
Barack Obama is acquainting himself more deeply with his country and has been surprised by some of his findings.
A code of behavior that says that “blood must be paid with blood” has trapped many Albanians in their homes.
We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, July 10 column.

Unless you live on another planet, you know that contemporary Chinese art is as hot as Beijing in August. Works by Zeng Fengzhi, Yue Minjun, Cai Guo-Qiang, Zhang Xiaogang and other Chinese artists are fetching millions of dollars, and China last year displaced France as the art world's third biggest auction market, after the United States and Britain.

Brandon Jennings will pursue a professional career in Europe, backing out on his commitment to Arizona. Jennings, who played his final two high school seasons for Oak Hill Academy in Virginia, had not yet become academically eligible at Arizona. He had been awaiting the results of a third entrance exam, but decided instead to give up his scholarship, his lawyer said.
“Darkness and Light” is an engrossing work that seems at once a return to pure Pilobolus essence and a complete departure from basic Pilobolism.
The irascible Nascar driver who has brought titles and trouble to Joe Gibbs Racing since 1999, will leave the organization at the end of this season.

With the All Star Game next week in Yankee Stadium, we’ll see baseball’s greatest stars. One thing we likely won’t see is a pitcher batting, because, as we’ve been told relentlessly, “pitchers can’t hit.”.

Much has been written lately about Jason Giambi’s new facial hair. On Monday, Giambi got two mustache-related boosts for his all-star candidacy: the American Mustache Institute officially offered its support for him, and the Yankees issued a press release urging fans to “Support the ’Stache.”.

In his book “A Few Seconds of Panic; A 5-foot-8, 170-pound, 43-year-old Sportswriter Plays in the N.F.L.,” published this month by Penguin Press ($25.95), Stefan Fatsis suits up with the Denver Broncos for a summer of place kicking. His skills on the field improved to the point that he could drill 40-yard field goals, but more meaningful to readers is that he used his deep access to provide an insightful and sometimes amusing look at the inner workings of pro football. Fatsis recently talked to us about what he learned along the way.

Since late May Play Magazine has brought you "The Climb” by Rob Mackey, about his training for, and ultimate ascent of, a mountain stage of the Tour de France. Rob made it on Sunday, finishing the 105-mile course in just over eight hours. As Rob chronicled his progress, a debate arose -- a divide, really -- among those following his quest and commenting on his blog. Some contended that this was an indulgent, expensive ”drop-in” on a serious pursuit that missed the point of what cycling is really about; others found it an inspiring example of what anyone can do with a little determination and hard work; some simply said it sounded like a blast.

Federal prosecutors are investigating whether State Department employees broke the law by snooping into the passport records of prominent politicians, athletes and entertainers, Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey said.
Warren S. Jeffs, the imprisoned polygamist leader, was taken from jail in Arizona to a Las Vegas hospital after he was found feverish and “convulsive” in his cell.
A compact designed to prevent remote regions or countries from tapping into the Great Lakes was approved by the last of the eight states that border the lakes.
New details and observations about the gunman in a February shooting rampage at Northern Illinois University were published in a magazine article.

Michigan and its football coach, Rich Rodriguez, have agreed to pay a $4 million buyout and settle a lawsuit that West Virginia filed after Rodriguez broke his contract and left in December. Rodriguez will pay $1.5 million in three annual payments beginning January 2010. The Wolverines’ athletic department will pay $2.5 million by the end of July.
The Mets are now only a game and a half behind the first-place Philadelphia Phillies in the National League East.
More than three dozen cable car passengers were stranded for hours Wednesday night at the Bronx Zoo after an emergency mechanism caused the ride to shut down.
Senator Barack Obama asked loyal donors in New York to help pay off part of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s $23 million debt she ran up trying to beat him.
Relatives recalled a 71-year-old man and his 5-year-old godson who died in a fire as being very close.
Verizon Wireless has agreed to pay $21 million to settle a lawsuit filed by customers in California upset with the company’s early termination fees, a lawyer in the case said Wednesday.

In the wake of Scott Kalitta’s recent fatal accident, the National Hot Rod Association took an interim step, reducing the length of top fuel and funny car races from 1,320 feet to 1,000. The change will take effect this weekend at the Mopar Mile-High Nationals in Colorado. The pro stock and pro stock motorcycle classes will continue to run a quarter-mile. It will be the first time the N.H.R.A. has conducted racing at any distance other than a quarter-mile at a national event. Kalitta died June 21 in Englishtown, N.J., after his funny car burst into flames and slammed into a retaining barrier.

Comments by the former touring professional Justin Gimelstob on a radio show have cost him again. Television commercials featuring Gimelstob promoting the United States Open Series are being scrapped by the United States Tennis Association because of his derogatory and sexually suggestive remarks about Anna Kournikova and other women last month. Previously, Gimelstob was suspended for one match without pay by World Team Tennis, and the Tennis Channel, for which he also works, requested that he make a “substantial” donation to the Women’s Sports Foundation.

Jerry Yang, who won $8.25 million in capturing last year’s World Series of Poker, was knocked out in Las Vegas and finished out of the money. On Thursday, the 466 players who survived on Tuesday will join those left after Wednesday, bringing all the entrants together for the first time this tournament, likely 1,200 to 1,400 players.

The top-seeded Mardy Fish lost his first match at the Hall of Fame championships for the second straight year, falling to Rohan Bopanna, 7-6 (6), 7-5, on Wednesday. A No. 1 seed has not won the title in the event’s 32-year history on the Hall of Fame grass courts in Newport, R.I.
Turkish troops have been sent to rescue three German climbers who were kidnapped by Kurdish rebels high on Mount Ararat, an official said.
A former United Nations employee accused of killing some of his colleagues and others during the genocide in Rwanda in 1994 has been arrested in Frankfurt.
The Eiffel Tower, host to nearly seven million visitors per year, is about to get a makeover.
The police in London charged an unemployed 33-year-old man in the stabbing murders of two French students.
A committee in Brazil’s lower house of Congress voted down a bill that would have legalized abortion in the world’s most populous Roman Catholic nation.
Nothing in Chris Duhon’s résumé suggests budding stardom, but the Knicks see untapped talent in their new point guard.
French police on Wednesday detained an executive of EADS, the parent of Airbus, as part of an insider trading probe, according to his attorney.
The city says it will explore the possibility of creating a bike-sharing program that could make hundreds or even thousands of bicycles available for public use.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s return to the Senate helped Democrats deliver a victory on a signature health care issue despite his own treatment for brain cancer.
A growing number of people are skipping out on grocery stores and instead going right to the source by buying shares of farms — in essence hiring personal farmers.
Hal Steinbrenner has supported Brian Cashman’s philosophy of building the Yankees through the farm system, low-risk trades and occasional free-agent spending.
John Devaney, who made and then lost a fortune trading mortgage investments, has finally called it quits. He shut his hedge fund, and told his investors that all their money was gone too.
The Knicks publicly insist that Chris Duhon’s arrival does not indicate Stephon Marbury’s departure. But the team president said little Wednesday to dispel the notion.
A group of residents in the South Bronx is suing the city and the owner of one of two sewage plants over bad odors.
In an interview, Sumner M. Redstone, chairman of Viacom and CBS, said that his daughter was no longer the company’s heir apparent.
A top Democratic senator accused an Army general of misleading Congress about problems with a major defense contractor in Iraq, and said he had asked for an investigation.
FRONT PAGE.
An invitation for Senator Barack Obama to speak at Brandenburg Gate has created an uproar and has exposed fissures in the German government.
Jess Jackson is hoping to prove that his horse, Curlin, is not merely a chemically enhanced colt, but a true champion.
Damion Easley has been so effective that Manager Jerry Manuel has raised the possibility that Luis Castillo will not automatically reclaim his job when he returns.
The pens, pads, mugs and other gifts that drug makers have long showered on doctors will be banned from their marketing campaigns under a guideline that the industry is expected to announce Thursday.
Eight Iraqis were killed in a suicide attack against Iraq’s top military commander in the northern city of Mosul. The commander escaped unharmed.
Robert K. Steel, the under secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, has been chosen to be Wachovia’s new chief executive.
An increase in the number of foreign fighters may reflect a change that is making Pakistan’s tribal areas the preferred destination for some Sunni insurgents.
On Wednesday, Jorge Posada was the designated hitter for the fourth time in five games, a reduced role that left him unsatisfied.
Steven Silva and a group of private investors said Wednesday that they would buy the New York Dragons, the city’s Arena Football League.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson apologized for critical and crude comments he made about Senator Barack Obama, remarks that were recorded by a live microphone.
The Finance Committee has agreed to ease restrictions on “partial gifts,” in which collectors claim tax deductions for donating artwork in increments to museums.
Nduka Obaigbena, a Nigerian media mogul — part Bono, part Diddy — has been challenging his country’s often brutal kleptocracy for decades.
A man was charged with reckless endangerment after his elderly father died in a hot vehicle with the windows rolled up in Beacon.
In Greenwich, Conn., a lot that teenagers cleared for Wiffle ball brought out angry neighbors and police.
Congress should pass a law that allows the government to look at data on laptops only when it has a reasonable suspicion about the specific person being searched.
Federal and state authorities are looking into accusations of voting fraud in three largely black counties of Alabama.
The widow of Thurman Munson said she will auction the former catcher’s memorabilia. The money raised will help finance the college educations of her seven grandchildren.
The final agreement in this week’s G-8 summit establishes no interim goals that would require prompt and meaningful investments in cleaner energy.
The Neo FreeRunner from Openmoko is a completely open-source cellphone with a few interesting high-end features.
Product placement is shaping up to be advertisers’ holy grail in television shows. The question is, should we worry?
Canon’s Rebel XS, unveiled this week and available next month, is a simple digital S.L.R. that is meant to take top-quality pictures painlessly.
Once upon a time, all that singer-songwriters needed was a six-string and a dream. Now they could also use a G-Track U.S.B. microphone.
Memorex eliminates the need for a dedicated backup program with its SimpleSave Photo & Video Backup DVDs, which include the necessary software right on the recordable disc.

Bloomberg announced a revamping intended to play up its growing assets in television, radio and Internet content.
A Filipino woman says a former ambassador to the United Nations enslaved her for three months, after she was lured with a promise of help in finding work.
A Japanese labor bureau has ruled that one of Toyota’s top car engineers died from working too many hours.

A union official said the case of Ryan Church, the Mets’ right fielder, highlighted the challenge that concussions present, and how greater scrutiny of the injury could benefit future players.
Dustin Pedroia hit a three-run double as the Boston Red Sox followed an overturned triple-play call with seven runs in the seventh inning to beat Minnesota, 18-5.
Daniel Lyons, the former Forbes magazine journalist who wrote the blog The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs for the last two years, is moving on with his professional life and creative pursuits.
Music lovers can create Electronica at home with this new class of musical gadgets.
A new DNA technique has found genetic traces of an unidentified male on clothing worn by JonBenet Ramsey on the night she died, clearing the family of her death.
Melinda R. Katz, a candidate for city comptroller, wants to set up an account for next fall’s election so she can keep collecting big donations from the real estate industry this year.
Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s once enfeebled government, emboldened by several recent military successes, is eager to assert its sovereignty.
The Russian gas export monopoly Gazprom wants to buy any available natural gas produced by Libya and some of the country’s oil, the top Libyan oil official said.
Some food safety experts tied problems in tracing the source of the salmonella outbreak to what they say are shortcomings in the Bioterrorism Act of 2002.
For the second time in three starts for his new team, Sidney Ponson pitched a gem for six innings, as the Yankees won their fourth in a row.
The new law would make it possible for people in dating relationships, heterosexual or gay, to seek protection from abusers in family court.
Two Russian astronauts are to undertake a highly unusual procedure intended to help engineers understand a malfunction in the capsule that will bring them back to Earth.
Drug makers whose products are not ready for approval in the U.S. will soon get the word from regulators in a new format intended partly to avoid scaring investors.
The devices, like digital Swiss Army knives for conductors, are part of a long transition by the railroad to go cashless.
Last August, Tim Donaghy admitted to providing inside information to gamblers and helping them pick N.B.A. games.
Yahoo wants to enlist a small army of search start-ups as allies in the hope that collectively they will be able to stop the Google juggernaut.
The App Store for iPhone software is the first step in an attempt to dominate the next generation of computing.
Some of the nation’s older cities registered small gains in population, while others slowed their declines, according to the latest census figures.
The power forward gives the Philadelphia 76ers the low-post presence they need to contend in the Eastern Conference.
If you hate to be without your Flickr photos while doing other things on the computer, you can still keep them close.
Is there any way to import the old messages from both my expiring college account and Hotmail into a new Gmail account — besides forwarding each one individually?
Now that Windows XP is retired, will Microsoft still put out security patches for the system?
The campaign has given Barack Obama a chance to visit large swaths of the U.S. that he had never seen before.
Mr. Burgard was a leader in the movement to create arts programs in communities around the country.
Mr. Simon, a Civil War scholar, created a new standard for the organization of historical documents after his mammoth effort in editing the papers of Ulysses S. Grant.
Seven international peacekeepers were killed and 22 injured in an ambush in the Sudanese province of Darfur on Tuesday, according to United Nations officials.
None of G.M.’s management miscues was so damaging to its long-term fate as the rich pensions and health care that robbed General Motors of its financial flexibility.

David H. Koch has agreed to contribute $100 million toward the renovation of the New York State Theater.
The latest in a long line of model dwellings aimed at telling us how we might live in years to come, Disney’s new Innoventions Dream Home turns out to be positively retrograde.
The rec room, once a wood-paneled corner of the basement with a dumpy couch and a TV with rabbit ears, is enjoying a revival in more upscale form.
Two more days of extreme heat and low humidity could make the job of protecting homes from scores of wildfires even more difficult.
Two prominent theater entities, the Acting Company and the Guthrie Theater, are joining forces to present a co-production and national tour of “Henry V.”

Lisa Ling, below, a former co-host of “The View” on ABC, will return to that network as a contributor to “Nightline,” ABC said on Wednesday. Ms. Ling is already a special correspondent for “The Oprah Winfrey Show” and the National Geographic Channel. Her first segment for “Nightline,” on the rapid growth of luxury retirement communities, will be shown on Thursday’s episode, beginning at 11:35 p.m.

Ingrid Betancourt, below, the Colombian-French politician who was held hostage by guerrillas in a Colombian jungle for six years, has been on a full-court press with the European news media after her dramatic rescue last week. Now the American media will have their turn, beginning with NBC News, which announced on Wednesday that it had been granted the first United States television interview with Ms. Betancourt since her rescue. Ann Curry, the NBC news anchor, conducted the interview, scheduled for broadcast on the “NBC Nightly News” on Wednesday night and on “Today” on Thursday. And Ms. Betancourt’s American publisher, Ecco, a division of HarperCollins, quickly made plans to release a new paperback version of her 2001 memoir, “Until Death Do Us Part,” in August. The book, an attack on political corruption in Colombia, was published under the title “The Rage in My Heart” in France, and became a best seller there. Susanna Lea, Ms. Betancourt’s longtime literary agent in Paris, said in an e-mail message that Ms. Betancourt was “thinking of writing a book and a play too.”.

Lil Wayne and Coldplay switch places on the Billboard chart this week: Lil Wayne’s “Tha Carter III” (Cash Money/Universal Motown), which was No. 2 for two weeks, returns to the top spot in its fourth week of release, with sales of 156,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That was 25 percent fewer than “Tha Carter” had the week before, but Coldplay’s “Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends” (Capitol) had a bigger drop. It sold 149,000, a weekly loss of 40 percent, sending the album to No. 2 after two weeks in the lead. Disney’s soundtrack to “Camp Rock” remains at No. 3 with 116,000, and the next two spots on the chart are new. G-Unit, the rap crew led by 50 Cent, sold 102,000 copies of “T.O.S. (Terminate on Sight)” (G-Unit/Interscope), bowing at No. 4, and John Mayer’s live album, “Where the Light Is” (Columbia), is No. 5 with 75,000. Down the chart, the Kansas City rapper Tech N9ne’s “Killer” (Strange) opened at No. 12, and Alkaline Trio’s “Agony & Irony” (Epic) opened at No. 13.

A worker, above, removes fake condensation from a display of a woman in a thermal bath at Herculaneum, below, in one of more than 70 multimedia installations at the new Virtual Archaeological Museum there. The museum offers a 3-D virtual tour of that ancient Roman town, south of Naples, which was destroyed along with Pompeii in the A.D. 79 eruption of Mount Vesuvius.

Leonard Cohen, above, made his first appearance in 23 years at the Montreux Jazz Festival on Tuesday night, Agence France-Presse reported. Natty in a pinstripe suit, gray shirt and hat, Mr. Cohen, nearly 74, joked with the crowd about his decision to tour again after a long layoff. “It’s been a long time since I’ve stood up on the stage, about 14 years” he said. “Since then I’ve taken a lot of Prozac” and “also studied religion and philosophy, but cheerfulness kept breaking through,” he said, drawing laughter in leading to a song called “Ain’t No Cure for Love.”.

Victor Willis, the original lead singer of the Village People, who performed dressed as a helmeted policeman, underwent surgery at a San Diego hospital on Monday to remove nodules from his vocal cords, a spokeswoman told Reuters. As a result of the surgery, Mr. Willis, who wrote the hits “Y.M.C.A.” and “Macho Man,” has been forced to cancel a solo American tour. The spokeswoman told Reuters that she expected him to make a full recovery and that a new tour could begin as soon as October.
A musical based on John Milton’s “Paradise Lost” will open on Broadway this fall.

Salman Rushdie is considered the favorite to win the Best of the Booker award on Thursday, at least among oddsmakers surveyed by Reuters. The award coincides with the 40th anniversary of one of the world’s most sought-after literary prizes. Mr. Rushdie, whose 1988 novel, “The Satanic Verses,” angered some Muslims and prompted death threats against him, was the overwhelming 1-to-8 front-runner for “Midnight’s Children,” which won the Booker Prize in 1981. His competition includes J. M. Coetzee and Nadine Gordimer, each a Nobel Prize winner, among others. Nick Weinberg of the bookmakers Ladbrokes said Mr. Rushdie had attracted 90 percent of all wagers on the “Best of the Booker” award.

Fox’s finale of “Hell’s Kitchen” led Tuesday night’s ratings among adults 18 to 49, concluding a strong fourth season of the series, which was up by an average of 15 percent in that demographic from last summer. Although the finale drew just a modest audience of 8.8 million in total viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, the show still dominated its 9 o’clock competitors among the 18-to-49 set. The competition included “America’s Got Talent” on NBC, the night’s most-watched show, with 12.4 million total viewers. For the night over all, NBC averaged the most total viewers, drawing decent ratings at both 8 and 10 with “Celebrity Family Feud” (7.5 million) and a repeat of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (7.2 million). But NBC trailed among adults 18 to 49, behind Fox and ABC, which tied for first. ABC’s 8 o’clock reality show “Wipeout” nearly matched “Hell’s Kitchen” in the 18-to-49 set, while attracting 10.6 million total viewers. ABC’s 9 and 10 o’clock offerings, “I Survived a Japanese Game Show” (6.8 million) and “Primetime: The Outsiders” (7.1 million), also fared better than Fox’s 8 o’clock game show, “The Moment of Truth” (5 million).

Annette Bening, below, who has been nominated for an Academy Award three times, has been elected to the governing board of the organization that gives out the Oscars, according to Reuters. Ms. Bening, 50, who is married to Warren Beatty, joins the 43-member Board of Governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. It draws up the rules and regulations for administering the awards.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, battling cancer, made an unexpected return to the Senate to vote on a Medicare bill.
Q. How often does my container garden need to be fertilized?
Widespread fear about the health of the mortgage industry took hold Wednesday afternoon, and investors could not shake the jitters.

Eugenio Barba and his experimental group, Odin Teatret, have been practicing intercultural exchanges for almost half a century.

Conran’s summer sale starts Thursday and continues through Aug. 3, with discounts of up to 60 percent. Angel Street is opening a warehouse in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, on Saturday.

KLEIN--William. The untimely and sudden passing of our friend and trusted advisor will be truly missed. We extend our condolences to the entire Klein family. The Yagoda Family KLEIN--William, a lifelong New York resident, died Tuesday, July 8, at NewYorkPresbyterian Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Klein graduated from NYU and pursued a career as a certified public accountant. He ran his own practice for 30 years and was fiercely dedicated to all of his clients. He is survived by his wife, Peggyann Klein; son Richard Klein; daughter Risa Greene; stepchildren John Adams, Kacey Peck, and Courtney McLaughlin; and his grandchildren, Nicole and Melanie Klein, Daniel and Jessica Greene, Austin and Ryan Peck, and Liam Adams. Funeral services are being kept private.

LEE--Dr. Sherman E. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Cleveland Museum of Art mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Dr. Sherman E. Lee. During 24 years of service as director, Sherman left an indelible mark on this institution through the acquisition of many of the most significant and treasured works of art in our collection, the expansion of our facilities, and a strong commitment to scholarship. Esteemed for his broad knowledge of the history of art and sound aesthetic judgment, Sherman was instrumental in encouraging a broader appreciation of Asian art among art historians and the general public. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Ruth and the members of his family. James T. Bartlett, Co-Chairman Michael J. Horvitz, Co-Chairman Alfred M. Rankin, III, President Timothy Rub, Director

When Apple opens its online App Store for iPhone software on Thursday, Steven P. Jobs will be making an attempt to dominate the next generation of computing as it moves toward Internet-connected mobile devices. The store, which will offer more than 500 software applications, including games, educational programs, mobile commerce and business productivity tools, may be a far more important development than the iPhone 3G, which goes on sale at the same time. An abundance of software could make the iPhone's operating system dominant among an abundance of competing phones.

Bruce Conner, an artist internationally admired for his haunting, surrealistic sculptures and groundbreaking avant-garde films, died on Monday at his home in San Francisco. He was 74. His death followed a long illness, said Susan Inglett, his New York dealer.
Measure for Measure Words and Bridges The musician Peter Holsapple describes what a bridge can and can't do for a song ... and nudges along the lyrics for a new one he's writing.

Brett Beldock, a Manhattan interior designer, was thinking about El Morocco and the Monkey Bar when she designed the interiors of a new assisted living facility, the Lodge at Otter Creek, in Middlebury, Vt. ''That was their heyday,'' Ms. Beldock said, referring to the facility's intended residents. She also was imagining a preppy New England vernacular, with framed botanicals, woodland creatures and the like. These nostalgic touchstones collide in oversize, graphic imagery meant to soothe and elate the inhabitants. Ms. Beldock designed five wallpapers, made by Stark (which will now produce them for sale), including a huge tropical print embedded with monkeys for the Great Room, top right. In the dining room, she covered the walls with Lucite printed with lace that she had photocopied and enlarged; the library, below right, has glowing bookshelves like those on an ocean liner.

The Frugal Traveler, Matt Gross, discovers Bucharest and its cool, semi-underground culture. There are new museums, art projects, boutiques and a revolution that has sprung up on the streets. At left, some of the stately Art Nouveau and neo-Classical architecture that has seen better days. nytimes.com/frugaltraveler

In an audacious spacewalk scheduled for Thursday, two Russian astronauts aboard the International Space Station are to saw away insulation from the Soyuz capsule that is to be used for their ride home later this year, remove a live explosive bolt that is part of the capsule's re-entry apparatus and take it back into the station. The highly unusual procedure is intended to help engineers on the ground understand why the last two Soyuz capsules returned to Earth in a harrowing ''ballistic'' descent that subjected those aboard to higher than normal g-forces.

Rabbi David Ellenson, President Rabbi Shirley Idelson, Dean, New York School Barbara Friedman, Chair of the Board DREYFUS--Rabbi A. Stanley. The Central Conference of American Rabbis mourns the death of its Placement Director Emeritus, Rabbi A. Stanley Dreyfus, who provided significant leadership to the Reform Rabbinate and the Reform Movement as leader of the Joint Commission for Rabbinical Placement. As chair of the CCAR Liturgy Committee, his vast scholarship and his liturgical expertise contributed greatly to the publication of Reform prayer books, particularly The Gates of Prayer. His teaching at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion touched many rabbis as well. We extend our condolences to his beloved family. ''Woe unto those who are lost and cannot be replaced.'' (Sanhedrin 111a) Rabbi Peter S. Knobel, CCAR President Rabbi Steven A. Fox, CCAR Executive Vice President DREYFUS--Rabbi A. Stanley, 87, on July 8. Beloved husband of Marianne (nee Berlak), loving father of Dr. James (Rabbi Ellen) and the late Richard (Helen) Dreyfus, proud grandfather of Benjamin, Lina (Adam Wallace), David, Daniel and Adam. Fond brother of Julie Zager, the late Alan (Fran) and the late Elaine Dreyfus. Revered rabbi, teacher and mentor of generations. Service, Thursday, July 10 at 1pm at Union Temple of Brooklyn, 17 Eastern Parkway. Donations to Union Temple, CCAR Hesed Fund, HUC-JIR. DREYFUS--A. Stanley, Rabbi. Congregation Beth Elohim extends heartfelt condolences on behalf of its entire membership over the loss of Rabbi A. Stanley Dreyfus, our neighbor and dear friend as Rabbi Emeritus at Union Temple. Stanley was an exemplar of greatness in scholarship, teaching, and friendship. His scope of knowledge of liturgy and rabbinic wisdom will be a continuing inspiration. With his wife, Marianne Baeck Dreyfus, granddaughter of the great Rabbi Leo Baeck, their home was a sanctuary and altar for learning, warmth and goodness. To Marianne, Dr. James Dreyfus and their family, we offer our love and support. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and may Stanley's memory be forever a blessing. David Kasakove, President Andy Bachman, Rabbi Gerald Weider, Rabbi Emeritus Rabbi Dan Bronstein Rabbi Shira Koch Epstein Cantor Janet Leuchter Paul Basista, Executive Director DREYFUS--Dr. A. Stanley, Rabbi Emeritus. It is with the most profound sadness that Union Temple of Brooklyn records the death of its beloved and esteemed Rabbi Emeritus, Dr. A. Stanley Dreyfus, on Tuesday, July 8. He was one of the brightest luminaries of the American Reform Rabbinate, and was lovingly embraced by one and all in our congregational family. As Rabbi from 1964-1979, and then as Rabbi Emeritus until his death, he served our congregation with complete devotion and love, the highest standards of scholarship and spiritual guidance, and inimitable wit and good humor. He had a deep reverence for history, as he himself helped to shape Jewish history over the past half - century. Through his teaching at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, he helped to raise up an entire generation of rabbis. His formidable intellect and scholarly achievements were recognized and honored by colleagues, students, congregants, and all who crossed his path. Along with the entire Reform Movement of Judaism, our congregation has prayed for the past three decades from the prayer books he edited as Chairman of the Liturgy Committee of the Central Conference of American Rabbis. His love for Judaism and the Jewish People knew no bounds. Our hearts go out to his beloved wife Marianne, ''M'love,'' as he called her, and their wonderful family: son Dr. James Dreyfus and daughter-in-law Rabbi Ellen Weinberg Dreyfus of Homewood, IL, and their children, Ben, David, and Lina and Adam Wallace; daughter-in-law Helen Bagot Dreyfus of Houston, TX, widow of Richard, z''I, and her children Daniel and Adam; and sister Julie Zager. Funeral services will be conducted at Union Temple of Brooklyn, 17 Eastern Parkway at Grand Army Plaza, Thursday, July 10, 1:00pm. Y'hi zichrono fv'rachah -May he always be remembered for honor and blessing in the Household of Israel. Dr. Linda Henry Goodman, Rabbi Doris Klueger, President

There was a time, locals say, when you could not walk more than a few blocks on Jamaica Avenue, in Richmond Hill, Queens, without coming across a pool hall. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, devotees at the Hermes Billiards Cafe recalled this week, there were halls at 111th, 102nd, 98th and 90th Streets in the neighborhood.

In a surprising reshaping of the urban landscape, the city is creating a public esplanade along a part of one of its most prominent streets, Broadway in Midtown, setting aside the east side of the roadway for a bicycle lane and a pedestrian walkway with cafe tables, chairs, umbrellas and flower-filled planters, William Neuman reports. The esplanade, which the city is calling Broadway Boulevard, will run from 42nd Street to Herald Square. Scheduled to open in mid-August, it will change that section of Broadway from a four-lane to a two-lane street.

Updated, July 14 | When the Metropolitan Transportation Authority unveiled a public-service advertisement in January urging subway riders to dispose of their newspapers, because loose papers are a frequent cause of track fires, it used a partially obscured image of The New York Times. A second ad in the series, unveiled in April, showed a coffee cup being tossed into a trash can — but the coffee cup was blank and could not be associated with any particular brand or vendor.

Updated, 5 p.m. | Representative Charles B. Rangel held a 20-minute news conference on Friday afternoon after The New York Times reported that he had four rent-stabilized apartments in Harlem at a time when the city is experiencing an affordable housing crisis. At one point angry residents accosted the congressman, the dean of Harlem politics, in an unusual sidewalk confrontation, as Mr. Rangel faced questions from reporters.

Consolidated Edison is expecting to bill its residential customers in New York City and Westchester County 22 percent more for electricity this summer than last because of rising fuel costs, officials at the utility said Friday. A customer who uses 350 kilowatt hours of power per month, a typical amount, would pay about $105, $19 more than a year ago and $8 more than an earlier estimate. Business customers will likely see their bills rise by 25 percent, to an average of $2,893.08 a month.

I just moved into an apartment and signed a lease for $1,850. Someone told me that I may be paying a "preferential rent," so I looked again at the documents. The lease was on a form used for rent-stabilized tenants, and there was a section saying that the "market rate" was $2,009 a month.
I live in a rent-stabilized apartment and have installed my own locks on the front door. My landlord is planning to replace these locks with his own.

We're in the middle of the summer doldrums. The presidential candidates are doing their mightiest to focus our thoughts on the economy, on Iraq, to sharpen their messages to voters. They're up with new ads, attacking each other. The counters on the gas pumps roll ever higher. And the candidates are making moves in battleground states, places that just don't cotton to the stripes of the extreme left or the extreme right. That's the July landscape, and probably will be part of August's as well.

Andrew Kligerman is a native New Yorker who now lives in Research Triangle Park, N.C., where he's a genetic toxicologist and research biologist. He's also an avid vegetable gardener, homebrewer, sourdough bread maker, and cook, especially of Asian cuisine. And one day, he got to wondering about beer and tea. Here is his fascinating rumination. --MB

Jitters about the solvency of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two government-sponsored mortgage financing companies, took a big toll on financial-industry stocks Friday. Looming over Wall Street was the fear that if these companies should fail, it might completely shut down the market for mortgage-backed securities.

It's a grab bag - a little of this, a little of that - but the item I was most passionate about had to do with the allegations that Bear Stearns was brought down by rumors by short-sellers. This view has been promulgated by Vanity Fair's Bryan Burrough and even J.P. Morgan's head, Jamie Dimon, and I think it is nonsense - a classic case of shooting the messenger. Feel free to weigh in!

Hard to believe that with all its problems, the airline industry has the time to set up a Web site - and send out e-mail to just about everyone in America who has ever flown a plane - to complain about oil speculators. When I talked to the flack from the airline transport association, he basically blamed speculators for the cramped seats, the new charges for luggage, the foul meals, and just about everything else unpleasant about air travel. The cost of fuel this year, he added, is going to be more than $60 billion, compared to $40 billion-plus last year.

This just in from the Dept. of Unintended Consequences: among the many, many pieces of e-mail I received about my column about Google's day-care woes last week were several from parents who had children in other day-care centers in Silicon Valley, particularly the small handful that use the Reggio Emilia philosophy. Apparently, when Google was preparing to open its ultra-fancy center, The Woods, it aggressively recruited Reggio Emilia-trained day-care teachers from all over the Bay Area. It lured them with much higher salaries and the prospect of being full-fledged Google employees - status that more than a few Google engineers can't claim.

Whew! General Electric met analyst's forecasts Friday morning when it announced second-quarter earnings, after last quarter's quasi-disaster, when G.E. missed badly. I guess that means Jeff Immelt get to keep his job as C.E.O. I'm being only mildly facetious.

The biologist and writer Edward O. Wilson spent a couple of hours at The New York Times on Thursday. He mused on the halting courtship he's nurtured between religion and science since writing "The Creation."

Normally conservative investors like insurance companies and pension funds are starting to hunt for bargains in the loans used to finance private equity deals, The New York Post reported, suggesting that the credit crunch is beginning to ease for troubled investment banks.

Alarmed by the growing financial stress at the nation's two largest mortgage finance companies, senior Bush administration officials are considering a plan to have the government take over one or both of the companies and place them in a conservatorship if their problems worsen, people briefed about the plan said on Thursday.

In a reversal of its previous hostility to the idea, Anheuser-Busch is in active talks to sell itself to the Belgian brewer InBev in a friendly deal, people briefed on the matter said. InBev has raised its offer to $70 a share, more than the $65 it had originally offered, a person close to the talks said on Friday.

Lehman Brothers, Wall Street's favorite punching bag, took another beating on Thursday as jittery investors fretted over problems at home-loan giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and absorbed regulators' statements that they would not bail out all financial institutions.
The chief executive of General Motors did his best to strike down rumors on Thursday that the automaker might seek bankruptcy protection soon.

Trulia, a real-estate search startup, said it raised $15 million in additional capital in an investment round led by Deep Fork Capital. Sequoia Capital and Accel Partners, both previous Trulia investors, also took part in the round, Trulia said.
Terry Semel's attempt to buy management and marketing firm IMG is apparently over before it even began, The New York Post reported.

Last month's Justice Department opinion related to Halliburton may allow United States-based buyers of foreign firms to avoid risk under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act -- but there's a catch, Compliance Week reports.

Switzerland's Federal Banking Commission has outlined plans to impose higher capital requirements on UBS and Credit Suisse in the wake of their massive losses in the credit crisis, The Financial Times reported.
Midwest Air Group has set Friday as a deadline to reach new deals with its union pilots and crew as it scrambles to avoid a Chapter 11 filing, Dealscape reported.
General Electric has agreed to sell its Japanese consumer-finance business to Shinsei Bank for 580 billion yen ($5.4 billion), according to reports citing undisclosed sources.

June has been a cruel month for two high-profile hedge funds. New York-based Prentice Capital Management and London-based Tosca Holdings have each suffered steep declines, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Sanofi-Aventis has made a formal $2.02 billion offer to buy the rest of Zentiva, challenging PPF Group's bid for the Czech drugmaker, Bloomberg reported.
Citigroup will sell its German retail business to France's Credit Mutuel for $7.7 billion, it said on Friday, part of a global reorganization of the U.S. bank.

Asian I.P.O.s worth about $20 billion have been shelved this year due to turmoil in the market and bankers are beginning to fear a rush in the second half should conditions improve, The Wall Street Journal reported.

National Australia Bank is in talks with ABN Amro to acquire its Australian and New Zealand wholesale and investment banking businesses in what would be a 1 billion Australian dollar ($962 million) deal, The Financial Times reported.
Shares in Britain's Taylor Wimpey Plc rose as much as 18 percent on a report in Building magazine that it may sell a third of the company to a U.S. private equity investor, Bloomberg News said.
While announcing first-half results, Investor chief executive Börje Ekholm said the company is planning to start acquiring companies within the next six to 18 months, The Financial Times reported.

An auction of restaurant chain Dave & Buster's may not have had enough flavor to continue. The process to sell the Wellspring Capital Management-owned group began early this year, but has been silent for the past several weeks, sources told The Daily Deal.
Italy's UniCredit has named Andreas Bohn, Bernhard Brinker and Piergiorgio Peluso as co-heads of investment banking, Bloomberg reported.

In a sign that there may have been some improvements in credit strains, Wall Street investment firms did not borrow from the Federal Reserve's emergency lending program during the past week while commercial banks scaled back, The Associated Press reported.

One day after reports said that he backed out of the buyout of International Asset Management, Sir Ronald Cohen has bought a stake in Millennium Global, one of London's oldest hedge fund managers, The Financial Times said.

POSCO Engineering & Construction, the construction arm of steel giant POSCO, and Daewoo Capital have each been given a green light for initial public offerings in Seoul that will raise up to $1.48 billion in total, The Financial Times reported.

Timothy Schwertfeger, the longtime Nuveen Investments chief, has left the company, The Chicago Tribune reported. Mr. Schwertfeger sold the investment management firm to Madison Dearborn Partners last year.

Zurich Financial Services has withdrawn from the 7 billion pound ($13.8 billion) auction for Royal Bank of Scotland's insurance assets, The Financial Times reported. The decision raises further questions about whether the bank will be able to divest of the operations.

Britain's Helphire is set to raise $89.1 million through a placing and open offer. The vehicle rental and accident management group has also announced the retirement of chief executive Mark Jackson, The Financial Times reported.

HBO has given the green light to three television pilots: a comedy based on a book about the sexual exploits of a Capitol Hill staffer, a look at post-Katrina New Orleans by the creator of "The Wire," and a drama about Atlantic City in the 1920s.

A photograph showing four Iranian missiles being launched was “apparently digitally altered” by Iranian state media, the news agency Agence France-Presse said Thursday.

CHISHOLM FEICK-Rosemary . Darlings, Ms. Rosemary Chisholm Feick has gone to continue her travels in her hot air balloon up in the sky. She passed away peacefully in the loving arms of her family on July 7th, 2008 at 7:25pm. Ms. Feick is survived by her daughter, Ms. Gayle Boxer Willson, her son, Mr. Brian Boxer (Ms. Jan Boxer), her grandchildren, Mr. Blakeley Willson and Ms. Tiffany Willson. Ms. Feick is also survived by her sister Mrs. Nancy Young, (Mr. David Young) and her brother Mr. Scott Fennell, (Mrs. Cecil Fennell). For the past five years, Ms. Feick lived with her cherished companion, Ms. Francesca Zomoreno Moreno. Ms. Feick was a journalist and lived all over the world. Under the publishing umbrella of Canada's MacLean Hunter and the pen name of Rosemary Boxer, she honed her appreciation of both the written and spoken word. While fashion and beauty editor of Chatelaine Magazine, she hosted two hourly TV shows: one a weekly news broadcast for Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and the other, the first woman's TV afternoon show hosted together with Monty Hall, again for the CBC. In the 60s, she accepted a position in Rome as foreign correspondent for the Toronto Telegram. In the 70s she married Robert Chisholm O.B.E., and wrote under the name of Posy Chisholm. In the 80s her editorial territories enlarged to include all the major cities of the world. This time she was filing for the Toronto Sun as the Assistant Bureau Chief of Rome. During this period she was honored as a Dame of the First Class of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta for her work with Italian orphans. A private family service has taken place. A celebration of her life will be held on September 2nd at two o'clock at the Palais Royale, 1601 Lake Shore Boulevard West, Toronto. In lieu of flowers, gifts should be directed to the Posy Feick Fund in Venice made payable to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, 1071 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128. Services under the direction of Humphrey Funeral Home-A.W. Miles Chapel, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, 1-800-616-3311. Condolences and memories may be forwarded through: www.humphreymiles.com. Posy, as she was known by her family and friends, was larger than life.

'GOING PLACES (DOING STUFF)' Necessity breeds invention. Also, gas is expensive, and everyone loves a road trip. Thus was born ''Going Places (Doing Stuff),'' an artist-led group bus adventure and the newest project from the Flux Factory, an alternative gallery space. Since 2002 the gallery has occupied a former air-conditioning warehouse in Long Island City, Queens. But that building was recently sold, and now Flux Factory is being evicted, said Jean Barberis, a curator there. No future site has been determined. So Mr. Barberis and his team conceived a summer group show that required no space: they asked a half-dozen artists to create trips for visitors to take on a rented school bus. Adventure seekers don't know the destination; they are given only the name of the artist, the tour's title, duration and a list of supplies before they board the bus. ''We think of it as road trip as performance art,'' Mr. Barberis said.

In a surprising reshaping of the urban landscape, the city is creating a public esplanade along a portion of one of its most prominent streets, Broadway in Midtown, setting aside the east side of the roadway for a bicycle lane and a pedestrian walkway with cafe tables, chairs, umbrellas and flower-filled planters. The esplanade, which the city is calling Broadway Boulevard, will run from 42nd Street to Herald Square. Scheduled to open in mid-August, it will change that section of Broadway from a four-lane to a two-lane street.

'IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA' This Rossini favorite is perhaps the opera world's most popular comedy and an inevitable box office hit. But Will Crutchfield, above, director of the Bel Canto at Caramoor series at the Caramoor International Music Festival, says audiences are not presented with music that a Rossinian audience would have heard. ''Il Barbiere'' is the earliest Italian opera to gain a permanent place in the repertory, he says, and thus went through more transformations than most works, with current performance practice owing ''a lot to the way later scores by Donizetti, Verdi and even Puccini influenced its interpreters.'' A new Bärenreiter edition supervised by the Rossini expert Philip Gossett, in which Mr. Crutchfield says ''outright errors in old scores'' are corrected for the first time, will receive its East Coast premiere on Saturday at Caramoor.

TEMPLETON--Sir John Templeton joined the Board of Princeton Theological Seminary in 1951 and served with the utmost faithfulness until being named a trustee emeritus in 1988. He served two terms as board chair bringing quite extraordinary long-sightedness to the vision and sense of purpose of the Seminary. Generous to a fault and utterly disciplined with regard to himself, possessed by hope and drawn forward by belief in the immensity of God's future, John Marks Templeton was the Seminary's greatest benefactor. Much of the security we now enjoy in our endowment may be attributed to his wise counsel and the direction he set for the board. Truly, we thank God for his life and his many gifts. Iain R. Torrance, President Princeton Theological Seminary Princeton, New Jersey

PETER SARKISIAN This artist is best known for projecting videos of naked subjects onto the four sides of Minimalist Plexiglas boxes, with results that are mesmerizing as technology but thin and somewhat maudlin as art. In his current show at I-20, Mr. Sarkisian cuts to the chase. His latest efforts focus on technology's inner workings while more thoroughly integrating video and sculpture to achieve a kind of Pop-Art Precisionism. Mostly illusory, in-camera assemblages, the works consist of contoured, clear plastic reliefs of engines or engine parts set in the wall; details are filled in by rear-screen video projections and include pistons, gears and ball bearings spinning, whirring and clicking at different rates.

ANIMAL ANTICS WEEKEND How do you prepare a delicious meal for a hungry puma? O.K., very carefully. But the Queens Zoo also has more serious suggestions for big-cat cuisine, which it will offer on Saturday and Sunday, when it invites children to become chefs for wild appetites. Part of Animal Antics Weekend, the kitchen detail is a chance to make enrichment treats, intended to stimulate zoo residents' minds and muscles as well as their taste buds. The menu includes stuffed watermelons and ice pops, which sound tempting until you hear the ingredients.

The double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius will resume his bid to qualify for the Olympics on Friday at a Golden Gala in Rome featuring a large cast of standouts honing their form for the Beijing Games. Pistorius needs to meet an Olympic qualifying time of 45.55 seconds in the 400 to make South Africa's relay team for Beijing. Last week in Milan, in his first world-class race against able-bodied runners in nearly a year, he ran 47.78.

There's the social Bernardo's List, the political Emily's List and, of course, the all-practical Craigslist. For New Yorkers this summer, there is the very useful Becca's List -- a compilation of the outdoor free summer movies in the New York City region. Rebecca Shapiro, a 27-year-old editor at Random House, started the list about three years ago and now sends it to 75 or so of her friends and co-workers. Her interest in outdoor movies started during college, when she had summer internships in the city and would go to outdoor movies in Bryant Park.

The police said they had detained four people in an investigation into a shooting on Wednesday at the United States Consulate in Istanbul that left six people dead and two injured. It was unclear what role the detainees may have played in the attack. Besir Atalay, Turkey's interior minister, said the number held could rise as the inquiry expanded. NTV, a private television channel, said Erkan Kargin, 26, one of the gunmen who was killed, belonged to a militant group known as the Islamic Great Eastern Raiders' Front, or IBDA-C. Two other assailants who were killed, the TV report said.

While aggressive evictions are reducing the number of rent-stabilized apartments in New York, Representative Charles B. Rangel is enjoying four of them, including three adjacent units on the 16th floor overlooking Upper Manhattan in a building owned by one of New York's premier real estate developers. Mr. Rangel, the powerful Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, uses his fourth apartment, six floors below, as a campaign office, despite state and city regulations that require rent-stabilized apartments to be used as a primary residence.

SCHAUMBERGER--Norman , born May 28, 1929, died July 10, 2008. Loving and loyal husband to Helene, devoted and caring father to Sari and Ann. The kindest and dearest grandfather to Melissa and Erica. Adoring father-in-law to Steve. We have always loved you and admired your integrity, warmth, and generosity. Your amazing wit and intellect goes unsurpassed and you can leave this earth knowing it is a far better place for having felt your human presence. Norman was a Doctor of Mathematics and Professor Emeritus at CUNY for many years. In addition, he taught at Columbia University, Hofstra, and Cooper Union. He was well loved and revered by all of his students. Dr. Schaumberger was an associate editor of the NYS Math Teachers' Journal and contributed over 350 math proposals and solutions to many periodicals over the years. Norman was a great athlete who loved tennis as well as basketball in his younger years. Norman raised his daughters to believe that women could be on the same playing field as men in all realms of education, especially math and science. Norman's courage was infinite and his tremendous endurance during this difficult period amazed everyone. He fought to the end with bravery and dignity. Helene and Norman were and will forever be the greatest of soul mates. We will miss you and love you always. May you rest in peace our dear and courageous Norman. Your loving family. Funeral service will be at Sinai Chapels in Fresh Meadows, Queens (Horace Harding Expressway) at 11:15am today (Friday.)

FOR CHILDREN 'CINDERELLA' (Saturday) Forget about a wicked stepmother and a pumpkin-turned-coach. At 2 p.m., Chez Bushwick, 304 Boerum Street, (212) 352-3101, youthontarget.org; $15; $10 for 12 and under.

The baboons were walking free at the Bronx Zoo on Wednesday night. The humans were in cages -- trapped in storm-tossed Skyfari gondolas high above the wildlife, the lookers turned into the looked-at, and vice versa. Danica Herbert, one of 37 stranded zoo visitors, did not like the role reversal one bit. Out of one window of Car 44, dreading what lay beneath, she could glimpse the zoo's World of Darkness, home to fruit bats and glowing scorpions. On the other side, she saw grass and trees and the outline of a scurrying animal.

EAST TO EDINBURGH The annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe, which begins on Aug. 3 in Scotland, will include a wide assortment of productions, more than 2,000, some of which may eventually find their way to New York. The recently ended theater season here included several hits from Edinburgh, like the National Theater of Scotland's production of ''Black Watch'' by Gregory Burke; Enda Walsh's dark comedy ''The Walworth Farce''; and James Braly's comic solo show ''Life in a Marital Institution'' (which is running through Aug. 15 at the SoHo Playhouse). Instead of waiting for Fringe shows to come west, 59E59 Theaters is offering, for the fifth year, a chance to see a few of them here first in this festival, which offers a sneak peek at productions bound for Scotland. Among the offerings is ''7 Sins,'' written and performed by James Judd. The show is a comical look at his own life, one that seems reasonable enough in some aspects (he went to law school and practiced as a criminal defense attorney) and completely mad in others (his mother paid him to skip school, watch ''The Young and the Restless'' and later act it out for her). Mr. Judd has told his stories at festivals in the United States and Canada, and, after finishing up here on Sunday, he will head to Washington to perform in the Capital Fringe Festival.

KARP--Irving , beloved father, grandfather, and brother. U.S. WWII Veteran, who participated in liberation of Buchenwald, passed away on Thursday, July 10th, 2008. Funeral will be held Friday, July 11th, 10am at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY.

'DANCE OUT!' New York has a proud tradition of offering outdoor performances of all kinds during the summer, but there is something about watching people dancing outdoors that feels particularly right. (Perhaps it harks back to an atavistic sense of dance as community based, at root a tribal activity.) And on Wednesday the Joyce Theater and the City Parks Foundation introduce ''Dance Out!,'' a free, five-day outdoor festival featuring three works that will be performed throughout the five boroughs. The event is part of the Joyce's 25th-anniversary celebrations, and the theater's director, Linda Shelton, should be congratulated for picking this intriguing bunch of European choreographers, fairly well known across the pond and almost never seen here. Michael Schumacher, an American choreographer who has danced with the Ballet Frankfurt and Pretty Ugly and has worked closely with the theater director Peter Sellars, will perform ''Dans le Jardin,'' an improvised dance set to live music by his frequent collaborator, the cellist Alex Waterman. Dominique Boivin's Compagnie Beau Geste presents a duet for the dancer Philippe Priasso, above, and, ahem, an excavator, all performed to Callas arias. (If this sounds unlikely, bear in mind that Mr. Boivin, a French choreographer who trained with Alwin Nikolais, managed some years ago to condense the history of dance into a funny and pertinent hourlong show, ''Dance, a History My Way.'')
