GRAMMER--Sally . Sally Cranmer Grammer, mother of Kelsey Grammer (1928-2008) passed away peacefully on July 7 at her home, at the Sherwood Country Club in Westlake, California. Mrs. Grammer died of natural causes. She was preceded in death by her daughter Karen Grammer (1975) and her husband Frank Allen Grammer, Jr. who was killed in 1968. Following the tragic death of her daughter, Mrs. Grammer endured the past 33 years with grace and laughter in spite of a broken heart. Grammer was a four time president of Tarzana Women's Republican Club. She was president of the organization at the time of her death. She was also a member of the Sherwood Country Club and the Kiwanis Club. She is survived by her son Kelsey and his wife Camille, and three grandchildren, Spencer, Mason and Jude. According to her son Kelsey ''I was proud to be the son of Sally Grammer. I will miss her laughter.'' Grammer, who was a dancer and actress, performed under the name of Sally Sullivan. She was educated at Valedean, a private girl's prep school in New Jersey, before continuing her education at the David Mannes School of Music in Manhattan. She met her husband at the school. Her father, Gordon Savage Cranmer, was a retired colonel in the Untied States Army and a former executive with Chevron Oil in New York. Her mother, Evangeline Dimick Cranmer, was a Roaring 20s Flapper. Funeral services are pending.

TSAI--Gerald . The Board of Directors of Triarc Companies, Inc. extends its sincere and heartfelt condolences to the family of Gerald Tsai, Jr. on his passing on July 9, 2008. He was a dear friend and a valuable member of our Board and its predecessors since 1986. He will be greatly missed. Nelson Peltz, Chairman Peter W. May, Vice Chairman TSAI--Gerald, loving friend of 57 years, consummate gentleman, brilliant businessman. You will be greatly missed. My deepest sympathies to your children and grandchildren. Robert Weltz, 415 Hot Springs Road., Montecito, CA TSAI--Jerry. Jerry was a major influence in my life. In 1967, I asked him what firm I could go to so that I would be paid an equal salary to what men were being paid. He first said don't be ridiculous, and then advised me to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange and work for myself. On December 28, 2007, he joined me on the podium as I rang the ''Closing Bell'' at the NYSE in celebration of my 40th anniversary. Jerry gave me this brilliant idea, and I have always given him the credit for being the Inspiration behind my success. I will miss Jerry -he was a unique and very special person. Muriel ''Mickie'' Siebert TSAI--Gerald, Jr., 79, resident of Manhattan and Rye, NY, died peacefully July 9, 2008. Beloved father of Christopher and Veronica. Caring grandfather of Vanessa O'Brien. Jerry was an enormously talented and successful businessman, serving as a Chairman, President and Chief Executive officer of several large publicly traded companies. He was known as a highly gifted analytical problem solver and a skilled negotiator. His understanding of the capital markets was unparalleled, recognizing opportunities where others saw confusion. Jerry was born in Shanghai, China, on March 10, 1929, and attended St. John's Middle School and St. John's University. He came to the United States in 1947 and, after one semester at Wesleyan University, transferred to Boston University, where he earned both a Bachelor of Arts in Economics from the College of Liberal Arts and a Master of Arts in Economics from the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences in 1949. In addition, Jerry attended courses at the School of Management. Jerry began his distinguished investment career in 1951 as a security analyst at Bache & Company. A year later, he joined the Boston firm of Fidelity Management and Research Company, Inc., as a security analyst. After only six years, at the age of 29, he started the Fidelity Capital Fund, Fidelity's first public growth fund. He has been credited as one of the main initiators of the modern performance fund idea. At Fidelity he rapidly rose through the corporate ranks, ascending to Assistant Vice President of Fidelity Fund, Inc., to Vice President, to director and Executive Vice President of the company in 1963. In 1965, Jerry established the Tsai Management & Research Corporation and Manhattan Fund, which proved to be a huge success. The initial offering was planned for $25 million but the public's response was so enthusiastic that the fund was greatly oversubscribed and $247 million in shares were sold. He joined CNA Financial Corp in 1967 as President and served until 1973. Jerry was also Chairman of Associated Madison Companies, lnc., the cornerstone of Primerica's financial services business, He joined Primerica Corporation, then American Can Company, as Executive Vice President of financial services and as a member of the company's Board of Directors in 1982, when the company acquired Associated Madison in its first move into the financial services industry. He rose to Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, becoming the first ChineseAmerican to lead a company in the Dow Jones Industrials Index. He became the principal strategist in building Primerica's financial services businesses, which included the purchase of Smith Barney in 1987. Jerry was a devoted son, and regularly sought out his mother's advice before making a major business decision. For instance, Ruth encouraged him to join Primerica, despite his reservations, and then backed his idea of acquiring Smith Barney. He often said that her faith in him have gave him the confidence to succeed. From 1993 to 1997, he served as Chairman, President, and Chief Executive Officer of Delta Life Corporation, a life insurance; and annuity company. Jerry also served on the boards of several companies, including United Rentals, lnc., Sequa Corp., Zenith National Insurance Corp., Triarc Companies, Inc. Apollo Investment Corp., and Saks Inc. In addition to his business successes Jerry was a highly distinguished member of the community serving on a variety of philanthropic boards including the Boston University Board of Trustees and the Norton Museum of Art Board of Trustees. He also served as a trustee of the New York University Medical Center and School of Medicine Foundation Board. He was a member of the Board of Overseers of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. Jerry has been honored for his philanthropic and humanitarian work, receiving a Doctor of Humane Letters from Boston University in 2003. He received the Man of the Year Award from the Chinatown Planning Council of New York and the Boston University Alumni Award for Distinguished Public Service to the Profession in 1985. Jerry was an Associate Founder of Boston University, and served on the Board of Trustees for many years. He was a trustee emeritus at the time of his death. Funeral services will be held Saturday, July 12, 5pm, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY.

The tasters, young and old, lined up outside the American Museum of Natural History on Thursday at 10 a.m. They sipped the waters, swooshing the liquid in their mouths, sometimes spitting it out. The five competitors in the 2008 Regional Water Tasting contest came out of taps in Nassau, Orange, Suffolk and Westchester Counties, and New York City, where the tap water is praised by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as ''the best water in the world.'' Two winners would be selected to join the winners from four other regional contests at the state fair.

The actor Kevin Spacey plays a political operative in the HBO movie ''Recount'' and is a member-in-good-standing of Friends of Bill, having traveled with former President Bill Clinton to South Africa. But one political event Mr. Spacey will not be attending is the Democratic Convention Summit, the invitation-only for-profit conference sponsored by Nancy Jacobson, a Democratic fund-raiser and the wife of the pollster Mark Penn. The conference, during the party's August convention in Denver, costs $10,000 to attend, and Ms. Jacobson is soliciting attendees among deep-pocketed Democrats. In sending out a draft conference agenda as part of her invitation, Ms. Jacobson said Mr. Spacey, along with the actress Laura Dern, would be holding a discussion on their movie, which chronicles the 2000 Florida recount.

My Sunday column is about the work of Greg Mortenson, a Montanan who went seamlessly from climbing mountains in the Himalayas to building schools in remote areas of Pakistan and Afghanistan. He makes a fine counterpoint to American policy in Pakistan, which has been to shower billions of dollars worth of military aid on President Musharraf, without doing much to support education. Supporting Musharraf and bribing him (in effect) to seek a military solution in the Tribal Areas has been a failure; the Tribal Areas are more radicalized than ever, anti-American sentiment has grown throughout Pakistan, and the militants are now threatening Peshawar, a major city of 3 million in northwestern Pakistan.

Chad Dawson will surrender the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title rather than face a title showdown with Adrian Diaconu of Romania, the W.B.C. announced. Each fighter is unbeaten. Dawson’s decision to vacate the crown came after representatives of the two fighters took part in a purse bid for promotion rights to the fight and Diaconu’s side won the bidding.

The Nets reached agreements with the free-agent forwards Eduardo Najera and Jarvis Hayes. Najera, an eight-year N.B.A. veteran, averaged 5.9 points and 4.3 rebounds in 78 games last season for Denver. Hayes played in 82 games for Detroit last season and averaged 6.7 points and 2.2 rebounds.

Ken Stabler, the former N.F.L. quarterback and current Alabama football radio color analyst, has been granted a leave of absence for the coming season after his arrest on a drunken driving charge in June. His arrest in south Alabama was at least the third time he has been charged with D.U.I. Stabler, the Tide’s color analyst for 10 years, will be replaced by Tom Roberts.

The Lightning won two Southeastern Division titles and made the playoffs four times in Feaster’s five full seasons as general manager. Six major film studios have agreed to include antismoking public service announcements produced by the California Health and Human Services Agency in the DVD releases of all new movies rated G, PG or PG-13. The move was announced Friday by the Entertainment Industry Foundation, a nonprofit group that has been working to reduce the presence of tobacco on screen and on film sets. The new plan stops short of steps that have been requested by some antismoking groups. One proposal that the studios have resisted is to put an automatic R rating on any film that depicts smoking. Paramount Pictures, Sony Pictures Entertainment, 20th Century Fox, Universal Pictures, the Walt Disney Company and Warner Brothers, all members of the Motion Picture Association of America, joined in the agreement. In a statement, Dan Glickman, the association’s chief executive, said the industry’s approach was to inform parents “about smoking depictions in films so they can make informed decisions.”.

Culture will have a place in connection with China’s grandiose packaging of the Beijing Olympics. Cultural officials said the National Center for the Performing Arts, above, would play host to the Olympic Centenary Piano Extravaganza of China on Aug. 19. Ten pianists will perform, then join for a concerto newly composed by Cui Shiguan, accompanied by the Beijing National Symphony Orchestra, said Lin Hong, the event’s coordinator. He said six Western pianists had been invited: Claude Frank, Philippe Entremont, Louis Lortie, Vladimir Feltsman, Cyprien Katsaris and Guillermo Gonzalez. The other four are Chinese: Lang Lang, Sa Chen, Liu Shikun and Qin Yunyi.

Ending a yearlong experiment, the Seattle Symphony is cutting its concertmaster contingent to one from four. The orchestra said it named Maria Larionoff to the position after the players’ union objected to multiple leaders. Last summer the orchestra’s music director, Gerard Schwarz, named a quartet of violinists, including Ms. Larionoff, to share the post, saying “it doesn’t make sense” to have one person, given the length of the season. On Friday Mr. Schwarz called the arrangement a “tremendous artistic success” but said Ms. Larionoff, the associate concertmaster since 1997, would take over. “The way she has embraced this new position speaks volumes about her remarkable talent and ability to lead the orchestra,” he said. Tom Philion, the executive director, said the other three players — Ani Kavafian, Emmanuelle Boisvert and Frank Almond — would continue to appear with the orchestra. Michael Crusoe, the leader of the union, said it had protested the four-concertmaster arrangement as a contract violation. Mr. Philion said the appointment, which was part of a deal reached with the union, would address their concerns.

A 17th-century Shakespeare volume valued at $30 million, stolen from a university a decade ago, has been recovered, The Associated Press reported. On Tuesday police officers in England arrested a man in connection with the theft. The arrest followed an incident two weeks ago when a man brought the book, a First Folio from 1623, the first collection of Shakespeare’s plays, to the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington to have it authenticated. Members of the library staff alerted the F.B.I. The volume had been taken in 1998 from the Durham University library, along with six other works. It remains at the Folger, but plans are being made to return it.

Six months after reaching a similar agreement with Italy, the New York collector Shelby White, right, will hand over two antiquities to Greece that the Greek government says were illegally excavated and exported from the country. In a statement on Friday, the Greek Culture Ministry and a spokesman for Ms. White said she had acquired the objects in good faith. The antiquities will be transported to Greece this month and exhibited at the National Archaeological Museum in Athens before being sent to museums in the regions from which they are thought to have been taken. One object is the upper part of a grave marker dating from the early part of the fourth century B.C. The lower part was found in the early 1960s in a legal excavation in Porto Rafti in Attica and is currently in the Vravrona Archaeological Museum. The two parts will be exhibited together. The other object is a bronze calyx krater dating from around 340 B.C. that Greek archaeologists say was probably found in illegal excavations of a royal tomb. Countries like Greece and Italy have waged an aggressive campaign in recent years to recover artifacts from museums and private collectors that they contend were looted. Ms. White agreed in January to return 10 classical antiquities to Italy.

“Greatest American Dog,” a new reality show on CBS, got off to a decent start on Thursday, leading most competitors with 9.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although that was less than CBS’s repeat of “CSI” at 9 p.m. (9.8 million), it was enough to compensate for the network’s low ratings at 10 with “Swingtown” (5.4 million). CBS averaged the most viewers but trailed Fox in the 18-to-49 demographic. Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance” led the night in that group, even as it drew a more modest audience at 9 of 8.7 million total viewers. Fox’s “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” drew 7 million viewers but nearly overtook CBS’s dog show to lead the 8 p.m. slot among the 18-to-49 set. NBC was third for the night, as “Last Comic Standing” garnered 5 million viewers from 9 to 11. ABC lagged behind in fourth, with repeats early in the night followed by “Hopkins” at 10 (5.5 million).

HBO is working with Warner Brothers to develop a sequel to the “Sex and the City” movie. “There is enormous interest” on the part of Warner Brothers, Michael Lombardo, president of the HBO programming group, told reporters at the Television Critics Association press tour. Since its release, “Sex and the City” has taken in more than $145 million in the United States. Also on Thursday, HBO said it had approved three television pilots. The first, a comedy, was inspired by “The Washingtonienne,” a novel by Jessica Cutler, who wrote a blog about her sexual exploits when she was an assistant to former Senator Mike DeWine of Ohio. Sarah Jessica Parker, above, is the executive producer of the half-hour pilot. The second, “Treme,” a drama set in New Orleans, was written by David Simon, creator of “The Wire.” Martin Scorsese will be the executive producer of the third, a drama set in Atlantic City in the 1920s.

Republicans have gone into high dudgeon over Senator Barack Obama's suggestion at a town-hall-style meeting this week in Georgia that Americans might profitably emulate the European dexterity with language. (Many Europeans speak more than one foreign language, while Americans tend to know none, aucun, ningunos.) ''You know, it's embarrassing when Europeans come over here, they all speak English, they speak French, they speak German. And then we go over to Europe and all we can say is 'merci beaucoup,' '' Mr. Obama said to laughter from the crowd.

Ten years ago the Japanese rock band Boris made a record called ''Amplifier Worship.'' Some much less serious band was bound to come up with that title, so it was good that Boris claimed it first, as a perfect two-word poem of intent. This band deals out volume in striated, fuzzed-out clouds; there's a lot going on in there, if you can take it. And it transmits a feeling of transparency and piety toward its sources. On Thursday night at Webster Hall, Boris was often a vessel, seemingly transmitting some other band or performer -- Blue Cheer, Keiji Haino, the Melvins. The show could be taken as sweet, abrasive, studious, solemn, weird, a greasy gift for the senses: all those things and possibly none. In the end, well-handled, nearly unbearable volume was the show's ultimate meaning, its deep agenda.

Terrible Towels are waving at half-staff today. It was only Wednesday when Senator John McCain was talking about how Pittsburgh's beloved Steelers helped him get through his years in a North Vietnamese prison. ''When I was first interrogated and really had to give some information because of the physical pressures that were on me, I named the starting lineup -- defensive line -- of the Pittsburgh Steelers as my squadron-mates,'' he told KDKA-TV in Pittsburgh, a city filled with the white, working-class voters who could be up for grabs in November (many of whom also happen to be diehard football fans).

It seemed like just yesterday that President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela was calling President Álvaro Uribe of Colombia a ''pawn of the American empire'' and comparing him to Don Vito Corleone, with Mr. Uribe lashing back by threatening to sue Mr. Chávez for the ''financing of genocidists.'' But the name-calling was put aside Friday when the two leaders met in Venezuela, trying to mend relations after months of bickering over issues that included Colombia's claims that Mr. Chávez tried to finance leftist guerrillas and Venezuela's ire over the possible transfer of an American military base to Colombia from Ecuador.

BORKAN--Florence , of New Vernon, NJ died on Thursday, July 10th after a long difficult battle. Surviving her is her husband, Lionel, her children, Marjorie Hersch (Daryl) and James Borkan (Barbara) and grandchildren, Leah and Zachary. She was predeceased by two daughters, Amy Ellen Freedman and Sharai May Freedman and her brothers, Robert and Harold Cohen. She was born and educated in Boston, having completed her university education there. She was Vice President in a pharmaceutical manufacturing company and was considered a visionary, creating products in the dietary supplement market. Many of these products exist presently. An elegant lady with much dignity and grace but humble and down to earth in her relationships and functions. She touched many lives and was loved by many. She impacted many who were fortunate to know her. She will be tremendously missed by those who loved her. Funeral services will be held at Bernheim, Apter and Krietzman in Livington, NJ on Sunday, 11:30am. Donations in her memory can be made to The Amy and Sharai Freedman Memorial Fund c/o McGill University, Montreal or Mass. General Hospital, Boston, MA.

A picture caption last Saturday with a television review of ''Coming Home: When Parents Return From War'' on Nickelodeon, using information provided by the production company, misidentified the rank of an Army officer shown with his daughter. The officer, John K. Russell, known as Ken, is a lieutenant colonel, not a lieutenant.

Paradigm, the group formed 10 years ago by Gus Solomons Jr. with Carmen deLavallade and Dudley Williams, has always seemed like a good idea on paper. But this company, created for and by older dancers, hasn't always produced work equal to the talent. In the troupe's latest program, presented on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop as part of the SummerDANZ series, Paradigm began with a bang: Kay Cummings's ''Stayin' Alive,'' set to the Bee Gees' disco hit of the same title. Mr. Solomons, Valda Setterfield and Mr. Williams, wearing hospital gowns and pushing IV stands, took shaky sideway steps across the stage. Occasionally pointing a tired finger in the style of John Travolta or flashing a manic grin, the dancers, notably the hilarious Ms. Setterfield, sparkled like vaudeville stars.

An article on Wednesday about David Wroblewski, author of the novel ''The Story of Edgar Sawtelle,'' about a mute Wisconsin boy's extraordinary communion with his dogs, misidentified the town in Wisconsin where Mr. Wroblewski's parents ran a kennel when he was a child. It was Pittsville, in central Wisconsin -- not Oconomowoc, where Mr. Wroblewski was born. The article also misidentified the region of the state in which Oconomowoc is located. It is in southern Wisconsin, not northern.

''Foyle's War,'' the British drama commissioned by the ITV network to fill the void created by the departing ''Inspector Morse'' eight years ago, has lasted as long as the Second World War itself, the setting for the show's crime solving, but the tenure has hardly bred fatigue. The sixth season, which was seen in England earlier this year (and begins on Sunday on PBS as part of ''Masterpiece Mystery!''), had been slated as the last, but fans apparently refused to think in funereal terms, and the series's creator, Anthony Horowitz, has since discussed charging on. ''Foyle's War'' is exacting in its period details and outstanding in its personalization of political disturbance and fury. At the center is Detective Christopher Foyle (Michael Kitchen), shut out of the action on the front lines and sent to Hastings on the south coast of England to counter war's residual malfeasance: the murder, bribery and wretchedness committed by profiteers, the politically ambitious and, nearly as often, those whose psychological balance war has irreparably destabilized.

Thanks to a rise in Amazon rankings, a revamped lawsuit and an ''Oprah'' rerun, the debate over ''vegetable plagiarism'' has entered Round 2. ''Deceptively Delicious,'' the cookbook by Jessica Seinfeld whose recipes for concealing puréed vegetables in comfort food for children bore such similarities to another cookbook's that it inspired a lawsuit from that book's author, shot to the top of the Amazon best-seller list on Wednesday, nine months after it was published.

FEICK--Rosemary (Posy) . Dearest friend, fellow ''funster'' and trusted guide along life's bumpy highway; widow of my friend of 41 years and mentor in business, Bill Feick. She infused life, light and joy into his life and into the lives of all with whom she came in contact, illuminating any corner shadowed by difficulty. She was forever the enduring, endlessly generous spirit that, last Monday evening, took new form to continue to serve those she loved. Count on it! My heart goes out to Nancy, David, Gayle, Brian and Jan and her grandchildren Blakeley and ''Tiff'' whom she so adored. Bedtime in heaven has now been extended to 4:00am! Love ya Starshine. You and Bill take Veronica to the karaoke clubs. Jack Kehoe

TSAI--Gerald , loving friend of 57 years, consummate gentleman, brilliant businessman. You will be greatly missed. My deepest sympathies to your children and grandchildren. Robert Weltz, 415 Hot Springs Road., Montecito, CA TSAI--Gerald, Jr., 79, resident of Manhattan and Rye, NY, died peacefully July 9, 2008. Beloved father of Christopher and Veronica. Caring grandfather of Vanessa O'Brien. Jerry was an enormously talented and successful businessman, serving as a Chairman, President and Chief Executive officer of several large publicly traded companies. He was known as a highly gifted analytical problem solver and a skilled negotiator. His understanding of the capital markets was unparalleled, recognizing opportunities where others saw confusion. Jerry was born in Shanghai, China, on March 10, 1929, and attended St. John's Middle School and St. John's University. He came to the United States in 1947 and, after one semester at Wesleyan University, transferred to Boston University, where he earned both a Bachelor of Arts in Economics from the College of Liberal Arts and a Master of Arts in Economics from the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences in 1949. In addition, Jerry attended courses at the School of Management. Jerry began his distinguished investment career in 1951 as a security analyst at Bache & Company. A year later, he joined the Boston firm of Fidelity Management and Research Company, Inc., as a security analyst. After only six years, at the age of 29, he started the Fidelity Capital Fund, Fidelity's first public growth fund. He has been credited as one of the main initiators of the modern performance fund idea. At Fidelity he rapidly rose through the corporate ranks, ascending to Assistant Vice President of Fidelity Fund, Inc., to Vice President, to director and Executive Vice President of the company in 1963. In 1965, Jerry established the Tsai Management & Research Corporation and Manhattan Fund, which proved to be a huge success. The initial offering was planned for $25 million but the public's response was so enthusiastic that the fund was greatly oversubscribed and $247 million in shares were sold. He joined CNA Financial Corp in 1967 as President and served until 1973. Jerry was also Chairman of Associated Madison Companies, lnc., the cornerstone of Primerica's financial services business, He joined Primerica Corporation, then American Can Company, as Executive Vice President of financial services and as a member of the company's Board of Directors in 1982, when the company acquired Associated Madison in its first move into the financial services industry. He rose to Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, becoming the first ChineseAmerican to lead a company in the Dow Jones Industrials Index. He became the principal strategist in building Primerica's financial services businesses, which included the purchase of Smith Barney in 1987. Jerry was a devoted son, and regularly sought out his mother's advice before making a major business decision. For instance, Ruth encouraged him to join Primerica, despite his reservations, and then backed his idea of acquiring Smith Barney. He often said that her faith in him have gave him the confidence to succeed. From 1993 to 1997, he served as Chairman, President, and Chief Executive Officer of Delta Life Corporation, a life insurance; and annuity company. Jerry also served on the boards of several companies, including United Rentals, lnc., Sequa Corp., Zenith National Insurance Corp., Triarc Companies, Inc. Apollo Investment Corp., and Saks Inc. In addition to his business successes Jerry was a highly distinguished member of the community serving on a variety of philanthropic boards including the Boston University Board of Trustees and the Norton Museum of Art Board of Trustees. He also served as a trustee of the New York University Medical Center and School of Medicine Foundation Board. He was a member of the Board of Overseers of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. Jerry has been honored for his philanthropic and humanitarian work, receiving a Doctor of Humane Letters from Boston University in 2003. He received the Man of the Year Award from the Chinatown Planning Council of New York and the Boston University Alumni Award for Distinguished Public Service to the Profession in 1985. Jerry was an Associate Founder of Boston University, and served on the Board of Trustees for many years. He was a trustee emeritus at the time of his death. Funeral services will be held Saturday, July 12, 5pm, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY. TSAI--Jerry. Jerry was a major influence in my life. In 1967, I asked him what firm I could go to so that I would be paid an equal salary to what men were being paid. He first said don't be ridiculous, and then advised me to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange and work for myself. On December 28, 2007, he joined me on the podium as I rang the ''Closing Bell'' at the NYSE in celebration of my 40th anniversary. Jerry gave me this brilliant idea, and I have always given him the credit for being the Inspiration behind my success. I will miss Jerry -he was a unique and very special person. Muriel ''Mickie'' Siebert TSAI--Gerald. To a very very special friend and a wonderful man who did more for his friends than himself. Gerald Tsai will be greatly missed. Fondly, Elaine Sargent TSAI--Gerald Jr. Dear Jerry, we miss our Sunday night diners and will think of you then, especially hearing of your deep respect, love and admiration for your mother. Marilyn and Bob TSAI--Gerald, Jr., 79. The Board of Directors of Apollo Investment Corporation offers its deepest and heartfelt condolences to the family of Gerald Tsai, Jr. on his recent passing. He was a beloved friend and a valuable member of our Board since its inception. He will be greatly missed. John Hannan, Chairman TSAI--Gerald Jr. The family of the late Norman E. Alexander remembers the long friendship between two extraordinary men. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. The Family of the late Norman E. Alexander

A picture caption last Saturday with a television review of ''Coming Home: When Parents Return From War'' on Nickelodeon, using information provided by the production company, misidentified the rank of an Army officer shown with his daughter. The officer, John K. Russell, known as Ken, is a lieutenant colonel, not a lieutenant.

Ending a yearlong experiment, the Seattle Symphony is cutting its concertmaster contingent to one from four. The orchestra said it named Maria Larionoff to the position after the players' union objected to multiple leaders. Last summer the orchestra's music director, Gerard Schwarz, named a quartet of violinists, including Ms. Larionoff, to share the post, saying ''it doesn't make sense'' to have one person, given the length of the season. On Friday Mr. Schwarz called the arrangement a ''tremendous artistic success'' but said Ms. Larionoff, the associate concertmaster since 1997, would take over. ''The way she has embraced this new position speaks volumes about her remarkable talent and ability to lead the orchestra,'' he said. Tom Philion, the executive director, said the other three players -- Ani Kavafian, Emmanuelle Boisvert and Frank Almond -- would continue to appear with the orchestra. Michael Crusoe, the leader of the union, said it had protested the four-concertmaster arrangement as a contract violation. Mr. Philion said the appointment, which was part of a deal reached with the union, would address their concerns.

McCRINDLE--Joseph F . We mourn the passing of our friend and colleague even as we take comfort in the joy and fullness of his life. Joe had been an active member of the Board of Trustees since 1986. His uncommon generosity was a natural outgrowth of his interest in encouraging young talent and applauding its achievement on the stage of Carnegie Hall. Joe exuded a passion for all things artistic, eager to help them grow and flourish. His courtly demeanor accented by a wry humor were the grace notes of a life richly touched by a deep humanity. We shall miss him. Board of Trustees New York Youth Symphony Leslie J. Garfield, Chair A. Slade Mills, Jr., Pres. Barry Goldberg, Executive Director

LONDON, July 11 -- I am writing from London where I am attending the Ninth International Milton Symposium which also marks John Milton's quatercentenary. (He was born December 9, 1608, and died in 1674.) In a sense it's just a big birthday party for a big birthday, although none of us is likely be honored by a party at which some 200 people from all around the world give papers celebrating our achievements, either during our lifetimes or after we have been dead for centuries.

Listening to talk radio while driving up I-95 after watching the Phillies lose to the Diamondbacks yesterday was a reminder of what a long season it can be. Even after losing, the Phillies were a half-game ahead of a Mets team that had just won eight in a row. And it has only been a few months since the Phillies stormed past the Mets in the final week of last season.

In a roundabout way, this little run by the Mets' pitching staff reminds me of their former manager Willie Randolph. Whenever something a little unique, a little out of the ordinary would happen, Randolph would inevitably respond to a question on the matter by saying that he had seen it before. Usually, he had. But others, he hadn't. So I'm only left to wonder what he might have said after Saturday's game, when the Mets did something that no other team -- repeat: no other team -- has done in the modern baseball era, since 1900, by allowing three or fewer hits in five consecutive games.

To the Editor: Regarding “Hidden Gardens of Paris” (June 29): Is there a more gifted, knowledgeable writer than Elaine Sciolino on the hidden splendors of Paris? Last year (October 2007) she led us on a tour of Paris’s lesser-known churches. Now, it is Paris’s hidden gardens. Thanks to Ms. Sciolino, I discovered in May, among the many churchly treasures she identified, the icons and the living tree trunk in St. Seraphin-de-Sarov. Now I can’t wait to return to Paris to see the otter surface in the pond of the Jardin de la Vallée Suisse. Merci encore, Ms. Sciolino. Peter Stamelman.

To the Editor: In “Unrest in India’s Hill Country” (June 29), Somini Sengupta describes a tourism industry crippled by ethnic conflict between Nepalis and Bengalis. As a cultural anthropologist working in Darjeeling, I believe that it is too simplistic to say that the current agitation “represents a resurrection of old grievances” and to quote from a work of fiction, Kiran Desai’s “The Inheritance of Loss,” to describe reality.

BALTER--Leslie M . Les Balter was an entrepreneurial and successful businessman who enjoyed the good things in life: sailing, fishing, convertibles, a dry martini and Seinfeld. He inspired everyone he met with his optimism and spirit of adventure. He had unflagging curiosity, was passionate about his projects, and liked to advise others about how to achieve their goals, especially in the area of business. Born and raised in the Bronx, Les was a graduate of Townsend Harris H.S. and Columbia School of Engineering. A lifelong ham radio enthusiast (W2HRT), he was involved in the early days of FM radio. During World War II he worked on tank and vehicular communications for the Army Signal Corps while in England. He started Jersey City Technical Institute, followed by the Plaza School in Paramus. A longtime resident of Ramsey, NJ, he had recently relocated to Deerfield Beach, FL, where he passed away peacefully on July 2nd at age 88, with many projects in the works. Survived by devoted daughter Sheila, brother Stanley, sister Lynn, in-laws Jean and Ted, and extended family. Predeceased by wife Gladys, mother of Sheila and the late Kenneth, and wife Frances. A memorial will be held on August 10th in Ridgewood. If desired, donations in his memory to WNYC radio, or the American Heart Association. He will be missed.

TORNEK--Allen Vernon, 91, of Aventura, FL, passed away on July 1, 2008. Allen could start a conversation with anyone. He was just a friendly guy. This quality served him well throughout his 91 plus year life, and who knows, is probably doing him some good now. His business career was successful and in mid 1960s included the development of the Tornek/Rayville dive watch for the U.S. Government, which has become an international collectors item with several websites devoted to it. As the sole U.S. Sales representative for Blancpain Watches he supplied nationally known companies from Lucien Piccard to Tiffany & Company. He had a solid reputation in the industry as an honest and innovative man. Allen Tornek was an honest, respected, and congenial man; a devoted Son, Brother, Father and a loving Husband. The world is a little less blessed and friendly place without him. He is survived by his loving wife Gertrude, sons Larry and Terry, grandchildren Scott, Beth, Joshua, Jessica, and Rachel, and great-grandchildren Benjamin, Carmela, Sydney, Matthew, Annabella, Samuel, Kaely, Giannina and Sylvia. For complete obituary, visit www.legacy.com.

OUTPOSTS For every death on Mount McKinley, about 500 people will make the summit. An 11-year-old boy and a 76-year-old man -- the youngest and oldest summiteers -- have looked out from that glorious place in the Alaska Range where you run out of earth. Death can come from crossing the street, or eating a tomato. My first literary agent, a wonderful woman with a full life ahead of her, was killed by a bus in Manhattan. Why not experience the heightened sense of living that comes from getting closer to the edge -- controlled risk, in the mountains or on a wild river? So goes my internal palaver whenever I think of what happened on Denali. The other side of the argument is about loved ones, the people who are left behind.

FEICK--Rosemary (Posy) . Dearest friend, fellow ''funster'' and trusted guide along life's bumpy highway; widow of my friend of 41 years and mentor in business, Bill Feick. She infused life, light and joy into his life and into the lives of all with whom she came in contact, illuminating any corner shadowed by difficulty. She was forever the enduring, endlessly generous spirit that, last Monday evening, took new form to continue to serve those she loved. Count on it! My heart goes out to Nancy, David, Gayle, Brian and Jan and her grandchildren Blakeley and ''Tiff'' whom she so adored. Bedtime in heaven has now been extended to 4:00am! Love ya Starshine. You and Bill take Veronica to the karaoke clubs. Jack Kehoe

METCALF--Teresa Peabody , 84, of Peterborough, NH, died on July 11, 2008, at Monadnock Community Hospital. She moved to Peterborough in 1976 from Rumson, New Jersey. Mrs. Metcalf was born on October 5, 1923, in New York City, the daughter of Mary Cunningham (Bishop) and John D. Peabody. She attended Radcliffe College and was a member of the Colony Club in New York City. She was an avid tennis player and a former member of the Seabright Lawn, Tennis, and Cricket Club. She enjoyed sailing and summered for many years on Merchants Island, Maine. She is survived by her devoted and loving husband, Manton B. Metcalf III; her daughters, Teresa D. Metcalf of New York City and Elizabeth B. Metcalf-Perez of Hood River, Oregon; her son, John P. Metcalf, of Ridgway, Colorado; four grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. She was predeceased by a son, Manton B. Metcalf IV and a daughter, Mary Metcalf-Deault. The funeral will be held at 12:00 Noon, on Wednesday, July 16, at All Saints Parish, 51 Concord Street, Peterborough, New Hampshire. Reverend Adrian Robbins-Cole, Rector, will officiate. Flowers may be sent, or memorial gifts in her memory may be made to the Island Heritage Trust, PO Box 42, Deer Island, Maine 04627. Jellison Funeral Home, Peterborough, New Hampshire, is assisting the family with the services.

WHILE much ado was being made over the sheer dress Kate Moss wore in Istanbul this summer (devout Muslims didn't find it so chic), it was her enormous gypsy earrings that caught our attention. After seasons of breastplate necklaces, chunky cocktail rings and bangles stacked up the arm, statement earrings were due a fashion moment. Alber Elbaz accessorized his jewel-tone dresses at Lanvin with jangly earrings and slicked-back hair. And Miuccia Prada showed huge crystal ones in her resort collection. But leave it to La Moss, who has since worn them around London, right, to initiate a trend. She certainly put see-through dresses on the map. Erickson Beamon earrings, $393 at Curve; (212) 966-3626.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

WHEN Suzy Kline, a grandmother of five and author of the ''Horrible Harry'' series, visits with her young fans at elementary schools, she takes along a notebook because she never knows where Harry, her third-grade rabble-rouser, might find his next adventure. At the Riverview Elementary School in Denville last year, it was in the gym. While watching children climb a rope, she was inspired to write ''Horrible Harry and the Valentine Rope,'' to be published by Penguin next year as the latest in the 22-book series, which has sold more than four million copies.

BOWMAN--Michael Edward, Jr. , known as ''Bo,'' died suddenly at age 39 on July 9, 2008 at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City. He is survived by his beloved partner, Andy Wilcox; his loving mother Joan Cowen Bowman and siblings Jonathan Bowman, Derrik (and Margie Pivar) Hoitsma, Jim Hoitsma (and Pam Callander), Lisa (and Attilio) Hoitsma Favorini, and Teke (and Kristie Ramirez) Hoitsma; adored nephews and nieces Jasper and Sheyna Hoitsma, Jovi Federici, Cruz and Pilar Hoitsma, Sam, Katy and Molly Fulton; aunts and uncles Jim and Katie Peterson, Roberta Bell, Sue Porter and Constance Cowen; many cherished cousins and friends. He was predeceased by his father, Michael Edward Bowman, Sr., and uncle Edwin A. Cowen, Jr. Bo graduated from Trinity-Pawling School in 1986; attended Vassar College and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1993. He was employed by MAC Cosmetics and also worked as a freelance make-up artist in the metropolitan area. Bo will always be remembered for his wacky sense of humor, unique interpretive dancing, ebullient writing and rampant creativity. His greatest gift was making everyone with whom he came into contact feel special. Bo was the kindest, most adorable, fun-loving, creative, loving man who has ever graced Manhattan (and Brooklyn). We have lost our spark. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to MAC AIDS Fund, 130 Prince St., New York, NY 10012. A celebration of his life will take place on August 23rd in Manhattan. Time and place to be announced.

HOWE--Edith Ingraham Crary , a wonderful daughter, mother, sister, friend and inspiration for many, passed away peacefully on Sunday, July 6th, 2008 at her home in Cambridge, MA from breast cancer. She was 61 years old. Edie received her B.A. at Simmons College, her Ed.M. at Boston University and her J.D. from Northeastern University School of Law in 1983. She served as General Counsel in the Executive Office of Human Services in the Dukakis administration, and was a trust and estate attorney at Palmer & Dodge LLP. After many years as a lawyer, Edie enrolled in theological studies where her passion for interfaith dialogue helped spark joint initiatives between seminary and rabbinical students at Andover Newton Theological School and Hebrew College. After the events of 9/11 Edie felt called to do something to mitigate the misunderstanding and fear between Jews, Christians, and Muslims. This prompted her to form a woman's interfaith book group called the Daughters of Abraham, which has now become a national movement with groups all over the country. Edie was also a trustee of the American University in Cairo, and a board member and former co-chair for Massachusetts Advocate for Children. Plans are being made for a service at Andover Newton Theological School in the fall, to honor her life and work. Contributions may be made to: the Daughters of Abraham through the First Church in Cambridge, Congregational, 11 Garden St., Cambridge 02138, memo line: Daughters of Abraham; or to the Andover Newton Interfaith Fund at the Andover Newton Theological School, Attention Priscilla Deck, 210 Herrick Road, Newton, MA 02459.

A WHILE back, Naomi Johnson, a communications professor at Longwood University in Virginia, sent me her doctoral thesis, which she described as a feminist analysis of the new wave of teenage romance novels. I don't read lots of dissertations, and almost tossed this one when the words ''ontological,'' ''objectivist'' and ''constructivist'' appeared in the same sentence, on Page 38. But I kept at it, because one of the series for teenagers that Dr. Johnson analyzed was the best-selling ''Clique'' books, which my 14-year-old daughter, Annie, loves and we buy the moment the newest one hits the bookstore. As others have, Dr. Johnson questions the female characters' preoccupation with looks, thinness, fashion, makeup, wealth -- we're talking spoiled, rich middle-school girls from Westchester County. But what grabbed me as new was her documentation of what she called the ''incessant litany of brand names.'' She examined three series, with combined sales of 13.5 million -- ''Clique,'' ''Gossip Girl'' and ''A-List'' -- and found, on average, there was more than one brand mentioned per page, 1,553 brand mentions in 1,431 pages of the six books she had read.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''With Flags as Big as Outfields, It's Stars and Stripes Forever,'' July 4: This overlooked the flag that started it all. The Great Flag, two acres of fabric weighing 14,000 pounds, was a noncommercial effort involving thousands of individual donations in a campaign similar to that of the Statue of Liberty's pedestal fund of the 1880s.

WHITMAN--Sylvia Choate , 85, June 19, Simsbury, CT. Beloved wife of the late Alexander H. Whitman. Raised in Boston and Topsfield, MA. Graduated from Westover School and attended Bryn Mawr College. After secretly taking flying lessons, she flew weather checks for the Civil Air Patrol in WWII. Lived most of 61-year marriage in Cedarhurst, NY, raising five children and volunteering at Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center and elsewhere. An avid athlete, gardener, world traveler, and investment adviser, she approached life with energy and spunk. Survived by brother Robert Burnett Choate; sons Alexander H. Whitman, of Seattle, Stephen V.R. Whitman, of Simsbury, CT; daughters Angelica Schuyler Whitman of Northampton, MA; Jennifer Whitman Foster of Decatur, GA, and Sylvia Whitman, of Arlington, VA; and 10 grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7106. Service 10:30am, September 20, Emmanuel Church, 15 Newbury St., Boston.

To the Editor: ''A Look Back at Canarsie, Clouded by Copyright Woes'' (June 29), about the Brooklyn Historical Society's refusal to allow two of its photographs to be published in a book about Brooklyn, perfectly described the ''orphan works'' conundrum: Under copyright law, an author needs permission to use a historical photo, but the photo's owner no longer exists. Congress is considering two bills to address the problem, but many artists remain concerned.

IT took Prosper Assouline, the publisher of high-end fashion and art books, two years to find the right space for his first boutique in the United States. ''I didn't want an ordinary box,'' he said. ''And what I found was a jewel.'' The mezzanine of the Plaza Hotel is now home to Assouline's second free-standing store in the world, after the one in Paris. And as would be expected, the L-shaped space is more library of luxury than dusty old bookshop. Aside from the Assouline titles that line the blackened oak ''Mondrian'' shelves (available by custom order), there is a collection of rare literary classics, special-edition Goyard trunks, African artifacts, cashmere throws and customized book sets like a Chanel one in a quilted leather case designed by the fashion house itself.

BAKER--Anthony Kane , 65, of Palm Beach, FL, and Mill Neck, NY, on July 9, 2008. Son of George F. Baker, Jr. and Frances Drexel Munn Baker. Devoted father to Asia Alexandra and Callie Frances Victoria. Brother of the late George F. Baker III, Pauline Baker Pitt, Lavinia Baker Logan and Kane Kendall Baker. A graduate of Brooks School and Trinity College. He was a trustee of Brooks School, Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities, Society of the Four Arts, Quebec - Labrador Foundation and senior trustee of The George F. Baker Trust, a foundation established in 1942 by his grandfather that supports educational, medical and civic concerns. His greatgrandfather, George F. Baker, helped found the First National Bank in New York City in 1863 and was instrumental in the establishment of the Harvard Business School and several university libraries including the Baker Library at Dartmouth College. He co-authored ''Long Island Country Houses and their Architects 1860-1940'' and was an authority on architectural preservation. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, July 22, at St. John's of Lattingtown Church, Locust Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made in his memory to Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities or to CARP, West Palm Beach, FL.

ASIDE from being Soul Brother No. 1, James Brown was also a premier pack rat. ''He kept everything,'' said Simeon Lipman, who cherry-picked the singer's funkier effects for an auction at Christie's on Thursday. A total of 329 lots will go on the block. Among them: a mink coat (estimated at $1,000 to $1,500); a ''Godfather of Soul'' cape ($15,000 to $20,000); a collection of platform boots ($3,000 to $5,000); sunglasses ($1,000 to $1,500) and cuff links ($200 to $300); many embroidered jumpsuits ($5,000); and an assortment of grooming products, including the barber chair and dome hair dryer ($1,000 to $1,500) from his in-house beauty parlor. If it all sounds a little ludicrous ... well, that's the point. ''This is a man who proclaimed himself the 'Sex Machine,' '' Mr. Lipman said. ''He was all about fun, and we wanted to express that.''

Squire, son of Isidore and Edith (nee Friedman), brother of Sidney Squire, father of Jeffrey and Judi Squire and grandfather of Evan and Emma Squire, died on July 4 at home after a brief illness. Albert, 87, was born in NYC May 3, 1921, graduated from City College and became a CPA. He served in the U.S. Army during WWII, graduated from St. John's University School of Law and became a tax litigator at the IRS Office of Regional Counsel in Philadelphia, retiring after 29 years. He cared deeply for the people in his life and they will miss him terribly. The family will hold a memorial service July 20 at 1pm at Temple Beth Kodesh, 561-586-9428. His family wishes to express their heartfelt appreciation to his caregivers, Anne Mene, Kimberly Harvey, and Jacques Clervil, and deeply thank the Hospice of Palm Beach County for their support. Contributions made in his name may be sent to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407 or the charity of your choice.

The tube or pencil skirt, with hems slashed for movement, or designed with seaming to accentuate the body's curves, is a favorite this summer. It is almost always worn with high heels, not flip-flops, and is often officebound. The classic model, with three seams and a back slit, is the most popular.

WHEN Suzy Kline, a grandmother of five and author of the ''Horrible Harry'' series, visits with her young fans at elementary schools, she takes along a notebook because she never knows where Harry, her third-grade rabble-rouser, might find his next adventure. At the Riverview Elementary School in Denville, N.J., last year, it was in the gym. While watching children climb a rope, she was inspired to write ''Horrible Harry and the Valentine Rope,'' to be published by Penguin next year as the latest in the 22-book series, which has sold more than four million copies.

THE NEWS At a summit meeting in Japan, leaders of the eight major industrial economies, including the United States, pledged to cut global emissions of greenhouse gases in half by 2050. BEHIND THE NEWS Though the pledge included few specifics and no shorter-term goals, it was seen as a marked departure for President Bush, who had resisted calls for concerted international efforts to combat global warming for years, ever since he rejected the Kyoto Protocol early in his tenure. In return, the other G-8 nations went along with his insistence that any binding treaty to cut emissions must also include major developing economies like India and China.

HENNING--Alison Peake , died on June 2nd of cancer at home in New Haven, CT. Beloved wife of the late Basil Duke Henning, Colgate Professor of English History and Master of Saybrook College at Yale University for 29 years. Born to Mr. and Mrs. William Woodhouse Peake in 1918 in Camden, SC. A graduate of Westover School and Smith College (Phi Beta Kappa.) A founder of the Smiffenpoofs at college. Sang with a quartet, the Magpies, for many years. Honorary member of the Yale Glee Club and the Whiffenpoofs. With her husband, she was the recipient of the Yale Medal for service to the University. For more than fifty years, the Hennings traveled to the U.K., principally London, where Professor Henning, a noted scholar of the Tudor and Stuart periods, was an editor of the History of Parliament Trust. She was a member of the Colony Club. She is survived by a daughter, Morgan Stebbins, of Providence, RI, two sons, William of Rumson, NJ and Cameron of New Haven, CT, and by grandchildren Rowland Stebbins, Alicia Peake Henning and Basil Duke Henning. Predeceased by her grandson Cameron Duke Stebbins and her three brothers, Robin, Cameron and David. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 20th at Battell Chapel, 300 College St., New Haven at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Westover School, Mimi Falsey, Director of Development, P.O. Box 847, Middlebury, CT 06762 or to the Cameron Stebbins Memorial Fund, Geoff Liggett, Director of Development, Pomfret School, 398 Pomfret St., Pomfret, CT 06258.

He served on the boards of the Youth Foundation and the Huguenot Society and was also a member of the SAR, Acorn Society, St. Nicholas, Descendants of Colonial Governors. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Holland Lodge Foundation, 71 West 23rd Street, New York City 10010. SMITH--Dorothy K. , formerly of Manhattan, July 8. Funeral Monday 11am, Church of the Transfiguration, Tarrytown. SMITH--Prentice Kellogg, 88, Lt. Col. US retired of Edgartown, MA, Essex CT and Harbour Island, Bahamas, died on July 5. He is survived by his beloved wife Patricia of 60 years, two sons, Prentice K. Smith Jr. of Greenwich, CT and Henry W. F. Smith of Edgartown, MA, and one daughter, Patricia F. Smith, Jr. of Needham, MA, and six grandchildren. He graduated from The Peck School in Morristown, NJ, St. Paul's School in Concord, NH in 1938 and Princeton University in Princeton, NJ in 1942. Upon graduation he was commissioned a 2nd Lt. Field Artillery. He was a member of the Cottage Club. During WWII he served as an Artillery Officer in the 32nd F H Batallion, which was part of the 18th Infantry Regiment, the First Infantry Division. He served in seven campaigns in the ETO as an Artillery Observer. He was awarded the Silver Star, two Oak Leaf Clusters, the Bronze Star, and two Invasion Arrowheads worn on his theater ribbon for participation in the Gala Invasion in Sicily and Omaha Beach. After the war he became interested in the Boy Scouts of America and worked for many years as a volunteer. From 1963 to 1966, he was President of Morris and Sussex Area Council of the Boy Scouts. In the business world, he worked for four years in the family business of Smith & Gallatin, member of the NY Stock Exchange and worked for 25 years with First Boston Corp., later named Credit Swiss FBC. He will be fondly remembered as a caring father, beloved husband, and a loyal friend. Those planning an expression of sympathy may send contributions to: Society of the First Infantry Division, 1933 Morris Road, Blue Bell, PA 19422-1422. Future memorials will be held in Edgartown in August and Essex, CT in September.
To the Editor: Re: ''At Penn, the Subject is Gossip,'' by Alex Williams (Sunday Styles, July 6):

As dusk settled on the Pioneer Mountains in Sun Valley, Idaho, last Thursday, the party was just beginning: a group of close to 100 people with name tags, mostly men, mingled, drank beer and told stories of their day on the golf course or at other diversions, like fly fishing or skeet shooting.

Several major bus routes will be diverted from 9:30 a.m. until about 6 p.m. on Tuesday because of Major League Baseball’s All-Star Procession, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced on Monday.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made increasing affordable housing a pillar of his administration, vowing to build and preserve 165,000 units in New York City by 2013.

How many English majors does it take to figure out a “Service Changes” poster by which the Metropolitan Transportation Authority tried to inform subway riders about last weekend’s construction re-routings?

More than 250,000 New Yorkers who have used up all of their jobless benefits in the last two years may start collecting unemployment checks again as soon as this week, the state labor commissioner said on Monday.
What we’re looking at on the Web today …

An article in The New York Times last week about Representative Charles B. Rangel’s use of four rent-stabilized apartments in Harlem drew an outpouring of responses from readers and an angry defense from Mr. Rangel, who called the arrangement legal and fair.

The fire escapes, roofs and top-floor windows of three apartment buildings on Gerard Avenue, two of them six stories and the other eight, are the Bronx equivalent of free Shakespeare in the Park: no-cost entertainment that generations of New Yorkers have cherished, envied, mythologized and taken for granted, Manny Fernandez writes.
State Senator Rubén Díaz Sr., a Bronx Democrat, said today that he is also running as a Republican.

A new audit by the city comptroller’s office has found disorganization and mismanagement within the Department of Sanitation’s program for cleaning up vacant lots, which remain significant eyesores in low-income neighborhoods. This week I want to discuss a volatile topic: the relatively low numbers of women in some fields of science and engineering. As I explain in my Findings column, federal agencies have begun "Title IX compliance reviews" of some science departments -- a novel step, because until now this anti-discrimination law has been enforced mainly for sports programs, not academic departments. Why, now that women students are approaching a 3-to-2 majority on campus and predominate in so many disciplines (including many science departments), is Washington singling out a few male-dominated departments in engineering and physical sciences?

First Lady is the unofficial title given to the wives of American presidents, or to the female relatives whom single or widowed presidents designated to serve as their hostesses. Never mentioned in the Constitution and unsalaried for the full-time work required, First Ladies have been idealized on the national and then the global stage as a symbol of American womanhood. Their roles have evolved under pressure from the press and the public, and provided a window on American political, economic and social life generally.

An article on Thursday about the Army Marksmanship Unit, a squad dedicated to training and employing Olympic-level shooters, referred incorrectly to shooters from the Army on this year’s United States team for the Beijing Games. An obituary on June 25 about the Nigerian singer and musician Sonny Okosuns referred incorrectly to his role on the 1985 anti-apartheid benefit recording “Sun City.” The Malopoets, a band from Soweto, South Africa, were also on the recording; Mr. Okosuns was not the only African.

The Khurais Oil Field Journal article on July 1, about the development of one of the world’s last giant oil fields, in Khurais, Saudi Arabia, misstated the capacity of three tanks constructed for storing the extracted oil before shipping. Each tank holds 600,000 barrels — not 600,000 gallons. (A barrel equals 42 gallons.).

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions last Monday about the dramatic Olympic qualifying of the American pole vaulter Jenn Stuczynski described her initial struggles incorrectly. She missed the first two attempts at her opening height, 15 feet 1 inch — not at the “lowest height” for the competition, 13 feet 9 inches.
OBITUARIES.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about investigations into possible voter fraud in Alabama carried a credit that misstated the name of the photographer’s newspaper. The picture was taken by John Allan Clark of the Perry County Herald, not the Perry County Record.

An article last Monday about the United States Olympic swimming trials, including the accomplishments of Dara Torres at age 41, misstated the age of a Canadian swimmer from the 1972 Games. Brenda Holmes was 14, not 44, when she competed for Canada.

An article on Thursday, about a spacewalk to remove a live explosive bolt from the Soyuz space capsule’s re-entry apparatus, described incorrectly the system that malfunctioned when the last two Soyuz capsules returned to Earth. There are 10 — not five — explosive bolts (two in each of the five latch assemblies that secure a propulsion module to the descent capsule). The malfunction, which led to “ballistic” descents subjecting those inside to higher than normal G forces, appears to have occurred in the fifth of the five latch assemblies, not in the “fifth of five explosive bolts.”.

An article last Monday about Senator Barack Obama’s new-media presidential campaign misstated the name of the company that provided the software for his donor and volunteer database. It is NGP Software, not N.P.G.

An obituary on Thursday about John Y. Simon, editor of the papers of Ulysses S. Grant, misstated the publication schedule for Volumes 29 and 30 of the papers. They are to be released this year, not in 2009. The obituary also referred incorrectly to the Grant papers as a model for other presidential papers. The Princeton University Press published the first volume of the Woodrow Wilson papers in 1966 and the first volume of the Thomas Jefferson papers in 1950, so the Grant papers, with the first volume in 1967, were not an influence on those volumes. And the obituary misstated the length of Mr. Simon’s tenure at Southern Illinois University. He taught for 44 years, not 34. (As the obituary noted, he began teaching there in 1964.).

An obituary on Wednesday about Ruth Greenglass, who gave damning testimony in the 1950s atomic espionage trial of her sister-in-law Ethel Rosenberg, misstated her age at the time of her death, in April. She was 83, not 84.

An article on Wednesday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign debt referred incorrectly to the significance of that debt when compared with other presidential candidates who had financial problems. At least two other losing presidential candidates, Mitt Romney, in 2008, and Steve Forbes, in 1996, had more total debt, including what they loaned their campaigns. Mrs. Clinton did not amass more personal and campaign debt than any other candidate en route to losing the nomination.
An outspoken advocate for the freedom of hostages in Colombia is reunited with her son after five and a half years.

The All-Star center Vincent Lecavalier signed an 11-year, $85 million contract extension with the Tampa Bay Lightning. Lecavalier, a 28-year old forward scored an N.H.L.-leading 52 goals during the 2006-7 season. He had 40 goals last season.

Graeme McDowell won the Scottish Open by two shots after three straight birdies on the back nine gave him a three-under 68 in the final round. Phil Mickelson had a 73 and finished 11 shots off the lead in a tie for 38th. McDowell trailed Simon Khan by two shots until Khan double-bogeyed the 12th. McDowell then birdied the next three holes to move ahead and went on to win with a total of 13-under 271 at Loch Lomond.

Paula Creamer shot a two-over 73, going wire to wire to win the Jamie Farr Owens Corning Classic in Sylvania, Ohio, by two strokes. Creamer had higher scores every day after breaking the tournament record with an 11-under 60 in the first round. She followed with a 65 and a 70, and finished at 16-under 268, two shots better than Nicole Castrale.

Kenny Perry beat Brad Adamonis and Jay Williamson in a one-hole playoff to win the John Deere Classic in Silvis, Ill. Perry escaped with his third victory in five starts despite bogeying the 18th hole. Perry had a one-stroke lead at 17 under par through 17 holes. While Adamonis and Williamson hit approach shots into the pond during the playoff at No. 18, Perry’s stopped just short of the hole. He tapped in from about 16 inches for par and the victory.

NAS ''Untitled'' (Def Jam) Nas is a martyr of his own making, from his shortsighted proclamations about the death of hip-hop and his steadfast resistance to radio-friendliness on down to the original title of this album, which was to be a too-familiar racial epithet up until, inevitably, the needs of commerce trumped the whims of art.

The Honest Jon's Revue started with more than two dozen musicians walking on stage. This made a good minute of theater: there were musicians from Mali, sitting down to ancient and modern instruments, from a one-stringed fiddle to an electric guitar. There were Americans too: among them a brass band, a folk singer and a soul singer. There were a few British hipsters too. But more to the point, they all stayed there, through the whole of Saturday night's concert. The standard strategy for a polystylistic, multicultural concert in New York City -- the kind of thing that flourishes in the summer's high-minded festivals -- is that one act clears out before another appears. It's assumed that the audience can take only one or two cultures at a time. But this was the opposite, a planned ruckus.

HEMLOCK--Lupe Cardenas, passed away peacefully in the arms of family and friends, on July 10th, 2008. Her life was an exemplar of making a difference on Earth. She gave generously of time and charity, especially working with children at risk and in need, to better their lives at the most personal and meaningful level, in homes, hospitals, and churches. With a zest for life, extraordinary beauty, grace and style, she always drew the admiration and attention of others. She was truly a treasured gift from God, and will live forever in the hearts and minds of everyone she touched, while she was here. Lupe is survived by her husband Alfred, son Adam, and a large and loving family. A memorial service will be held in September.

METCALF--Teresa Peabody, 84, of Peterborough, NH, died on July 11, 2008, at Monadnock Community Hospital. She moved to Peterborough in 1976 from Rumson, New Jersey. Mrs. Metcalf was born on October 5, 1923, in New York City, the daughter of Mary Cunningham (Bishop) and John D. Peabody. She attended Radcliffe College and was a member of the Colony Club in New York City. She was an avid tennis player and a former member of the Seabright Lawn, Tennis, and Cricket Club. She enjoyed sailing and summered for many years on Merchants Island, Maine. She is survived by her devoted and loving husband, Manton B. Metcalf III; her daughters, Teresa D. Metcalf of New York City and Elizabeth B. Metcalf-Perez of Hood River, Oregon; her son, John P. Metcalf, of Ridgway, Colorado; four grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. She was predeceased by a son, Manton B. Metcalf IV and a daughter, Mary Metcalf-Deault. The funeral will be held at 12:00 Noon, on Wednesday, July 16, at All Saints Parish, 51 Concord Street, Peterborough, New Hampshire. Reverend Adrian Robbins-Cole, Rector, will officiate. Flowers may be sent, or memorial gifts in her memory may be made to the Island Heritage Trust, PO Box 42, Deer Island, Maine 04627. Jellison Funeral Home, Peterborough, New Hampshire, is assisting the family with the services.

19.6 percent -- received ads in the form of short text messages in May 2008, an increase of 25 percent over May 2007. The ads offer news, financial data and retail information. Users can respond via text message, for example, to enter a contest or sign up for regular sports updates, like those for the Olympics (shown above, on NBC's Web site). Most people received one to five messages in May, and most ads came directly from the mobile service provider. Five percent of users said they received ads from companies without permission. PARKER--Frederick A., on July 10, leaving loving wife of 38 years, Susan, sons Nicholas and John and grandson Julian. Raised in China and Japan, graduated from The American School in Japan, Middlesex School, Harvard College and New College, Oxford. Fred was a member of the Union Club, The Harvard Club and the Madison Beach Club. A well traveled Raconteur, Oenophile and shipping industry veteran. He was the RW Past Master of Holland Lodge, Governor of the Colonial Wars in the state of New York, President of the New England Society and current Commander of the Military Order of Foreign Wars. He served on the boards of the Youth Foundation and the Huguenot Society and was also a member of the SAR, Acorn Society, St. Nicholas, Descendants of Colonial Governors. A Masonic memorial service will be held at the Church of the Incarnation, 35th Street and Madison Avenue, at 11am on Thursday, July 17. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Holland Lodge Foundation, 71 West 23rd Street, New York City 10010.

For all the drama, for all the frustration, for all the underachieving the Mets went through in their first 95 games, they are going into the All-Star break just a half-game out of first place. The same team that started the season under a shower of boos from its fans, behind the same pitcher who started the year with six losses in eight decisions, extended its winning streak to nine games Sunday night with a swaggering 7-0 defeat of the Colorado Rockies at Shea Stadium. The shutout was the Mets' fourth in six games, and the bullpen's scoreless-innings streak reached 19. The Rockies did, however, have seven hits, the first time since last Monday that a Mets opponent had more than three.

KAUFFMAN--Shirley (Rosengarten), of Princeton, NJ, an actress and political activist well-known throughout the region--but never happier than in the intimate company of her family and closest friends--died July 7 at home after a two year battle with cancer. She was 82. After graduating from Temple University, she studied with legendary drama coach Stella Adler in New York City. She had a lifelong interest in politics and was named to President Nixon's ''Enemies List'' in 1972. She is survived by her husband of 57 years, Ellwood (''Woody''); her sons and daughters-in-law, Scott and Nanci, Geoffrey and Antonella, and Matthew and Wendy; her daughter, Jane; five grandchildren, Stephen, Sarah, David, Sam and James; and a brother and sister-in-law, Earl and Florence Rogers. Her son - in - law, James Barthman, died in 2006. A celebration of her life was held July 9 in Princeton.

ECONOMIC REPORTS The markets will be looking for signals on the condition of housing and inflation in this week's batch of indicators. They will include the Producer Price Index for June, June retail sales, the New York Fed Empire State Survey for July and business inventories for May (Tuesday); the Consumer Price Index for June, industrial production and capacity utilization for June and the minutes from the June meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee (Wednesday); and housing starts for June (Thursday).

Two players, Nick Nickell and Mike Passell, will be inducted into the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame on Thursday in Las Vegas at the start of the Summer North American Championships. The expert's expert, Passell has won two world titles, the Bermuda Bowl in 1979 and the Transnational Teams in 2001, and has two world silver medals. He has 10 national team titles: one Grand National, four Reisingers, three Spingolds and two Vanderbilts.

BURKE--Dr. John Michael, of Copiague, LI, on July 12, 2008. Professor of Organic Chemistry at St. Francis College, Brooklyn, NY for 60 years. Dr. Burke was Chairman of the Science Division and head of the Chemistry Department at St. Francis College. He attended St. Francis Prep and St. Francis College earning a B.S. in Chemistry and received his Masters from NYU and his Ph.D. from St. John's University. Dr. Burke was best known for his research in chemically purifying and identifying toxins in red tides, clams and mussels. Before his teaching career, Dr. Burke worked for ITT Development and General Foods Research Laboratories. Teacher, scientist, avid fisherman and traveler, Dr. Burke is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Mary, his loving children Mary Jo Chiara, John Burke, Thomas Burke, Marguerite Burke and James Burke. Cherished grandfather of Margaret Mary, Nicholas, John, Thomas and John Michael. Adored great-grandfather of William, Kieran and Megan. The family will receive friends today (Monday) and Tuesday 2-4:30 and 79:30pm at the Powell Funeral Home, Inc., 67 Broadway (Rt. 110), Amityville. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:30am. St. Martin of Tours R.C. Church, Amityville. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

McCRINDLE--Joseph F. We mourn the passing of our friend and colleague even as we take comfort in the joy and fullness of his life. Joe had been an active member of the Board of Trustees since 1986. His uncommon generosity was a natural outgrowth of his interest in encouraging young talent and applauding its achievement on the stage of Carnegie Hall. Joe exuded a passion for all things artistic, eager to help them grow and flourish. His courtly demeanor accented by a wry humor were the grace notes of a life richly touched by a deep humanity. We shall miss him. Board of Trustees New York Youth Symphony Leslie J. Garfield, Chair A. Slade Mills, Jr., Pres. Barry Goldberg, Executive Director

As players and officials at the Futures Game on Sunday spoke hopefully about the players' imminent major league stardom, they also spoke regretfully about the recent news that the F.B.I. was looking into whether major league personnel improperly pocketed money earmarked for Latin American teenagers. Players primarily from the Dominican Republic and Venezuela, who are not subject to baseball's amateur draft, have traditionally paid portions of their bonuses to local baseball insiders -- called buscones -- who help them be seen by scouts. But the F.B.I. is investigating whether some major league club officials paid the players small fractions of the bonuses they reported to Major League Baseball and kept most of the difference.

TRACY--Gerard B., of New Canaan, CT, formerly of Crestwood, NY, died on July 12, 2008 at age 90 in New Canaan, CT. He was a former Special Agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a leading producer for Prudential Insurance & Founder and President of Gerard B. Tracy Associates. Mr. Tracy was a Knight of Malta, a Commissioner of the East Hudson Parkway Authority, a Life Member of the Million Dollar Round Table, and a recipient of the Townsend Harris Medal of CCNY for outstanding post-graduate achievement. In addition to his wife of sixty years, Muriel, he is survived by a sister, Terese Salmon, his eight children and twentytwo grandchildren. His children are: Gerard Tracy of Columbus, OH; Kathleen O'Flinn of Bonita Springs, FL; Timothy Tracy of Fairfeild, CT; Patrice Melley of Windsor, CT; Maryjo Morris of Ridgewood, NJ; Terence Tracy of New Rochelle, NY; Kerry Tracy of NYC and Megan Grant of NYC. A Mass will be celebrated on Monday, July 14, 2008 at 10:00am at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, followed by interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Waveny Care Center, 3 Farm Road, New Canaan, CT 06840.

The call he will never forget came for Peter Ueberroth in the middle of the night on May 12, 1984, over a crackling phone line from Beijing. It carried the news he believed would determine the fate of the Olympics, not just the Games he was working to organize in Los Angeles that summer but all the ones beyond. At the other end of the line was Charles Lee, the man he had sent to persuade the Chinese to send their team to the Olympics for the first time. Ueberroth, the leader of the Los Angeles organizing committee, was asking China to defy a Soviet Union-led boycott that was announced four days earlier. The Soviets said the boycott would keep 100 countries away from the '84 Games. If the Soviets succeeded, Ueberroth said flatly, ''we were done.''

TSAI--Gerald. The Board of Directors of Triarc Companies, Inc. extends its sincere and heartfelt condolences to the family of Gerald Tsai, Jr. on his passing on July 9, 2008. He was a dear friend and a valuable member of our Board and its predecessors since 1986. He will be greatly missed. Nelson Peltz, Chairman Peter W. May, Vice Chairman TSAI--Gerald Jr., you were a treasure mentor and an invaluable confidant and a true friend. As much as you taught me about finance, you taught me more about life. I will be forever grateful for your kindness, generosity and loyalty. My deepest sympathies to his family. Natalie Packer Freedman TSAI--Gerald Jr. Extraordinary friend, mentor and colleague. Incredibly distinguished life and career you built since coming here from China almost 60 years ago. Amazing brain and intellectual curiosity, coupled with the discipline and ambition to achieve remarkable goals. Impeccable and uncanny sense of timing combined with good luck leading to good fortune. Highly cultivated aesthetic sense complemented by your business acumen to create, appreciate and ultimately market beautiful works. Your ability to think with your heart and your head -lovely but often painful. Your loyalty as a brother and friend for 28 and 53 years. We will love and miss you forever. Pamela and Todd Cole

And now we've reached the next stage of our seemingly never-ending financial crisis. This time Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are in the headlines, with dire warnings of imminent collapse. How worried should we be? Well, I'm going to take a contrarian position: the storm over these particular lenders is overblown. Fannie and Freddie probably will need a government rescue. But since it's already clear that that rescue will take place, their problems won't take down the economy.
