E-mail users over 70 believe more firmly in prompt replies than people in any other age group, according to the results of an annual study released recently by the Center for the Digital Future at the University of Southern California. When asked how quickly one should reply to a personal e-mail message, members of that age group were the most likely to answer ''as soon as possible'' or ''in one day.'' Internet users over 70 also check e-mail as often or more frequently than people in any other age group.

In the season finale of ''CSI: NY'' in May, the show's characters gathered around videoconferencing screens to share information about a shooting. ''She wants everybody on a TelePresence call,'' says an investigator, Lindsay Monroe. ''O.K., we have a full house, network's secure, you're good to go, Stella.'' The unlikely supporting player in the episode was Cisco Systems, which wanted to show off its TelePresence videoconferencing system. Cisco's on-air cameo may seem puzzling to viewers more familiar with product placements for soft drinks or cars (who would rush out to buy a complex computer system after seeing it on CSI?), but the placement resulted from careful deal-making by the company's entertainment agency, Davie Brown Entertainment, with CBS and the show.

ZIARAT, Pakistan -- The mountain of white marble shines with such brilliance in the sun it looks like snow. For four years, the quarry beneath it lay dormant, its riches captive to tribal squabbles and government ineptitude in this corner of Pakistan's tribal areas. But in April, the Taliban appeared and imposed a firm hand. They settled the feud between the tribes, demanded a fat fee up front and a tax on every truck that ferried the treasure from the quarry. Since then, Mir Zaman, a contractor from the Masaud subtribe, which was picked by the Taliban to run the quarry, has watched contentedly as his trucks roll out of the quarry with colossal boulders bound for refining in nearby towns.

So I hear through the grapevine that eBay's executives are dancing in the street in the wake of the company's victory in the Tiffany counterfeiting case. (Several years ago, Tiffany sued eBay for not proactively monitoring the site to prevent counterfeit items from being offered for sale or auction. One person involved in the case on the Tiffany side told me at the time that 95 percent of everything on eBay that was supposedly made by Tiffany was, in fact, fraudulent.) I hope they don't party too hard at eBay not only because Tiffany is sure to appeal but also because it has lost three similar cases in Europe, brought by Rolex, Hermes and Louis Vuitton. No, the real problem here stems from eBay's attitude toward its customers: namely, the site had no real responsibility toward rectifying wrongs -- of any sort -- that occur during an eBay transaction.

For violating the do-not-call list, the government initially ordered two companies to pay more than $11 million. A new book, "Sway," details the many ways that psychological forces can turn even the most logical thinker into an irrational, impulse-driven being. After reading "Sway" and having a series of conversations with its authors, I am suddenly questioning things. Am I right to believe a certain colleague is a star, or am I merely attributing characteristics to him based on his reputation? Am I sticking with a project long after I know it's doomed for fear of accepting a loss? Have I been blind to a person's talent because I am held sway by a first impression and interpret all facts in a way that supports that mistaken impression?

I had never gotten around to reading "Before the Storm," Rick Perlstein's 2001 book on Barry Goldwater and the rise of the conservative movement. So when Perlstein's follow-up, "Nixonland," came out this spring, I decided to read them in sequence. But when I visited Amazon last week I found that "Before the Storm" was available only through five used booksellers, at prices ranging from $131.09 to $184.02. I could imagine paying that kind of money for an autographed "Augie March" or a first-edition Faulkner, but a Perlstein paperback? How did the booksellers arrive at these figures, which seemed prohibitively high and oddly precise (would it have been $131.10 had one fewer page been dog-eared by the original owner)? And why wouldn't at least one seller have tried to undercut the others? I e-mailed the store proprietors to find out.

Here's another video dispatch from my little spot on this pale blue dot. I promised to provide views of four seasons here in the Hudson River Valley (e.g., sticky snow). I pretty much missed spring thanks to endless news, but at least now provide a glimpse of the transition to summer. It's a dance that constitutes one of the rare rituals that still connect people here to the season's transitions. What rituals and traditions persist on "your dot?" Down the dirt road from my house, there's a white barn with a loft that's empty only once each year -- in mid June. It's now already partly stacked with hay harvested and baled on the hilltop fields nearby, set aside to feed several dozen head of Angus beef cattle through the winter when they're not freely grazing. That brief moment of June emptiness is filled with music and dancing:

OK, this doesn't matter for anything -- but Alex Tabarrok mentions the "peso problem", and links to an article that gives credit for the term to Milton Friedman.
On opposite sides of the country today, the presumptive presidential nominees will once again sharpen their positions on how to manage the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan if elected.

Waste Management's $6.2 billion offer to buy Republic Services -- which is already in a deal with Allied Waste -- shows the rising confidence of corporate buyers, even as troubled credit markets have all but shut out private equity firms.

Midwest Airlines, the troubled airline bought by TPG earlier this year and a subject of bankruptcy speculation, said that it would cut its work force by 1,200 employees, or 40 percent, making it the latest airline to reduce staffing amid soaring fuel prices.
Venture capital fund-raising got a slight bump in the second quarter, according to figures published Monday by Thomson Reuters and the National Venture Capital Association.

As part of its investigation into the possible spreading of false rumors along Wall Street, the Securities and Exchange Commission has sent subpoenas to more than 50 hedge-fund advisers, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

The Bush administration hastily arranged the dramatic Sunday evening rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac after Wall Street executives and foreign central bankers told Washington that any further erosion of confidence could have a cascading effect around the world, officials said on Monday.

The Federal Reserve adopted sweeping rules on Monday aimed at barring abusive or deceptive mortgage lending practices of the kind that analysts say have led to widespread delinquencies and foreclosures, a collapse of the housing market and an economic downturn.
The Children's Investment Fund lost more than $1 billion in June, marking its worst month ever, The Financial Times reported.
Vikram S. Pandit summoned 60 executives to Armonk, N.Y., last Tuesday to present his plan to buck up Citigroup, the beleaguered bank he runs.
Even as the Bush administration moved to rescue the nation's two largest mortgage finance companies, confidence in the banking sector spiraled downward Monday.

More cash is being raised by a special type of acquisition vehicle that shows its greatest strength in a bear market - easing some of the pain bankers feel through a lack of initial public offerings in Europe.

A former star trader at Bear Stearns has formed a new hedge fund called Covepoint Capital with nearly $1 billion in assets, Reuters reported.

Barrick Gold has started a hostile bid of 354 million Canadian dollars, or $350 million, for Cadence Energy to lock in cheaper oil prices and get control of soaring production costs, the world's top gold miner said on Monday.
Duvernay Oil, a natural gas company based in Alberta, agreed on Monday to be acquired by a larger rival, Shell Canada, for $5.9 billion.
Reports of the death of a Dave & Buster's initial public offering have turned out to be premature.
Russian billionaires who own the TNK-BP oil venture with BP are prepared to buy the latter's 50 percent stake to end a struggle for control, Bloomberg News reported.
At last week's annual Allen & Company mogul retreat, the topic du jour was the ongoing tussle for control of Yahoo.

As my colleagues over at the Rings blog point out, there are some oldies but goodies at this year's Olympics.
Retail investors have returned applications for half their shares in the upcoming listing of Sociedade de Jogos de Macau, after the trading debut was delayed by a court dispute.

Venture capital funds invested $158 million in India during April to June, funds-tracker Venture Intelligence said on Tuesday. The total number of deals for the period came to 26, although no comparative data was given.

Companhia Vale do Rio Doce will seek to raise about $15 billion in the biggest sale ever by a Brazilian company. The share offering from the world's largest iron-ore producer is set to be priced on Wednesday.

As Lehman Brothers ponders how to boost its ailing fortunes, its leadership is considering a drastic plan, according to The New York Post: taking the securities firm private.

At the height of the housing boom in the U.K., several contrarian Web sites emerged, warning that the bubble was sure to burst. But as prices continued to soar, many openly scoffed at the pessimism of forums like housepricecrash.co.uk, pricedout.org.uk and globalhousepricecrash.com, including a 2006 article in The Independent which labeled the sites "doomsters" and "Jeremiahs."

Aired Monday night on NBC: Earlier today, President Bush announced he is lifting the executive ban on offshore drilling. The President made the announcement during a speech entitled "Eh, What the Hell."

Is Brett Favre worth all the fuss?Full disclosure on this post: I went into it expecting to find numbers to back my hunch that the performance of quarterbacks nearing 40 drops off significantly -- even for elite quarterbacks like Favre, who will turn 39 in October.

It's not a surprise that search advertisers are wary of Yahoo's deal to have some of its search ads sold by Google. After all, that extra money that Yahoo is hoping to get from the arrangement is coming from somewhere: the pocketbooks of advertisers.
Blacks and whites hold vastly different views of Senator Barack Obama and the state of race relations, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
Representative Charles B. Rangel will move his office from one of four rent-stabilized apartments he leases.

Javelin thrower Breaux Greer made the United States track and field team for the Beijing Games even though he failed to reach the final round at the Olympic trials. He was placed on the team, USA Track & Field said, based on a rule that allows for “the selection of an injured athlete who competed in the Olympic trials but did not final ... as long as another athlete is not displaced from the team.”.
In a significant shift, Microsoft unveiled a strategy for its gaming unit that is meant to help the company’s Xbox 360 console appeal to the mainstream.
Danilo Gallinari scored 14 points in his N.B.A. Summer League debut Monday, and showed that he is a work in progress.

An article last Tuesday about a new three-dimensional chat service from Google misidentified the university whose students helped test the service. It is Arizona State University, not the University of Arizona.

An article on Thursday about a CNBC television interview with Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman and controlling shareholder of Viacom and CBS, in which he said that his daughter, Shari, was no longer the company’s heir apparent, misidentified the source of the information that a deal had been reached in principle to buy out his daughter’s interest and have her leave the boards of the two companies. That information was provided by people close to the negotiations who declined to be identified because the talks were continuing. Mr. Redstone did not make those points during his interview with David Faber of CNBC.

A picture caption on Saturday with an article about General Electric’s quarterly earnings may have left the incorrect impression that G.E. was selling appliances in Iran. While the picture, from The Associated Press, showed the company’s products in a Tehran appliance store, General Electric said that the sales were unauthorized and that the company had stopped supplying the distributor who provided the appliances to the Tehran store.

An article on Saturday about opposition to a plan to name a new research center at the University of Chicago after the economist Milton Friedman misstated the name of a research organization at Stanford University. It is the Hoover Institution, not Hoover Institute.
Tiger Woods is absent from one of golf’s four majors for the first time since 1996, and speculation abounds about the impact this will have on the 137th British Open.

An obituary on June 8 about Bill Finegan, who formed an innovative big band with Eddie Sauter in the 1950s, referred incorrectly to part of the band’s unusual instrumentation. It used a xylophone and a marimba, not two xylophones. The error was pointed out in a letter dated June 9 from Alan Abel, who was a percussionist in the band. This correction was delayed because his letter went astray at The Times.

An article on Sunday about some left-wing voters’ dissatisfaction with Senator Barack Obama misstated the political affiliation of Ralph Nader, who is also seeking the presidency. Mr. Nader is running as an independent; he is not the candidate of the Green Party, which nominated Cynthia McKinney on Saturday.

An article on Thursday about cases involving the illegal transfer of sensitive information to China misstated the legal status of Dongfan Chung, a defendant in one case. Mr. Chung, a former Boeing engineer known as Greg, has been indicted on economic espionage charges, which he has denied. He has not been convicted.
NATIONAL.

An answer in the Q&A column on the Circuits pages on Thursday about plans by Microsoft to stop issuing security updates for consumer versions of its Windows XP operating system misstated the date of the change. Microsoft will stop the updates on April 8, 2014 — not on April 14, 2009.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about a government report showing a slower pace of wage increases for hourly workers in New York State over the last few years compared with the rise in the minimum wage misidentified, in one reference, the measure of overall wages that was cited. It was the median — not the average — hourly wage.
A listing on Friday about a movie series that is paying tribute to the Japanese actor Tatsuya Nakadai, at Film Forum in the South Village misstated the admission price. It is $11, not $10.50.
In a dramatic reversal of fortunes, former Assemblyman Robert A. Straniere was endorsed for Congress by the Staten Island Republican Party.
A wildfire in the Los Padres National Forest continued to spread, forcing residents of the rural community of Cachagua to stay out of their homes for a third day.
The husband of an Army nurse at Fort Bragg’s hospital was charged with murder in her death, a day after her body was discovered by the authorities.
A judge decided not to make public text messages involved in the perjury and misconduct case against Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick of Detroit.
Islanders General Manager Garth Snow fired Ted Nolan on Monday, although the team softened the news by saying he would not return as coach.

Tanya Hollander, who worked as a part-time booker for the prostitution ring, is expected to plead guilty next month to lighter charges than those faced by her fellow defendants, her lawyer said.
There is no better way to get a blogger fired up than by telling him what he cannot publish -- although you might forgive a government prosecutor for thinking otherwise.

USA Boxing’s judicial committee on Monday upheld the organization’s decision to bar Luis Yanez from the Olympic team. Yanez, a light flyweight, is expected to appeal to an independent arbitrator this week, hoping for a decision before his eight teammates leave for China next week. Yanez was kicked off the roster July 1 for missing more than three weeks of workouts at the team’s residency training program in Colorado Springs.

Lindsay Davenport’s troublesome right knee forced her to withdraw from the Bank of the West Classic in Stanford, Calif. It was the third time in six weeks that Davenport had pulled out of a tournament. Davenport, 32, was scheduled to play eighth-seeded Francesca Schiavone in a first-round match Tuesday evening, but dropped out after warming up Monday. Davenport was attempting to play for the first time since pulling out of her second-round match at Wimbledon.

The son of North Carolina State basketball coach Sidney Lowe pleaded guilty to dozens of charges connected to a March 2007 armed robbery. A sentencing hearing for Sidney Lowe II, 23, is expected to end Tuesday in Greensboro, N.C.

Teddy Dupay, who played on the Florida team that lost to Michigan State in the 2000 N.C.A.A. tournament title game, made an initial court appearance on charges of raping and kidnapping a woman at a Utah ski resort. Dupay did not enter a plea. Dupay, 29, is charged with felony rape, aggravated assault and aggravated kidnapping. In court documents, Dupay denied raping the woman.

Ryan Newman, projected as a possible teammate for the two-time Nascar Cup champion Tony Stewart on his new team, will leave Penske Racing at the end of the season, Penske announced in a statement. Newman, 30, got a full-time Cup ride in 2002 and has notched 13 victories, including this year’s Daytona 500. In a statement, Newman gave no indication where he would race next season. Stewart announced last week that he would leave Joe Gibbs Racing at the end of 2008 to become a driver and a part-owner of the team currently known as Haas-CNC Racing. The name will be changed to Stewart-Haas.

Masonic services to be held Thursday, July 17 at Church of the Incarnation, 35th Street and Madison Avenue, at 11am. Walter F. Bottger, Master Michael M. Maney, Secretary

DeBAKEY--Dr. Michael, is celebrated by the Directors, staff and friends of the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation. Dr. DeBakey received the Lasker Award for Clinical Medical Research in 1963, now renamed the Lasker-DeBakey Award for Clinical Medical Research. For 30 years Dr. DeBakey chaired the Lasker Awards Jury, guiding the Foundation's Awards that honor outstanding researchers in medical science. Teaming with Mary Lasker, Dr. DeBakey generously lent his voice and resources to the campaign for strong public support of medical research. He saved thousands of lives, inspired generations of researchers and surgeons, and challenged public leaders to invest in basic and clinical research.

To reach Edward O. Wilson's office on the Harvard campus, one must first push through a door with a sign warning the public not to enter. Then, enter a creaky old elevator and press two buttons simultaneously. This counterintuitive procedure transports one into a strange realm. It is a space that holds the world's largest collection of ants, some 14,000 species. Curators are checking the drawers, dominated by the tall figure of Dr. Wilson, who is trying to contain his excitement: the 14,001st ant species has just been discovered in the soils of a Brazilian forest. He steamrolls any incipient skepticism about the ant's uniqueness -- the new species is a living coelacanth of ants, a primitive throwback to the first ant, a wasp that shed its wings and assigned all its descendants to live in earth, not their ancestral air. The new ant is so alien, Dr. Wilson explains, so unlike any known to earthlings, that it will be named as if it came from another planet.

McCRINDLE--Joseph F., art collector, philanthropist and publisher, died at his home in New York on July 11 at the age of 85, following an extended illness. Great grandson of the American painter Henry Mosler, he developed an early appreciation of the arts and began collecting 16th-century books at the age of eight. Joe graduated St. Paul's School and Harvard College, class of 1944. During World War II, he served in the OSS in London, and after being discharged as a 1st Lieutenant, MI, USAR, he attended Yale Law School, class of 1948. After a brief period with a Wall Street law firm and stints at one London and two New York publishing companies, Joe became a literary agent, with clients including Philip Roth and John McPhee. In 1959, following a summer at Oxford, Joe founded Transatlantic Review, a London-based quarterly that went on to publish work by such writers and artists as W. H. Auden, Paul Bowles, Anthony Burgess, Jean Cocteau, Iris Murdoch, Grace Paley, Harold Pinter, Larry Rivers, William Trevor and John Updike. Joe remained editor and publisher of Transatlantic Review until it ceased publication in 1977. He also established the Henfield Foundation, now known as the Joseph F. McCrindle Foundation, which makes grants to arts, music and social justice organizations; and the Henfield Prize, an annual award to students in leading creative writing programs. A collector of old master paintings and old master and 19thcentury drawings as well as historical manuscripts, letters and Pre-Columbian Art, Joe was a donor to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the British Center at Yale, the Fine Arts Museum of San Francisco, Legion of Honor, the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Morgan Library and Museum, and was a major benefactor of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, among many others. Joe served on the boards of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the American Academy in Rome, and the New York Youth Symphony. He is survived by his half-brother, Antoine duBourg of Newport, Rhode Island. A memorial service is being planned for September. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the New York Youth Symphony, 850 Seventh Avenue, Suite 505, New York, NY 10019.

DONNELLEY--Strachan, Ph.D. The trustees and staff of the American Museum of Natural History are deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Strachan Donnelley, trustee of the museum, a longtime benefactor and friend, and a founding member of the Museum's Center for Biodiversity and Conservation. A man of conviction, exquisite moral fiber, and profound affinity for nature, he truly exemplified the very best of humanity. We are grateful that he so generously Championed the museum's work to train the next generations of scientists to meet global environmental challenges in ways that foster sustainable and ethical human relationships with nature. It is with great admiration and gratitude that we will remember him for his intelligence, integrity, and kindness. Our heart felt sympathies go out to his wife Vivian, and to his daughters Inanna, Naomi, Aidan, Ceara, and Tegan, and to the entire Donnelley family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President DONNELLEY--Strachan, a passionate conservationist, philosopher, fly-fisherman, husband, father, grandfather, brother, friend, and lover of all things natural, died peacefully on Saturday, July 12th, 2008 at his home in Manhattan, NY from gastric cancer. Strachan, son of the late Gaylord Donnelley, former president and chairman of the Chicago-based printing company R.R. Donnelley & Sons, and Dorothy Donnelley, was 66 years old. Up until the time of his death, Strachan continued to serve as Founder and President of the Center for Humans and Nature, a nonprofit organization whose mission is to explore and promote moral and civic responsibilities to human communities and to natural ecosystems and landscapes. Strachan received his B.A. in English Literature from Yale University in 1964, studied philosophy at University College Oxford University from 1964-1967, and received his M.A. and Ph.D. in Philosophy in 1972 and 1977, respectively, from the New School for Social Research. Prior to founding the Center in 2002, Strachan worked at the Hastings Center, the noted nonprofit bioethics research institute in Garrison, NY (1986-2002), and served as its President from 1996-1999. At the time of his death, Strachan was a trustee on the following boards of directors: the Gaylord and Dorothy Donnelley Foundation (chairman emeritus), the American Museum of Natural History, The Land Institute, The University of Chicago, the New School for Social Research, the National Humanities Center (trustee emeritus), Sarah Lawrence College (honorary trustee), The Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago (life trustee). He was also active on the Advisory Committees of the following boards: the Yale Institute of Biospheric Studies, the American Fisheries Foundation, the Coldwater Conservation Fund (Trout Unlimited), Human Rights Watch, World Wildlife Fund, Christ College (Valparaiso University), the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, and the Aldo Leopold Foundation. In the months preceding his death, Strachan worked closely with cherished colleagues on Living Waters, Magic Mountains: Explorations of a Flyfishing Philosopher, an anthology of his professional essays to be published posthumously. Strachan's lively spirit and wildness will continue to thrive in his six Donnelley women: his wife of 40 years, Vivian, and his five daughters, Inanna, Naomi, Aidan, Ceara and Tegan, and in the life and laughter of his five (almost six) grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister Laura and brother Elliott. Strachan will live on in the winds and waters of his favorite places the family home in Mill River, Massachusetts, The Coleman Lake Club in Northern Wisconsin, Ashepoo Plantation in Green Pond, South Carolina, and Windblown Hill, his childhood family farm, in Libertyville, Illinois, where a private family funeral will be held on Thursday, July 17th, 2008. Strachan will be celebrated among family, friends, and colleagues at a public memorial service on Saturday, July 19th at 10 am at Fullerton Hall, the Art Institute of Chicago and at a second memorial service in Manhattan in the fall. Strachan's family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Center for Humans and Nature http:/ /www.humansandnature.org/ or to The Land Institute http:// www.landinstitute.org/ DONNELLEY--Strachan. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The New School are deeply saddened by the death of Strachan Donnelley, accomplished alumnus, beloved teacher, and respected trustee and board of governors' member. A committed conservationist and philosopher, Strachan dedicated his life's work to promoting social and moral responsibilities to human communities and natural ecosystems. During his 37year relationship with our university, his leadership and generosity have always set the bar high and advanced numerous worthy initiatives, none more important to him than fellowship support that has benefited and will continue to benefit generations of students. His profound influence on The New School, both personal and professional, will remain with us always. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Vivian and their five daughters and their families. Bob Kerrey, President, The New School Julien J. Studley, Chair, Board of Trustees Michael Schober, Dean, The New School for Social Research

My Thursday column is about Darfur in the aftermath of the ICC Chief Prosecutor's announcement that he is seeking an arrest warrant for Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir. I argue that instead of wringing our hands over the dangers, we should applaud this action -- and that it just might create additional leverage to end the slaughter. I didn't have space to quote him, but I had a long talk with David Crane, the prosecutor of the Sierra Leone tribunal, and he is convinced that this is the beginning of the end for Bashir. I'm not sure that's true, but I think it's possible.

It seems to be a recurring theme at Halston: another collection, another designer. Women's Wear today reported that Marco Zanini, who showed his first collection for Halston this past February, has left the company. Zanini came from Versace, and was duly praised by Tamara Mellon, one of Halston's new owners. I thought his first collection was terrific-exactly what these over-rich, over-starched times need. But I know that a number of retailers were disappointed with the clothes, saying they weren't special enough. Stay tuned. There is bound to be more news from this house. (And, of course, everyone is asking: Now who? Ain't that a puzzle.)

[Update Wed. afternoon: Oscar Pistorius failed in his final bid to qualify for the Olympics in the 400 meters, finishing third at 46.25 seconds in a race for able-bodied athletes at Lucerne, Switzerland. The time was a personal best for Pistorius, but still well short of the 45.55 he needed. However, he is still eligible to be selected for South Africa's 4x400 Olympic relay team. ]

Updated: 7 p.m. CINCINNATI -- Senator John McCain faced a quandary Wednesday when he addressed the N.A.A.C.P. in Cincinnati at the group's annual convention. Running against the first black to (presumably) win the presidential nomination of a major party, Mr. McCain came to praise Senator Barack Obama, not to bury him. And he did it in a humorous, self-deprecating way.
(James Ewing)

In much of Europe, the Old Town is the only town that matters. Centuries-old stone houses, crammed into shoulder-width alleyways that swerve at random and wind uphill toward ancient churches dedicated to forgotten saints - this is, to many of us, what Europe is all about. But Old Towns often give me pause: Will the quaintness mask a lack of vitality? Is it a museum for tourists, or a place where locals live, work and play? And if the Old Town is boring, will the New Town - the less-densely populated, less charming sprawl outside the medieval city walls - be any better?

The long-running drama over CSX drew closer to completion on Wednesday, as the independent inspector of the railroad operator's shareholder vote said that a pair of activist hedge funds appears to have gained four seats on the company's board.
Christopher Tennant

Betsey Armstrong is the goalkeeper for the U.S.A. women's water polo team, which is favored to win the gold medal in the Olympics this summer. Armstrong is an Ann Arbor, Mich., native and a 2005 Michigan graduate who helped Team U.S.A. win gold at the 2007 Pan American Games. She'll be writing occasional posts for the Rings blog in the buildup to the Olympics.

I cannot possibly write about grilling lamb -- as I do in today's Minimalist column -- without including this all-time favorite. As I point out in the column, shoulder is the best cut of lamb for skewering; its fattiness keeps it moist. But for a big, impressive piece of meat, you can't beat boneless leg. And because of its uneven thickness, you can get rare, medium, and even well-done meat on the same piece; and even well-cooked lamb is delicious.

I just finished a Skype video chat with about 80 people from the new Climate Protection Partnership within the Greater Kansas City Chamber of Commerce. Over 150 companies, with something like 100,000 employees, have joined the group, which is committed to reducing greenhouse-gas emissions from the metropolitan region of some 2 million people. The session provided fresh evidence that progress on curbing energy demand and greenhouse gases may well come from the bottom up before it comes from the top down. The evidence cited by a participant involved Girl Scouts and school buses. What's happening around "your dot" that gives you hope, or concern?
Oh, man, I was laughing so hard at the cleverness of this Web video.

Mick Sussman's fascinating post yesterday about the prices of used books sent me scurrying to do a little research of my own. Since Mick had me thinking about the vagaries of market valuation, and since the stock market closed below 11,000 yesterday on continued worries about housing and inflation, I headed to Amazon and shot fish in a barrel: I looked for "Dow 36,000," the 2000 book by James Glassman and Kevin Hassett that was seen as propagandistic hype even when it was published, at the height of the tech bubble. On the day it was released, the Dow closed at 10,681.06. That's essentially the same as yesterday's close, and substantially higher once you adjust for inflation. So there's a little thrill of schadenfreude in seeing that used copies of the book are available starting at 47 cents.

Public reaction was fast and furious to a surveillance video shown last year on local news broadcasts in New York City. It showed a 101-year-old woman on a walker battered and bloodied in the vestibule of her apartment building by a mugger who made off with $33 and a set of house keys. Who could watch the attack on Rose Morat, headed home from church in broad daylight, and not think of their own mother or grandmother? She was gritty, good-humored -- and boy, did she look good for her age.

So Congress has overridden Bush's veto on the Medicare bill. This is huge news. As I tried to explain last week, it's not really about maintaining doctors' payments -- some fudge would have been found to avoid drastic cuts. It's about rolling back Medicare privatization -- and it's a big win for reformers against the insurance companies.

The Los Angeles Clippers have acquired center Marcus Camby from the Denver Nuggets for a future second-round draft pick. Camby led the N.B.A. in blocked shots with 3.61 a game last season; he is only the second player to do so in three straight seasons. He averaged 9.1 points and 13.1 rebounds last season.
Two women were sentenced to life in prison without parole for murdering two indigent men to collect insurance policies taken out on their lives.

A pickup truck carrying two people collided with a sport-utility vehicle transporting six farmworkers, sending both vehicles plunging into an irrigation canal in rural central California, the authorities said.
Scientists predicted that this year’s summer dead zone off the Louisiana coast would be the largest ever and would threaten commercial and recreational fishing in the Gulf of Mexico.

A Pennsylvania-based lobbyist was charged with destroying evidence related to a Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry involving former Representative Curt Weldon and the awarding of government contracts.

A man who killed 11 people by causing a commuter rail disaster was spared the death penalty by jurors who wept while listening to victims’ relatives but decided he should get life in prison without parole.
Susan Atkins, a follower of Charles Manson who is dying of brain cancer, has been denied release from prison.
Opening and operating the nation’s first nuclear waste dump will cost more than $90 billion, an Energy Department official said.
The District of Columbia Council approved new firearms legislation that will allow residents to begin applying for handgun permits this week.
Hundreds of pounds of garbage has washed onto Lake Michigan shores in recent days, leading to an investigation by the Coast Guard and the temporary closing of a public beach.

The actors Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins did not have kudos in mind for St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan during a public hearing on whether the hospital should be allowed to build a medical tower and condominium.

The Yankees’ principal owner wept as he was driven across the outfield warning track and onto the field. He received a prolonged ovation.

China expressed “grave concern” over the decision by the International Criminal Court’s prosecutor to charge President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan with genocide.
President Dmitri A. Medvedev criticized the United States and Western Europe for creating a missile defense shield and for recognizing Kosovo’s independence.

World Youth Day, an event that the Roman Catholic Church describes as the largest gathering of young people on the planet, began in a festive atmosphere in Sydney.

Curt Styres is believed to be the first individual American Indian — known in Canada as First Nations people — to own a major professional sports franchise.
Less than a year before its 60th anniversary, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is determined to revamp its image.

Kansas gave Coach Mark Mangino a raise and extended his contract two years, amending his deal to increase his compensation to $2.3 million a year. The contract runs through 2012. Mangino was The Associated Press Coach of the Year last season. The Jayhawks went 12-1, including a 24-21 victory over Virginia Tech in the Orange Bowl.

A judge in Greensboro, N.C., has sentenced the son of the North Carolina State basketball coach, Sidney Lowe, to 15 months in a prison farm on charges that include robbery and kidnapping. Superior Court Judge Henry Frye Jr. also ordered that Lowe serve five years of probation.

Red Bulls midfielder Claudio Reyna is expected to announce his retirement at a news conference Wednesday afternoon in Newark. Reyna, who has often been injured, has not played in a game for the Red Bulls since May 25 as he struggled with a back injury.

Danilo Gallinari sat out the Knicks’ practice Tuesday because of a sore back and is listed as questionable for Wednesday’s Summer League game in Las Vegas. Gallinari, the sixth pick in the June draft, hurt his back in his N.B.A. debut Monday in a collision with Cleveland’s Robert Traylor. The team does not consider the injury to be serious.

Ronaldinho, the Brazilian playmaker, was transferred to A.C. Milan late Tuesday. The team said Ronaldinho would arrive in Milan on Wednesday for a medical exam and to sign a contract through June 30, 2011.

Coming off the fastest elimination win in the history of the Meadowlands Pace, the undefeated Somebeachsomewhere was made the overwhelming favorite for this weekend’s $1.1 million race. Somebeachsomewhere, who will be driven by Paul MacDonell, was made the 2-5 favorite in the morning line to win his 11th straight race.
A warm-up jacket that Lou Gehrig likely wore the day he stopped playing in 1939 sold for $325,000 at an auction on Tuesday.
Blacks and whites hold vastly different views of Senator Barack Obama and the state of race relations, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

President Bush vetoed a bill protecting doctors from a Medicare pay cut, but both houses of Congress overrode the veto with large bipartisan majorities and made the bill a law.
Gov. David A. Paterson has tapped into a broad array of special-interest groups and casting aside the self-imposed fund-raising limits of his predecessor, Eliot Spitzer.

HENNING--Alison Peake, died on July 2nd of cancer at home in New Haven, CT. Beloved wife of the late Basil Duke Henning, Colgate Professor of English History and Master of Saybrook College at Yale University for 29 years. Born to Mr. and Mrs. William Woodhouse Peake in 1918 in Camden, SC. A graduate of Westover School and Smith College (Phi Beta Kappa.) A founder of the Smiffenpoofs at college. Sang with a quartet, the Magpies, for many years. Honorary member of the Yale Glee Club and the Whiffenpoofs. With her husband, she was the recipient of the Yale Medal for service to the University. For more than fifty years, the Hennings traveled to the U.K., principally London, where Professor Henning, a noted scholar of the Tudor and Stuart periods, was an editor of the History of Parliament Trust. She was a member of the Colony Club. She is survived by a daughter, Morgan Stebbins, of Providence, RI, two sons, William of Rumson, NJ and Cameron of New Haven, CT, and by grandchildren Rowland Stebbins, Alicia Peake Henning and Basil Duke Henning. Predeceased by her grandson Cameron Duke Stebbins and her three brothers, Robin, Cameron and David. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 20th at Battell Chapel, 300 College St., New Haven at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Westover School, Mimi Falsey, Director of Development, P.O. Box 847, Middlebury, CT 06762 or to the Cameron Stebbins Memorial Fund, Geoff Liggett, Director of Development, Pomfret School, 398 Pomfret St., Pomfret, CT 06258.

MALEKOS--Nick, passed away on July 10. A service will be held Saturday, July 19 at 7pm in the Ellington Room at Manhattan Plaza, 400 W. 43 St., 2nd Fl. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his honor to Actors' Equity Foundation, c/o Arne Gundersen, 165 W. 46 St., NYC, NY 10036.

LEE--Gayle K. RN, MHA of Larchmont, NY. A pioneer in hospice care and patient advocacy, Gayle founded the Cancer Support Team in 1978, the first hospice organization in NY and one of the first in the country. At a time when cancer care was focused on clinical treatment, Gayle helped revolutionize the treatment of cancer by providing psychological, emotional and spiritual support for patients and their families in their homes. Today, the Cancer Support Team is a thriving organization serving hundreds of cancer patients and their families throughout Westchester County every year. After graduating from Massachusetts General she met her future husband, John Lee, at the Newport Jazz Festival. They settled in Larchmont, NY and had a wonderful adventuresome life together. She is survived by her four children, Jocelyn, Lauren, John and Roger, her ten grandchildren and her partner Bob Williams. Her Memorial Service will take place on Thursday, July 17th at 10am at St. John's Episcopal Church, 4 Fountain Square, In Larchmont NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Cancer Support Team, 875 Mamaroneck Ave, Suite 204, Mamaroneck, NY, 10543. LEE--Gayle K. Gayle's many friends on Martha's Vineyard will miss her terribly. She was a very special person and a wonderful friend to all of us. We send our love and sympathy to her family.

He later retired and established DM Antiques. He is survived by his wife Mary Alice (nee) Cullen; children Anne, Charles, and Peter; and grandchildren Tamina and Sinclair.

DYNER--Richard, died July 13th, 2008. Devoted father to Peter, loving grandfather to Emily. Loyal friend to June and Larry Roth and Mimi Dyner. He had a wide range of friends: domestic and international. Memorial to be announced.

PBS, as you may have heard, is now in the animated sitcom business, and I can anticipate what you're going to say next: ''Oh, no, not another cartoon version of 'Lady Windermere's Fan.' '' Instead the network has pilfered from NPR, spinning the popular radio program ''Car Talk'' into a half-hour of television every Wednesday. The series is called ''Click & Clack's As the Wrench Turns,'' and stars graphically rendered versions of the famous Click & Clack brothers, Tom and Ray Magliozzi of Cambridge, Mass., who have been solving carburetor and girlfriend problems on their national radio program for over a decade. (Other titles the Magliozzis considered: ''Transmission Impossible'' and ''Ken Burns Presents Car Talk.'') The Magliozzis, with their distinctively nonpatrician Boston enunciations (nozzle is ''NAU-zel''), provide the voices, and from there the comedy flows. They could say ''exhaust fan'' and nothing else, and still you would feel inclined to laugh. A huge part of the radio show's appeal exists in the disconnect between how they talk and what they know -- both brothers, as their listeners all know, are graduates of M.I.T.

The prime minister offered to quit, having failed to broker a deal between the country's main linguistic groups. Yves Leterme, a Flemish Christian Democrat who took office in March, offered to resign after failing to meet a self-imposed deadline for agreement on a package of constitutional changes that included shifting more economic power to the regions. Belgium is divided between French speakers in the south and Flemish speakers in the north. It was unclear whether King Albert II would accept Mr. Leterme's resignation.

WALLACH--Myra K., age 90, beloved wife of Milton, passed in Delmar, NY on July 14. An attorney for the Legal Aid Society, a dynamic leader in community events and charities, Myra was the devoted mother of three daughters, eight grandchildren and a great-grandson.

ROTTENBERG--Jacob. Passed away on July 13, 2008 after a long illness. A Holocaust survivor, he came to the United States in 1950 with his wife Sonia and children Mark and Miriam. He founded a successful business and raised a family, like himself, committed to Torah, Tzedakah, and Jewish values. Loved and respected by so many, he his survived by his loving wife Sonia Rottenberg; his children Mark and Livia Rottenberg, and Miriam and Shopsy Kanarek; grandchildren Robin and Shlomo Weinstein, Ari and Robyn Rottenberg, Shimmy and Pnina Kanarek, and Chani Kanarek; great-grandchildren Izzy and Birkatia Ben Shlomo, Malka and Yisrael Lubitan, Moshe, Raffi, Burry and Avi Weinstein; Sheva, Yehuda, Azi, and Matan Rottenberg; Chaim, Yair, Yehoshua, Betzalel, and Yaffa Kanarek. His devotion and love will be remembered forever. His family and friends will miss him always. May his soul be bound up in the bonds of eternal life, and his memory blessed.

WASHINGTON -- The killing of 11 Pakistani paramilitary soldiers by American airstrikes last month might have been prevented if the precise location of a border checkpoint had been in an American database used to prevent accidental attacks on friendly forces, according to American and Pakistan officials. Had the grid coordinates of the post on the border with Afghanistan been in the database, red flags would have immediately gone up when allied troops called in airstrikes during a border clash with insurgents, American officials briefed on an investigation into the strikes said Tuesday.

LACCHIA--Madeline, of Valley Stream, NY, on July 14th, 2008 from ovarian cancer, age 62. Cherished wife of Carl Lacchia, loving mother of Paul Lacchia and Laura and David Rose, and adoring grandmother of Charlotte Elizabeth Rose.

It's really not a good idea to mess with Violet Weston, the fire-breathing dragon lady of Pawhuska, Okla., who presides over a feast of family combat in ''August: Osage County.'' As all who have seen Tracy Letts's celebrated comedy-drama on Broadway no doubt vividly recall, Violet does not brook much interference when it comes to indulging her favorite pastimes. Raise an objection to that eviscerating commentary on her daughter's looks and you are likely to find your own being mercilessly dissected. Delicately suggest that she refrain from airing the family's dirtiest laundry over dinner and you will be subjected to eyebrow-singeing bursts of invective.

An article on July 2 about an agreement by New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation to increase the monitoring of patients at a Brooklyn hospital's psychiatric ward after a videotape surfaced showing a patient collapsing on the floor and dying referred incorrectly to a lawsuit accusing the hospital of neglect. It is still pending in federal court; it has not been settled.

LEVINSON--Louis J., of Crestwood, NY. Passed away peacefully July 15, 2008 in his 100th year at his home of 63 years surrounded by family. Married for 70 years to his loving wife, Rose, who preceded him, he will be mourned by family including daughters Elsa Kleinman (Ira), Susan Zolov, Gigi (Keith Brubaker); his grandchildren, Michael Zolov (Liz), Karen Kleinman, Eric Zolov (Terri), Marni Fried (Kevin); and four precious great - grandsons, Noah, Toby, Jonah and Sascha. He was the last surviving member of five siblings. He and Rose met as students in 1927 at New York University and, marrying into the Quitman family, he helped to establish the Kwitman & Son textile business as a traveling salesman. They were early members of Genesis Hebrew Center in Tuckahoe, where he twice served as president; his curtain booth was a beloved fixture at the annual temple flea market. Avid golfers, they were charter members of Willow Ridge Country Club and traveled the world, always with a set of clubs in hand. A lover of words and verse, Lou was known to spontaneously recite poetry and Latin from his youth. He and Rose are together again. Memorial services 12pm Thursday, Shaarei Tikvah, 46 Fox Meadow Road, Scarsdale, NY.

Michelle Obama is sometimes compared to Jacqueline Kennedy, but she may now have something in common with another first lady, Eleanor Roosevelt. Mrs. Roosevelt became an honorary member of the Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority, a historically black organization founded in 1908, and the group announced this week at its centennial convention that Mrs. Obama had agreed to join. The sorority said that once Mrs. Obama was formally inducted into the organization, which has 225,000 members, she could not become a member of any of the other ''Divine Nine'' organizations, as black sororities and fraternities are often called. Other honorary members of Alpha Kappa Alpha include the poet Maya Angelou, the late Coretta Scott King and the former astronaut Mae Jemison.

Peyton Manning's streak of 160 consecutive starts does not appear in danger after a minor knee operation on Monday. But his medical problem -- an infected bursa sac in his left knee -- only adds to the long injury list the Indianapolis Colts will have when they open training camp July 25. Not only will Manning be unavailable, but so will defensive end Dwight Freeney, wide receiver Marvin Harrison and safety Bob Sanders, the N.F.L.'s defensive player of the year last season.

WASHINGTON -- A sense of economic gloom gripped Washington on Tuesday as President Bush urged Americans not to lose faith, the Federal Reserve chairman offered a mostly bleak assessment of the difficulties ahead for the economy, and the administration's latest effort to help the housing sector faced tough questioning in Congress. Despite widespread concern about losses suffered by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two giant housing finance companies, the Bush administration's call for quick passage of legislation to authorize the use of government funds to save them ran into heavy fire, especially among some Republicans concerned about taxpayer liability.

An article on Saturday about a dispute over rival cookbooks that both have recipes for concealing puréed vegetables in food for children contained outdated information about a lawyer who did not return calls on behalf of Jessica Seinfeld, author of ''Deceptively Delicious,'' who is being sued by Missy Chase Lapine, author of ''The Sneaky Chef.'' The lawyer, who was not identified, was no longer representing Ms. Seinfeld at the time he was asked to comment. (Her new lawyer, Orin Snyder, has since told The Times that he filed a motion on June 17 that argues for dismissal of the lawsuit on the grounds that it is ''opportunistic and baseless.'')

BALTIMORE -- When Barbara Terry fell behind on her mortgage payments earlier this year, she did the previously unthinkable. Through a local housing organization, she and her daughter, Imani, 9, rented part of their single-family house to a stranger. ''I had to do something,'' said Miss Terry, 46, who helps formerly homeless people move into new housing. ''I said, I am not going to lose this house. Thinking about having a stranger was not a pleasant thought. I have a daughter. But the positive part was that I needed extra help, and I wanted to help someone.''

He served in the US Navy during WWII and worked for Abraham & Strauss for 25 years before starting his own sportswear business. Loved by all who knew him for his quick wit and sense of humor. Commissioner Bud Selig said there was a possibility that instant replay would be used during the postseason. If Major League Baseball adopted instant replay, it would be used on fair and foul calls and for plays that happen over or near the outfield fence. ''Is there a chance?'' Selig said in a news conference before the game. ''The answer is yes, there's a chance, but we've got work to be done yet.''

GOLDHABER--Paul, D.D.S. New York University College of Dentistry records with sorrow the passing of its esteemed alumnus, Dr. Paul Goldhaber, Class of 1948. A giant in the field of dental education, Dr. Goldhaber served as Dean of the Harvard School of Dental Medicine from 1968 to 1990. His distinguished tenure as Dean at Harvard produced an array of innovations and enhancements, including the addition of a compulsory extra fifth year of dental school, during which students could elect either to do research or obtain an advanced degree; diversification of the student body; and establishment of a combined MD/DDS program in oral surgery together with Harvard Medical School. Dr. Goldhaber's impact as a researcher was equally impressive. His research in bone biology ushered in a new era in dentistry, enabling tooth implantation to become a routine dental procedure. One of a handful of truly transformational figures in 20th century dental education and research, Dr. Paul Goldhaber brought great distinction to his alma mater, which awarded him its Alumni Medal of Merit. The students, faculty, administration, and staff of the NYU College of Dentistry extend sincere condolences to the Goldhaber family. Charles N. Bertolami, D.D.S., DMedSc Herman Robert Fox Dean NYU College of Dentistry GOLDHABER--Paul, D.D.S., of Newton, MA, July 14, 2008. Beloved husband of Ethel Renee (Gurland). Loving father of Samuel Z. Goldhaber, M.D. and his wife Reeve of Brookline, MA and Joshua I. Goldhaber, M.D. and his wife Michelle Hamilton, M.D. of Los Angeles, CA. Cherished grandfather of Alissa, Benjamin, Nicole and Matthew. Dear brother of Stanley Goldhaber and his wife Shirley of New York and Norman Goldhaber and his wife Iris of Florida. Services at Congregation Mishkan Tefila, 300 Hammond Pond Parkway, Chestnut Hill, MA on Thursday, July, 17, at 11:00am. Interment to follow at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA. Memorial observance at the home of Dr. Samuel and Reeve Goldhaber following the burial through 9:00pm and Friday from 2:00-7:00pm. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Dr. Paul Goldhaber Fund at the Harvard School of Dental Medicine, 188 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA 02115. Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA, 617277-8300.

An article on Sunday about the history and growth of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two government-chartered mortgage companies, misstated their tax status. They are exempt from state and local taxes; they are not exempt from federal taxes.

Air pollution. Heat and humidity. Time zone changes. All have been cited as potential issues at next month's Beijing Olympics. And the fear is that any of them can throw a superior athlete into dissolution, allowing an inferior athlete to win a competition. But the truth, exercise physiologists say, is not always the same as conventional wisdom. Jet lag may have no effect on performance. Although Beijing's pollution can be a problem, the biggest drag on performance probably will come from the city's heat and humidity.

He said the department's database on these street stops was available to all in the National Archive of Criminal Justice Data.

SHAYON--Robert Lewis passed on Saturday, June 28. Born in New York City, August 15, 1912, he spent his career in media as a writer, producer, director for WORMutual, and CBS Radio where he worked with Edward R. Murrow and created You Are There. Shayon was the first television critic for the Christian Science Monitor and Saturday Review. He was Professor Emeritus at The Annenberg School for Communication, University of Pennsylvania-on the faculty from 1965 to 1990. His first wife of 47 years, Sheila Russell, passed on in 1983. He worked with her late mother, Frances Russell, an Australian opera singer, as a music/ lyrics team. He is survived by his wife, Nash Cox, Frankfort, KY, daughters, Diana and Sheila Shayon and three grandchildren, Kristyn and Keith Shayon and Leah Novak. A memorial service will be held in New York, September 20, 11am at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80th Street.

DeBAKEY--Dr. Michael, is celebrated by the Directors, staff and friends of the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation. Dr. DeBakey received the Lasker Award for Clinical Medical Research in 1963, now renamed the Lasker-DeBakey Award for Clinical Medical Research. For 30 years Dr. DeBakey chaired the Lasker Awards Jury, guiding the Foundation's Awards that honor outstanding researchers in medical science. Teaming with Mary Lasker, Dr. DeBakey generously lent his voice and resources to the campaign for strong public support of medical research. He saved thousands of lives, inspired generations of researchers and surgeons, and challenged public leaders to invest in basic and clinical research.

A few months ago, I went to hear Gloria Steinem speak. She said many memorable things, including this: If women were more willing to reveal their salaries to one another, they would make strides in eliminating the gender gap in wages. I think that's true for all of us interested in boosting our earning potential. Of course, we all know what we're worth to our employers or our investors by the amounts written on the checks they issue. But how many of us know what we are worth relative to others in the same or similar positions to us?

Arctic Ocean IceThe latest summary of experts' projections for this summer's retreat of sea ice on the Arctic Ocean is out, and -- partly because of different weather patterns than last year -- the consensus for the moment is that the remarkable ice loss in 2007 will not be matched this year. But all of the 15 teams offering projections say ice extent will remain well below the average for the last quarter century and a downward trend in summer ice around the North Pole has not abated. As I've discussed before, the sea ice around Antarctica in winter has been expanding of late (there's virtually none in the austral summer). The Antarctic sea-ice changes are consistent with expectations in a warming world, some experts say.) When both polar ocean ice sheaths are tracked together, this year is back below the quarter-century sea-ice average again.United States Climate ImpactsThe Bush administration's Climate Change Science Program has issued the detailed draft of its report on impacts of human-caused climate change and is now seeking public comments before the final version is produced later in the year. The straightforward descriptions stand in stark contrast to those in government reports on climate science earlier in President Bush's tenure, when Phil Cooney, the former head of the oil industry's "climate team," was the White House editor of such documents. At the time, the passage, "Warming will also cause reductions in mountain glaciers," was excised along with other passages described as "speculative findings/musings." Mr. Cooney moved on to Exxon Mobil.

It's easy to deride celebrity perfumes. Writing about his friendship with Robert Redford in The New Yorker, James Salter said that "when I went into restaurants with Redford, eyes turned to watch as we crossed the room - the glory seems to be yours as well." But celebrity came with a cost; Salter remembered Redford's saying of movies: "My presence in something is enough to give it an aura of artificiality." If people buy celebrity perfumes, it is precisely because the glory seems to be yours as well. Yet the celebrities don't make the perfumes; professional perfumers do. Celebrity inexorably lends an aura of artificiality, and not just to the celebrity scent; it extends to us as well. We are, at best, torn.The fact of the matter is that some celebrity perfumes are just as good as those from fashion designers. Others are better. We often forget that a designer's name on a scent is no more logical than that of a 20-year-old singer/actress. Before Gabrielle Chanel claimed perfume for fashion designers in 1921, it had been the exclusive territory of perfumers (see: Guerlain, Daltroff, Coty). If fragrance is now to be given to Hilary Duff - whose Wikipedia entry includes the music genre "bubblegum pop" - and her colleagues, so be it. Scents should be judged by the art form's standard criteria: structure, quality of the raw materials, persistence on skin and diffusion, innovation, beauty.

Kay Ryan has been named poet laureate of the United States, replacing Charles Simic. According to the website of the Library of Congress, the laureate is "the nation's official lightning rod for the poetic impulse of Americans," which sounds deliciously sordid and possibly painful, but mostly means that the laureate acts as Chief Diplomat for the Art. This could be a little tricky for Ryan, since she's responsible for perhaps the most hilariously skeptical article ever published about a writers' conference (although this one is pretty good too).

Regular readers of my column--and I mean really regular readers -- might recall that several years ago, I asked for nominations of good examples of business fiction written in the last 25 years. I promised to return to the subject in a future column once readers weighed in. This was a promise, alas, I failed to keep. Once I got the nominations, I bought many of the books, but there they sat, on the floor of my office, looking at me balefully for months, begging to be read. I just couldn't do it. Doug Coupland's brand of alienated-office-drone fiction didn't move me.

George Steinbrenner’s reign in New York coincides roughly with the lifespan of Yankee Stadium II, which for the most part, it bears noting, is not the same thing as the Yankee Stadium that figured so prominently in all the ceremonial foofaraw during Tuesday’s All-Star Game. The original stadium, as we learned over the long course of the evening, was erected around 2000 B.C. and for many years served as a sacred burial ground and an astronomical calendar. Oh, sorry. That’s Stonehenge. In any case, the Yankee Stadium of all those sepia-toned montages was the old Yankee Stadium, predating the extensive renovation in the mid-1970s. The old Yankee Stadium was a very different place. It did not have instant replay, Moonie weddings or Reggie Jackson.

The Jets signed cornerback Dwight Lowery, the team’s fourth-round pick. Lowery started all 25 games at cornerback in two seasons at San Jose State, with 13 interceptions, including a university-record 9 in 2006. The Jets have signed three of their six draft picks, with the first-rounders Vernon Gholston and Dustin Keller, and the fifth-rounder Erik Ainge, still unsigned. The Jets’ first training camp practice is July 24.

Terry Murray has been hired as the new coach of the Los Angeles Kings. A team spokesman said Murray would be introduced Thursday at a news conference. Murray coached the Philadelphia Flyers to the Stanley Cup finals 11 years ago. He has been an assistant coach with the Flyers since the 2003-4 season. Murray will succeed Marc Crawford, who was fired June 10 after two years on the job.

The former United States national team captain Claudio Reyna retired, less than two seasons after returning from Europe to join Major League Soccer’s Red Bulls. Reyna, who will turn 35 on Sunday, had been bothered by hamstring and back injuries this season that had limited his playing time. He said the injuries played a role in his decision. Reyna said he would stay with the Red Bulls in an advisory role, though he said details were still being worked out.

Jack Swarbrick, a lawyer who helped draw numerous sporting events to Indianapolis, including the 2012 Super Bowl, was named the athletic director at Notre Dame. He succeeds Kevin White, who left the university May 31 to become the athletic director at Duke. Swarbrick is a 1976 graduate of Notre Dame.

The Islanders agreed to terms with forwards Sean Bergenheim and Jeff Tambellini on two-year deals. Bergenheim’s deal is worth $1.725 million and Tambellini’s $1.175 million. Last season, Bergenheim played in 78 games with the Islanders and posted 10 goals and 12 assists. Tambellini, 24, led the Islanders’ Bridgeport affiliate with 38 goals and 38 assists in 57 games. An article last Thursday about designer sunglasses misstated the given name and misspelled the surname of an executive with a sunglass retailer. He is Rick Talmage, not Richard Talmadge. It also misidentified the company for which he is the chief operating officer. It is the Solstice Sunglass Boutique chain -- not Safilo, which is Solstice's parent company. Because of editing errors, the article also misstated two statistics provided by Marshal Cohen of the NPD Group, a market research firm. The average price of handbags has declined 14 percent over the last year; handbag sales did not decline 14 percent but, in fact, increased 6 percent for the first five months of this year compared with the same period in 2007. And the $3 billion figure for total sales over the last year referred to sunglasses, not the overall eyewear market. Finally, a picture caption with the article misstated the price of the Dior sunglasses shown. They are $275, not $345.

SOUTHPORT, England -- July winds, chilled and blowing at 30 miles an hour, are not cause for celebration in most places. But the northwest coast of England -- where July can be just a rumor -- is not most places. Here, the highest sand dunes on the British coastline have been formed by eons of such weather. On the eve of the 137th British Open, many bundled-up Britons traipsed through the dunes at Royal Birkdale Golf Club wearing cashmere, tweed, woolen stocking caps and big smiles. These hardies may be getting even giddier at 6:30 a.m. Thursday, when Craig Parry of Australia hits the opening tee shot, because the forecast is for rain to complement the winds off the Irish Sea.

DONNELLEY--Strachan . Sarah Lawrence College deeply mourns the loss of Strachan Donnelley, whose many contributions to the College community will be remembered for years to come. He served on the Board of Trustees from 1981-1989 and was named Honorary Trustee in 1994. One of the College's most generous benefactors, he supported student financial aid and the construction of new campus buildings, including the country's first LEED certified visual arts center. His passion and devotion to environmental ethics helped to inform and inspire his fellow Trustees, raising the College's environmental consciousness and commitment to sustainability. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Vivian, their five daughters, and his sister, alumna of the College and former trustee, Laura Donnelley. John A. Hill, Chairman of the Board Karen R. Lawrence, President DONNELLEY--Strachan. The Board and Staff of the Center for Humans and Nature are deeply saddened by the death of the Center's Founder and President, Strachan Donnelley, Ph.D. (1942-2008). Strachan combined several vocations as a writer, an educator, and a builder and supporter of organizations in service to the common good. He was at once a conservationist, philanthropist, and philosopher; and he was also a man of remarkable love, dedication, and care for his family, friends, and colleagues. Fly fishing and music were Strachan's passions and Verdi's Requiem, his anthem. He spent his life ardently pursuing an understanding of the appropriate relationships between humans and nature. He came to see humans as utterly dependent on nature and argued forcefully against setting human beings apart from the natural world. He drew many of his own insights not only from the life sciences but also from the study of the history of philosophy, and in particular his work with his mentor, Hans Jonas, at the Graduate Faculty of the New School for Social Research. After working for many years at The Hastings Center and serving as its second President from 1996-1999, Strachan founded the Center for Humans and Nature in 2003. He gave that organization the vision and financial support necessary to extend the work of collaboration and open intellectual exploration of fundamental ideas and values. We are grateful to him, have been graced by our association with him, and stand ready to carry on and extend the work he began. As a philanthropist Strachan supported numerous civic and educational organizations. He served on several boards of trustees, including those of the New School University, the University of Chicago, the American Museum of Natural History's Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago, the Yale Institute for Biospheric Studies, and the Land Institute. He also served on the Board of the foundation created by his parents, the Gaylord and Dorothy Donnelley Foundation, and was Chairman of the Board from 1992 to 2003. We extend our condolences to Strachan's wife Vivian; his five daughters, Inanna Donnelley, Naomi Donnelley, Aidan Donnelley Rowley, Ceara Donnelley Berry, and Tegan Donnelley, and five grandchildren; his brother, Elliott; sister Laura; and the rest of his family. A public memorial gathering will be held at the Art Institute of Chicago at 10am on Saturday July 19 and a second memorial gathering will be held in New York. Gerald Adelmann, Chairman Brooke Hecht, Acting President Center for Humans and Nature

''Cloud computing'' is a white-hot buzzword these days. It basically means working with files and programs that reside on the Internet, beyond your company's walls -- out there in the ''cloud.'' Everyday consumers are doing cloud computing, too, maybe without even realizing it. When you use an Internet-based backup service, or Google's online word processor or spreadsheet, or a Gmail or Yahoo mail account, you're working with data on a secure Internet server somewhere -- not on your hard drive.

Senator John McCain faced a quandary Wednesday when he addressed the N.A.A.C.P. in Cincinnati at the group's annual convention. Running against the first black to (presumably) win the presidential nomination of a major party, Mr. McCain came to praise Senator Barack Obama, not to bury him. And he did it in a humorous, self-deprecating way. The focus of Mr. McCain's speech was education. He endorsed a variety of ideas, including charter schools, some forms of school vouchers and greater autonomy for parents, teachers and principals. In a question-and-answer session after his remarks, he had a spirited exchange with a Head Start teacher about the financing and monitoring of that program.

BYARD--Paul Spencer . The Trustees, Officers and staff of The Green-Wood Cemetery mourn the passing of Paul Byard, a Trustee and good friend of the Cemetery since 2000. Paul's expertise in historic preservation and architectural design was a tremendous benefit to the Cemetery and its unique place in the history of the City of New York. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Paul's family. By Order of the Board of Trustees of The Green-Wood Cemetery BYARD--Paul S. The Board and Staff of The New York Landmarks Conservancy mourn the loss of our longtime Board Member and friend Paul Byard. Paul's skills as an architect and attorney were unique and instrumental in the Conservancy's early growth. His vision helped us obtain the then vacant former Federal Archives Building in Greenwich Village and find a private developer for the property. He also devised a pioneering revolving loan fund for preservation from the proceeds. The Historic Properties Fund has now loaned more than $18 million to more than 200 properties throughout the boroughs. Paul also challenged us to expand our view of what buildings and additions are appropriate in historic areas. We will miss is expertise, opinions and flair. Frank J. Sciame, Jr., Chair Peg Breen, President

KORTCHMAR--Michael , 64, of Southold, NY, passed away on Monday, July 14th at Peconic Bay Medical Center. A Swarthmore graduate, Mr. Kortchmar was a builder and restorer of wooden boats whose technical knowledge and problem-solving skills of all kinds greatly contributed to the maritime communities of the North Fork and NYC. He was the longtime captain of the schooner Pioneer in New York Harbor and an expert transatlantic sailor whose tales of seafaring adventures delighted many. He was a beloved member of the Recorder Orchestra of New York, a brilliant teacher, filmmaker and lover of words, who did the NYT diagramless and doublecrostic puzzles in a shamelessly short time. He and his family moved in 1989 from NYC to the North Fork, where he ran his boatbuilding shop in Greenports Sterling Harbor. The husband of Ellen Wiener, adoring father of Sophia and Samuel Kortchmar, brother to Daniel Kortchmar and wonderful friend to many, he will be dearly missed. A memorial service will held Friday, August 8th at 5pm at the Founders' Landing Wharf House in Southold.

BAKER--Anthony Kane , 65, of Palm Beach, FL, and Mill Neck, NY, on July 9, 2008. Son of George F. Baker, Jr. and Frances Drexel Munn Baker. Devoted father to Asia Alexandra and Callie Frances Victoria. Brother of the late George F. Baker III, Pauline Baker Pitt, Lavinia Baker Logan and Kane Kendall Baker. A graduate of Brooks School and Trinity College. He was a trustee of Brooks School, Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities, Society of the Four Arts, Quebec-Labrador Foundation and senior trustee of The George F. Baker Trust, a foundation established in 1942 by his grandfather that supports educational, medical and civic concerns. His great-grandfather, George F. Baker, helped found the First National Bank in New York City in 1863 and was instrumental in the establishment of the Harvard Business School and several university libraries including the Baker Library at Dartmouth College. He co-authored ''Long Island Country Houses and their Architects 1860-1940'' and was an authority on architectural preservation. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, July 22, at 3pm, at St. John's of Lattingtown Church, Locust Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made in his memory to Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities or to CARP, West Palm Beach, FL.

EHRENREICH--Dolores , nee Vanetti, died peacefully in her sleep at home on July 14 at the age of 96. She was the wife of the late Dr. Theodore Ehrenreich. A rare and wonderful woman, Dolores was a force in the intellectual and artistic millieu of pre-World War II France. Her life was an adventure lived to the fullest among the greats of the art world of the mid-20th century. She was a broadcast journalist during the war, speaking to the French from New York on the Voice of Free France. She wrote The Querulous Cook in 1963, and also contributed articles to Vogue. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. Services were held privately.

WOOLNER--James . It is with great sorrow that we announce the passing of our beloved longtime member and former Club President, James Woolner on July 15, 2008. Rosenberg, Secretary WOOLNER--Jim. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of Jewish Home Lifecare extend their heartfelt condolences to the family of our longtime Trustee, Jim Woolner. We mourn his passing, and feel a deep sense of loss which is only magnified by the recent passing of his dear wife, Trudy. Jim has been a Trustee since 1985, and served on the Jewish Home Lifecare System, Bronx and Sarah Neuman Boards. He was a longtime advocate for Senior Housing, and was passionate about communicating the benefits that Jewish Home Lifecare brings to the community. The ''Walk for What Matters,'' an event that Jim chaired annually since 1994, has raised over half a million dollars for Sarah Neuman. Everyone who worked with Jim could not help but be impressed by his tenacity, dedication and love for ''The Home.'' The life of every elder served by Jewish Home Lifecare has been enriched by his contributions. He will be missed by all. Gene D. Resnick, M.D. Chairman of the Board Audrey S. The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission designated several sites across the city as landmarks on Tuesday, including the former George G. Cunningham Store, a small, Queen Anne-style 1892 building in Tottenville, Staten Island. The commission's chairman, Robert B. Tierney, called it ''a rare example of 19th-century commercial construction.'' The commission also approved the creation of the West Chelsea Historic District, a collection of 30 buildings, built from 1885 to 1930, that were central to the city's role as a manufacturing center. The new district runs roughly from West 25th to 28th Street, between 10th to 12th Avenues. Finally Morningside Park in Manhattan, designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux and opened in 1895, was named the city's 10th scenic landmark.
