Merrill Lynch & Company, the financially ailing investment brokerage, has terminated talks with the Port Authority and the developer Larry A. Silverstein over moving its headquarters to one of the new office towers planned for ground zero. The company's decision is a major setback for the Port Authority and Mr. Silverstein, who had hoped to revive commercial interest in the 16-acre site by luring Merrill as an anchor tenant for one of the four office towers to be built there. Merrill was one of the first private companies to express strong interest in any of the towers. Concerns about stirring memories of 9/11 and the long-term noise and construction at the site have discouraged potential tenants, state officials say.

SCHLIFFER--Marcia , 91, died peacefully on July 16, 2008 in Stratford, NJ. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, aunt, and educator. She will be missed by her family and many others whose lives she touched with love and grace.

The musicians of the Columbus Symphony Orchestra, which has been on the edge of shutting down for lack of money, are standing by their music director. The orchestra's board of directors made what it called a last-ditch contract offer that reduced a previously proposed pay cut of 40 percent to 27 percent, The Columbus Dispatch reported on Tuesday. One of the conditions, though, would have been the firing of the music director, Junichi Hirokami, and using his salary for the extra pay, according to the Dispatch report, which was confirmed Wednesday by Tony Beadle, the orchestra's executive director. The musicians rejected the offer, though the two sides remain in mediation. Mr. Hirokami has been an outspoken critic of the board. Mr. Beadle has said that the conductor failed to spend enough time in Columbus to help with fund-raising or to tend to the orchestra. Some orchestra members countered that Mr. Beadle himself had not settled down in Columbus, maintaining his home and family in Boston. ''I'm here seven days a week,'' Mr. Beadle responded, saying that he returns on weekends only when there are no concerts, and that his family is in Boston for personal reasons. ''I don't think anybody would have seen less of me or more of me if my family were here,'' he said.

LONDON -- Every day, it seems, there are more victims. Shakilus Townsend, 16, stabbed to death by a masked gang. Ben Kinsella, also 16, fatally stabbed during an argument outside a pub. Victims in Bristol, Manchester and Glasgow. Four people fatally stabbed in London in one 24-hour period alone last week. In a country where few people have guns or access to them, a spate of knife attacks, many involving teenagers, has forced the issue to the top of the domestic agenda. The Metropolitan Police are so concerned, they said recently, they have made knife crime their top priority, along with terrorism. Government and law enforcement officials are scrambling to produce plans to allay public fears.

The managers were becoming antsy with each scoreless inning, the empty seats were multiplying with the outcome still in doubt and, most important, the pitchers left in the bullpens were dwindling. It was the final All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium, and it was the game that did not want to end. When Justin Morneau slid across the plate in the 15th inning and the umpire Derryl Cousins gave a demonstrative safe sign at 1:37 a.m. Wednesday, the American League had beaten the National League, 4-3. Again. There was excitement and relief throughout the Stadium, especially in the suite where Commissioner Bud Selig was sitting and no longer sweating.

LOS ANGELES -- ''Eddie doesn't walk,'' Lori Bogin, a publicist with VH1, said on Saturday, running down a list of who was to walk the red carpet, hours before the start of taping for ''VH1 Rock Honors: The Who.'' Eddie Vedder, the lead singer of Pearl Jam, would not; nor would Sean Penn, one of the evening's celebrity presenters. But walk, Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend, the surviving original members of the Who, would. Yet after 40 years and about 100 million records sold, the Who weren't exactly red-carpet naturals. Mr. Townshend, 63, seemed amused when photographers asked him to pose with Rainn Wilson, star of ''The Office.'' Mr. Daltrey, 64, sans an assistant, lugged his stage clothes in a plastic shopping bag. ''I carry my own bag,'' he told a reporter as he made his way.

Round Top, Tex. BUILDING a home, like getting married, is not for the faint of heart. It is a rare individual (or couple) who can manage the mix of high expectations, inexperience and a ballooning budget in service of a goal -- a home! -- so freighted with meaning, and come out unscathed.

FOIX, France -- The French police arrested a Spanish rider for the Barloworld team Wednesday morning after finding banned substances in his hotel room, which they raided after the rider, Moisés Dueñas Nevado, failed an antidoping test during the Tour de France. The Barloworld team announced on its Web site Wednesday afternoon that the police had found ''some banned medicines that were absolutely not supplied or prescribed by the team doctor'' in Dueñas Nevado's hotel room in Tarbes, where the team had spent the previous three nights.

Maybe it takes a strayed New Yorker to truly cherish New York City. Billy Joel, who was born in the Bronx and became the quintessential Long Island songwriter, was flanked by New York cityscapes and video backdrops on the Shea Stadium stage Wednesday night. It was the first of Mr. Joel's two ''Last Play at Shea'' shows, which are to be the final concerts there before it is demolished. Mr. Joel played to two kinds of local pride. ''This is where New York meets Long Island,'' he said with a smile. ''Queens -- politically, that's New York City. But geographically, we are on Long Island.'' In a three-hour concert dotted with guest stars, Mr. Joel hinted that a long pop career -- like his -- can parallel the life of a city, full of pleasures and disappointments, triumphs and mistakes, changes and tenacity.

Lil Wayne's ''Tha Carter III'' (Cash Money/Universal) topped this week's Billboard album chart for the third time, Nielsen SoundScan reported. It sold 125,000 copies, a 20 percent drop in sales from the previous week. For a second week Coldplay came in second with ''Viva La Vida or Death and All His Friends'' (Capitol) with 113,000 copies sold. The soundtrack to Disney's ''Camp Rock'' featuring the Jonas Brothers keeps the No. 3 spot with 88,000 copies. Beck's ''Modern Guilt'' (Interscope) sold 84,000 to debut at No. 4 while Kid Rock's ''Rock N Roll Jesus'' (Atlantic) climbs two spots to No. 5 with 61,000 copies. The soundtrack to the film ''Mamma Mia!'' (Decca), opening Friday, reached No. 7, 48,000 copies.

DETROIT -- Consumers used to buy small cars for a simple reason: they were cheap. A decade ago, many budget-minded shoppers turned down even options like air-conditioning, power windows and compact disc players to keep the price low. Now people of all income levels are buying small cars to pinch pennies at the gas pump, but they are not scrimping on creature comforts. Instead, they are spending hundreds or even thousands of dollars on options, like heated leather seats and high-end entertainment systems, usually found in luxury cars.

PHILADELPHIA POISON IVY is one of those weeds proliferating like mad as rising levels of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide heat up the atmosphere. Researchers at Duke University who studied the weed between 1999 and 2004 in a controlled forest area near Chapel Hill, N.C., where high levels of CO2 are pumped into test plots, found that poison ivy not only grew more vigorously, but also produced a more toxic form of urushiol, the resin that causes its rash.
Q.Is there a way to use garden ornaments without going overboard like my neighbors do?

When Thierry W. Despont, the Manhattan designer commissioned to renovate the Boca Raton Resort and Club, began work on the Palm Court, he had to enclose it so it could be used on inclement days. Still, he wanted to create the illusion that it was open to the sky, the way Addison Mizner, the architect of the 1926 building, had intended. ''I wanted to do something light and spacious with a modern vocabulary and with a modern technology,'' Mr. Despont said. The transparent ceiling he created, is made of Texlon ETFE, a material with multiple layers of plastic film; the steel structure supporting it was designed to recall palm trees.

ALBANY -- Senator Joseph L. Bruno, who led the State Senate for 14 years, has offered many reasons why he is leaving the Senate by the end of the week after a public career of four decades. Mr. Bruno, 79, has said that he wants to spend more time with his family, including a new great-granddaughter; and that he wants to return to the private sector (''I don't want to be in a not-for-profit,'' he said in a radio interview on Wednesday); and that he has wearied of the scrutiny accompanying a two-year federal investigation of his business interests.

It was barely five years ago when the word ''netroots'' first surfaced as a description of grass-roots activists who pushed their political agendas on the Internet, especially through blogs. Now the word is becoming a bona fide entry in the new edition of Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary, and the netroots are preparing for their third annual convention, starting on Thursday in Austin, Tex.

As chairman of the Senate Indian Affairs Committee, John McCain began hearings that helped bring down Jack Abramoff, the disgraced lobbyist who was the central figure in a political scandal that landed Mr. Abramoff in jail. Now, as Mr. McCain releases the names of hundreds of ''bundlers'' -- his top money collectors -- one person who popped up is Juan Carlos Benitez, a lawyer and lobbyist whom Mr. Abramoff had championed for a Bush administration post.

A SURPRISING number of appliances in the home need to be vented to the outside to get rid of toxic fumes. Venting is needed for any appliance that uses fire, including furnaces, hot water heaters, gas stoves, and clothes dryers. Fireplaces also need proper venting because of fumes created by burning wood or gas.
McMAHON--William . The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William McMahon, associated with The New York Times from September 1, 1966 until retiring on July 1, 2002.

Doctors operated successfully to remove a kidney from the conductor James Levine, right, on Tuesday after a cyst was discovered, his brother, Tom Levine, said in a statement released by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which declined to name the hospital. ''There were no unexpected incidents or surprises,'' the statement said, adding that a routine biopsy would be performed. The symphony had said earlier that the operation would be ''curative.'' Mr. Levine, who is music director of the Boston Symphony and Metropolitan Opera, will spend several days at the hospital and then recuperate at home, the statement said. Mr. Levine, 65, was forced to cancel the rest of his dates at the Tanglewood music festival.

Paterson, in his first major speech to a national audience since becoming governor of New York, said in an address in Cincinnati that even as black Americans rejoice about the possibility that Senator Barack Obama could become president, they cannot lose sight of the serious social and economic ills that plague their community and should remain mindful of the racism that still exists. “The gap between the haves and have-nots right in our own community is wider than it has ever been before,” Mr. Paterson told a crowd of thousands at the N.A.A.C.P.’s annual convention.

This blog is written by an Iraqi employee from Diyala Province. His name is withheld to protect his identity from militias who target journalists.

Well, we have no shortage of debate material, thanks to the couple of hundred Lab readers who responded to my request for evidence of bias against women scientists (and my column.). Thanks for your contributions. Let's start with Yolio's complaint that I was guilty of "intellectual dishonesty":
Citigroup is out of the doghouse at Deutsche Bank.
Garbage disposal company Republic Services rejected on Friday an unsolicited $6.19 billion takeover offer from rival Waste Management, saying it prefers an earlier deal with another suitor.

A broad analysis of childhood bullying and the link with suicide has found that it's not just the victims of bullying who are at risk. Bullies themselves also are more likely to have suicidal thoughts.

Joel Stein, writing in his column for The Los Angeles Times, is annoyed by comedians who think it's too hard to make fun of Barack Obama. He writes: "Really? They have an arsenal of jokes to use against a 71-year-old ex-POW cancer survivor and Obama is too touchy a subject?"
AUSTIN -- We're here in Texas, the site of dueling bloggers' conventions this weekend.

It's time for me to gush, once again, about Estate Romana -- the fabulous annual 2 month-long summer music festival that brings this normally sleepy city to life on warm summer evenings. For a city that is generally not the least bit diverse, the diversity of music during summer time makes your head spin. Each year there is more than the last, and each year it is more interesting.
The Associated Press reports:
Click this photo to watch a video interview of Seth Rogen.
If motorcycles generally get better mileage than cars, and if everyone is so concerned about the price of gasoline these days, why are motorcycle sales cratering instead of skyrocketing?

Financial industry executives are mustering on Capitol Hill to head off a Congressional effort to rewrite the rules for the nation's energy markets, The New York Times reports. They say it could unsettle already nervous markets and push more energy trading abroad, beyond the reach of domestic regulators.

The chief executive officer of mortgage finance giant Fannie Mae, Daniel Mudd, said on Thursday the company was unlikely to tap emergency credit measures that have been proposed for it by the Treasury department.

Banks' direct borrowing from the Federal Reserve at the discount window rose in the latest week, one of the most tumultuous weeks for the U.S. banking system in decades, Fed data showed on Thursday, according to Reuters.
John A. Thain never said that turning around Merrill Lynch would be easy. "We have not seen the bottom," he declared in December, when he took the reins of the troubled Wall Street giant.

Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage financing company, is considering raising capital by selling as much as $10 billion in new shares, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing undisclosed sources. The report comes as lawmakers debate a proposal from the U.S. Treasury and the Federal Reserve to aid Freddie Mac and its sister company, Fannie Mae.

Unions in 23 countries, led by the Service Employees International Union, took the the streets on Thursday to target the private equity industry and one of its largest representatives, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

Sex| A critic ponders why it's so stultifying to read a sex memoir in which a woman enlists her ex-lovers to reminisce about doing it. Possible answer from one lover who declined to dish details: "I'm not against sex, or even sexy stories. But it pales in comparison with the excitement of discovering what it means to be alive and under your own power." [thesmartset.com]
Bathed in the glow of the skyline's glitter, the centerpiece of Dubai's financial hub seems equal to the thrusting ambitions of the foreign investment bankers rushing to set up shop here.

Teva Pharmaceuticals Industries, the world's largest maker of generic drugs, confirmed Friday it would buy Barr Pharmaceuticals of New Jersey for about $7.5 billion in cash and stock. Early reports of such a deal sent shares of Barr soaring Thursday.

Perella Weinberg Partners' Xerion hedge fund rose 24 percent this year, Bloomberg News reported citing a letter sent to investors. The increase was helped by bets that the value of investment-grade bonds of financial-services firms would fall.

From Thursday's Sports Business Journal. I especially love the last line. Tell me again why any company should pay millions of dollars to be an Olympic sponsor when a clever marketer like Nike can link itself to the Olympics without paying a penny? For its (reported) $40 million a year to be an Olympic sponsor, Adidas gets the right to dress the officials in the Olympic Village. Whoop-ee!

Responding to pressure from fund managers and brokerages to clarify how new short-selling restrictions would work, the Securities and Exchange Commission said late Thursday it would grant some leniency to certain market makers, Reuters reported.
Samuel Israel III bilked his investors out of $250 million, but they are hoping to recoup some of their money from one of Wall Street's deepest pockets: Goldman Sachs.
Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson will deliver remarks on financial markets and the economy on Tuesday in New York, Reuters reported.

My colleague Felicity Barringer, who covers the environment for our National desk, has been tracking developments related to the White House fight with some Environmental Protection Agency officials over the need to restrict carbon dioxide. You may recall her story last month about how the White House refused to open an e-mail carrying the E.P.A. "finding" supporting CO2 restrictions. She sends this new dispatch:
The collapse of Paramount Pictures' and Deutsche Bank's $450 million film financing deal earlier this week underscores how dramatically the credit crisis is affecting Hollywood.

While the credit crisis may be wreaking havoc on Wall Street, some claim to have found an environmental upside: According to a study commissioned by Merrill DataSite, the crisis could mean a smaller carbon footprint from investment bankers.

Bumi Resources, an Indonesian coal miner, has won its battle to acquire Australia's Herald Resources, with a bid that values the target company at 563.5 million Australian dollars ($551 million). The final bid is 27 percent higher than Bumi's original offer, FinanceAsia reported.
The Spanish government broke European Union law by insisting that mergers in its energy sector be preapproved, the E.U.'s top court said Thursday.

Virtual experiences are becoming a thing of serious reality when it comes to raising venture capital these days. Citing data from Virtual Worlds Management, BusinessWeek reported that startups selling virtual goods and offering virtual experiences have raised $345 million in the first half of 2008.

The Qatar Investment Authority became the largest shareholder of Barclays, the British bank, after just 19 percent of Barclays' existing shareholders took part in a 4.5 billion pound ($9 billion) share sale.
Zentiva rejected Sanofi-Aventis's $2.02 billion-offer for the shares of the Czech generic-drug maker that it doesn't already own. Zentiva said the bid, made last week, was too low.

Real estate and infrastructure management sector saw private equity deals worth $2.32 billion in the first half of 2008, The Hindu Business Line reported. The figure is nearly three percent higher than the comparable period last year.

Faced with a federal investigation into its private banking practices, the Swiss banking giant UBS said on Thursday that it would stop offering offshore banking services to clients in the United States.
The window for HireRight to enter an alternative deal to its merger with U.S. Investigations Services is nearing its close, The Daily Deal reported.
Barrick Gold, the world's largest gold producer, raised its bid for the oil and natural gas explorer Cadence Energy by 13 percent to widen its advantage over a competing bid.
Bradford & Bingley shareholders approved the bank's 400 million pound ($799 million) rights issue at an extraordinary general meeting on Thursday, The Telegraph reported.
A year into the tight credit market, and the losses keep coming. The latest come from Citigroup, which said Friday morning that it lost $2.5 billion, or 0.54 cents a share, in the second quarter.

Arbel Medical, an Israeli start-up, has completed a $4.5 million second funding round, the company said in a press release. Arbel develops the next generation of medical equipment for removing tumors by freezing.
Housing slumps last:
China's Wind Information is planning an initial public offering to raise about 1 billion yuan ($147 million) to support expansion, Reuters reported.
Sava Senior Care is up for sale and could fetch more than $1 billion, The Daily Deal reported citing investment banking sources.
The winner and runner-up of a contest to come up with more "amazing Iranian technology created with Photoshop":
Senator Barack Obama has a tight-knit group of foreign policy aides supported by a huge 300-person bureaucracy, organized like a mini State Department.

Aired Thursday night on NBC: Reporters assigned to Barack Obama say that this week Obama has been working out like crazy at a gym and he's also been playing hours of basketball. Meanwhile, John McCain has joined a group of mall walkers.
Location: Lincoln, Neb.
If the insanely inventive and entertaining “Mad Detective” weren’t so weird -- and in Cantonese -- hordes of action geeks would be lining the block to see it.
Written and directed by Ric Roman Waugh, and filmed at the New Mexico State Penitentiary near Santa Fe, “Felon” is one of the most realistic prison films ever made.
A struggling anorexic and her physical opposite form an unlikely friendship in “disFIGURED,” a funny, awkward and often uncomfortable drama.

Costa Rica is the granddaddy of the Central America vacation home scene. It was attracting hordes of U.S. retirees with the promise of tropical paradise and sandy beaches in the Eighties, posting huge run-ups in prices long before Mexico, Panama and Belize started rolling out mass quantities of high-end resorts.
Everything is, for a good long while, very nice indeed in “Wonderful Town.”
“Transsiberian” is a handsomely remodeled variation of a cherished genre you might call the mystery-train movie.
If there is anything the cinema needed less than another angst-ridden, cross-cutting tragedy about crime, fate, memory and redemption, it’s the kind shot in an ugly monochromatic palette like “Take.”
Assembled without frills or fuss, “A Man Named Pearl” is as much a portrait of a small Southern town as of an unassuming black folk artist.
You can have a perfectly nice time watching this spirited adaptation of the popular stage musical and, once the hangover wears off, acknowledge just how bad it is.
Pitched at the divide between art and industry, poetry and entertainment, “The Dark Knight” goes darker and deeper than any Hollywood movie of its comic-book kind.
In keeping with the grandeur of its title, “The Human Condition” is anything but modest in scope and ambition.
“A Very British Gangster” plays less like a documentary than an E! exposé of lowlife skulduggery.
“Before I Forget” is an unblinking portrait of a complicated, solitary gay man who has outlived his working years.
“The Doorman,” a mockumentary about the people who run Manhattan nightlife, has solid-gold satire at its cocaine-stained fingertips.
Journalism is all about having the courage to write the truth even if it will get you mocked by your relatives and co-workers, so here goes: “Space Chimps” is hilarious.
In Julian Schnabel’s grimly majestic concert film “Lou Reed’s Berlin,” Mr. Reed wears the deadpan smirk of a Zen master who has endured punishing Buddhist training.
Marquee-name playwrights, directors and actors lend an air of glamour, fill the houses and help keep the bills paid at the main stages at these Massachusetts festivals.
The Modern makes a convincing case that prefabricated housing was both a central theme of Modernist history and a dream that remains very much alive today.
A show at the Sackler Gallery in Washington showcases 82 rarely seen paintings commissioned by Mughal emperors.
Four workers were killed and six injured when a crane collapsed on Friday during routine maintenance at a chemical plant.
Ms. Stafford was the wistful singing voice of the American home front during World War II and the Korean War.
With just six months left before a new president takes over, the White House is looking more and more like a baseball team reaching deep into its bench.
A police officer responding to a complaint about a dispute on a quiet block of the Upper East Side shot and killed a man on Thursday night, the authorities said.
Most Japanese stocks fell on Friday, led by oil explorers after crude prices fell to a one-month low.
A two-run homer in the ninth rallied the Mets to their 10th straight victory Thursday night and moved New York back into first place in the National League East.
Starbucks said that 11 of the 600 coffee shops it planned to shut by mid-2009 would be in New York City, which would leave New Yorkers with 225 Starbucks to choose from.
The Yankees have reached a preliminary agreement with Richie Sexson, and hope he can help them against left-handed pitchers.
The Liberty moved three games above .500 for the first time since it was 6-3 last year, and won its fifth straight at home to improve to 8-2 at Madison Square Garden.
BP said that it had agreed to buy 90,000 acres of natural gas properties in Oklahoma from the Chesapeake Energy Corporation for $1.75 billion.
Fending off a last-ditch protest from within the church, Southern Methodist University received final approval to house the George W. Bush Library complex.
Another defendant has pleaded guilty to charges stemming from the torture of a young black woman held captive in West Virginia last summer.
A worker for a Roman Catholic organization in Richmond who signed a consent form allowing a 16-year-old Guatemalan foster child to receive an abortion last winter will not face prosecution.
A sinkhole shut down the northbound lanes of the Pasadena Freeway for hours as transportation workers rushed to repair the chasm.
State overseers of the Big Dig highway project in Boston said total costs of the project would reach $22 billion, nearly 50 percent higher than the most recent public estimate.
A jury convicted two Nashville brothers who are members of the Kurdish Pride gang in the attempted murder of a man accused of being a drug dealer.
Groupe Eurotunnel, which operates of the undersea rail link between England and France, said first-half profit rose as traffic increased on passenger trains and its vehicle-carrying shuttle service.
The drug maker Novartis reported a 17 percent increase in net income for the second quarter, helped by recent acquisitions and strong sales.

Electrolux, the European appliance maker, reported second-quarter profit that missed analysts’ estimates and reduced its full-year earnings forecast after sales declined in the United States and Europe.
The French government issued a decree allowing for the privatization of Gaz de France, enabling the utility to merge with Suez and form one of the largest utilities in the world.
The Barrick Gold Corporation, the world’s largest gold producer, raised its bid for the oil and natural gas explorer Cadence Energy by 13 percent to widen its advantage over a competing bid.
L’Oréal, the cosmetics maker, said 2008 sales would be lower than it projected after second-quarter growth was the slowest in more than three years.
A cruise ship with 67 safety problems found by inspectors was allowed to leave New York, but only to sail to Tampa, Fla., to be repaired, a Coast Guard spokeswoman said.
In one of the worst All-Star Games by a second baseman, Dan Uggla made a record three errors, going 0 for 4 with three strikeouts and grounding into a double play.
The Amagansett Farmers Market, a fixture on eastern Long Island, will be operated by Eli Zabar, the youngest of the three Zabar brothers.
Even in the sort of place that The New Yorker’s founder considered a cultural backwater, a much-dissected cover illustration of Barack Obama was recognized as satire.
Theresa A. Mari is a childless children’s advocate, the law guardian who tried to close the courtroom at the Christie Brinkley v. Peter Cook divorce trial to spare their children the details.

With the Karachi Stock Exchange suffering through its worst losing run in at least 18 years, investors are taking to the streets to show their anger at the new government.
After aggravating a right groin injury last week, Pedro Martínez will miss his scheduled start here against the Reds on Sunday.
An 8-month-old Pakistani girl has tested positive for polio in an area where militants have opposed vaccination, a World Health Organization official said.
A French flight attendant will become one of Europe’s pioneer space tourists after she found a winning number in a lottery to fly to the upper reaches of the Earth’s atmosphere.
Morocco plans to send scores of moderate Muslim clerics to Europe in September in the holy month of Ramadan to help fight extremism among Moroccans abroad.
The commander of the police unit that investigates organized crime and kidnapping in Coahuila State was himself kidnapped on Monday.
Kuwait named its first ambassador to Iraq since the Persian Gulf war in 1991, a step toward reconciliation between the countries.
Financial industry executives say that a Congressional effort to rewrite the rules for the nation’s energy markets could unsettle already nervous markets and push more energy trading abroad.
Talks to resolve Zimbabwe’s political crisis have stalled after the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, declined to sign a framework for negotiations, the opposition party said.
The investigation found that people awaiting trial at the Cook County Jail have endured inadequate medical care, beatings at the hands of jail workers and dangerous building conditions.
Shoddy work by private contractors is causing more deaths and injuries on U.S. military bases in Iraq than previously acknowledged, according to documents.

A map accompanying an Op-Ed article on the Fourth of July, about the Declaration of Independence, misstated the location of one of the earliest copies of the document. The copy in Dallas is housed at the Dallas Public Library, not City Hall.

The welterweight Oscar Diaz spent Wednesday night in surgery for bleeding on the brain and is in a coma after collapsing between rounds of a nationally televised bout in his hometown, San Antonio. The 25-year-old Diaz was taking a beating from Delvin Rodriguez at Municipal Auditorium when he collapsed on his stool entering the 11th round.

Venus Williams, Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova are among the five past United States Open women’s champions in the tournament field announced Thursday. Lindsay Davenport and Svetlana Kuznetsova are the other previous winners entered in the hard-court Grand Slam tournament, which begins Aug. 25 at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens. Top-ranked Ana Ivanovic, the reigning French Open champion, heads a group that includes 99 of the top 100 women in the rankings.
The finding is a step toward forcing property owners to sell their land as part of eminent domain proceedings to make way for the expansion of Columbia University.
The Boston Red Sox slugger David Ortiz homered in his rehabilitation debut in the minors.

Christina Kim shot a nine-under-par 63 Thursday to take a one-stroke lead at the State Farm Classic in Springfield, Ill. Kim who has two career wins and 30 top-10 finishes, had seven birdies and an eagle, and no bogeys. There were many low scores, including a 67 from Michelle Wie that was her best of the year. Wie was playing on a sponsor’s exemption. The South Korean Sun Young Yoo finished a stroke behind Kim at 64.

Autopsy results show a University of Central Florida football player who died after spring drills had a pre-existing medical condition worsened by physical stress. The Orange County Medical Examiner’s Office said Thursday that the player, Ereck Plancher had a sickle cell trait that caused problems with his red blood cells during physical exertion. Plancher, 19, collapsed in March, the day before spring practice was to begin.
Cleveland Browns wide receiver Joe Jurevicius likely will miss the start of the regular season because of his recent knee surgery.

A former women’s basketball coach who sued Fresno State for sex discrimination said she had been hired as the general manager of a minor league professional men’s team — and she is negotiating a movie deal. The coach, Stacy Johnson-Klein, will begin her new job with the Lawton Fort Sill Cavalry, the Continental Basketball Association’s champion, on Friday. She reached a $9 million settlement with Fresno State last month.
Second-quarter profit rose 11 percent at the conglomerate United Technologies on brisk business at Otis elevator and strong orders for its Carrier air-conditioners.
Some doctors are hailing surgery for centenarians, but others say such procedures can be wasteful and barbaric.

The N.H.L. released the season’s schedule under its new alignment. Teams will meet each team in its division six times instead of eight, and every team will play each other.
Quarterly net income soared 29 percent at the online brokerage firm TD Ameritrade Holding because of growth in the number of trades handled and in asset-based revenue.

The CIT Group posted a $2.1 billion quarterly loss after selling assets at a loss, but the company’s shares surged after it said it could meet its cash needs through the end of next year.
Mattel won a nearly complete victory in its federal copyright infringement case against a rival over which toy maker owns the original drawings for the Bratz fashion doll franchise.
Seven New Jersey troopers who were suspended after a woman claimed she had been raped at one of their homes will not be charged with a crime, a prosecutor said on Thursday.

DONNELLEY--Strachan . The Trustees and staff of the National Humanities Center are deeply saddened by the death of Strachan Donnelley on July 12. Donnelley joined the Board of the National Humanities Center in 1993 and served as a trustee until his retirement from the Board in 2003, when he was elected Trustee Emeritus. In 2006 he and his wife Vivian permanently endowed the Donnelley Family Fellowship, which is awarded annually to a scholar working at the intersection of nature, the environment, and the humanities. All who knew Strachan Donnelly at the National Humanities Center will remember with gratitude and admiration his friendship and generosity. Carl H. Pforzheimer III, Chairman Geoffrey G. Harpham, President and Director of the National Humanities Center

FOR CHILDREN ACT YOUR AGE: PLAYS THAT GROW ON YOU (Friday through Sunday) Despite the title, the 9-to-18-year-old participants in this series of one-acts are having an experience extraordinary for people their age: they are starring in mini-musicals written expressly for them by adult theater professionals. The creative partnerships are a result of the One-on-One program, part of the 52nd Street Project, which provides theater opportunities for disadvantaged youth in the Clinton neighborhood. Most shows have a cast of two: the child and his or her mentor. Friday and Saturday at 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m.; Theater 3, 311 West 43rd Street, third floor, Clinton, 52project.org. Free, but reservations required: (212) 642-5052.

SCHATZ--Caryn . The partners of Prager and Fenton extend their deepest sympathies to the family of Caryn Schatz, a partner in the firm's New York office and a trusted advisor to many clients for more than thirty years. She will be greatly missed and always remembered.

It may be the blogosphere's equivalent of the scarlet letter, and the organizers of Netroots Nation, a gathering of liberal bloggers taking place this week, want to pin it on Fox News. Planners of the conference would like to force representatives of the cable news network to wear credentials identifying them as ''opinion media'' rather than provide them with the regular press passes that other news outlets will receive.

WEISBEIN--Ann (nee Levin) , died at the age of 101 on July 16th, 2008 at her home in Hollywood, FL. Cherished wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of the late Eugene (Diane) Weisbein and Roberta (Arthur) Lewis, proud grandmother of Michael and Robert Weisbein, Allison Sisun and John Lewis, and great-grandmother of six. Beloved sister of Jack Levin, Arthur Levin, Peggy Keller and the late Irving Levin. In 1954 Ann and Sam built the Driftwood Motel in Amagansett which they operated for nearly 30 years. Ann developed lifelong friendships with her guests who marveled at her stamina and wit, her love and devotion to Sam, and the military precision with which she operated the Driftwood. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends. Services Sunday July 20th, 2008 at Mount Ararat Cemetery 11:15am graveside.
A MAN NAMED PEARL Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

WOOLNER--James L. ''The greatest generation'' has lost another of its preeminent members. Jim died peacefully in his sleep on Tuesday, July 15, 2008, at age 88. We mourn his passing, which is magnified by the recent passing of his beloved wife Trudy of 63 years. Devoted father of Jim Jr., deceased in 1998, Dan, Steve and his wife Andrea and their son James Thomas, loving brother of Mary W. Kaufman and Dr. William R. Woolner, fond uncle of his brother's and sister's children and grandchildren. A graduate of Horace Mann and Yale University, 1941, he was in the Army four and a half years, commanded a Battery of Artillery in the 95th Infantry Division through training and in combat across Europe in 1944/45 in Patton's Third Army, was decorated in action and emerged as a Major with four Battle Stars. He was a Pioneer in the Ski Industry as President of Beconta Inc., served on the Ski Industry Board for 25 years and held almost every office, including two terms as President. He was an active member of Fairview Country Club for over 70 years, chaired its Golf, Green and Admissions Committees prior to three terms as President. He was on the Board of Governors of the Jewish Home and Hospital Lifecare System for over 20 years and also on the Regional Boards of its two Campuses, Sarah Neuman Center and the Weinberg Campus in the Bronx, where he served actively on several committees. He was honored by UJA/Federation in 2004 for ''A Lifetime of Community Service''. Funeral services for Jim will be held on Tuesday, July 22nd at 11:00am at Temple Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave, Rye, New York. (914967-4382)

This 5,277-square-foot house was built in 1807. It is within walking distance of Le Chateau Frontenac, a Quebec City landmark and one of the nation's premier hotels. It is also near all of Old Town's amenities, including its many terrace cafes, and the newly constructed Promenade Samuel de Champlain, which provides access to the shores of the St. Lawrence River. The house, which includes an attached stable that has been turned into a garage, has been fully restored. It has had only three owners in its history. The property shares its original stone-walled yard with an Ursuline convent and has views of the convent's French gardens from its upper levels. The restored interior includes marble fireplaces, hardwood floors and arched doorways, as well as deep windows and hand-carved woodwork. There are seven bathrooms and three balconies and a terrace on the upper level. Taxes: 9,727 Canadian dollars. Listing agent: Cyrille Girard, Sotheby's International Realty Quebec, Quebec City, (418) 264-2809; www.cyrillegirard.com.

Aboard their three-wheel Piaggio MP3 500 scooters, Bernard Rosenbaum, 71, and Bob Chase, 72, pulled into Times Square on Monday morning, ending a monthlong trip along the route of the old Lincoln Highway, the nation's first transcontinental highway, mostly constructed in the 1910s. Starting on June 13 and using the book ''Greetings From the Lincoln Highway,'' by Brian Butko, as their guide, the two men rode from the highway's western terminus in Lincoln Park in San Francisco to its eastern terminus at Times Square.

Armed with buckets of silver paint and rollers, local officials and community leaders were in East Harlem on Wednesday morning to paint over a mural depicting a cartoon rat with a noose around its neck and a sign that said, ''Stop snitchin'.'' The slogan, which some say promotes a culture of silence when it comes to giving police information about crimes, will not be tolerated, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, said in front of the wall at East 111th Street.

GAST--Diana Levitow , died peacefully on July 16, 2008 in the comfort of her home of 54 years in Westfield, NJ. Bom September 22, 1919 in New York City to Esther Ricklan Levitow and Bernhard Levitow, Diana was raised in Kew Gardens, Queens and then moved to Manhattan as a young adult. A lifelong collector and patron of the visual and performing arts, Diana volunteered at the Newark Museum in New Jersey and the Heard Museum in Phoenix, AZ. She worked as an interior designer with Dorothy Ginsberg & Associates in Metuchen, NJ. She was preceded in death by ber husbands Leslie Sobo and Harold N. Gast, and her sister Miriam Epstein. She is survived by her three children: David Sobo Gast of San Francisco, CA, Barbara Sabo Gast of Blodget, Oregon, and Sara Faith Gast and her husband Stephen Fabrico of Bloomington, NY. She also leaves behind her cherished grandchildren: Hillary Gast Fabrico, Anna Leslie Gast, Michael Joseph Gast, and Samuel H.N. Gast, and her sister Sally Harlow and her husband Chester. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, July 20, 2008 at 5pm at Temple Emanuel in Westfield, NJ. The family requests contributions be made to tile Newark Museum, Newark, NJ or the Heard Museum, Phoenix, AZ.

HAFERLING--Bella , died peacefully in her sleep at home on July 17th, 2008 at the age of 94. Devoted wife of the late Abraham, beloved mother of Marilyn (Judah), Paul (Carole) and Estelle Haferling. Grandmother of four and great-grandmother of twelve. A talented cook, baker, nature lover and feisty lady. Services at Sinai Chapels, 10am, July 18th, 2008 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY. 718-445-0300.

VICTORIAN GARDENS AND ASTROLAND AMUSEMENT PARK New York may never sleep, but it certainly gets sluggish this time of year. Yes, we know, there's the Siren Festival, Warm-Up at P.S. 1, Central Park SummerStage and countless other chances to test the impact of alcohol consumption and sweating like a hog on your hydration. Those of us not fortunate enough to be on vacation make the most of these grown-up versions of amusement parks, lining up for concerts instead of stomach-scrambling rides. Well, there's no need to simply make do. What best captures the spirit of summers past is a trip to an actual amusement park. Fortunately two bite-size ones are reachable by subway.

The Hall of Famer's son, 13 years old and over 6 feet tall and with a strikingly familiar face, shagged flies in the Home Run Derby on Monday night at Yankee Stadium. He rode in the Sixth Avenue parade of baseball legends and heard fans call out his father's name, which happens to be his name, too. He went into the Yankees' clubhouse and was shown where the old man dressed. ''He wasn't born when I played here,'' Dave Winfield said of his son, David II. ''But he got a chance to see firsthand that I was part of the place, part of the Yankee fabric, and that made me happy.''

'CINDERELLA' She doesn't lose her mother. She doesn't lose a glass slipper. She doesn't even lose her dignity: no rags, no chores, no sleeping in the fireplace ashes. Dignity may be the chief trait of this Cinderella, heroine of a modern-dress production from Youth on Target, whose publicity material says it draws on Italian traditions. Yet this whimsical, partly improvised retelling seems most suited for the era of ''Sex and the City.'' (Don't worry; no traces of Samantha.) The Fairy Godmother (Sierra Marcks) narrates in a Carrie-esque voice-over, introducing Cinderella's mother (Christina Zagarino), a newly widowed careerist who is the Prince's assistant, and her older daughters, Margaret (Caitlin Heibach) and Gertrude (Sarah Bellantoni). They're not mean to Cinderella (Isabel Steuble-Johnson, also the director), just mystified by her lack of interest in fashion, makeovers and the Prince. (Above, from left, Ms. Steuble-Johnson, Ms. Heibach, Ms. Marcks and Ms. Bellantoni.)

Images from ''Muraqqa: Imperial Mughal Albums from the Chester Beatty Library, Dublin'' at the Smithsonian Institution. ''Muraqqa'' refers to a luxury object from the Mughal empire in India, and this exhibit involves a patchwork of imagery. nytimes.com/design

To the Editor: ''All Grown Up, and Glad to Drop By'' (July 11) brought a knowing smile to my face. During her teen years, my daughter had to be literally dragged kicking and screaming to spend weekends at our country house in the Pocono Mountains of Pennsylvania. However, I now get a phone call or text message from her every March 1 requesting (more like begging) that the house be reopened for the season. We usually compromise on a date in April as I do not come up north until some time in June. She spends most weekends there either alone or with a friend in tow. And always with her laundry. STACEY LICHTMAN Hawley, Pa.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- American Special Forces troops and Afghan commandos killed two influential tribal leaders and a number of their followers in western Afghanistan in a joint airborne operation on Wednesday night, military officials said Thursday. But as with some previous operations, there were differing accounts over whether the strike also killed Afghan civilians. NATO and the Afghan Ministry of Defense declared that the tribal leaders were high-priority Taliban targets and that the operation against them was successful. In a statement from its press office in Kabul, NATO said there was no evidence of civilian casualties.

Senator Barack Obama is known for his diligent attendance at the gym, but when reporters followed him for three trips to Chicago fitness centers in one day, up cropped speculation that these workouts were not exactly physical -- the only people sweating were potential vice-presidential candidates in the hot seat. On Wednesday morning, Mr. Obama went to his former driver's luxury apartment building to use its gym, as he has done before. Then he campaigned in Indiana before returning to his friend's building for another gym visit. Then, that evening, he appeared at his usual basketball site, the East Bank Club.

This two-story, 1,076-square-foot condominium is in an 1850s building on a quiet, narrow street close to the St. Lawrence River and the shops, cafes and restaurants of Quebec City's Old Town. It was fully restored and renovated about 10 years ago. On the upper floor is the dining room, kitchen, a living room and a half-bathroom. From this level, there is an entrance to a small garden area in the back. On the lower floor are two bedrooms and a full bathroom. There is an exposed fieldstone wall, original to the building, in the open dining and living area, and there is a wood-burning fireplace. There are hardwood floors throughout except in the bathrooms, where the floors are ceramic. The building has only one other condominium unit. Taxes: 1,600 Canadian dollars, about the same in United States dollars. Listing agent: Danielle Themens, Themens Real Estate, (418) 353-3456; www.daniellethemens.com.

BYARD--Paul Spencer . The Trustees, Officers and staff of The Green-Wood Cemetery mourn the passing of Paul Byard, a Trustee and good friend of the Cemetery since 2000. Paul's expertise in historic preservation and architectural design was a tremendous benefit to the Cemetery and its unique place in the history of the City of New York. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Paul's family. By Order of the Board of Trustees of The Green-Wood Cemetery BYARD--Paul Spencer. The board and staff of The Architectural League of New York mourn the death of our colleague, mentor and good friend, Paul Spencer Byard. Paul was passionate about the art of architecture and its profound significance as the expression of the ethos and values of society. He led the Architectural League as president from 1989 to 1995, and served on its board for more than 30 years. Paul helped us think through difficult issues and, often, with his characteristic and very particular eloquence and wit, he made us laugh. He enthusiastically encouraged and supported young architects and students. Paul brought fresh and provocative thinking to the field of historic preservation and its pedagogy through his teaching and writing. Paul loved words and music as much as architecture; he was vivid, optimistic, indefatigable. We will miss him terribly. Rosalie Genevro, Executive Director Calvin Tsao, President The Architectural League of New York BYARD--Paul Spencer. The architects and staff of Platt Byard Dovell White mourn the death of Paul Spencer Byard, architect, teacher, colleague, and friend. Charles A. Platt Ray H. Dovell Samuel G. White

WATERMAN--Faith D. , died peacefully on July 15, 2008 at age 102 at her home. Beloved and loving sister of John J. Waterman, Arthur Waterman, Jr., and Doris W. Neu, all of whom predeceased her. Treasured sister-in-law of the late Hugo Neu. Adored aunt of John L. Neu (Wendy), Richard W. Neu, and Karen W. Shorter. Cherished grandaunt of Jeffrey P. Neu (Amy Kramer), Robert T. Neu (Francine), Steven W. Neu, and Amy Scheman-Neu (Daniel). Special great-grandaunt of Chloe, Olivia, and Spencer Neu, and Abigail Scheman. Faith was an intelligent and cultured woman whose forceful personality and interest in people made her an unforgettable friend and family member. A lover of the arts with a passion for knowledge, and a wide circle of friends throughout the world, she held a variety of interesting positions, including personal assistant to Margaret Truman and to the noted journalist, Dorothy Thompson, and staff member of the Andre Seligmann Gallery. We will feel her loss greatly but celebrate her long, full and joyful life. Friends and family may call at Centolire Restaurant, 1167 Madison Ave at 86th Street, on Monday, July 21, from 5:30-7pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Memorial Scholarship Fund at Colby College, 4345 Mayflower Hill, Waterville, ME 04901.

Jesus and the Leper, Mark 1:40-47... 40 And there came a leper to him, beseeching him, and kneeling down to him, and saying unto him, if though wilt, thou canst make me clean. 41 And Jesus, moved with compassion, put forth his hand, and saith unto him, I will; dost thou have insurance? 42 And the leper saith unto him, Yes. I have Empire Blue Cross. 43 And Jesus asked of the leper, Dost thou have the P.P.O. or the H.M.O.? 44 And the leper saith unto him, I have the H.M.O. 45 And Jesus saith unto him, I am sorry, my child, but heal you I cannot, for I only accept Empire Blue Cross's P.P.O. plan. 46 And the leper wept, but Jesus saith unto him, Perhaps another messiah will be along who accepts your plan. 47 And he sent the leper away from him.

As I write these words there is a game of poker going on in the Force India motor home a few short steps away from the media center in the paddock. Last year I wrote a story about chess and Formula One and I found that there was a small trend in the paddock of people playing backgammon - of all things. Now the paddock has found its real game of the moment. For several races now, a group of drivers has been meeting to play a private game of poker on the second floor of the Force India motor home in complete private, away from the media.

HUFFINGTON--Roy Michael, died Friday, the 11th of July 2008, in Venice, Italy, while on holiday. He was 90. He is survived by his son, Michael Huffington; his daughter, Terry Huffington; his son-in-law, Ralph Dittman; his granddaughters, Christina and Isabella Huffington and Sydney and Lindsay Dittman; his brother - in - law, William Gough; and numerous nieces and nephews. His wife of 58 years, the late Phyllis Huffington, predeceased him in 2003. A more detailed and specific obituary was previously published in Tuesday's edition of The Houston Chronicle; accordingly, this abbreviated notice serves to announce the services. Friends are cordially invited to a visitation with the family from four o'clock in the afternoon until seven o'clock in the evening on Sunday, the 20th of July, in the Library of Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, 1010 Bering Drive in Houston. The memorial service will be conducted at eleven o'clock in the morning on Monday, the 21st of July, in the sanctuary of Memorial Drive Presbyterian Church, 11612 Memorial Drive in Houston, where the Rev. Dr. David Peterson, Pastor, will serve as the lead officiant. Immediately following the service, all are invited to join the family for a reception in the adjacent narthex of the church. Services in Houston are entrusted to Geo. H. Lewis & Sons The Funeral Directors Since 1936, 713.789.3005. In lieu of usual remembrances, contributions in memory of Mr. Roy M. Huffington may be directed to the Huffington Center on Aging at Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, N320, Houston, TX 77030.

BYARD--Paul Spencer. The board and staff of The Architectural League of New York mourn the death of our colleague, mentor and good friend, Paul Spencer Byard. Paul was passionate about the art of architecture and its profound significance as the expression of the ethos and values of society. He led the Architectural League as president from 1989 to 1995, and served on its board for more than 30 years. Paul helped us think through difficult issues and, often, with his characteristic and very particular eloquence and wit, he made us laugh. He enthusiastically encouraged and supported young architects and students. Paul brought fresh and provocative thinking to the field of historic preservation and its pedagogy through his teaching and writing. Paul loved words and music as much as architecture; he was vivid, optimistic, indefatigable. We will miss him terribly. Rosalie Genevro, Executive Director Calvin Tsao, President The Architectural League of New York BYARD--Paul Spencer. We extend our deepest sympathies to Rosalie, Joshua, Eliza and the family of Paul Byard, our dear friend, former partner, and esteemed colleague. Paul's commitment to excellence in the profession and in education, his leadership of the Historic Preservation program at the Graduate School of Architecture Planning and Preservation at Columbia University, and his enthusiasm, vitality and commitment to improving the quality of life in New York City through his work and his longterm involvement in the Architectural League of New York will be greatly missed. Polshek Partnership Architects Joseph Fleischer Timothy Hartung Duncan Hazard Kevin McClurkan Richard Olcott James Polshek Susan Rodriguez Tomas Rossant Todd Schliemann Don Weinreich

JONES--Brooks. The trustees and staff of The Joyce Theater Foundation mourn the loss of Brooks Jones, a supportive board president and trustee for many years. Our dear friend and his enthusiasm for dance will surely be missed.

The next round in Germany's favorite parlor game -- where will Senator Barack Obama give his public speech during his visit to Berlin next week -- is under way. All bets are now riding on the Victory Column in the former West Berlin, with the Brandenburg Gate visible less than a mile away. The Obama campaign has yet to announce a location. But the daily Berliner Zeitung is reporting, based on local government sources, that it expects the speech to occur at the base of the column, which is more than 200 feet tall, topped with a golden statue of an angel and known as the Siegessäule in German.

The Summer North American Bridge Championships of the American Contract Bridge League started on Thursday in the Hilton Hotel, Las Vegas. The Spingold Knockout Teams is the premier event. The defending champions are Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Chris Compton, Bob Hamman, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell (although last year Hemant Lall played instead of Freeman, who was recovering from surgery, and Paul Soloway, who died in November, partnered Hamman). In last year's final, the Nickell team played against Andrew Gromov and Alexander Dubinin from Russia and Cezary Balicki and Adam Zmudzinski from Poland. After 32 of the 64 boards, Nickell led by only 43 international match points to 40. But Nickell won the third quarter by 35 imps to 8 and the final session by 42 imps to 7.

A woman of many interests and friends. A long career as a Statistician in private industry, federal and state governments. Member Phi Beta Kappa at Hunter College. M.S. Columbia University. Past Chairman Membership Committee New York branch of American Statistical Association. Graveside service: Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY, Sunday, call 888-536-7426.

ABRAMS--Irving, passed away July 15, 2008 in Richardson, Texas. Preceded in death by his wife Selma Abrams. Cryptside services 10:30am Sunday, July 20, 2008 at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

General Motors is the ''official car provider'' for the Republican and Democratic conventions. As such, it is lining up hundreds of hybrid and flex-fuel cars to shuttle officials around -- and to try to create a positive buzz about its ''green car'' lineup. The troubled automaker can use all the good publicity it can get. This week, it announced major cuts in its work force, its health care benefits and its dividends, in light of plummeting sales.

LEVY--Joan Cecile 85, formerly of New York and Scarsdale. This gentle, kind and giving soul peacefully passed away on July 13 in Palm Beach, Florida in the loving arms of members of her adoring family. Cheerful and good-natured, she always looked for the good in people, as they always recognized the goodness in her. Joan was as beautiful inwardly as she was outwardly. She brightened the lives of everyone who met her; and was loved and cherished by all who knew her, especially by her family and life-long friends. Daughter of the late Rose and Jacob Branower, she spoke of herself as the ''real'' daughter of the late Bertha Borgenicht Levy; was beloved wife of the late Travis; loving mother of Karen, Kenneth, Stuart and Jerald; special ''mom'' to Ira, Karin, Charlie and Herm; kind friend to Karen C.; dear sister of Marcia; adored cousin of her ''sister'' Helene; much loved aunt of Susan and Paul; cherished grandmother of Michael and Jenny, David and Pamela, Paul and Kimberly, Jessica, Sonja, Eric and Allyson; devoted great-grandmother of Zachary, Maxwell, Jacob, Alexandra, Noah, Nicholas, Benjamin, Eli, Lexi; loving aunt of Nancy and Steven, Jack and Leslie, Tom and Diane, Richard and Gerrie, Jeffrey and Patti; special ''aunt'' of Nancy and Danny and Steven; and loving ''great-aunt'' of Amy and Jason, and Steven. In confronting life's trials, Joan always saw a ''glass half-full''. Though our ''glass'' will be emptier without her, Joan's beautiful spirit will forever be reflected in the beautiful things she made by hand and gave us: knitted-wear, needlepoint, rugs and beaded flowers. We, and all who knew her, will always remember her sweet, loving and positive presence. Karen, Kenneth, Stuart, Jerald. Interment service will be on Sunday, July 20, at 2:00pm, Cedar Park Cemetery Sanctuary Mausoleum, Paramus, NJ .

Add Dan Rather to the list of those who have made that dreaded political gaffe when discussing Senator Barack Obama. On Friday, while appearing on ''Morning Joe'' on MSNBC, Mr. Rather, the former CBS News anchor who is now managing editor of HDNet, mistakenly referred to Mr. Obama as Osama bin Laden. Yup, the full name.

KERR--Elizabeth ''Betsy'', 87, formerly of Manhattan, Bridgehampton and Wainscott, NY, passed away peacefully at Vicar's Landing in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL on July 15, 2008. She is survived by two brothers, seven nieces and nephews, and 14 grandnieces and nephews. A private graveside service is planned for this fall.
How did the economy become such a mess? As the week brought another batch of bad news, this basic question has stepped to the fore of American life.

JENKINSON--Wendy Weisman, 45, died at her home on Martha's Vineyard on Thursday, July 17, 2008, after a year long struggle with brain cancer. She was a graduate of Scarsdale High School and the Cordon Bleu and attended Hampshire College, an accomplished chef and successful caterer, loved by her friends and family. She is survived by her husband Patrick, her children Marguerite and Wyatt, her adoring parents Hugh and Suzanne Weisman, her loyal sisters, Jennifer Sullivan and Alexandra Weisman, her nephew Timmy and niece Annie. She was an extraordinary beauty and one of the bravest people in the world. We are all lucky to have had her in our lives. A celebration of her life will be held on the Vineyard on August 23rd.

BAGATELLE--Hedy. We are once again heart broken because of the loss of our friend Hedy Bagatelle. Our love and condolences goes out to the entire family. Leslie and Charles Roden BAGATELLE--Hedy S. (Schwartz), wife of the late Warren Bagatelle, mother to David, Tracy and Adrien, grandmother to Olivia, Molly, Emma and Alexander, died July 17, 2008. Hedy graduated magna cum laude ('60) from The University at Albany and continued to the support the college as a member of the university's Foundation Board, the Jewish Studies Advisory Board and the Library Development Committee. A service will be held on Sunday, June 20, 10am at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, 68 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston, NJ 07039. Gifts in her name may be payable to The University at Albany Foundation Board (1400 Washington Ave, UAB 226, Albany, NY 12222) for the Center for Jewish Studies.

Pope Benedict XVI, in Australia for World Youth Day, said a prayer on Friday in St. Mary's Cathedral Crypt in Sydney during a reenactment of Jesus' last days, including the Last Supper and crucifixion. The pope apologized on Saturday for the sexual abuse of children by members of the church and called for the abusers to be punished. ''These misdeeds, which constitute so grave a betrayal of trust, deserve unequivocal condemnation,'' he said. ''They have caused great pain and have damaged the church's witness.'' He added: ''Those responsible for these evils must be brought to justice.''

8 P.M. (TCM) NO CAN DO Turner Classic Movies dedicates a whole evening to films with the confining contraction ''can't'' in the title. At 8, ''You Can't Take It With You'' (1938), the film version of the play, with Lionel Barrymore, James Stewart and Jean Arthur. At 10:15, ''You Can't Run Away From It'' (1956), with June Allyson and Jack Lemmon (above). At midnight, Lucille Ball and James Ellison play newlyweds who split up in ''You Can't Fool Your Wife'' (1940). At 1:15 a.m., ''You Can't Get Away With Murder,'' a death-row drama with Humphrey Bogart. And finally, at 2:45, ''You Can't Win 'Em All'' (1970), in which Tony Curtis and Charles Bronson play American war buddies who join up with Turkish mercenaries in the 1920s. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Five types of headaches, and how to treat them.

WEISBEIN--Ann (nee Levin), died at the age of 101 on July 16th, 2008 at her home in Hollywood, FL. Cherished wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of the late Eugene (Diane) Weisbein and Roberta (Arthur) Lewis, proud grandmother of Michael and Robert Weisbein, Allison Sisun and John Lewis, and great-grandmother of six. Beloved sister of Jack Levin, Arthur Levin, Peggy Keller and the late Irving Levin. In 1954 Ann and Sam built the Driftwood Motel in Amagansett which they operated for nearly 30 years. Ann developed lifelong friendships with her guests who marveled at her stamina and wit, her love and devotion to Sam, and the military precision with which she operated the Driftwood. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends. Services Sunday July 20th, 2008 at Mount Ararat Cemetery 11:15am graveside.

An article last Sunday about the golf history of Royal Birkdale, home to this year’s British Open, misstated the number of players who have won that tournament and the United States Open in the same year. It is six, not four. (In addition to Lee Trevino, Bobby Jones, Ben Hogan and Gene Sarazen, Tom Watson and Tiger Woods also accomplished the feat.).

An article in some editions last Sunday about the Man o’ War Stakes at Belmont Park, in which Red Rocks defeated Curlin by two lengths, misstated the year that Red Rocks was the Breeders’ Cup Turf champion. It was 2006, not last year.

An article last Sunday about the presence of the retired cyclist Greg LeMond at this year’s Tour de France, a race he won three times, misstated the timing of his last extended visit to the event. It was in 1994, not in 1990. (Although LeMond’s third Tour title came in 1990, he competed in the race as late as 1994, when he withdrew during the sixth stage.).

An article in some editions last Sunday about the Bon Jovi concert in Central Park misidentified, in some copies, the employer of a spokeswoman who said that the Great Lawn had reached its 50,000-person capacity and that there were thousands more people in the overflow areas. The spokeswoman, who was not identified in the article, works for NYC & Company, the city’s tourism organization — not the mayor’s office.

An obituary last Sunday about Tony Snow, the former columnist, television commentator and press secretary to President Bush, misstated, in some editions, the year that President Bush sought re-election. It was 2004 — not 2006, which was the year Mr. Snow helped raise money for Republicans running in the midterm elections.

In his July 6 profile, Zev Chafets writes that Rush Limbaugh fears “being branded a racist,” but ignores numerous examples of Limbaugh’s inflammatory rhetoric. Limbaugh, among other things, claimed Democrats concerned about Darfur were merely courting the black voting bloc; said this year, “Democrats will bend over, grab the ankles and say, ‘Have your way with me’ ” to African-Americans and gays; claimed Senator Barack Obama’s “only chance of winning is that he’s black”; labeled Obama “an affirmative-action candidate”; and, according to The Washington Post, “often played ‘Movin’ on Up’ when referring to Carol Moseley Braun.” Chafets writes that “serious people” have called Limbaugh “a serial liar,” without actually citing the abundant evidence. For example, after calling service members who support U.S. withdrawal from Iraq “phony soldiers,” Limbaugh vehemently denied he had done so and, to refute the charge, played a spliced audio clip of his comments, while falsely claiming he was providing the “entire” segment at issue.

To the Editor: I would like to congratulate Adam Begley on his excellent article, “Sicily, Through the Eyes of the Leopard” (July 6). Having been born in Siracusa, Sicily, and grown up there in the 1960s, I was made to read “Il Gattopardo” in high school and never appreciated it. Not sure how, but recently I found the old high-school book, reread it and loved it. The article captures, better than any I have ever read, the essence of the book, the author, the land, the people, the contradictions, the culture. Paul Pirrotta.

To the Editor: I got a kick out of the travel section’s “36 Hours in Pittsburgh” (July 6). Pittsburghers have known for a long time that the only people who don’t like our city are those who have never visited. The theater scene here is vibrant. Not to be missed is Quantum Theatre (www.quantumtheatre.com), which since 1990 has been producing works in sites specific to them like a city park, abandoned industrial warehouse or an empty swimming pool in Andrew Carnegie’s first library building in Braddock, Pa.

To the Editor: I was very distressed that the Travel article “36 Hours: Bangkok” (June 29) chose to include a trip to Patpong, the infamous red light district. First, with a mere three days in a city rich with art, culture, religion and food, why would anyone waste their time at strip clubs or buying porn? But more disturbing, why would The Times advocate visiting a part of the city that profits from the sex trade, a business that exploits men, women and children? Visitors who want that experience will find it without a tacit endorsement by The Times. Lauren Bufferd.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended July 5, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Perennial sellers are not actively tracked. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. All four children’s lists appear each week on the Book Review’s Web site. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children’s titles.

KLINGENSTEIN--Selma F., on Longboat Key, FL on July 18, 2008 at age 86. Adored wife of the late Paul Klingenstein, mother of R. James (Susanne) Klingenstein and Irene K. Hess. In addition, she leaves grandchildren David (Diane) and Suzanne Hess, Rachel and Julie Klingenstein, great-grandchildren Jacob and Ethan Hess, and many loving friends. She will be greatly missed. Services will be private.

WATERMAN--Faith D., died peacefully on July 15, 2008 at age 102 at her home. Beloved and loving sister of John J. Waterman, Arthur Waterman, Jr., and Doris W. Neu, all of whom predeceased her. Faith was an intelligent and cultured woman whose forceful personality and interest in people made her an unforgettable friend and family member. A lover of the arts with a passion for knowledge, and a wide circle of friends throughout the world, she held a variety of interesting positions, including personal assistant to Margaret Truman and to the noted journalist, Dorothy Thompson, and staff member of the Andre Seligmann Gallery. We will feel her loss greatly but celebrate her long, full and joyful life. Friends and family may call at Centolire Restaurant, 1167 Madison Ave at 86th Street, on Monday, July 21, from 5:30-7pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Memorial Scholarship Fund at Colby College, 4345 Mayflower Hill, Waterville, ME 04901.

IF Paris is the capital of France, Toulouse is the nation's campus. With three major universities and a thriving high-tech center, including the headquarters of Airbus, France's fourth-largest city hums with inventiveness and creativity. Under its medieval church spires, the spider web of cobblestone lanes brims with art museums, theaters, upstart fashion boutiques, all-hours night life and an expanding bevy of fine restaurants serving everything from haute cuisine to hearty cassoulet. And thanks to its location in France's sunny southwest -- closer to Barcelona than Paris -- Toulouse is suffused with a laid-back Latin vibe. No wonder ''La Ville Rose,'' so named for the dusty rose-hued bricks in many of its old edifices, is France's fastest-growing city. Friday

What distinguishes the summer imagery of some men is their suave, cool look, not the high jinks of designer experiments. A few men focus on the quality of cloth, tailoring and fastidious fitting of custom-made suits, including jacket cuffs that actually unbutton, unlike ready-mades with purely decorative cuff buttons. This year, a sleek look is all white (including shoes) for day or evening. Also seen are minor revivals of wide ties, two-tone shoes and the double-breasted shawl-collared waistcoat. There was even the surprise of red suede shoes.

GOLDWASSER--Ehud. The officers, board, supporters and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) deeply mourn the death of Sergeant Major Ehud Goldwasser of the Israel Defense Forces (IDF), who was brutally abducted along with IDF soldier Eldad Regev by Hezbollah two years ago. Ehud was a brilliant graduate student in the Faculty of Aerospace Engineering at the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. He was married to Karnit Goldwasser, who recently received her master's degree from the Technion, for only 10 months before his death. Ehud and Karnit planned to receive their graduate degrees together, in what would have been a joyful milestone in their history of love coupled with hard work. Israel, the world, and we, have lost one of the best, and our future is dimmer without Ehud and the important contributions he would surely have made. We are outraged by the inhumanity of Hezbollah's actions and express deep sympathy for Ehud's wife Karnit, his parents Shlomo and Miki, and the entire Goldwasser family. A Memorial Fund for Technion students in memory of Ehud Goldwasser has been established at the ATS. Please contact your local office for information on the special fund. Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Professor Yitzhak Apeloig, President Larry Jackier, Chairman, Technion International Board of Governors American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen Laser, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

HIGH school can be hard to shake. Some people never make it out of the cafeteria; they're still trying to find the cool kids' table. With ''American Teen,'' opening nationwide on Friday, Nanette Burstein can claim a certain expertise on the subject. This movie earned her the documentary directing award at this year's Sundance Film Festival and set off a bidding war. It's also something of an exorcism. Ms. Burstein was co-director, with Brett Morgen, of two highly regarded documentaries: the Oscar-nominated ''On the Ropes,'' about three young boxers hoping to fight their way out of poverty, and ''The Kid Stays in the Picture,'' a portrait of the flamboyant Hollywood producer Robert Evans. But the impetus for ''American Teen'' was more personal: her own intense high school experience two decades ago in Buffalo. To make the 90-minute film Ms. Burstein moved to Warsaw, Ind., and, deploying multiple cameras, gathered 1,000 hours of footage as she and her crew followed four 17-year-olds through their senior year at the town's large, modern high school. The students could almost be the template for a John Hughes teen pic: the pampered queen bee Megan, whose imperious will to power masks a terrible secret; the basketball player Colin, who must win a sports scholarship or forgo college for the Army; the gifted bohemian Hannah, ready to break away but terrified that she may have inherited her mother's bipolar disorder; and the lonely band nerd Jake, funny and appealing but afflicted with vivid acne flare-ups that complicate his wry, determined search for a girlfriend.

8 P.M. (Military) SATELLITE SHOOT-DOWN Remember when a dying 5,000-pound spy satellite loaded with toxic fuel was headed straight toward Earth? If it seems like a distant memory, that's probably because the United States Navy incinerated it more than 130 miles above the Pacific Ocean in February, averting a minor environmental disaster. This one-hour special examines the science and technology, like that above, used to intercept and destroy the ailing satellite. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Adm. HARDMAN--Harold Frances, M.D., Ph.D. August 2, 1927-July 14, 2008. Age 80, of Eden Prairie, MN, a native of Bloomfield, NJ, and long term resident of Brookfield, WI. Dr. Hardman served as Professor and Chairman of the Department of Pharmacology at the Medical College of Wisconsin for 30 years, until his retirement in 1992. Author or co-author of nearly 100 scientific publications and recipient of numerous awards and honors, he was an internationally recognized scholar in the field of cardiovascular pharmacology. Dr. Hardman received his B.S. degree in Pharmacy from Rutgers University in 1949, his M.S. degree in Pharmacology from the University of Illinois in 1951, and his Ph.D. and M.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1954 and 1958. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Jean, of Eden Prairie, MN; his sons David, of Chapel Hill, NC; Tim, of Allenton, PA; John, of Rosemount, MN; daughter Susan Hardman-Conklin, of Eden Prairie, MN; his four grandchildren; Chris and Kayla Conklin, also of Eden Prairie, MN; and Christine and Kimberly Hardman, of Chapel Hill, NC. A celebration of life service was held yesterday in Eden Prairie, MN. The family suggests donations in memory of Dr. Harold Frances Hardman to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research (www.michaeljfox.org), Church St. Station, P.O. Box 780, New York, NY 10008-0780
