BYARD--Paul Spencer. The board and staff of The Architectural League of New York mourn the death of our colleague, mentor and good friend, Paul Spencer Byard. Paul was passionate about the art of architecture and its profound significance as the expression of the ethos and values of society. He led the Architectural League as president from 1989 to 1995, and served on its board for more than 30 years. Paul helped us think through difficult issues and, often, with his characteristic and very particular eloquence and wit, he made us laugh. He enthusiastically encouraged and supported young architects and students. Paul brought fresh and provocative thinking to the field of historic preservation and its pedagogy through his teaching and writing. Paul loved words and music as much as architecture; he was vivid, optimistic, indefatigable. We will miss him terribly. Rosalie Genevro, Executive Director Calvin Tsao, President The Architectural League of New York BYARD--Paul. The Board of Trustees and staff of the New-York Historical Society mourn the passing of Paul Spencer Byard, principal architect at the firm of Platt Byard Dovell White. Paul did outstanding work for the NYHS, both in designing and in advocating changes to our landmark. His spirit, exuberance and enormous enthusiasm for the N-YHS and its collections made him the perfect architect for our renovation. We offer our deepest sympathy to Paul's family, friends and colleagues. Roger Hertog, Chairman Louise Mirrer, President and CEO Andrew Buonpastore, Vice President for Operations BYARD--Paul Spencer, Esq., FAIA, age 68, died Tuesday, July 15th at his home in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Rosalie Warren Byard, father of Eliza Starr Byard and Joshua Spencer Byard and two grandchildren, brother of Margaret Byard Stearns. Partner, Platt Byard Dovell White Architects. Director, Historic Preservation Program, Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation 1999 -2008. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Architectural League of New York, 457 Madison Avenue, NYC, NY 10022 or to The Center for the Victims of Torture, 717 E. River Parkway, Minneapolis, MN 55455. A memorial service will be held in the fall, time and place to be announced.

THE CAPITAL OF MEDITERRANEAN COOL Pictures of Tel Aviv, a youthful, vibrant city in an ancient and troubled land. The city is ''half Iran, half California; it's a synagogue meets a sushi bar,'' says the writer and lifelong Tel Aviv resident Etgar Keret. The city's beaches illustrate the point. The ''orthodox beach,'' where men and women alternate bathing days, is 50 yards from the ''gay beach.'' And the Mediterranean provides both young and old a reprieve from the desert heat. Although, the young may settle for the random fountain.

BAKER--Anthony Kane, 65, of Palm Beach, FL, and Mill Neck, NY, on July 9, 2008. Son of George F. Baker, Jr. and Frances Drexel Munn Baker. Devoted father to Asia Alexandra and Callie Frances Victoria. Brother of the late George F. Baker III, Pauline Baker Pitt, Lavinia Baker Logan and Kane Kendall Baker. A graduate of Brooks School and Trinity College. He was a trustee of Brooks School, Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities, Society of the Four Arts, Quebec-Labrador Foundation and senior trustee of The George F. Baker Trust, a foundation established in 1942 by his grandfather that supports educational, medical and civic concerns. His great-grandfather, George F. Baker, helped found the First National Bank in New York City in 1863 and was instrumental in the establishment of the Harvard Business School and several university libraries including the Baker Library at Dartmouth College. He co-authored ''Long Island Country Houses and their Architects 1860-1940'' and was an authority on architectural preservation. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, July 22, at 3pm, at St. John's of Lattingtown Church, Locust Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made in his memory to Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities or to CARP, West Palm Beach, FL.

VINTAGE wedding presents brought for appraisal to ''Antiques Roadshow'' may have outlasted some of the marriages, but durability doesn't always translate into value. Once in a while a vase turns up on the PBS television show that is worth nearly a million dollars. Here are five artist-designed vases, some signed and some from limited editions, with long-term investment potential. Along the way they double as sculptural objects when not holding blossoms. 1. Dan Yeffet, a designer born in Jerusalem who studied and worked in the Netherlands before setting up his current studio in Paris, designed the hidden.mgx vase in rigid nylon. It resembles a leafless tree or a creature from the depths of the sea and comes in four sizes, from 3 inches high ($515) to 10 inches high, ($4,752); from unicahome.com or (888) 898-6422.

Dictionary writers are not kind to flummery. The innocent pudding is referred to as ''bland custard'' and ''a sort of pap.'' Webster's says an alternative meaning is ''Something insipid, or not worth having.'' The dish has had a number of incarnations -- many of them insipid -- but those lexicographers have obviously never tasted raspberry flummery, which is more pop than pap. It is made by gently breaking down the fragile berries with heat and sugar, fortifying them with a little cornstarch and then drenching the pudding with cool, fresh cream at the table.

ROTH--Jerome Henry (Rothstein), 90, one of the last surviving artists of the 1930s WPA Federal Art Project, died July 12. At age 16, he worked on the WPA poster division, designing posters for tourism and culture, many owned by the Library of Congress. During WWII he flew 30 missions with the 8th Air Force and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross. After the war he resumed his career as an art director. He operated his art studio in New York from 1953 to 1983 when he retired to paint full time. His painting has been described as playful and colorful, expressing the joy in life. He had solo shows in New York, Boston and Miami. Born in the Bronx, he lived in Westchester for the past 50 years. He is survived by wife Nettie, son Matthew, daughter Ellen Satlof and three grandchildren.

ERNIE URSINI is the general sales manager of Scap Dodge in Fairfield, Conn., where a window is adorned with a big handmade ''Buy American'' sign. In an office decorated with racing pictures, Mr. Ursini is looking at the latest incentives he can offer customers on the Dodge Ram Quad Cabs. ''It's amazing what they're doing to get rid of these trucks,'' he said. One thing Chrysler is doing is extending its Let's Refuel America program through the end of July, offering a guaranteed $2.99 a gallon for three years (based on 12,000 miles of annual driving).

SEN--Dr. Keshap Chander Retired United Nations senior development economist and philanthropist, Dr. Keshap Chander Sen was born 6 July 1926 and died 16 July 2008 in Mysore, India in the loving presence of his nephew Group Captain Ajay Dudeja (IAF retired) and his niece Indu Dudeja. In a career that spanned 55 countries across Asia, Africa and Europe, Dr. Sen served with the ILO, ECAFE, UNDP and UNIDO. He is survived by his wife of 32 years, Zoe Antoinette Calvert, their four sons Kiran Keshap, Arun Keshap, Atul Keshap and Rahul Keshap, two grandsons and five granddaughters. inmemoriam@keshap.com

A review last Sunday about ''Rome 1960: The Olympics That Changed the World,'' by David Maraniss, referred incorrectly to the Rome Games. They were the first commercially televised Summer Games, not ''the first televised Olympics.'' (Olympic events had been televised in various formats since the 1936 Summer Games, which were shown on screens around Berlin.) The error is repeated in the Editors' Choice column on Page 18 this weekend.

Greece and Croatia qualified for the men's Olympic basketball tournament in Beijing next month by winning their respective matches at the qualifying tournament in Athens on Saturday. The Greek national team defeated Puerto Rico, 88-63, to win entry to the Beijing Olympics. Greece, none of whose players play in the N.B.A., got double-digit scoring from six men.

THE CAPITAL OF MEDITERRANEAN COOL Pictures of Tel Aviv, a youthful, vibrant city in an ancient and troubled land. The city is ''half Iran, half California; it's a synagogue meets a sushi bar,'' says the writer and lifelong Tel Aviv resident Etgar Keret. The city's beaches illustrate the point. The ''orthodox beach,'' where men and women alternate bathing days, is 50 yards from the ''gay beach.'' And the Mediterranean provides both young and old a reprieve from the desert heat. Although, the young may settle for the random fountain.

THE NEWS The prosecutor at the International Criminal Court in The Hague formally sought an arrest warrant for Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the president of Sudan. BEHIND THE NEWS The charges of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity are the court's first against a sitting president. They stem from the five years of bloodshed in the Darfur region of Sudan, where Mr. Bashir's government is accused of trying to wipe out three ethnic minorities as it scoffed at international efforts to hold it accountable. While the warrant is unlikely to ever be executed, some diplomats hoped it would give them new leverage in seeking peace in Darfur.
Television Mike Hale

Americans have long been willing to get ahead by taking on debts. But much has changed since modern consumer loans took form in the 1920s. In 2008, more people of all races, classes and ages have access to credit. Their debts are growing rapidly: Americans carry $2.56 trillion in consumer debt, up 22 percent since 2000, when figures are adjusted for inflation. And household debt is now 130 percent of disposable income, up from 30 percent in 1929. Lenders, too, have shifted. Diligent borrowers are no longer the best customers. Lenders now seek and profit from customers least able to pay their debts. To help reduce the risk, lenders sell debts to investors in the form of securities. AMY SCHOENFELD

GOTTLIEB--Alan, 96, of Southampton, MA, formerly of Yonkers, NY, died Thursday at a local nursing home. Born in the Bronx, NY, he was a graduate of the New York City schools. He was a graduate of St. John's University where he received his CPA and the Brooklyn School of Law where he received his LLB. Prior to his private practice specializing in tax fraud he was a special agent for the Treasury Department and was an agent for the IRS. Alan was a veteran of the US Army and served during WWII. He was predeceased by his wife Doris (Wolpin) Gottlieb who died in 1994. Alan leaves two daughters, Hollis (Yuri) Kehler of Monsey, NY and Robin Gottlieb of Southampton, MA, one brother, Philip Gottlieb and two grandchildren, Marina and Vera. A graveside service will be Sunday, 11:30am at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. The Ascher-Zimmerman Funeral Home is assisting the family.

Few rental buildings in the city have been as hospitable to public officials, past and present, as the Rudin Management Company’s high rise at 215 East 68th Street, Ralph Blumenthal writes. A fancy white brick monolith of 608 apartments between Second and Third Avenues, the 33-story structure, built in 1962, is home to an unusual concentration of luminaries of the public and private sectors.

But two news accounts today — in The Daily News and in Metro New York — question whether the mats themselves pose a hazard: They can get so hot under the summer sun that they can burn bare feet.

Some 2,000 customers lost power in parts of Bay Ridge, Borough Park, Park Slope and Sunset Park on Sunday. Con Edison showed up not just with cable splicers and other work crews, but also tons of dry ice. The main advice I got from people who blog -- as well as from people who know people who blog -- is that I should be careful, lest it take over my life. Blogging has a way of doing that -- you're always looking at the new comments coming in, and posting them (so long as they aren't ad hominem attacks on someone, or contain foul language, etc. etc.) And you're always thinking of subjects you can blog about. And then you feel guilty if you're not. I wanted to say something about Hector Ruiz being replaced as chief executive of AMD -- as much as I like Ruiz and admire his rags-to-riches story, it sure looks like AMD has returned to taking two steps back for every one step forward, just as it always has. (Hmm...I guess I just posted after all!) I continue to want to mock the anti-short-selling mania in Washington and on Wall Street. I thought it was only the Chinese whose government tried to prop up falling stock prices. I guess not.

The American Academy of Pediatrics has issued new guidelines regarding cardiovascular health in childhood, most notably raising the possibility of drug treatment to lower cholesterol levels in kids as young as 8 years old. The resulting flurry of controversy has centered -- correctly -- on the lack of proof that taking cholesterol-lowering drugs in youth actually prevents cardiovascular events later in life, as well as on the dearth of long-term safety data regarding such treatments in children. How to incorporate cholesterol screening into clinically effective pediatric practice presents a quandary itself.

My colleague John Tierney has talked to journalist Gary Taubes about his reaction to the latest diet study. The report, published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine, compared low-carbohydrate, moderate fat and Mediterranean-style diets. Nobody lost much weight over two years, but Mr. Taubes, author of "Good Calories, Bad Calories,'' said weight loss isn't the point.

NYTimes.com's interactive series allow us to report the news as well as discover how the news affects people, through video, graphics and traditional articles. In the first installment of The Debt Trap, we observe how unprecedented debt levels and financial instability have affected average Americans. We hear from Diane McLeod, more than $280,000 in debt, along with a young couple and older single mother about to lose their homes. We show how, since the 1920s, the use of mortgages and installment loans, and, later on, home-equity loans and credit cards, have influenced debt levels.

Yahoo and Carl Icahn said Monday that they had reached a settlement that would keep most of Yahoo's directors in place but add Mr. Icahn and two of his allies to the Web company's board. Manchester United has told Cristiano Ronaldo that it will not give him a new contract with a pay increase to match any Real Madrid offer, and that he must start displaying “commitment and loyalty.” Ronaldo, a wing from Portugal, has spent the summer making no secret of his desire to join Real Madrid, the Spanish champion. Manchester United has told Cristiano Ronaldo that it will not give him a new contract with a pay increase to match any Real Madrid offer, and that he must start displaying “commitment and loyalty.” Ronaldo, a wing from Portugal, has spent the summer making no secret of his desire to join Real Madrid, the Spanish champion. The second-year L.P.G.A. player Ji Young Oh won her first tournament, sinking a 6-inch putt for par to win the State Farm Classic in a playoff over the rookie Yani Tseng in Springfield, Ill. A day after the tournament lost its marquee player, Michelle Wie, to disqualification, the sudden-death playoff injected life into what had been an ordinary final round. Tseng, the third-round leader, chipped her third shot over the green and into the rough, then pitched to about 6 feet from the cup. But Oh’s third shot, from just inside the rough, left her with the tap-in that gave her the win.

Richard S. Johnson birdied three of the last four holes to shoot a six-under-par 64 on Sunday to win the U.S. Bank Championship in Milwaukee for his first PGA Tour victory. Johnson finished at 16-under 264 on the 6,759-yard Brown Deer Park Golf Course to beat Ken Duke by a stroke. He is the sixth golfer from Sweden to win on the tour and the seventh first-time winner this year. Johnson, the first-round leader, sank a birdie putt of about 12 feet on the par-4 17th hole to break a tie with Duke.

R. W. Eaks was the runaway winner in the Champions Tour 3M Championship in Blaine, Minn., posting the lowest score in the tournament’s 16-year history. Eaks shot a seven-under 65 in the final round to finish with a 54-hole total of 193, four shots better than Ed Dougherty’s finish in 2000. Gary Hallberg and Bernhard Langer tied for second at 199.

Ryan Briscoe took advantage of a surprising pit strategy on the way to a victory in the Honda Indy 200 at Mid-Ohio Sports Car course in Lexington, Ohio. The team owner Roger Penske made the call to put Briscoe out of sequence with the other contenders, and it paid off with his second victory of the season. Hélio Castroneves finished second, giving the team a 1-2 sweep at the event.

Lewis Hamilton won the German Grand Prix in Hockenheim with two dramatic passes that made up for a strategic blunder by his McLaren team, solidifying his lead in the Formula One standings. Hamilton overtook Ferrari’s Felipe Massa, then the runner-up Nelson Piquet Jr. of Renault at the same hairpin after a crash involving Timo Glock brought out a safety car that nearly cost Hamilton his fourth victory of the season.

Gilles Simon of France won his first ATP title on American soil, beating Dmitry Tursunov, 6-4, 6-4, at the Indianapolis Tennis Championships. Simon, seeded second and ranked 25th in the world, had not reached an ATP semifinal in the United States before this tournament.

(Travel) ANTHONY BOURDAIN: NO RESERVATIONS After a countrywide casting call, Danya Alhamrani, a Saudi-American woman who lives in Jeddah but is originally from Bismarck, N.D., was selected to be part of the “No Reservations” crew that filmed an episode in Saudi Arabia. Ms. Alhamrani wrote in her Travel Channel blog that under his “crusty, cynical, sarcastic exterior,” Mr. Bourdain (above, with Ms. Alhamrani) has a deep faith in humanity. But during his show’s last visit to the Arab world, when Mr. Bourdain was stranded in Beirut at the outset of the 2006 war with Israel, that faith was shaken. “Maybe in the real world — the one without cameras and happy food and travel shows — everybody, the good and the bad together, are all crushed under the same, terrible wheel,” he said.

Gov. David A. Paterson plans on Monday to embrace one of the central recommendations of a report highly critical of the state's higher education system, asking the Legislature to create a low-cost student loan program to make New York more competitive with other states. A spokeswoman for Mr. Paterson, Marissa Shorenstein, said that ''hundreds of thousands of students would be eligible for low-interest loans,'' and that the administration planned to introduce legislation for the program in next year's budget. She declined to provide any further details.

The eighth Siren Music Festival, the annual free indie-rock extravaganza at Coney Island, was a sunny day at the beach full of ringing rock guitars and forecasts of doom: for romances, for lives, for nations, for mankind and, closer to home, for Siren in its current form. It would have been impossible for the Siren festival, presented Saturday by The Village Voice, to encompass indie rock with only 14 bands -- even more difficult this year, perhaps, because it was competing for bookings with the three-day indie-rock Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago the same weekend. (One Siren band, Times New Viking, was scheduled for Pitchfork on Sunday.) The Siren lineup progressed from irritants to melodists, starting with noisy New York City bands -- Dragons of Zynth, These Are Powers -- and winding up with the slyly meandering songs of Stephen Malkmus and the Jicks and the grand crescendos of Broken Social Scene, in simultaneous headlining sets.

Google's QuestFor Ad Quality May Be Overdone Listening to Google's executives in their conference call with investors Thursday afternoon, you'd never know that the company's second-quarter results fell short of expectations and its shares plummeted in after-hours trading.

ROTH--Jerome Henry (Rothstein), 90, one of the last surviving artists of the 1930s WPA Federal Art Project, died July 12. At age 16, he worked on the WPA poster division, designing posters for tourism and culture, many owned by the Library of Congress. During WWII he flew 30 missions with the 8th Air Force and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross. After the war he resumed his career as an art director. He operated his art studio in New York from 1953 to 1983 when he retired to paint full time. His painting has been described as playful and colorful, expressing the joy in life. He had solo shows in New York, Boston and Miami. Born in the Bronx, he lived in Westchester for the past 50 years. He is survived by wife Nettie, son Matthew, daughter Ellen Satlof and three grandchildren.

For more than a decade, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the housing giants that make the American mortgage market run, have attracted overseas investors with a simple pitch: the securities they issue are just as good as the United States government's, and they usually pay better. The marketing plan worked. About one-fifth of securities issued by Fannie, Freddie and a handful of much smaller quasi-governmental agencies, some $1.5 trillion worth, were held by foreign investors at the end of March. One out of 10 American mortgages is, in effect, in the hands of institutions and governments outside the United States.

Sales of video games, like those of music albums and song downloads, benefit from advance orders by eager fans. ''Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots,'' for example, was not released until June 12, and ''Battlefield: Bad Company,'' above, became available only on June 23. Video game sales from January through June totaled $8.3 billion, an increase of 36 percent over the first half of 2007. Nintendo led console sales in June, with 783,000 for the DS and 667,000 for the Wii. Sony's PlayStation 3 ranked third with 406,000.

LOS ANGELES -- Fevered fans pushed ''The Dark Knight,'' the sixth of the Warner Brothers series of ''Batman'' movies, to record three-day ticket sales of $155.3 million over the weekend, shoring up what so far had been a wobbly year at the box office. By Warner's estimate the film narrowly eclipsed opening-weekend ticket sales last year of $151.1 million for Sony Pictures' ''Spider-Man 3,'' the previous record holder.

ASHER--Ralph L., passed away at his Old Tappan, NJ home on July 19, 2008. Services will be held on Monday, July 21, at 1pm at Gutterman Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Cherished husband of Susan (Pinsky) and beloved father of Dana (Scott Reiner), Larry (Janpei) and Scott (Karen). Adored grandfather of Arielle, Juliana, Stephanie, Eric and Jeremiah. A man of many passions and achievements, Ralph was loved and respected by all who knew him. A 1958 graduate of RPI, he went on to earn an MEE and MBA. During a 40-year tenure at ITT Avionics, he served as Executive Vice President of Business Development. In a second career, he was a financial planner. He was devoted to Temple Beth El, Closter, NJ, and, among other positions, served as its president. Ralph left an indelible impact on the lives he touched and will be deeply missed.

With good ratings for the premiere of ''Flashpoint,'' a police drama produced with a Canadian television network, CBS says it will consider importing other shows and concepts. The pilot of ''Flashpoint,'' which is filmed and set in Toronto, was produced by CTV in Canada last year. With CBS as a co-producer, the show had its debut in Canada and the United States on July 11, making it the first Canadian series to be broadcast simultaneously in both countries since ''Due South'' in 1994. On CBS it was the most popular program of the night, with 8.1 million viewers. Speaking at the summer press tour for critics, Nina Tassler, president of CBS Entertainment, said, ''It's a global playground.'' One of CBS's shows coming this fall, ''The Ex List,'' is based on the Israeli drama ''Mythological Ex.''

SOUTHPORT, England -- By doing what major championship winners do best, Padraig Harrington of Ireland won the 137th British Open at Royal Birkdale by four strokes on Sunday, defending the Open title he won in a playoff last year at Carnoustie. He faltered but did not fall, stared down defeat without blinking, overcame his own mistakes, ignored an aching right wrist and outlasted his opponents. In the process, he validated his place in golf history, shooting a final-round 69 for a total of three-over-par 283 to become the first European in more than 100 years to successfully defend the Open title. Playing the final six holes in four under par, with an eagle at the 17th hole, he rendered moot Ian Poulter's late charge and turned back 53-year-old Greg Norman's quixotic and compelling quest to become the oldest major championship winner.

CAIRO -- Global food shortages have placed the Middle East and North Africa in a quandary, as they are forced to choose between growing more crops to feed an expanding population or preserving their already scant supply of water. For decades nations in this region have drained aquifers, sucked the salt from seawater and diverted the mighty Nile to make the deserts bloom. But those projects were so costly and used so much water that it remained far more practical to import food than to produce it. Today, some countries import 90 percent or more of their staples.

SOUTHPORT, England -- Style over substance no more, Ian Poulter was tied for the lead late on Sunday at the British Open. Poulter, a slender Englishman with an avant-garde fashion sense, made his biggest waves this season in an interview with the British magazine Golf World when he was quoted as saying, ''Don't get me wrong, I really respect every professional golfer, but I know I haven't played to my full potential and when that happens, it will be just me and Tiger.''

The traditional recipe for vichyssoise -- cold potato-leek soup -- calls for potatoes, leeks, water or stock, salt, pepper, butter and cream. What little complexity the soup has comes from lightly browning the vegetables in the butter and using lots of salt and pepper, good stock and, of course, the cream. There is a better way to make vichyssoise, however, that is not only easier and more interesting but also lower in fat: add extra vegetables, just as a French home cook would with soupe bonne femme, the inspiration for vichyssoise.

Kim Severson has an interesting story in the paper today on "lazy locavores," people who want to buy local produce or raise it on their own property but don't want to get their hands dirty (or lack the time). I suppose it's great to think that a new class of "green jobs" might emerge in this kind of service sector (paying someone to create and weed your vegetable garden). But to my mind it shares some of the qualities of going "carbon neutral" by buying credits from some entity that's planted trees somewhere.

Mets' closer Billy Wagner had a magnetic resonance imaging scan on his left shoulder at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan on Tuesday. Because of an editing error, an article on July 4 about a suit based on American racketeering law that was brought in Russia against Bank of New York Mellon referred incorrectly to a United States Supreme Court decision relevant to the law, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. In the case of Sedima v. Imrex, which was cited by a lawyer for a Russian government agency, the court ruled that to establish proof of racketeering, the offenses must be related to one another and must demonstrate continuity. The court did not rule in that case that a single fraudulent scheme, even one that is part of a legitimate business’s “regular way of doing business,” could establish proof of a racketeering violation. (That determination was made by the Supreme Court in a later case, H. J. Inc. v. Northwestern Bell Telephone Co.).

The About New York column on Saturday, about “The Castle,” an autobiographical drama performed by four ex-convicts at the New World Stages theater, included an erroneous surname from a publicist for one of the actors. He is Kenneth Harrigan, not Harrington.

An article on Friday about earnings at JPMorgan Chase misstated the bank’s income from investment banking in its second quarter. The division reported a net income of $394 million, not a loss of $785 million.
BUSINESS DAY.

An article on the Square Feet pages on July 2 about the new North American headquarters of HSBC in Mettawa, Ill., rendered incorrectly the name of the company to which HSBC traces its beginning. It is the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, not the Hong Kong Shanghai Banking Corporation.

An article on Friday about the Argentina Senate’s defeat of an agricultural export tax, a repudiation of President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, misidentified the city where she made her only public appearance that day. It was in Resistencia, not Chaco (Resistencia is the capital of Chaco, a province in northern Argentina.).

A report in “Arts, Briefly” on Monday about CBS’s plans to import television shows from other countries misidentified the Canadian producer of “Flashpoint,” which is now showing in the United States. The producer is CTV, not the CBC.
An article on July 14 about the potential for bank failures as a result of the credit squeeze misstated the number of banks that have failed so far this year. It is five, not six.

An article in some editions on June 27 about Keyanna Jones, a 15-year-old from Queens who was stabbed to death after an altercation aboard a New York City bus, misidentified the location of the school where she had just finished her freshman year, and misidentified the campus she attended. John Adams High School is in Ozone Park, not Far Rockaway, and she took classes at the annex in South Ozone Park, not at the main campus.

An article on Thursday about plans by the nonprofit Second Stage Theater to buy a Broadway house, the Helen Hayes, using information provided by Second Stage, omitted one of the current owners of the theater. In addition to Martin Markinson, it is owned and operated by the family of Donald Tick, who died in 2006.

The doubles specialists Frantisek Cermak and Michal Mertinak, each coming off a tournament title, were suspended by the ATP for betting on tennis matches. Neither player wagered on his own matches, and an independent hearing officer found no evidence of any intent to affect the outcome of matches bet upon, the governing body of men's tennis said. Cermak, a Czech ranked 34th in doubles, was suspended for 10 weeks and fined $15,000. He teamed with Rogier Wassen to win the doubles title Sunday at the Dutch Open.

Comic books are filled with stories about protagonists who overcome seemingly impossible odds as they fight for truth, justice and the American way. Where better to chronicle the stories of Senators John McCain and Barack Obama and their campaigns for the White House? ''There have been comic book biographies before. That's not new,'' said Scott Dunbier, special projects editor at IDW Publishing of San Diego, which will issue the comics, for sale on Oct. 1. ''But we're talking about a story that isn't finished: two views of the candidates, two men who are both vying for what is arguably the most important job in the world.''

NEDERLANDER -Gladys, 83, July 21, 2008. Wife of Robert E. Nederlander, Sr., mother of Steven Stryker, mother-in-law of Beverly Stryker, and grandmother to Micah and Teri Ann Stryker, passed away at Calvary Hospital in New York City. For more than 40 years she produced dozens of plays and television programs of extraordinary breadth and quality. Gladys Nederlander grew up in New York City and moved to Chicago and then to Los Angeles, where she got an early start in show business landing her first job as an assistant on the television show, ''Queen for A Day'' In the mid-1970s she began a theatrical career with Roger L. Stevens developing material for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and for the Broadway stage. Producing credits included ''West Side Story'', ''Caesar and Cleopatra'', ''Perfectly Frank'' and ''Platinum''. In 1992 she became Executive Producer for Nederlander Television and Film Productions, producing a number of television dramas. In 1990 and 1991 she developed and produced for the Arts & Entertainment Network fourteen one act plays written by Pulitzer Prize winning playwrights. Mrs. Nederlander was formerly a member of the Board of the League of American Theatres and Producers and a lifetime Tony voter. Other survivors include niece Debbie Holloway and nephew Richard DeGorter and two stepsons, Robert E. Nederlander, Jr., and Eric Nederlander. Gladys will be deeply missed by her family as well as a large group of devoted friends in New York, Florida and California who treasured her generous gifts of loyalty and friendship. The funeral will take place on July 23, 2008 at 2:30pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York City. Burial will be at Palm Springs Cemetery, Palm Springs, California. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Broadway Cares or the Sloane Kettering Memorial Cancer Institute. A memorial service in New York will be announced in the next few weeks. NEDERLANDER--Gladys. Dear in our hearts forever. Bob, Suzanne, Richard, William and Ava NEDERLANDER--Gladys. We will miss our beloved friend Glady forever. Sue and Roy Pollock

MILLER--Kenneth Allen. On July 20, 2008, at the age of 63, surrounded by his wife and children at his home in Woodbury, NY. Beloved husband of Galyna. Cherished father of Johanna and (Ryan) Pepper and Kera and (Dennis) Donovan. Adored stepfather of Andrew and (Galyna) Sokolova. Loving brother of Jeffrey and (Deb) and Gammy and (Kenny) Kimerling. Uncle to Carla and Lauren Miller. Loving grandfather to Zachary, Brendan and Lily. Caring step-grandfather of Olexandra. Survived by his mother Inez. Predeceased by father, Marvin, and niece, Chelica Kimerling. Kenneth was president and co-founder of Globecomm Systems, Inc. in Hauppauge, NY. His integrity, positive attitude, strength, perseverance, and generosity of spirit touched all who knew him. These gifts will stay in the hearts of all who knew him. Services Wednesday 12 noon at ''Gutterman's''. 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to CancerCare, The Carcinoid Cancer Foundation or Carcinoid Cancer Awareness Network.

Spanish art experts say ''Guernica,'' above, the Picasso painting depicting the horrors of war, is in ''stable but serious condition'' and needs special care, Agence France-Press reported, citing El Pais, the Spanish newspaper. The painting, which records the destruction in 1937 of the Basque village of Guernica by the Nazis during the Spanish Civil War, has ''suffered a lot,'' Jorge Garcia Gomez-Tejedor, the head of restoration at the Madrid museum Reina Soifa, where the painting is housed, said. The prognosis was made following the first careful examination of the masterpiece in 10 years. Mr. Garcia Gomez-Tejedor said the canvas would not be restored because it could cause further damage.

JOYCE--John E. Jr. age 86 of Stratford, the beloved husband of Marjorie McAuliffe Joyce passed away peacefully in his home on Saturday, July 19, 2008. He was a native of the Bronx, New York and a graduate of Fordham, Prep, Fordham University and New York Law School. John served in the U.S. Army in Russia and North Africa during WWII. Prior to his retirement, he was an attorney for the New York State Department of Insurance Liquidation Bureau. In addition to his devoted wife Marjorie of fifty-six years, he is also survived by three daughters, Marjorie Tabak and her husband Jeremy of Miami, Florida, Jane Joyce and her husband Barry Smith of New York City, Laura Joyce of Norwalk, CT, five grandchildren, Megan, Deirdre and Claire Tabak, Madeline and Christopher Smith. He was also predeceased by his parents, John and Adaline Keppler Joyce Sr. and his brother James P. Joyce. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday July 23, 2008 at 10:00am directly in St. Mark Church 500 Wigwam Lane Stratford, where a Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated. The foreign minister of Syria reiterated that Syria intended to establish diplomatic relations with Lebanon for the first time since the two nations gained independence more than 60 years ago. ''We are determined to open an embassy and to exchange diplomatic representation,'' the foreign minister, Walid al-Moallem, left, told reporters in Beirut. ''But this determination has to be shared.'' At a conference of Mediterranean countries in Paris 10 days ago, Presidents Bashar al-Assad of Syria and Michel Suleiman of Lebanon agreed to open embassies in each other's capitals. The conference was seen as ending the diplomatic isolation of Syria that followed the 2005 assassination of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister, in a car bombing.

BRONNER--Susan, born Vienna, 1912, daughter of bass-baritone Arthur Fleischer, died peacefully at home in New York City, July 17. Widow of Hans Bronner, she is survived by her brother, Franz Martin, and the four children of her elder brother, conductor and opera translator Thomas Philipp Martin, who died in 1984. According to her wishes Mrs. Bronner was cremated without ceremony. Susan Bronner was an opera lover and dedicated correspondent, writing by hand or on her electric typewriter. She never entered the digital age, referring to herself as ''a female without email.'' She volunteered two days a week at Lincoln Center until stricken by a heart attack at age 95. A memorial is planned for the fall. Donations in her memory may be sent to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts or Bideawee Animal Shelter. BRONNER--Susan. Die holde Kunst brought us together and will keep you in our everlasting, loving memory. Maria, Lincoln Ctr Volunteers

A lab coat sits on a rack inside the darkened Vermont Market and Pharmacy, waiting for a druggist who, by the looks of the place, has not filled a prescription in decades. Dust has settled on a generation of clutter: bills, egg cartons, newspapers and a vintage scale that provides both a horoscope and a weight for 5 cents. A sign advertises goods that are ''fresh today,'' the coffee, apples, cheese and sausage that no one has delivered in years. Through the milky glass front window, tins of maple syrup and jars of vitamins are visible, improbably paired on wooden display shelves.

The British choreographer Christopher Wheeldon will return with his company to New York City Center in October. The engagement, the second annual season for Morphoses/The Wheeldon Company, will run Oct. 1 to 5 and include two American premieres, one choreographed by Mr. Wheeldon and co-commissioned by City Center and Sadler's Wells Theater in London, and a new work by Emily Molnar, a Canadian choreographer. Pieces by Lightfoot/León and Frederick Ashton will also be performed and the dancers will be accompanied each night by live music, featuring members of the Orchestra of St. Luke's. Mr. Wheeldon's company is made up of dancers from leading American and European ballet companies, including Tyler Angle, Gonzalo Garcia, Maria Kowroski andEdwaard Liang.

CARACAPPA--Roger. The employees of The Estee Lauder Companies deeply mourn the death of our dear colleague and beloved friend, Roger Caracappa. He was an outstanding innovator, great business leader, wonderful mentor and he will be missed greatly. Roger began his career with The Estee Lauder Companies 36 years ago at the Estee Lauder plant in Melville. He rose through the ranks of shipping, quality control, purchasing and package development, spearheading all promotional marketing for the Estee Lauder brand in North America. In July 2004, Roger became Executive Vice President --Global Packaging, Quality Assurance, Store Development, Design and Merchandising. Roger was a member of both the Advisory Council and the Action Council for the Department of International Trade and Marketing for the Fashion Institute of Technology, served on the FIT MPS Executive Committee and served on the Advisory Council of the International Package Design Competition. He was a Cartier Scholarship FIT Honor Roll Award recipient for participation in the Cosmetic/Fragrance Action Council. Among his many accomplishments, Roger was instrumental in establishing the first Masters in Cosmetic and Fragrance Marketing and Management at the FIT, serving on the Steering Committee and Industry Advisory Board for the FIT Master's Program, and as an executive mentor for students in the graduate program. In 2002, Roger was named the Packaging Executive of the Year by Health & Beauty America (HBA). He was inducted into the New Jersey Packaging Executive Hall of Fame in 2004. Our thoughts are with his wife, Elizabeth Park Caracappa, his children, Roger, Adam and David Caracappa, Michael and Lindsay Park, his mother, Theresa Caracappa and his brother, Victor Caracappa. CARACAPPA--Roger, on July 20, 2008. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Cherished father of Roger, Adam, David and his wife Alisa, Michael and Lindsay Park. Loving son of Theresa and devoted brother of Victor. Visitation on Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral service on Wednesday 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st, New York, NY.

CUNEO, Italy -- One day after taking the yellow jersey from Cadel Evans on the tough uphill finish to Prato Nevoso, the CSC Saxo Bank team promised that the war was not over. ''Yesterday was not a real mountain stage,'' Bjarne Riis, the manager of the CSC team and the winner of the 1996 Tour de France, said Monday, the Tour de France's second rest day. ''The next two stages are much more mountainous. So we'll attack in a very different way.''

Russia's prime minister and former president, Vladimir V. Putin, instructed his government to restore the Czech Republic's flow of oil, which had been reduced after the Czechs signed an agreement with the United States to base a missile-defense radar on their territory. The slowdown in oil supplies had stirred speculation that Russia, which opposes the antimissile system, was retaliating by curtailing energy exports; the Russian government denied that it was. Oil supplies dropped by about 40 percent on July 9, the day after the Czech government signed the missile defense deal, and have remained at that level since.

(49) BURNING SEASON ''Wide Angle'' visits the Indonesian rain forest, where areas the size of 300 soccer fields are being cut down and burned to clear land for crops like oil palms, turning the country into the world's third-largest emitter of carbon dioxide, behind the United States and China. Dorjee Sun, a 29-year-old Australian ''green entrepreneur,'' says he can solve the problem by selling carbon credits to polluters in the West, including Starbucks, eBay and Merrill Lynch. But small Indonesian farmers (like Achmadi, above) whose survival depends on cutting trees worry that the big corporations are going to be the only ones getting rich from Mr. Sun's plan. 7 A.M. When Gov. Alfred E. Smith ran for president in 1928, his candidacy was derailed in large part by anti-Catholic prejudice. It has been nearly 48 years since John F. Kennedy became the first (and so far only) Roman Catholic president, but experts say that anti-Catholic sentiment — much of it originating in, or as a response to, immigrants in New York — remains an enduring force in American culture.That was the consensus of a panel assembled at the Museum of the City of New York on Tuesday night to consider the question, “Is Anti-Catholicism Dead?”

My Thursday column is about the Middle East. I use Obama's visit as a peg to look at some of the reader comments I received here on this blog after my Hebron column, and to respond to them. By the way, readers regularly say something snide like: I know you'll never read this far in the comments and see this. In fact, I don't read every comment but I do look at most of them. They all have to be moderated, and so either I or my assistant, Natasha Yefimov, wades through them and approves or deletes (we approve about 90 percent; the main ones we delete are the all-caps, or those that are nasty about other posters, or that mix me up with Bill Kristol...)

I have lived in the same rent-stabilized apartment for 30 years. My landlord converted the building to a co-op under a noneviction plan in the early 1980s. This office is open only on Monday through Thursday during regular business hours, which represents a hardship for me because I would have to take unpaid time off from work to do what he is requiring. I was told the lease would not be accepted if I mailed it. Is this legal?

Seven months after Google began testing a service called Knol, a Wikipedia competitor, the company on Wednesday finally introduced it.

Sudanese President Bashir had the gall to begin a campaign-style swing through Darfur today. It is striking that for all the alarm about the risk that an indictment of Bashir would lead to retribution against humanitarians and peace-keepers, the opposite has happened. The humanitarians have had just about their best week so far.

The one thing Jorge Posada knows for sure is that he needs surgery to repair damage in his labrum and shoulder capsule. But Posada is not yet ready to concede the rest of this season, even if it means that his recovery would cost him part of 2009.

Updated | 4:25 p.m. In an interview Tuesday night with Katie Couric, Senator John McCain scolded Senator Barack Obama for getting his history wrong. But it appears that Mr. McCain might himself have inaccurately described the timing of a scene-changing development in Iraq.

President Bush's recent comments about the current economic mess -- "Wall Street got drunk," he said, in what he thought were off-the-record remarks at a Houston fund-raiser -- have inspired all kinds of commentary.

I'm reporting Wednesday from Facebook's second F8 conference in San Francisco. This is the company's annual forum for speaking to the thousands of entrepreneurs who create features and tools for the social network.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa.­ -- As Senator Barack Obama met with Israeli and Palestinian leaders in the Middle East on Wednesday, Senator John McCain talked up his own support of Israel a half-world away. "I look you in the eye, and I tell you, as the United States once said, and will say again and again, we will never allow a second Holocaust,'' Mr. McCain told a crowd at a town-hall meeting here.

Society | An article on recent studies suggesting that having children might lessen your happiness: one concluded that "no group of parents-married, single, step or even empty nest-reported significantly greater emotional well-being than people who never had children." [Newsweek]

An activist group managed to (briefly) interrupt NBC's "Today" show on Wednesday morning with a protest about the network's coverage of Darfur, which the group contends has ebbed as the network's broadcast of the Beijing Olympics approaches.

The Government Accountability Office, which tracks a wide range of issues on behalf of Congress, is trying to shift attention to the next phase in Iraq. In comments to lawmakers today, Comptroller General Gene L. Dodaro plans to label the Bush administration's strategy for Iraq as out-of-date, according to prepared remarks obtained by CNN:
CBS viewers seem to favor an elite police rescue force over a group of sexually experimental couples.

The Associated Press story yesterday that former St. Louis Blues chairman Mike Shanahan had plead guilty to one charge of manipulating stock options -- the same sort of charge to which Ducks owner Henry Samueli pleaded guilty -- stated that Shanahan engaged in backdating the options between 1996 and 2002. In the scheme, prosecutors claim executives and board members of Engineered Support Systems Inc. the company co-found by Shanahan, enriched themselves by nearly $20 million.

While the real estate bubble has popped on Main Street, the party is still going strong at 15 Central Park West, the newly built, Goldman Sachs-backed condominium complex that is home to many of New York's financial moguls.

To help American journalists headed to the Beijing Olympics strike more of a balance between what "we" think and what "they" think, UCLA's Asian American Studies Center has released a brochure it calls a "U.S.-China Media Brief," which contains pertinent statistics and concise explanations of the major issues confronting the two countries as the Olympics approach. The brief was prepared by the center's staff, UCLA faculty and scholars from other institutions in California and elsewhere.

Today's Minimalist recipe -- no-bake blueberry cheesecake -- is a refrigerator cake, a combination of ingredients that become dessert without cooking. Most of these -- my favorite, and I say that advisedly, is Dirt Cake, a stunning combination of Oreos and Cool Whip -- can be devastatingly (dare I say nauseatingly?) sweet.
KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- It has been almost a year since Oklahoma State Coach Mike Gundy's epic postgame rant against an Oklahoma newspaper columnist, but it remains a hot topic.
President Bush -- our only MBA president, you will recall -- was on to something when he offered this analysis of the current financial crisis:

If I had to make a list of the best players to interview, Jimmy Rollins of the Phillies would definitely be near the top. Rollins is candid, he is engaging, he is smart and, this part helps a lot, he loves to talk.
A newly designed section of Hudson River Park in Manhattan is finished and was opened to the public.

Things might be going swimmingly for Barack Obama overseas, but he may have a few concerns on the homefront. "John McCain has opened a modest lead over Barack Obama in the key swing state of Ohio," reports Rasmussen.

[UPDATE 7/24: The remains of Hurricane Dolly unleashed furious rains over southwest Texas and officials still warned of the risk of flooding along the Rio Grande.] Just before midday Wednesday, Hurricane Dolly was raking the Texas coast as a Category 2 storm with the potential to strengthen a bit more before the eye made landfall, forecasters said. We have a new Times Topics blog on issues in the news and the post on Hurricane Dolly is by Hugh Willoughby, formerly the head of hurricane research at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and now a professor at Florida International University. He notes that this one is mainly a warmup, given that storms like this one, below Category 3, comprise 80 to 90 percent of those that hit land but cause only 15 to 20 percent of hurricane damage. As Prof. Willoughby put it, "Dolly is a nice refresher training exercise for the forecasters and emergency response crews. It's also a good 'baptism of wind' for Bill Read, in his new job as director at the Hurricane Center."
The following is a transcript of Senator Barack Obama’s speech in Sderot, Israel, as provided by CQ Transcriptions, Inc.

Although farmed salmon is available all year, wild salmon does have a season, and that season is now. The wild fish from the Pacific has so much flavor that it needs little more than a sprinkling of salt. But the addition of oil or butter and a single herb, combined with a near-foolproof roasting technique, gives many more options.

This week's guest blogger is Laurent Vernhes, co-founder of the travel Web site Tablet Hotels. Vernhes, who was born in France and lived in half a dozen countries before settling down in Brooklyn, founded Tablet in 2000 as way of helping stylish, culturally-attuned travelers find hotels to match. The site's tight edit of properties spans high and low, includes opinionated commentary and ratings, and is showcased annually in a hard-cover guide. Read Vernhes's previous posts here.

I'm leaving today for a two-week trip that will eventually take me through Rome, where I already have my morning coffee planned at the legendary Caffe Tazza d'Oro, the eternal rival of Sant'Eustachio for the best espresso in town.
John Harwood discusses Obama's overseas trip and how he might best benefit from focusing on the U.S. economy over national security.

It was threatening rain when I walked unchecked into the Gdansk shipyards last Friday, my eyes focused on the beautiful jungle of industrial machinery up ahead. Elaborate steel cranes, painted green, loomed over the rusty carcasses of half-built ships, and inside the sagging brick warehouses, I imagined, were heavy and mysterious tools. My camera batteries were fully charged, and I was hoping to spend the day photographing these historic shipyards, birthplace of the Solidarity movement, which brought down Polish Communism in the 1980s, and now nearly bankrupt.

As I write, the Brownsville National Weather Service radar shows Dolly's eyewall reaching the Texas coast. Dolly is a CAT 1 hurricane, forecast (at 8:00 AM) to have winds of "only" 75-80 kt (or 86-92 mph) when it crosses the beach. An Air Force Reserve WC-130 crew is bouncing around through the storm right now. Their observations show indications of stronger winds, some at the threshold of CAT 2, just above the surface. There may be some last-minute strengthening before landfall.

His cover identity featured a Santa Claus facade and the voice of a New Age preacher, so would it really be so hard to believe that Radovan Karadzic's alter ego also posted his favorite Chinese proverbs to a personal Web site, as Reuters, Agence France-Presse and the Australian newspaper The Age all reported this morning?

Mother Nature has clearly awakened from her long slumber. While Hurricane Dolly's landfall today along the Texas-Mexico border will get much attention, the reality is that 2008 has already been a very activeyear for catastrophe losses in the United States. In fact, there were a record 109 catastrophes through June 30, according to Munich Re, one of the world's largest reinsurers. These catastrophes resulted in $9.3billion in insured catastrophe, the highest first-half total since 1994 (the year of the Northridge earthquake). This figure exceeds the total insured catastrophe losses recorded in 2006 ($9.2 billion) and 2007 ($6.7 billion). Tornadoes were the most significant cause of loss during the first half of the year. Historically, hurricanes and tropical storms have caused the bulk of second half losses.

While much of the world was heating up over the July 21 cover of The New Yorker, with its satirical cartoon of the Obamas, I was becoming frustrated by one of the articles inside. Benjamin Wallace-Wells's "Surfing the Universe" (abstract only) is about Garrett Lisi, a 40-year-old physicist who has come up with his own Theory of Everything in opposition to string theory.
The former Serbian dictator Radovan Karadzic's top knot hairdo, right. (Agence France-Presse/Getty Images)

With the Ohio State-Southern California game a little more than a month away, the former U.S.C. quarterback Carson Palmer isn't holding back. The only problem is he currently plays for Cincinnati, where many Bengals fans also root for the Buckeyes.

I returned from a quick trip to Washington, D.C., recently with two happy eating memories, two suggestions to pass along. And that isn't always the case with food and with Washington, which can delight and disappoint in pretty much equal measures.
Lehman Brothers' stock seems to have stopped its free-fall for the moment, but Wall Street is still seriously concerned about its future.

In the course of working on a piece about summer chick-lit books that plug fashion brands ("Chasing Harry Winston" and so on), I realized that this year marks the 50th anniversary of the publication of "Breakfast at Tiffany's." Can you believe it?
Events on Thursday in Carpi, Italy, and London will mark the centennial of the marathon run that is, arguably, the most celebrated race in Olympic history.
Revolutionary guards in support of Orlane's new Thermo-Active Firming Serum.

The Summer Olympics returned to the United States in 1996. Despite traffic trouble, disorganization and hot weather, the athletes of the world produced numerous great performances, many of them available on YouTube.

KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- Colorado Coach Dan Hawkins had a reasonable excuse for not declaring the ballyhooed freshman Darrell Scott the Buffaloes' starting tailback. After all, Scott just arrived on campus last week.

It didn't get too much notice outside of the oil patch, but Tuesday's bankruptcy filing by SemGroup LP -- which Forbes.com last year called the 12th-largest private company in the United States -- was one of the bigger corporate flame-outs of late. And there could be more where that came from.
"So you say you're selling your house?" The Wall Street Journal asked on July 14. "Hey, it could be worse. You could be selling a Hummer."

The tumultuous lives of Blair, Serena, Chuck and their wealthy New York friends will return to the Internet after a decision by the CW network to lift a ban on streaming its show "Gossip Girl" online, TV Week reported.
Barack Obama's four-part family interview drew viewers to "Access Hollywood" the week of July 7.

In today's New York Times, Felicia Lee writes about CNN's two-night miniseries "Black in America." It begins with "The Black Woman and Family" Wednesday at 9 p.m. and continues with "The Black Man" on Thursday.

Viagra doesn't work as a treatment for women, most studies show. But new research suggests that among women who suffer sexual side effects as a result of antidepressants, the little blue pill may help.
Remember when Iraq was a Vietnam-like quagmire? Things may have changed on the ground in Mesopotamia, but this week the two presidential candidates seemed stuck in the bog.

Carl C. Icahn wants you to know that, now that his proxy battle with Yahoo is over, he intends to blog more often. And he hinted that an upcoming post will be inspired by a recent article in The Wall Street Journal.
Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

Paulson & Company, the hedge fund firm whose founder, John Paulson, made a mint on bearish housing bets last year, is starting a fund to provide capital to financial firms hurt by mortgage writedowns, Bloomberg News reported.

When he talks about why the economy is ailing, President Bush often turns to euphemism, citing "challenges in the housing and financial markets." But Mr. Bush offered a far blunter assessment last week at a closed Republican fund-raiser in Houston: "Wall Street got drunk."

With the slowing economy taking a toll on the online advertising business, Yahoo said Tuesday that its net income dropped by nearly 19 percent in the second quarter from a year ago as revenue grew at a sluggish 6 percent rate.
Veteran U.S. lawyer Brendan Sullivan is joining the defense team of indicted former Bear Stearns hedge fund manager Ralph Cioffi, Reuters reported.
New York state Attorney General Andrew Cuomo is preparing to file civil securities-fraud charges against UBS The Wall Street Journal reported.

The proposed government rescue of the nation's two mortgage finance giants should appear on the federal budget as a $25 billion expense, the independent Congressional Budget Office said on Tuesday, but officials conceded that there was no way to really know what, if anything, a bailout might cost taxpayers.
Vodafone Group, the world's biggest mobile phone operator, announced a surprise stock buyback valued at about $2 billion Wednesday, saying a big share price fall Tuesday had left it undervalued.

Here's some good news for Warner Music Group's long-suffering private equity backers: According to The New York Post, the music label, whose artists include R.E.M. and Green Day, is the year's best-performing media stock.
SemGroup LPwas devised to shoulder the risks of commodities markets, but its backers did not count on $150-a-barrel oil.

Tokio Marine Holdings, Japan's largest insurer, agreed to buy specialty insurer Philadelphia Consolidated Holding for $4.7 billion, in an effort to gain a significant foothold in the United States market.
XTO Energy said it is buying gas properties across several states from various unnamed parties for $2.1 billion.

TPG Capital, the United States-based private equity group, is considering a bid for Paragon, the troubled British mortgage lender, according to The Financial Times. On Tuesday, the same newspaper reported that the Blackstone Group, a TPG rival, was in talks to buy Paragon.
Lion Capital agreed to buy Foodvest Group from crosstown private equity house CapVest for more than 1 billion pounds ($2 billion), including debt, according to The Deal.
Can the bad news for banks get any worse?
National City is trying to sell its money-management unit, according to The Wall Street Journal, which said it is working with Morgan Stanley to shop Allegiant Funds, which manages about $30 billion.
TechCrunch has again revived rumors that Digg is close to being acquired by Google.
Netflix is shuttering its nascent film financing unit, Red Envelope, saying the division competed with its main suppliers, Hollywood studios.
After going Hollywood, the Chateau Montelena Winery in California is now going French.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia is in exclusive talks with Royal Bank of Scotland to acquire the Australian and New Zealand operations of ABN Amro, in a deal that could be valued at as much as 1 billion Australian dollars ($971 million).

For several years, it seemed that prices for Manhattan office buildings would never stop climbing. But now, in perhaps the clearest demonstration so far of how commercial real estate values have deteriorated in the last year, 1372 Broadway, a 21-story brick building in the garment center that was one of the last to sell before the credit crisis, is under contract to change hands again at a loss of $41 million.
Chad Dickerson, the head of Yahoo's technology incubator Brickhouse, has left the company to join start-up Etsy.
Walter W. Bettinger II will become the chief executive of the nation's largest discount brokerage, the Charles Schwab Corporation, in the fall.

Chief executives and chief financial officers are increasingly likely to leave their posts -- willingly or not -- especially after an accounting restatement, according to a recent study by Audit Analytics.

Hedge fund managers are looking to global macro funds to try to steer clear of the mess created by the credit crisis, while cautiously dipping into a small pool of more risky assets, a Reuters poll found.

The downturn in the U.S. claimed another high profile victim on July 17, when Lake Las Vegas, the 3,600-acre luxury development surrounding a man-made lake in the foothills outside Sin City, filed for bankruptcy protection.
How scientists aboard the Riverkeeper organization’s patrol boat take samples from the Hudson River for water-quality testing.

KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- After finishing third in passing yards per game in the Big 12 last season, Kansas State quarterback Josh Freeman is quietly gaining attention.

Even with Johan Santana pitching eight superb innings, even with the Mets leading by three runs heading into the ninth, and even with first place just three outs away, I think it would have been difficult to find anyone in the Shea Stadium press box who did not expect Billy Wagner's unavailability to prove an obstacle, or at least prepare for the possibility.
The city’s official head count at large public gatherings in Central Park has gotten more specific in recent years.  Gone are the days of estimating the crowds.
At Szechuan Gourmet, the heat is almost always on, and it comes at you in different ways.
An ingenuous 24-year-old man-child is at the center of John Crowley’s wrenching melodrama “Boy A.”
In the depths of summer, it’s hard to think of a more refreshing choice from California than a chilled sauvignon blanc.
Helped along by the buzz created by two big scoops, OffTheBus.net, the online citizen-journalist arm of the Huffington Post, has grown to 7,500 citizen correspondents.
After mashing the Twins Tuesday night, the Yankees are just three and a half games behind Tampa Bay in the American League East and are 10 games over .500 for the first time this season.
Without Billy Wagner, the Mets bullpen was subjected to a remarkable ninth-inning rally, and the Phillies took the first game of a pivotal series at Shea.

The Navy has decided to halt construction of its newest model of destroyer after the first two are built in shipyards in Maine and Mississippi, Senator Susan Collins said. Ms. Collins, Republican of Maine, said the secretary of the Navy, Donald C. Winter, had called her to tell her the outcome of a meeting about the future of the ships, DDG-1000 Zumwalt destroyers. A spokesman for the Pentagon said it would have no immediate comment. The Zumwalt was conceived as a stealth warship with heavy firepower to pave the way for marines to make their way ashore. Each would cost about $2.6 billion.

A July 1 editorial on demolishing historic dwellings incorrectly said there was no opposition to the razing of a home in Greenwich, Conn. There were protests from individuals and members of the local historical society.
The Yankees had little to offer Tuesday about the tenuous status of catcher Jorge Posada, who could miss the rest of the season if he needs surgery immediately on his right shoulder.
The Canadian Pacific Railway said second-quarter profit fell 40 percent and cut its full-year profit forecast as fuel costs rose and a slumping economy reduced traffic.
United Steelworkers locals representing workers at three Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan mines have voted about 98 percent in favor of striking, the union said.
Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications equipment maker, posted a 70 percent decline in second-quarter profit, citing recent acquisitions and high development and revamping costs.

The oil giant BP settled the four remaining lawsuits in the latest civil trial resulting from the deadly 2005 explosion at its Texas City refinery. The latest round of settlements leaves only seven suits pending out of more than 4,000, said Daren J. Beaudo, a BP spokesman. The terms of the deals were confidential. The settlements were reached Monday night, nine weeks into the trial.

An Okaloosa County sheriff’s deputy was shot and killed in a shootout with a man who had been ordered by a court to undergo a mental evaluation and who had twice left a hospital before barricading himself in a home, the authorities said. Deputies later shot and killed the man, Mark R. Rohlman, 46, the police said. Sheriff’s deputies served the court order to Mr. Rohlman, and twice took him to a behavior health center for evaluation. Mr. Rohlman eventually obtained a shotgun and barricaded himself inside a home in Fort Walton Beach. Sheriff’s deputies, including a special response team, tried to talk Mr. Rohlman into coming out but received no response. Officers entered the home, and Mr. Rohlman fired the gun, killing Deputy Anthony Forgione, 33, of Niceville.

Prosecutors said they wanted a 78-year-old man committed to a mental hospital after he was found incompetent to stand trial in the 2003 killings of two South Carolina law enforcement officers. The announcement by Solicitor Jerry Peace came a day after a circuit judge ruled that the man, Arthur Bixby, could not stand trial because he had dementia. The authorities said Mr. Bixby and his son, Steven, ambushed the two officers over a road-widening project outside their home in Abbeville, about 85 miles west of Columbia. Steven Bixby, 40, was sentenced to death. His mother, Rita Bixby, 75, was sentenced to life in prison for not telling the authorities what her husband and son had planned.

Union Pacific will pay $102 million to the United States Forest Service to settle a lawsuit over damage caused by a huge wildfire north of Sacramento in 2000 that was started accidentally by railroad employees, officials said. United States Attorney McGregor Scott said the damage recovery would be the largest ever for the Forest Service in a wildfire. Union Pacific, based in Omaha, agreed to the settlement after a federal judge in Sacramento ruled against the company in February, said Zoe Richmond, a railroad spokeswoman. Judge Frank C. Damrell Jr. of Federal District Court decided the government could seek damages far beyond firefighting costs and the market value of burned trees.

A federal appeals court upheld a ruling that struck down as unconstitutional a 1998 law intended to protect children from sexual material and other objectionable content on the Internet. The decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, is the latest twist in a decade-long legal battle over the law, the Child Online Protection Act. The court ruled that the law, which has not taken effect, violated the First Amendment because filtering technologies and other tools offer a less restrictive way to protect children from inappropriate content.
Legal costs associated with removing tenants from the complex and a soft real estate market have contributed to Tishman Speyer’s losses.
The Rev. Al Sharpton’s lawyer said on Tuesday that federal prosecutors had ended a criminal investigation into his finances and those of his nonprofit organization, the National Action Network.
The plight of Gus Dominguez, serving time in federal prison for smuggling a Cuban baseball player into the U.S., has placed a pall over those agents who handle Cuban players.

The Iowa Board of Regents has reopened its investigation into how the University of Iowa handled an investigation into a reported assault of a woman last October by two football players. The board met Tuesday to discuss letters that were sent to the university by the mother of the woman. The letters were not disclosed to the board until last week. David Miles, the board president, said, “This board owes Iowans a full accounting, and they will get it.”.

Seven people were arrested in Italy in a crackdown on an organized crime group that is accused of trying to buy the Lazio soccer team with laundered money. The police official Gianluca Campana said that the authorities were still looking for three people, including the former Italy and New York Cosmos star Giorgio Chinaglia, who is now living in the United States. Chinaglia, 61, is accused of trying to influence the price of Lazio shares, prosecutors said in 2006. Chinaglia has said he did nothing wrong.

The San Antonio Spurs re-signed the veteran forward Kurt Thomas, who was acquired in a trade in February. Terms were not disclosed. Thomas averaged 4.5 points and 4.9 rebounds in 28 games for the Spurs.
A 61-year-old woman pleaded guilty to sex trafficking for her role in a family-run gang accused of smuggling women from Mexico to New York and forcing them, sometimes violently, into prostitution.

Andy Roddick had to work harder than expected to suppress an upset bid from Nicolas Mahut in a 6-1, 6-7 (8), 6-3 victory in the second round at the Rogers Cup in Toronto on Tuesday. Tommy Haas advanced to the second round in this Master Series event with a 6-3, 6-2 win over Carlos Moyà. Rain halted play in the afternoon.

Joe Calzaghe has postponed his proposed September light-heavyweight fight against Roy Jones Jr. because of a sprained right wrist. Jones accepted the delay, saying that he wanted Calzaghe to be at his best. Calzaghe, 36, who is unbeaten in 45 professional fights during a 15-year career, injured his hand Sunday while training. Calzaghe’s trainer and father, Enzo, said his son needed two or three weeks off before he started punching again.

The Delaware Thoroughbred Racing Commission reduced the suspension of jockey Jeremy Rose to three months for whipping his horse in the face. Rose, who won the 2005 Preakness and Belmont Stakes aboard Afleet Alex, was initially suspended for six months. He must still pay a $5,000 fine and the horse’s medical bills, and complete an anger-management course.

Serena Williams has withdrawn from the East West Bank Classic in Carson, Calif., because of an injured left knee. After practicing in the morning, Williams said she knew she could not play. Williams is scheduled to play for the United States at the Beijing Games.
The disagreement centered on the multiethnic city of Kirkuk, where there are competing claims over which province a city or district belongs in.
British Prime Minister Gordon Brown told Parliament that Britain planned a “fundamental change of mission” at the turn of the year.
The status of Ryan Church, on the disabled list since July 6 with postconcussion syndrome, remained murky on the first day he was eligible to be activated.
The Senate approved a bill that effectively grants Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi immunity from prosecution during his term, the ANSA news agency reported.
A Greek court has dismissed a request by residents of the island of Lesbos to prohibit the use of the word lesbian to describe gay women.
The Chicago Blackhawks are scheduled to host the defending Stanley Cup champion Detroit Red Wings on Jan. 1 at Wrigley Field.
The Maoists said they would not form Nepal’s first post-royal government after the defeat of Ramraja Prasad Singh, their candidate for president, on Monday.
Dueling opening statements in the trial of Salim Hamdan were suggestive of those at civilian trials, but there were also reminders of the differences in the military commission system.
Supporters of President Álvaro Uribe of Colombia are pushing for a referendum that would permit him to run for a third term to continue his fight against Marxist guerrillas.
German archaeologists say they have discovered the ancient chariot track at Olympia where the Emperor Nero of Rome bribed his way to Olympic laurels.
With a possible fare increase looming, New York City’s subway riders deserve better service, and more help from both their city and their state.
The nation’s leaders must act quickly and take the necessary, if politically unpopular, steps to rescue Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac from insolvency.
Attending a Google-sponsored debate in New Orleans, fed by text-messaging questioners and YouTube aficionados, would be a good move for both presidential candidates.
Radovan Karadzic’s capture should serve as a warning to other leaders who incite and abet genocide and believe they can escape justice.
Several hours after Jimmy Rollins said that the Phillies were “definitely” the class of the division, he lined a two-run double to deliver the go-ahead runs that pushed Philadelphia past the Mets.

The Congressional Budget Office said a proposed rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac could appear on the federal budget as a $25 billion cost to taxpayers, but the figure is, at best, a rough estimate.
Commanders said that rules intended to minimize civilian casualties restricted their ability to strike insurgents.
In the past year thieves have stolen hundreds of covers and grates, which are increasingly valuable as scrap.
A Texas grand jury handed up an indictment Tuesday against the Mormon polygamist leader Warren S. Jeffs, who is already serving time in prison, accusing him of sexually assaulting a girl under 17.
Carrying two handguns and a Bible, Jason Aiello, 36, was killed early Tuesday on a residential street in Staten Island by former colleagues who returned his fire, the authorities said.
Biogen Idec reported a higher-than-expected second-quarter profit on Tuesday as sales of its closely watched multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri surged past Wall Street estimates.

USA Gymnastics officials said a visa mix-up may mean that the alternates for the women’s team will have to train in Japan, three hours away by plane.
With a heavy recruiting class heavy with junior college players, the Wildcats have their share of critics. But for Coach Ron Prince, it’s part of a familiar strategy.
The secrecy of the grand jury process was weighed against the interests of public accountability in the atomic espionage case.
Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader in the State Senate for more than a decade, is now the chief executive officer of an information-technology company that has numerous state contracts.
Representative Ron Paul and six other members of Congress were trying to return to the capital in time for a Tuesday night vote on an aviation safety bill. The flight landed without incident.
Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed into law a bill that gives trees the right to grow as they please — as long as they predate any solar panels they might be shading.
The city’s more than 100 agencies will be required to provide language assistance in six foreign languages: Spanish, Chinese, Russian, Korean, Italian and French Creole.
Despite reassurances that he is cancer free four years after he was treated for pancreatic cancer, analysts are worried that Steven P. Jobs might be sick again.
The planned closing of a Starbucks in Newark pains those who saw it as a welcome sign of normalcy.
The Bush administration has said it “strongly” opposes the effort to give the Food and Drug Administration regulatory authority over tobacco.
Authorities have focused on Houston, Roger Clemens’s hometown, in search of someone who can directly link Clemens to the use of performance-enhancing drugs.
Telecommunication companies in the U.S. have to juggle the financial effect of customers dropping their landlines, and increased competition between wireless operators.
The Americans preparing for the Olympic sabre team have come to New York City, always a hotbed of fencing, to train for Beijing with Yury Gelman at the Manhattan Fencing Club.
As the popularity of chain-saw carvings increases, the man who claims he invented it is still carving strong after more than 50 years.

Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer is a target of a continuing investigation by a state ethics commission into his administration’s handling of travel records, people who have been briefed on the inquiry said.
Ocean Colors, who will be at Saratoga on Wednesday, has already done more than most offspring of Winning Colors, who won the Kentucky Derby nearly 20 years ago.
India’s finance minister, Palaniappan Chidambaram, said speculation in the market was a greater factor in rising oil prices than offer and demand alone.
E*Trade posted a net loss of $94.6 million, or 19 cents a share, in contrast to a profit of $159.1 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier.
Earnings rose as higher sales in its space, electronic systems and information technology units offset a drop in its fighter jet business.
The UnitedHealth Group beat Wall Street expectations on Tuesday, and its shares rose despite a sharp drop in second-quarter profit.
The Giants agreed to terms with their first-round choice Kenny Phillips on Tuesday, the last of their draft picks to sign. Terms of the deal were not released.
The company said that its second-quarter net income rose 30 percent from the same period a year earlier while inkjet printer sales fell 49 percent.
The company reported a jump in second-quarter profit, but said it expected third-quarter shipments to decline and costs were expected to increase.
