Ron Paul, the former Republican presidential candidate, and his followers have been making plans for their own miniconvention when his party gathers in St. Paul to nominate Senator John McCain. Except the Paulite gathering is no longer so mini. Due to popular demand, as the saying goes, Mr. Paul had to scrap plans to hold his event at the nearly 15,000-capacity Williams Arena at the University of Minnesota. Instead, his ''Rally for Liberty'' will move to the Target Center in Minneapolis, which can hold up to 18,000.

The arrest of Radovan Karadzic on Monday gave badly needed credibility to international war crimes tribunals that have struggled for years to bring fugitives to justice, according to former prosecutors, legal experts and human rights groups. Mr. Karadzic will be the third high-profile figure to be brought before a United Nations-backed tribunal on war crimes charges in the past six years, following in the footsteps of Charles Taylor of Liberia and Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president.

SIEGEL--Jerrad, of NYC, died on July 21st in his home at the age of 80 after a courageous battle with cancer. He is a WWII Navy veteran and a graduate of Brooklyn Law School. He worked for Nassau County as a Deputy County Attorney and New York State as an Administrative Law Judge. He served as the President of the Oceanside Democratic Club. He is survived by his beloved wife, Sandra, two children, Todd Siegel and Lynda Edwards, and four grandchildren. Donations in his memory can be made to Continuum/Jacob Perlow Hospice, 39 Broadway Suite 200, New York, NY 10006 attn Development. SIEGEL--Jerrad. Beloved brother of Enid Fisher, uncle to Abby, Leigh, Ruthie, Avi and David. Great-uncle of George, Emma and Evie. He had a zest for life and brought joy and laughter to all who knew him. He was loved and will be greatly missed by all. The Fisher Family

SCHANG--Mary Jane (Janie), died peacefully in her sleep after a long illness on July 21, 2008 in Vancouver, Canada. Beloved wife of the late Frederick Christian Schang III of New York City, cherished mother of Gabrielle, Antonia and Frederick Christian Schang IV, loving grandmother of Jason and Luke Savedoff of Vancouver Canada; and Christian Theodore and Vanessa Schang McCusker of New York City. Known fondly as Janie to her many friends and close family, she will be greatly missed by all. A memorial service is being planned for early Fall.

WIEGOLD--Frederic. A senior editor of Bloomberg Markets, the monthly magazine published by Bloomberg LP, died Saturday, July 19. He was 61. The cause of death was a brain hemorrhage. Wiegold joined Bloomberg News in 2002 as an editor-atlarge and served for five and a half years as New York bureau chief. Before coming to Bloomberg, Wiegold worked for 18 years at The Wall Street Journal, where he was a founding editor of the Money & Investing section and a contributing editor of Smart Money magazine. He served as the Journal's personal-finance editor for more than a decade, created the paper's annual Best on the Street survey of securities analysts and edited The Wall Street Journal Lifetime Guide to Money (1997, Hyperion). Previously, Wiegold was a vice president of J.P. Morgan & Co., managing editor of the Financial Times of London's World Business Weekly magazine, a reporter at the daily American Banker and a news writer at WFLD-TV in Chicago. Wiegold was born in New Bern, NC on January 26, 1947. He studied political science and broadcast journalism at Northwestern University in Evanston, IL, earning bachelor's and master's degrees. He was a governor of the Overseas Press Club Foundation. He is survived by his wife, Karen Pennar, and their daughter, Gwendolyn. Fred is also survived by his mother, Eloise Wiegold of WinstonSalem, NC, and a cousin, John Connor, of King's Mountain, NC. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions be sent to the Graduate School of Journalism at the City University of New York, specified in the name of Frederic Wiegold. A memorial service will be held Friday, July 25, at 10:30am at the Rye Presbyterian Church in Rye, NY. Reception immediately following the service at Whitby Castle at Rye Golf Club in Rye, NY

With the rise of talk radio in the early 1990s, conservative commentators derisively dubbed newspapers and broadcast television as the ''mainstream media.'' More recently, in the period leading up to the Iraq war, liberal bloggers joined in, abbreviating the term to MSM. But now the Internet has overtaken most newspapers and broadcasts as a source of news, and some on the left say the lingo ought to reflect that.

CUMMINGS--Henrietta, passed away on July 20, 2008, at the age of 95. A Florida native and resident of Miami Beach for 51 years. Beloved surviving wife of Sam. Loving mother of Joy (Steven) Klebanoff and Paul (Jolie) Cummings. Cherished grandmother of Peter Klebanoff, Jennifer (Bill) Lerner, Andrew Cummings and Scott Cummings. An elegant lady of fine character and perseverance, she was blessed with many talents. Among the last of a generation, she will be greatly missed. Contributions in her memory should be made to The Wien Center, Mt. Sinai Medical Center/Miami Heart, 4300 Alton Road, Miami Beach, Florida 33140.

LYMAN--Clara, 87, passed away on Monday, July 21, 2008. She is greatly missed by children Mark Lyman and Paula Nadelstern, grandchildren Arianne, Forrest, Aaron and Ariel, and great-grandchildren Luna and Stella.

VASILIADIS--Joan Stern, 78, passed peacefully at her home in Reston, VA on July 22, 2008. Survived by her husband, Col. Charles C. Vasiliadis (USAF Ret), three sons, Douglas, Mark and Roger, their wives, Helen, Lynne and Lisa, eleven grandchildren, and her brother, Roger Stern, and wife, Sandy. Joan was a lawyer and a teacher. Her caring and understanding drew people of all ages to her and was an inspiration to those who knew her. She will be ever in our hearts and minds. Burial will occur in early September at Arlington National Cemetery.

CARACAPPA--Roger. Dr. Joyce F. Brown, president of the Fashion Institute of Technology, and the FIT community regretfully acknowledge the passing of Roger Caracappa. Roger was instrumental in establishing the masters program in Cosmetics and Fragrance Marketing and Management at FIT, and he served on the programs Steering Committee and Industry Advisory Board. Roger also was a member of the Action Council for the bachelor's degree program in Cosmetics and Fragrance Marketing, and he served as an executive mentor to both undergraduate and graduate students. FIT honored Roger's achievements at the annual Cartier Scholarship luncheon for the bachelor's program in cosmetics in 1997. His leadership will be missed throughout the industry and by his colleagues at FIT.

Mrs. Russo was a payroll tax specialist for KPMG, graduate of Fordham University. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6-9pm Wednesday. MARCHESE--Ramona, 73, known as Tita to her friends, passed away July 3, 2008 from complications of pancreatic cancer. She is survived by her brother, Hector, her niece and nephews Peter, Michael, Victor, and Patricia, and her grand-nieces and nephews Nathan, Alexandra, Connor, and Hannah. NEDERLANDER --Gladys, 83, July 21, 2008. Wife of Robert E. Nederlander, Sr., mother of Steven Stryker, mother-in-law of Beverly Stryker, and grandmother to Micah and Teri Ann Stryker, passed away at Calvary Hospital in New York City. For more than 40 years she produced dozens of plays and television programs of extraordinary breadth and quality. Gladys Nederlander grew up in New York City and moved to Chicago and then to Los Angeles, where she got an early start in show business landing her first job as an assistant on the television show, ''Queen for A Day'' In the mid-1970s she began a theatrical career with Roger L. Stevens developing material for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and for the Broadway stage. Producing credits included ''West Side Story'', ''Caesar and Cleopatra'', ''Perfectly Frank'' and ''Platinum''. In 1992 she became Executive Producer for Nederlander Television and Film Productions, producing a number of television dramas. In 1990 and 1991 she developed and produced for the Arts & Entertainment Network fourteen one act plays written by Pulitzer Prize winning playwrights. Mrs. Nederlander was formerly a member of the Board of the League of American Theatres and Producers and a lifetime Tony voter. Other survivors include niece Debbie Holloway and nephew Richard DeGorter and two stepsons, Robert E. Nederlander, Jr., and Eric Nederlander. Gladys will be deeply missed by her family as well as a large group of devoted friends in New York, Florida and California who treasured her generous gifts of loyalty and friendship. The funeral will take place on July 23, 2008 at 2:30pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York City. Burial will be at Palm Springs Cemetery, Palm Springs, California. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Broadway Cares or the Sloane Kettering Memorial Cancer Institute. A memorial service in New York will be announced in the next few weeks. NEDERLANDER--Gladys, was a unique and lively person and always a devoted and caring friend. We will miss her. Our deepest condolences to Bob and her entire family. Linda and Sandy NEDERLANDER--Glady. My dear, darling, wonderful, sweet Glady, life will not be as much fun without you. You left the world a better place. My condolences to my dear friend Bob Nederlander and the children. Betsy S. Green and Family

KLINGENSTEIN--Selma. The American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) is deeply saddened by the passing of Selma F. Klingenstein, beloved wife of Paul Klingenstein (z''l) and mother of Dr. R. James Klingenstein and Irene Hess. Dedicated Benefactors of the University and devoted to Israel, Selma and Paul established the Paul and Selma Klingenstein Fellowship Fund for Biomedical Research. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Klingenstein Family. May her legacy of goodness live on as an inspiration to others. AFHU Ira Lee Sorkin Chairman George A. Schieren President Peter T. Willner National Executive Director

A headline in The Caucus column on Tuesday with a report about the Iowa Republican Party's decision not to give Senator Charles E. Grassley a vote at the Republican National Convention misidentified the location of the convention in some editions. It is Minneapolis-St. Paul -- not Denver, the site of the Democratic National Convention.

SLIDE SHOW: Great Lawn, Great Exaggerations City officials say slightly fewer than 50,000 fans attended the Bon Jovi concert on the Great Lawn a week ago, and they would know: access to the lawn was tightly controlled. What does that unusually precise figure tell us about past crowd estimates for concerts on the Great Lawn? Chances are good that estimates of 500,000 or more for those concerts were overblown. A retrospective of past concerts in Central Park. nytimes.com/nyregion

10 P.M. (Logo) SORDID LIVES: THE SERIES Del Shores created, wrote and directed this cleverly cast new series, based on his 1999 film, about Peggy Ingram (Rue McClanahan, above right), the matriarch of a small-town Texas family, who takes in Bitsy Mae Harling (Olivia Newton-John, above left), a bar singer who has just been released from prison. Ann Walker plays Peggy's wild-child daughter, LaVonda, who lives with her chain-smoking Aunt Sissy (Beth Grant); Bonnie Bedelia is Latrelle, Peggy's good-girl daughter, who is mainly concerned with keeping up appearances. And then there is Peggy's third child, Brother Boy (Leslie Jordan), who is locked in a mental institution, where he performs as Tammy Wynette and takes therapy sessions with Dr. Eve (Rosemary Alexander), who is attempting to ''dehomosexualize'' him. Caroline Rhea signs on as LaVonda's white-trash best friend. And Jason Dottley, Mr. Shore's real-life husband, plays Latrelle's son Ty, who is trying to come to terms with his own homosexuality by seeing several therapists, portrayed by Margaret Cho, Carson Kressley and Candis Cayne. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Amanda Peet discusses her role in ''The X-Files: I Want to Believe''; Jennifer Hudson performs.

BRIEANT--Charles. The trustees, officers and members of the Federal Bar Council extend their deepest sympathies to the family of Judge Charles L. Brieant, who served as a judge for thirtyseven years and as the Chief Judge for seven years of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. Judge Brieant was widely respected and admired, and he was a valued friend of the Federal Bar Council and the members of the Bar. He will be greatly missed. Mark C. Zauderer, President Federal Bar Council

BERG--Jerome S. The Baruch College community and the Trustees of the Baruch College Fund are saddened to learn of the passing of Jerome S. Berg, class of 1949. A lawyer who was also the president and owner of JahJah Realty, Jerry was a Staten Island resident and successful real estate developer. He was an active participant in the renaissance of The City University of New York, serving as a CUNY Trustee from 1994 to 1997. A Fellow of the Baruch College Fund since 2001, Jerry took great pride in his alma mater and was a generous and unflagging supporter and dear friend. His clear-eyed vision and commitment to Baruch College never wavered. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family, most especially to his wife Helene, his children and grandchildren. Kathleen Waldron, President, Baruch College Larry Simon '65, President The Baruch College Fund BERG--Jerome S. The City University of New York mourns the loss of our esteemed former Trustee and Baruch College alumnus Jerome S. Berg, who served with great distinction as chairman of the Board of Trustees Committee on Academic Policy, Program and Research, and as member of numerous other important Board committees, and whose expertise in construction and maintenance of facilities generously informed the University's capital programs. His exemplary service will be long remembered. We offer our deepest sympathies to his family. Benno C. Schmidt Jr., Chair Trustee Kathleen M. Pesile Trustee Rita DiMartino Matthew Goldstein Chancellor BERG--Jerome. Our heartfelt condolences to Helene, Nancy, Barry, Sarah, Danny and the Berg Family on the passing of our beloved Jerry. Nancy, Marc, Pam, Troy and Mark Bahiri

There must have been moments during the Democratic primary season when former President Bill Clinton wished he had never encountered a member of the press. But when it comes to his Clinton Foundation, Mr. Clinton is sending out the word: Bring it on. Mr. Clinton is inviting members of the press and the public to join him when he takes his annual trip to Africa later this month to promote and continue the work of the foundation he established after his presidency.

ANIXTER--Edward. The leadership and staff of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of Edward Anixter, a member of the American Committee's national Board of Directors and the President's Circle. Edward's longstanding support of the Weizmann Institute of Science reflected a commitment to the future of Science for the Benefit of Humanity and showed great sensitivity towards the individuals working towards it. Among his significant gifts to the Institute were the Anixter Family Foundation Early Childhood Village and the Edith and Edward F. Anixter Postdoctoral Fellowship. Edward's devotion to the Weizmann Institute lives on through his son and daughter, Steven Anixter and Joann Silva, to whom we send heartfelt condolences. May they and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lawrence S. Blumberg Chairman, American Committee Pennie Abramson President, American Committee Marshall S. Levin Exec. V.P. & C.E.O., American Committee Mandy Moross Chair, Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman Pres., Weizmann Institute

LEHMANN--Dr. Margaret Grennan, widow of the late Charles V. Lehmann, died on July 15, 2008 at the age of ninety-five. Born in Manhattan, she was the daughter of Benjamin and Helen Donovan Grennan. A member of Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma Tau Delta, she attended Hunter College for her undergraduate studies and received her M.A. and Ph.D. from Columbia University. She became a full professor of English at Hunter College and then at Lehman College; was later a Professor Emeritus at the City University of New York and lecturer at Columbia University's M.A. Seminars in Victorian Literature. She was elected to Hunter College Hall of Fame for her distinguished career. Her published works include ''The Heart of Newman's Apologia'', ''William Morris, Medievalist and Revolutionary'', ''English Voices -Seventeenth Century and Victorian Sections'', and many articles and reviews spanning English Literature from Chaucer to C.S. Lewis -including ''Lilliput and Leprechaun: Swift and the Irish Tradition'', ''The Lewis Trilogy: A Scholar's Holiday''. At the time of her death she was in the process of publishing a full scale novel set in Rome. Through the years, she has given lectures at colleges, convocations, and communion breakfasts. A Eucharistic Minister at St. Nicolas of Tolentine Church, she was engaged in relief work for Cambodians and Vietnamese in the areas of tutoring, tuition, and guidance. Her brother, Benjamin Grennan, predeceased her. She is survived by her cousins, Joan Scott Frary of Barrington, RI and Katherine Anne McNally Carretta of Framingham, MA, her extended family and many admiring and devoted friends. Visitation will be at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232nd St., Bronx, 718548-1100 on Thursday, July 24th from 2-4pm, and from 68pm. Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated at St. Nicolas of Tolentine Church, Friday, July 25th at 10:00am. Burial will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

In China for the Olympics and looking for some gene doping? Seems you can get everything you need for it, despite the country's well-publicized efforts to stamp out illicit performance-enhancing drugs. That was the experience of journalists in a report shown on the German TV network ARD on Monday. One of the journalists, posing as an American swimming coach, was offered performance-enhancing stem-cell therapy by a Chinese-speaking doctor for $24,000.

The World Bank and its partners need to do a far better job of considering the environmental effects of projects they finance in poor countries, its internal review group concludes in a new report. The review, released Tuesday, examined some of the $400 billion in investments in nearly 7,000 projects from 1990 to 2007. It found that recent pledges for environmental sustainability by the bank and sister institutions, including the International Finance Corporation, were often not put into practice when dollars were turned into dams, pipelines, palm plantations and the like.

In recent years, New York City has been going to great lengths to count the numbers of people who attend big events in the parks like rock concerts and Metropolitan Opera performances. One of those efforts literally ran out of gas, though, at the Bon Jovi concert on Central Park’s Great Lawn on July 12.

Bill Gates and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that they would spend $500 million to stop people around the world from smoking. Mr. Bloomberg’s foundation had already announced a $125 million gift two years ago, but he now plans to commit an additional $250 million over four years. The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is allocating $125 million over five years.Mr. Bloomberg has campaigned against smoking for years. During his administration, New York has adopted several antismoking measures, including a ban on smoking in bars and restaurants, and significant increases in cigarette taxes. But this is a new direction for the Gates Foundation.

One result of the economic crisis facing newspapers and most other media outlets is that the number of foreign correspondents is plummeting. Here at The New York Times, we still have all of our foreign bureaus -- partly because our strategy is to compete for readers who seek international news and analysis -- but most newspapers and TV networks have been pulling back. Only four American newspapers now have foreign desks. And for a network, it's very expensive to base a correspondent in London or Tokyo, and so much easier to film two people yelling at each other in a studio.

This week's guest blogger is Laurent Vernhes, co-founder of the travel Web site Tablet Hotels. Vernhes, who was born in France and lived in half a dozen countries before settling down in Brooklyn, founded Tablet in 2000 as way of helping stylish, culturally attuned travelers find hotels to match. The site's tight edit of properties spans high and low, includes opinionated commentary and ratings, and is showcased annually in a hardcover guide. Read Vernhes's previous posts here.

Many readers took issue with the good news on saturated fat, as I described Gary Taubes's take on a new Israeli study that compared an Atkins-like low-carb diet with other diets. Mr. Taubes, the author of "Good Calories, Bad Calories," noted that the people eating the low-carb diet ate more saturated fat than the other dieters but ended up with an improved cholesterol profile. He called it perhaps the best evidence yet that saturated fat has been wrongly condemned by the American Heart Association and the federal government.

It's a dreary time for Bay Area venture capitalists. Investments are slowing and exits are stalled. Venture capitalists don't expect the I.P.O. drought to ease until 2010, according to a new survey of dealmakers by audit, tax and advisory firm KPMG. Only 9 percent of those surveyed think I.P.O. activity will pick up next year and 12 percent predict it will never again reach historic levels.

Reactions to perfumes vary. Delight, disgust, joy, indifference, melancholy, amusement (both negative and positive), rapture. It is in anticipation of these emotions that we eagerly await new works from major artists like Jean-Claude Ellena, Hermès's in-house perfumer. Art is by definition a profession of risks, and if nobody bats a thousand, Ellena's risks have often actually altered the art form itself, and his contributions have been major. It is therefore somewhat strange that the primary emotion generated by Ellena's new Hermès scent, Un Jardin Après la Mousson, is the most profound bafflement.

In one sense, Dubai ran dry years ago. The tiny kingdom, one of seven that make up the United Arab Emirates, once used the cash it generated from pumping oil and gas to fuel its ambitions. But now that the wells are nearly depleted, it has focused on banking, finance and deal making to keep the boom times flowing.

BAGHDAD -- This spring I needed to interview former detainees in American detention centers who had recently been released, so I went to Anbar Province, a vast western desert area of Iraq that lies between Baghdad and Jordan. It is best known for the turbulent town of Falluja, which became a headquarters for Al Qaeda in Iraq and where the Americans fought bloody battles in 2004. It then became something of a ghost town peopled almost exclusively by fighters. Eventually, the Marines completely controlled it and the violence migrated elsewhere. But many of those who had been detained there were locals, and eventually they returned to their homes.

[UPDATE 7/25: More on Arctic oil and the environment.] The U.S. Geological Survey has released the first Arctic-wide estimate of undiscovered natural gas and oil deposits and come up with huge numbers for both, at least on first glance. The region north of the Arctic Circle, the agency said, probably has a third of the world's remaining uncharted gas and 20 percent of the remaining oil.

There are many, many reasons reporters at the Tribune Company newspapers feel that their new boss, Sam Zell, is in over his head. When he took over the Tribune -- in a deal where he cleverly put the employees' ESOP at risk, rather than his own fortune -- he promised that he and his team would approach things differently, and would revive ad sales instead of cutting jobs. But he soon discovered what everyone else in the business already knew: ad sales are falling off the cliff, and no amount of wishful thinking can turn that around. So what did he do? He started laying off people -- in some cases as much as 25 percent of the newsroom.
Thursday marks the 25th anniversary of the "Pine Tar Game" at Yankee Stadium, an episode that George Brett still can't believe is his most famous moment in baseball.

Even as two billionaires kicked off a global anti-smoking initiative on Tuesday, one of them tried to lower expectations just a little. "All the money in the world will never eradicate tobacco," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said, with Bill Gates at his side. This morning, a survey from Gallup seemed to back up his point, at least in the United States. Even though smoking is now at its lowest level ever, progress seems to be stalling in the low 20's in recent years. How low do you think American tobacco use can go?
A lot of bicycles are stolen in London -- nearly 19,000 a year, according to Reuters. But thieves who prefer to operate in the shadows have stumbled today into the top of Britain's headlines.

Congressional reapportionment will await the 2010 census, and won't affect the Electoral College until the 2012 presidential race, but that hasn't stopped Michael Barone from doing a little reading of the tea leaves. Relying on figures from the political statistics guru Clark Bensen at the site Polidata, which show states that George Bush won 2004 gaining eight electoral votes and states won by John Kerry losing eight, Barone sees happy days ahead for the G.O.P.

MINTZER--Mark A. , DMD. The Officers and Board of Directors of the New York County Dental Society are deeply saddened by the loss of its fellow board member. Mark's leadership as president in 2000 as well as his many contributions to the profession were exemplary and will always be remembered. Our sympathies to Beverly, Matthew, Barry and the entire family. Anthony E. Chillura, DMD President Michael G. Arvystas, DMD President Elect Edward J. Miller, Jr. DMD Vice President Patricia Sukmonowski, DDS Treasurer Ellen Gerber, Executive Director MINTZER--Mark Arthur, D.M.D., on July 22, 2008 at his family's country home on Shelter Island, NY after a short illness at the age of 65. Devoted husband of Beverly, proud father of Matthew and beloved brother of Barry, Mark figured prominently in the New York City, State and national dental community for much of his nearly 40year career in private practice. A board member and former president of the New York County Dental Society, at the time of his death he was 2008 Chair of the N.Y.S. Board for Dentistry, where he had served since 2002. A graduate of the University of Wisconsin and the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine, he joined the Manhattan practice of his father, the late Marcus A. Mintzer, D.D.S, in 1970 and continued it after his father's retirement. Mark will be greatly missed by the three generations of patients he cared for with consummate skill, deep compassion and unfailing humor. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to a charity of your choice. Service Friday 10am. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. MINTZER--Mark. So many years of your friendship and love. So many reasons to miss you always. Ric and Susan MINTZER--Mark, D.M.D. You will be so terribly missed by Cas and Carole. Our prayers and hearts are with Beverly and Matthew. Cas and Carole Castagnoli MINTZER--Mark. My family joins me in expressing our heartfelt condolences to Mark's family and staff. We have all suffered a great loss. Argie Simon

After years of false starts, a new industry selling motor fuel made from waste is getting a big push in the United States, with the first commercial sales possible within months. Many companies have announced plans to build plants that would take in material like wood chips, garbage or crop waste and turn out motor fuels. Rose's brilliance, expertise and compassion won the love and respect of all who had the privilege of knowing her. Rose was a lady in the fullest sense; she upheld sound judgment and strong values in a soft voice wearing fashionable hats. A proud and outstanding clinician, Rose was also a woman of vision who always had a kind word for everyone. Our hearts go out to Rose's devoted daughters, Alison, Beryl and Meredith, grandchildren, her family and many friends. Our legacy to Rose is that we will try to maintain her vision and follow in her elegant footsteps. Hannah Achtenberg Kinn, C.E.O. JONES--Rose Victoria Randolph, beloved widow of Dr. Cyril J. As many have been saying all along, Senator Barack Obama is only the presumed Democratic nominee. And that fact has given heart to some of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's supporters, who are investing tens of thousands of dollars to pressure the party to put her name to a binding vote at the convention next month. The Denver Group, founded by two political novices who say they have been frustrated with the treatment of Mrs. Clinton since February, ran full-page advertisements on Wednesday and two weeks ago in The Chicago Tribune and Congressional Quarterly calling for Mrs. Clinton to be placed ''in nomination'' in Denver. They contend that because neither candidate has enough elected delegates to claim the nomination, Democratic Party rules stipulate that a binding roll-call vote of the superdelegates must be conducted to break the tie.

(CNN) BLACK IN AMERICA: BLACK MEN In Part 2 of this four-hour report, Soledad O'Brien investigates whether there are two ''black Americas'' -- success for some, but challenges for many more -- using the stories of members of the 1968 class of Central High School (above, from left, Kenneth Talley, Akono Ekundayo, Donald Gray and James Warren) in Little Rock, Ark., and of their sons and grandsons. Topics include fatherhood; disparities between blacks and whites in educational, career and financial achievement; the high rate of incarceration of black men; and the positive influence of black fathers. Then Ms. O'Brien asks whether the dream of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is still alive. 10 A.M. SLOMAN--Marvin Sherk . Renowned Dallas appellate lawyer Marvin S. Sloman died peacefully Sunday morning, July 20, after struggling to recover from a stroke he suffered on December 15, 2007. He was 83. Mr. Sloman was an original founding member of Carrington, Coleman, Sloman & Blumenthal, LLP, a law firm respected and honored by its clients and other lawyers alike. In this age of specialization, Mr. Sloman maintained a general business practice, representing clients both big and small in business transactions and courtroom battles. Leaving jury trials to his close friend and partner James Coleman, Mr. Sloman focused on arguing matters of law and jurisprudence through motions, briefs, and appeals. His reputation and success in such matters lead to his representation of many local, national, and international clients, typically involving complex interpretations of the law. Not only did his partners seek his expertise regarding their own motions and appeals, but other law firms frequently asked him to contribute to theirs. His keen insight, writing ability, and oratory skills, not to mention his professional integrity, earned him praise from judges and justices throughout the nation. Mr. Sloman also willingly passed on his legal knowledge, skills, and abilities to seminar and conference audiences, but he particularly relished mentoring associates at the law firm. Of particular note during his 58 year legal career are his two appearances before the United States Supreme Court, both of which he won. And he was particularly proud to have been asked by the judges of the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals to form the Fifth Circuit Bar Association, becoming its first president. He also served as Chairman of the Corporation, Banking, and Business Law Section and, later, the Appellate Practice and Advocacy Section of the State Bar of Texas. Mr. Sloman was a long-time member of the American Law Institute. Mr. Sloman's college education was interrupted by World War II, in which he served in the Naval Reserve. He returned to the University of Texas after the War and earned his undergraduate degree in 1948. He was a member of Kappa Sigma fraternity. After graduating in 1950 from the University of Texas School of Law (where he served on the Board of Editors of the Texas Law Review), Mr. Sloman moved to New York to practice law at the Wall Street law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell under the tutelage of William Piel. While in New York, he met and married Margaret Jane Dinwiddie in 1953. They moved to Dallas in 1956 to raise their family. He joined the Dallas law firm of Carrington, Gowen, Johnson, Bromberg & Leeds as an associate, later becoming a partner in the firm of Carrington, Johnson & Stephens. Born in 1925, Mr. Sloman spent his youth in Fort Worth where he graduated from Pascal High School. His mother, Janette Sloman, and grandmother, Sarah Sherk, contributed to his interest in art, literature, cuisine, and, especially, music, preferably classical and 1920s jazz. He loved to debate the finer points of everything around him. His curiosity often lead him to carefully study and gain mastery, whether the subject was camping, fishing, hunting, sports, carpentry, travel, electronics, or one of his many other interests. He sought the best and to be the best. Such passion, at times, lead to a quick temper, but one that was easily overlooked by those who appreciated his broad knowledge and quick wit. A significant accomplishment was Mr. Sloman's single-handed construction, board by board and nail by nail, of a hexagonal country home outside of Winnsboro, Texas, commonly referred to as ''Homebrew'' for the creek that ran through the property. A loving husband, father, and grandfather, Mr. Sloman is survived by his wife, Margaret, daughter, Lucy, and son, Dinnie. Lucy Sloman, an urban designer and planner, is married to Stephen Antupit. They reside in Seattle, Washington with their son, Henry, and daughter, Natalie. Dinnie Sloman, a Cornell Cooperative Extension administrator, lives with his wife, Lisa Flachs, and two daughters, Josephine and Emmalee, in Oneonta, New York. Visiting hours will be held from 4:00pm to 6:00pm on Saturday, July 26, 2008, at Sparkman/Hillcrest Funeral Home in Dallas. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made in Mr. Sloman's name to the Texas Chapter of The Nature Conservancy, Texas Old Missions and Forts Restoration Association, or to a charity of your choice. An on-line memorial book is available at www.mem.com. Sparkman/ Hillcrest, 7405 W. Northwest Hwy., Dallas, TX 75225, 214363-5401.

GOLDSMITH--Ludwig Mi chael , known as Michael, 57, of Upper Montclair, NJ, died at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center on July 23, 2008. Michael was the owner of Ludwig Michael Goldsmith, AIA, an architectural firm in Manhattan. He specialized in interiors as well as building design for both profit and non-profit organizations. He is a graduate of the Cornell University School of Architecture and has a Masters in Urban Planning from the City College of New York. Michael served as an officer in the United States Navy for four years following his college graduation. His love for life was contagious as well as his laughter and beautiful spirit. Michael's funeral will be held on Thursday, July 24 at noon at Congregation Shomrei Emunah in Montclair, New Jersey. John McBride, a mason — or bricklayer — from Donegal, Ireland, started in construction work when he was 16, specializing in it in school and eventually completing four years of training and another three years of work to get full trade certification. He started his own company, then came to the United States, where he worked for someone else again for six years, then started another company of his own, Mulroy Masonry in Maspeth, Queens. In short, Mr. McBride, who is in his late 30s now, has spent more than half his life working with bricks. These are not the credentials that many people associate with modern Manhattan construction work, with its soaring glass-and-steel skyscrapers (notwithstanding the Empire State Building, which is, of course, made of stone).

The iconic style of the '70s surf star Mark Richards - subject of the new documentary "Bustin' Down the Door" - is making a comeback. (Dan Merkel)Ask the paradigm-shifting surfers of the '70s about style, and they'll talk about being the first to ride backside at Pipeline, or carving up waves that had only ever been surfed in a straight line - to them, style was something achieved in the water, not in front of a mirror. But catch "Bustin' Down the Door," a documentary opening today about the birth of modern pro surfing on Hawaii's North Shore in 1975, and you'll get an eyeful of audacious beachfront fashion. It reeks of the Ford era, but is somehow terribly now. So, if you're really intent on pulling off that authentic '70s look, ditch your American Apparel and paddle out into the lineup with these style-pioneering surf gods. We just hope you're man enough to rock the shortest of boardshorts.

British Airways' $108 million acquisition of L'Avion formally closed on Friday, marking the end, at least for now, of the independent, all-business-class airline. L'Avion, which operated out of Paris, was the last of the four trans-Atlantic, coachless carriers still standing following a spike in fuel prices that forced the other three to shut down.

Cornell's Jon Jaques gave Quad readers an inside look at the N.C.A.A. tournament in March. Now he's back to tell us how some Division I basketball players spend their summers. Jon is back in his Southern California home this summer, where he is interning for Think Cure, the official charity of the Los Angeles Dodgers which benefits cancer research in local hospitals. He is also playing in "Rico's Get Better League," which features college players from all levels. He'll be checking in with The Quad from time to time to let us know what he's up to. In this first installment he talks about the importance of conditioning. Be sure to check back for more from Jon in the next few weeks.

This week's guest blogger is Laurent Vernhes, co-founder of the travel Web site Tablet Hotels. Vernhes, who was born in France and lived in half a dozen countries before settling down in Brooklyn, founded Tablet in 2000 as way of helping stylish, culturally attuned travelers find hotels to match. The site's tight edit of properties spans high and low, includes opinionated commentary and ratings, and is showcased annually in a hardcover guide. Read Vernhes's previous posts here.

If you'll recall: A little movie called "Sex and the City" featured a fictional book, "Love Letters of Great Men." Well, fiction has become fact: Inspired by the movie, Pan Macmillan, the U.K. book publisher, is releasing "Love Letters of Great Men" next week. Darwin and Flaubert, Mozart and Twain, Browning and Wilde - "every shade of love is here," the book site proclaims. And it can all be yours, if you're willing to shell out £9.99 plus shipping. (Although, one has to think a U.S. version can't be far behind. ...)

"Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?" and "So You Think You Can Dance" made Fox the No. 1 rated network on Thursday, drawing 7.3 million and 8.3 million viewers, respectively, at 8 and 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates.

The United States lost Budweiser to Belgium last week, but the nation's love affair with beer remains strong. A survey released today on Americans alcoholic beverage preferences showed a widening lead for beer over wine, which slightly led the pack in 2005. Gallup says that 42 percent of those polled earlier this month preferred beer and 31 percent wine. Liquor devotees comprised another 23 percent.

Click this photo to watch a video interview of Anna Faris.Back in her high school days, Anna Faris could never have imagined herself in a Playboy Bunny costume, much less as the new star of our home page. Faris has acknowledged a theater-nerd past, albeit one in which she dreamed of becoming a serious, dramatic actor. And yet, with a handful of outrageous comedic roles under her belt, including as a vapid movie star in "Lost in Translation" and a past-her-prime Playboy Bunny in the upcoming "The House Bunny," it's safe to say her career took an unexpected turn. Today, in an exclusive Screen Test, the funny girl talks to Lynn Hirschberg about seeking her parents' approval, the astonishing kindness of real Playboy Bunnies and the difficulty of being a woman in comedy. Prepare to be charmed.

The news that Peter Som has left Bill Blass makes me think the owners (or the next owners) ought to find a good creative director type and stick with licensing. If my count is correct, I think the label has had four designers since Bill Blass sold the company and retired. Unless the owners are really prepared to manage and invest in a high-quality ready-to-wear business, I think they should just skip it. Too much ground as been lost in an increasingly competitive marketplace-and we are only starting to see what can happen with imaginative online fashion. Blass is behind the proverbial eight ball.

Lawmakers have leveled some scathing adjectives at the IntercontinentalExchange, known as the ICE, a technology company whose electronic markets are at the center of fierce debates about commodity speculation raging in Congress recently. Mike Weir shot a bogey-free six-under-par 65 for a share of the Canadian Open lead with Anthony Kim and Eric Axley during the suspended first round in Oakville, Ontario. Only half the players were able to finish the round, which was delayed by rain and lightning for 5 hours 42 minutes.

Chicago midfielder Cuauhtemoc Blanco scored one goal and helped set up another, and Houston midfielder Dwayne DeRosario snapped a tie with a penalty kick to give the M.L.S. All-Stars a 3-2 victory in Toronto over the English Premier League team West Ham United.

An article on Wednesday about Nissan’s plans for automaking in the United States referred incorrectly to the status of a Volkswagen plant to be built in Chattanooga, Tenn. While it will be the only VW plant in operation in the United States, it will not be the first VW factory here. Volkswagen operated a plant near Pittsburgh from 1978 to 1988.

The Shifting Careers column on the Small Business page on Thursday, about nonprofit groups that nurture new businesses, misspelled the surname of Chicago’s mayor, whose former technology adviser, David Weinstein, is president of one such group, the Chicagoland Entrepreneurial Center. The mayor is Richard M. Daley, not Daly.

A headline on a report in the Sports Briefing column on Tuesday about Marion Jones, the former track star sentenced to six months in prison for lying to federal agents about her use of performance-enhancing drugs, misidentified the type of application she has submitted to President Bush. It seeks to have her sentence commuted; it does not ask for a pardon.

A report in the National Briefing column on Thursday about the sentencing of Nicole D. Boyd, who was involved in a theft from an armored car company in Ohio, misstated the age of another woman charged in the case. S. Lee Gregory, one of Ms. Boyd’s co-defendants, is 49, not 48.

The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, of “Everything Is Cinema,” by Richard Brody, about the director Jean-Luc Godard, misidentified the distributor of a film by Madonna, who said she was influenced by the French filmmaker. It will be released by IFC, not iTunes.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about “Swimmable River,” a report by the Riverkeeper environmental group on the water quality of the Hudson estuary from New York Harbor to Troy, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a research assistant who was taking samples from the East River. She is Carol Knudson, not Knudsen.

An article on Thursday about John McCain’s campaign efforts in Arizona, his home state, referred incorrectly to Paradise Valley, the home of a Republican voter who said he was disenchanted with Mr. McCain. It is a town near Phoenix, not a neighborhood in Phoenix.

Four days after nearly making history at the British Open, Greg Norman labored to a four-over-par 75 in the opening round of the Senior British Open in Troon, Scotland. He finished seven shots behind the co-leaders, Bruce Vaughan and Eduardo Romero. Norman’s playing partner, Tom Watson, missed only one fairway in a bogey-free 70.

Lorena Ochoa shot a seven-under-par 65 to take a one-stroke lead after the first round of the Evian Masters in Evian-les-Bains, France. Ochoa started with a birdie on the first hole and added six more on the back nine in a bogey-free round. Ahn Sun-ju, Candie Kung and Angela Park trailed by one stroke.

Andy Roddick followed Roger Federer out of the Rogers Cup after he was upset by 44th-ranked Marin Cilic, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, Thursday in Toronto. Fourth-seeded Nikolay Davydenko became the latest upset victim when he dropped a 4-6, 6-4, 6-4 decision to Nicolas Kiefer.

The Brazilian swimmer Rebeca Gusmao has received her second two-year doping suspension after a positive test for testosterone at a 2006 competition. The ban was announced months after Gusmao was suspended for testing positive for the same substance before the 2007 Pan American Games in Rio de Janeiro. Gusmao could be banned from the sport if the current rulings stand.

The former Penn State football player Chris Bell has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of making terroristic threats. The case dated to April, when the police said that Bell stormed into a campus dining hall and threatened his teammate Devon Still with an eight-inch knife. The police said that three assistant football coaches disarmed Bell, who was later kicked off the team.

ANIMATION BLOCK PARTY Founded five years ago, Animation Block Party is a three-day festival of work from professional, amateur and student animators. The screenings this weekend in Brooklyn are made for an audience with a YouTube attention span: according to Casey Safron, the festival's founder, the longest piece is just 18 minutes, the shortest are only 10 seconds and the average is around 5 minutes. Mr. Safron selected the more than 100 films from more than 800 submissions, nearly double what he received last year; there are awards in categories like experimental work, documentary, music video and one-minute movie. (The longest work, ''24 Frames,'' is a stop-motion film about a stop-motion production being made at an art school -- a meta-stop-motion epic, Mr. Safron called it.) Several pieces screened in past years -- including ''Breakfast,'' above -- have been turned into television and Web series for MTV and the Sundance Channel.

A report in The Caucus column on July 12 about Republican criticism of Senator Barack Obama after he said that Americans would profit from learning foreign languages gave an incorrect name for the national language of Indonesia. It called Bahasa Indonesia, or Indonesian -- not simply Bahasa, which means ''language.''

'JACK AND THE BEANSTALK' It's hard to picture Manhattan skyscrapers being overshadowed by anything leafy and green. But that's happening now (with the help of children's imaginations) where hardy vegetation often takes root: Central Park. There the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater is presenting Michael Alogna and Larry Aumen's musical adaptation of ''Jack and the Beanstalk,'' that David-and-Goliath tale of a poor boy and his climb to a giant's stratospheric castle (above). The production's elaborate marionettes include a sprightly Jack; Citronella, the Giant's servant, who resembles Phyllis Diller; Dolly, Jack's cuddly-looking cow; and a Bing Crosby-like peddler, who sings ''Swinging on a Star'' when he offers the magic beans. They are almost eclipsed by the prodigious beanstalk, which grows before the audience's eyes center stage. It's a rare show in which the scenery does the scenery chewing.

Cas and Carole Castagnoli MINTZER--Mark Arthur, D.M.D., on July 22, 2008 at his family's country home on Shelter Island, NY after a short illness at the age of 65. Devoted husband of Beverly, proud father of Matthew and beloved brother of Barry, Mark figured prominently in the New York City, State and national dental community for much of his nearly 40year career in private practice. A board member and former president of the New York County Dental Society, at the time of his death he was 2008 Chair of the N.Y.S. Board for Dentistry, where he had served since 2002. A graduate of the University of Wisconsin and the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine, he joined the Manhattan practice of his father, the late Marcus A. Mintzer, D.D.S, in 1970 and continued it after his father's retirement. Mark will be greatly missed by the three generations of patients he cared for with consummate skill, deep compassion and unfailing humor. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to a charity of your choice. Service Friday 10am. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

HOLLANDER--Ralph , violinist, composer and inventor of the DAMPIT, died peacefully on July 23, 2008 at age 91 at his home in NYC. Born in Mount Vernon, NY on November 9, 1916. Preceded in death by his wife Ingrid in 1990. Survived by his brother Norman, three nieces and one nephew. He began performing classical trios at age eight with his two brothers as The Hollander Trio. A graduate of Juilliard School of Music, he had a career as a virtuoso violinist, performing with Casals Festival Orchestra and as soloist with national and international orchestras. Among other compositions, he composed and recorded an oratorio ''Psalms of David'' with Agnes Moorehead as narrator. He invented and manufactured the DAMPIT, the first humidification device to preserve and restore dry and damaged wood of violins and other valuable stringed instruments. The DAMPIT was endorsed by Isaac Stern, Mstislav Rostropovich, Pablo Casals, Yo Yo Ma, Leopold Stokowski and Arturo Toscanini. A memorial service will be held Monday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to Juilliard School of Music for students scholarships.

KOEHLER--Audrey , 81, on Saturday, July 19th at her home in Southampton, NY. The daughter of Walter L. Carey and Frances McKeever, Audrey was born June 4th, 1927 in New York City and grew up in Southampton and Santa Barbara, CA, where she went to Santa Barbara High School. A graduate of the New York School of Interior Design, she set up her own decorating firm in the 1960s, which she ran for more than thirty years. Among many charitable activities, she helped organize Les Boutiques de Noel, the holiday shopping bazaar that benefited Cancer Care and co-founded Parrish Presents, the annual holiday bazaar that benefits the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton. She is survived by her husband of 44 years, the artist Henry Koehler; her two sons, Alexander Mason (of Owings Mills, MD and Southampton) and Anthony Mason (of Rye, NY); and five grandchildren: Taylor, Christopher, Emily, Olivia and Nicholas. A private memorial service will be held later this summer in Southampton. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Parrish Art Museum, 25 Jobs Lane, Southampton, NY 11968 or East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978-7048.

BANKS--Wendy , 61, passed away July 17th from respiratory failure. She was the beloved daughter of Estelle and the late Lou Banks, former longtime director of Camp Kenico in Kent, CT. Wendy's marketing career began at Revlon, later becoming VP for Charles of the Ritz Group. She was at Liz Claiborne from 1986 to 1995, first as VP of Liz Claiborne Cosmetics, soon promoted to President of that division, and then SVP of marketing in 1990. Under her leadership, Claiborne launched ''Women's Work'', a program focusing on domestic violence. In 1995, Wendy created Banks, a marketing consulting firm, and more recently established The Village Sheep yarn shop in New Milford, CT. Wendy was an active and beloved member of the Greater Washington (CT) Coalition for Jewish Life. She had incredible energy and a zest for life, and will be missed by all who knew and loved her. She is survived by her mother, sister Roslyn Arkin, nephew David Arkin, and many cousins. A memorial service will be held Sunday July 27th at 10am at B'nai Israel Sanctuary, 444 Main St. N., Southbury, CT. Donations may be made to Safe Horizon victim advocacy fund.

PRYOR--Hubert , an editor who started the AARP publication ''Modern Maturity'' on its climb to becoming the largest circulation magazine in the world, died July 15 in his home in South Palm Beach, Florida at age 92. Pryor became editor of ''Modern Maturity,'' now known as ''AARP, The Magazine,'' in 1967, in the early years of the American Association of Retired Persons. A former senior editor of Look Magazine and editor of Science Digest, Pryor hired an editorial staff and called on writers, photographers and artists around the country to produce a magazine meeting the needs of America's fast-growing retirement population. When he joined the magazine in 1967, its circulation stood at 700,000. Fifteen years later, when he retired, the magazine's circulation had increased tenfold to 7 million. Upon retirement in 1982, he was an associate director of AARP. Born in Argentina of British and American parents, Pryor was educated at English schools in Buenos Aires and the University of London. He began his career as South American correspondent of the wire service then known as United Press. In 1940, in the United States, he went to work as a reporter for the New York Herald Tribune. Later he was director of shortwave news for CBS and also covered the United Nations in its earliest days following World War II. During the war years, he served as an officer in U.S. Naval Intelligence. For 15 years after that, he worked as a senior editor of Look Magazine and for four years was editor of Science Digest. After his retirement, he was a free-lance writer in South Palm Beach, Florida, and in 1995 published ''Soul Talk,'' a book of meditations. In 1940 he was married to Ellen May Ach. He later married Roberta Baughman Smith and Luanne Williamson van Norden. All three marriages ended in divorce. He had three sons with the former Ellen Ach, Alan of Novato, California, and Gerald and David, both of New York City. They survive him, along with six grandchildren and a brother, Louis Pryor of Palm Beach. A memorial service is planned in Palm Beach this Fall. Remembrances to pryor.alan@gmail.com

8 P.M. (TCM) BEDKNOBS AND BROOMSTICKS (1971) Turner Classic Movies pays tribute to Roddy McDowall -- ''a child actor who was able to continue his career when he grew out of his 'cute' phase,'' as a release puts it, even though he played 14-year-old boys until he was 23. This triple bill begins with ''Bedknobs and Broomsticks,'' the Disney musical starring McDowall as Mr. Jelk, a London vicar, and his friend Angela Lansbury as Eglantine Price, the apprentice witch of Portobello Road. In ''Lassie Come Home'' (1943), a 10-year-old McDowall, above, plays the young master of the stoic collie in her film debut. And in ''Lord Love a Duck'' (1966), at midnight, he portrays a possibly deranged high school student who recalls his infatuation with an exchange student (Tuesday Weld) who, through his Svengali-like influence, goes on to become a star. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Topics include looking younger and understanding colleagues' body language. And the latest castoff from ''Greatest American Dog'' shows the audience some new tricks.
