There is a Chase branch at Broadway and 58th Street. And there is a Chase branch at Broadway and 62nd. But in between, there is not a single Chase branch on Broadway. That means that a Chase customer stranded, say, at West 60th Street must walk two whole blocks before those bold blue octagons float reassuringly back into view. So residents of the Lincoln Square neighborhood may be cheered by the news that JPMorgan Chase has leased an 11,000-square-foot, two-level space at Broadway and 61st Street. The branch will occupy one corner of the full-block 15 Central Park West apartment tower and is to open later this year.

GAZA -- It may sound like the indulgence of a well-fed man fleeing the misery around him. But when Jawdat N. Khoudary opens the first museum of archaeology in Gaza this summer it will be a form of Palestinian patriotism, showing how this increasingly poor and isolated coastal strip ruled by the Islamists of Hamas was once a thriving multicultural crossroad. The exhibition is in a stunning hall made partly of stones from old houses, discarded wood ties of a former railroad and bronze lamps and marble columns uncovered by Gazan fishermen and construction workers.
GRANT--Annette Oliver . Memorial Service Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. at 90th St., Saturday 7/26, 11am.

A report in The Caucus column on Thursday about efforts by backers of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to have her name placed in nomination at the Democratic National Convention misstated the backers' position on the party's obligation to hold a binding roll-call vote of superdelegates. The backers, known as the Denver Group, say party rules call for the start of a process that could lead to Mrs. Clinton's name being presented for possible nomination at the convention; they do not contend that the rules dictate that her name be ''placed in nomination.'' The article also referred incorrectly to the job status of a co-founder of the group, Marc Rubin. He currently writes for television and movies; he is not a former television writer.

FOR CHILDREN AEROBALLOON RIDES (Friday through Thursday) Flying low over Central Park used to be the province only of the park's winged inhabitants and the occasional helicopter. But now, in celebration of the 150th anniversary of the park's original design, the Central Park Conservancy and the Department of Parks and Recreation are offering daily rides in the helium-filled AeroBalloon, which soars to a height of 300 feet, or about 30 stories. The balloon takes off every 10 to 15 minutes from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m., weather permitting, so voyagers (a maximum of four) can admire the park in sunlight or moonlight. (Through Aug. 22.) At Cherry Hill, at 72nd Street in the park, (646) 827-6287, aeroballoon.com; $25; $17.50 for children (must be at least 40 inches tall and accompanied by an adult if under 16). Reservations accepted for 7 to 10 a.m., then first come first served.

The home of the late naturalist Roger Tory Peterson, known as the Cedars, is on a seven-acre promontory surrounded by 63 acres of Nature Conservancy land. It includes the 1920s main house (above), a two-bedroom guesthouse and the original artist's studio. Agents: Diane Gregory and Roger Parkman, Coldwell Banker; (860) 395-8433, www.cbmove.com.

A Weekend in Palermo After decades of postwar neglect, the Sicilian capital is poised for a comeback. Crumbling roads are being repaved and landmarks are being scrubbed clean. A slide show of some of Palermo's best, including the statues in the Oratorio del Rosario di Santa Cita, far left, and the banyan trees in Piazza Marina, left.

California on Thursday ordered the 2,000 big ships calling on its ports every year to switch to low-sulfur fuel whenever they were within 24 miles of the coast, in what state officials said was the world's strictest emissions standards for marine diesels. The rule, promulgated by the California Air Resources Board, would require switching to a fuel with 97 percent less sulfur. Sulfur in diesel fuel combines with other pollutants to make tiny particles that are linked to cancer and other illnesses.

The walls between old allies on either side of the Atlantic cannot stand. The walls between the countries with the most and those with the least cannot stand. The walls between races and tribes, natives and immigrants, Christian and Muslim and Jew cannot stand. These now are the walls we must tear down. SENATOR BARACK OBAMA, speaking in Berlin. [A19]

Want to score one of the tickets to Senator Barack Obama's speech accepting the Democratic presidential nomination in Denver next month? You won't have to pay, but you may have to work for it, according to the Obama campaign. The speech will be unlike most other convention addresses in that it will not be at the convention hall. Instead, it will be given at Invesco Field, home of the Denver Broncos, allowing people who are not delegates, big donors or politicians to attend.

The Short Sales Syndrome James Cramer, the hedge fund manager turned ''Mad Money'' host, has proposed a solution to the raging controversy over short-selling. It mostly involves the troubled financial sector getting its act together -- and thus making itself immune to the ''carpet bombs'' that he says hedge funds have been raining down on vulnerable firms like Lehman Brothers.
Louis Langrée kicks off the festival on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall, conducting works by Mozart and Mahler.
''Being Brooklyn, superheroes have never been in short supply, especially in the neighborhoods (excuse me) south of Prospect Park!'' -- Victor Goodstone, on

The presidential candidates have tried all manner of ways to pry money out of donors this year through the Internet. Now, the Republican National Committee has come up with a technique that can generate cash for the party when a supporter searches the Web for, say, ''Barack Obama.'' Viewed as a win-win for both the committee and e-commerce sites, a new browser toolbar allows users to send two or three cents each time they conduct a Yahoo-based Web search through the toolbar. The service also lets the R.N.C. take a percentage of sales when toolbar users make purchases from about 300 vendors around the Web.

An online citizen-journalist project that sought innovative approaches to journalism celebrates its anniversary this month, having already had some effect on the presidential campaign. Of all the new political, noncandidate Web sites to spring up in the last year, OffTheBus.net is now probably the biggest, with 7,500 citizen correspondents. Despite its growing pains, the project, an arm of The Huffington Post, continues to develop the technological and organizational know-how to become a media force as it challenges the standard notions of traditional journalism.
A revival of Christopher Durang's snappy 1985 saga of a grimly unhappy marriage is playing Off Broadway at the Laura Pels Theater.
A look at some of the actress’s theatrical performances.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. - Major League Baseball on Saturday reiterated its decision to discontinue the annual Hall of Fame game here, a tradition that began in 1940. This year's game between the Chicago Cubs and the San Diego Padres was rained out. When M.L.B. announced its decision in January, it cited a problem scheduling teams to play on a day off.
A new breed of camp counselors deal with demanding parents.
A new brick building at 211 Elizabeth Street is being laid the old-fashioned way -- by hand.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. -- Rich (Goose) Gossage's first three seasons as a major league pitcher were spent with Dick Allen as a Chicago White Sox teammate. The slugger turned out to be a pretty good pitching coach for a right-hander with heat, who would reach the acme of his powers as a closer with the Yankees.

With the competition between the Iowa State sophomore quarterbacks Austen Arnaud and Phillip Bates ongoing, Cyclones Coach Gene Chizik is unlikely to pick a starter until the week of his team's season opener.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. -- The official record says that Dick Williams, who will be inducted Sunday into the National Baseball Hall of Fame, managed six major league teams. But he held the title for a seventh team, albeit briefly: the Yankees.
Jason Giambi was 10 years old when he sat in the stands at Dodger Stadium for Game 5 of the 1981 World Series. He clearly remembers the Yankees' Goose Gossage beaning the Dodgers' Ron Cey.

Updated It would seem that Senator Barack Obama and his campaign staff traveled to several countries during his overseas tour without saying or doing something that would fall into the "gaffe" category. But it appears to be what he didn't do - meeting with wounded soldiers, as he had originally planned - at Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Germany, that is continuing to reverberate after Mr. Obama's trip.
The candidates themselves are the highlight of Sunday's talk schedule, with both making multiple appearances.
With the Olympics two weeks away, track and field athletes are getting their last tune-ups in before the Beijing Games.
Sports Illustrated's web site has posted a long photo essay on the decline of the Islanders which starts here. If a picture is worth a thousand words, this is 27,000 words worth of misery.
Images from a 48-hour changeover between productions at the Cape Playhouse in Dennis, Mass.

Cooperstown during Hall of Fame induction weekend is a bonanza for autograph-seekers. Not everyone affixing his names to bats, balls and photographs is enshrined here, most notably Pete Rose, a perennial big draw.
Location: Eugene, Ore.

Senator Barack Obama spent the morning in London, meeting with British Prime Minister Gordon Brown, as well as the opposition party leader. On Friday, he appeared (briefly) in Paris with a gushing French president, Nicolas Sarkozy.

LONDON - Senators John McCain and Barack Obama engaged in a trans-Atlantic bickering match of sorts on Saturday, with Mr. McCain devoting the opening minutes of his weekly radio address to criticize Mr. Obama's weeklong trip through the Middle East and Europe.

Since the 2004 Olympics, blogs and the Internet have revolutionized the way athletes can relay their messages. Instead of enduring what they perceive to be injustices from the national governing bodies in their sports, athletes now can simply write about them on their blogs.
More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, July 26:

If someone wants to write against the grain, the equivalent of cutback moves by Emmitt Smith and Thurman Thomas in the 90s, I'm happy to provide a forum. It makes life more interesting (and you can't cash a check with conventional wisdom).
The ancient city of Pompeii has fallen so far into disrepair that the Italian government has declared a state of emergency.
From a collection (at TV Squad) of Saturday morning cartoons from 1960 to 1964: "Hoppity Hooper" ...
Just when you thought you were in for a three-month financial respite, along comes summer school, and more bills. How will you pay for it?

Re "When to Quote Those Potty Mouths" (July 13): As we contemplate The Times's role in maintaining a certain level of civility with regard to obscenities or vulgar words, you might reflect on the meaning of "civil."When George Carlin's seven words are the subject of an opinion of the highest court in the nation and many, including Times editorial writers, complained that the decision violated our civil liberties, it could be argued that The Times's self-censorship actually helps undermine our civil society.As to the editor who worries because The Times goes into schools, it is frightening that any Times editor would think that any of Mr. Carlin's words would be any news to a school child.Michael P. MillerPutnam Valley, N.Y., July 13, 2008 ● I've been thinking a lot about your column. What I can't accept - in your column and in Times policy generally - is the failure to distinguish between using "unfit" language and reporting on it.You write as if it would be the same thing for you or a columnist to offer an opinion in "unfit" language as for a Times writer to report in the third person what a public figure has said that includes accurately quoted "unfit" language.Surely this is a fundamental journalistic distinction. If there is an argument for ignoring that distinction in this sort of case, the argument needs to be made.The classroom-breakfast table issue is not an argument, if it even is an issue - don't you think most parents and teachers also distinguish between using bad language and speaking seriously about someone else's use of it?Bill Keller's statement about being reluctant to lead the charge to a coarser public discourse is a silly overstatement. The policy has the effect common to most fig leaves, visual and rhetorical, inspiring people to peek underneath, in these cases at other sources of information.Toni H. OlivieroBrooklyn, July 24, 2008The writer is dean of liberal arts and sciences, Pratt Institute. ● Putting aside the action that the Rev. Jesse Jackson described, why is the word in question "dirty" and other words describing the identical part of the anatomy, "testicles" or "gonads," not dirty? Why is this particular word "dirty" when used in one context, but not others?After all, the group of letters considered "dirty," when used as Mr. Jackson used them, are beyond reproach when used to name those small shelled fruit or seeds we gobble down with our beers, or that mad, eccentric character who hangs out at the street corner, or that small, usually square or hexagonal flat piece of metal or word, with a hole through it for screwing onto a bolt.What is there exactly that makes this word, a grouping of four perfectly neutral letters, "dirty"?Ronald RubinTopanga, Calif., July 14, 2008 ● You do a fine job of fence-sitting on the issue of reporting offensive speech.I propose two simple rules:Keep it clean (the present well-intentioned Times policy).Don't bowdlerize.If you can't say what they said, don't even say they said it. If it's too important to ignore, it's too important to censor.When the language is the story, you must report the language.Wittgenstein said it best: "What we cannot speak about we must pass over in silence."Kim de RielHavertown, Pa., July 14, 2008 ● The decision of The Times not to directly quote the Rev. Jesse Jackson's offensive words raises the question: Why not use the technical term "castration" to indicate what he really said about Senator Barack Obama, as you say The Washington Post did?By removing that specific information from Mr. Jackson's statement, The Times missed the sad irony that one form of physical assault inflicted by lynch mobs on African-American men was castration. Viewed in its full context, the statement demonstrates how badly out of touch Mr. Jackson is with many in the black community (including me, an African-American who participated in the civil rights movement and who worked in his 1988 presidential primary campaign).John Brown ChildsSanta Cruz, Calif., July 14, 2008The writer is a professor of sociology at the University of California, Santa Cruz. ● How about letting your grammar slip, and your spelling, to accord with common usage? Would the critical public similarly expect The Times to "slide with the times"? I think not.It is only where matters of a onetime prudish sensitivity are concerned, and it is only to justify their own such indulgence.But I just want to say that I'm with you on where you arrive with it. I don't see The Times as lagging behind current taste, but as upholding the long-standing standard of propriety.Irv ThomasSeattle, July 13, 2008 ● I hope you will soon write a column about oral and written language. Except for a brief nod to literature and the Internet, all the examples you provide are from oral language (talk, rappers, rock bands, stage, screen, television), and then you extend those examples to written discourse. But oral language is not the same as written language. I have no idea if the medium is the message, but the medium certainly affects the message and audience.It's not a matter of being "so prissy we're out of touch" or standards. It's a matter of accuracy and clarity, while appreciating and understanding the power and relationship between oral and written language and our humanity.Allen BergerSavannah, Ga., July 13, 2008The writer is emeritus professor of reading and writing at Miami University. ● One of the reasons given for why The Times doesn't use "dirty words" whereas The New Yorker does is because "The New Yorker is not delivered to middle- and high-school classrooms as 40,000 daily copies of The Times are."Perhaps if The Times did use dirty words, it would be delivering more than 40,000 daily copies. At least the 30,000 unread or barely skimmed copies would be scanned with more interest.Perhaps I'd even start believing what's written in it again.Alex DeringPrinceton, N.J., July 14, 2008 ● I enjoyed your column about the editorial squeamishness regarding reporting the Rev. Jesse Jackson's wish to separate Barack Obama from his testicles.A coven of prudish (old maid) librarians indeed.Do Times (and other) editors really believe that "children" of an age to read The Times, at this point nearly a decade into a new and increasingly ill-spoken century, aren't aware of most of the four-letter Anglo-Saxon adjectives bandied about so freely?To me, it's just another example of editorial self-righteousness. In a 43-year career at The Baltimore Sun, they provided me with an abundance of giggles as the editors struggled with euphemspeak - how to report something without actually reporting it. (And they don't want quotes cleaned up! Yuk, yuk!)Robert A. ErlandsonTowson, Md., July 15, 2008 ● The paper's writers and editors do not have to, and likely should not, write such vulgarities - except when such words are pertinent to the story. And in this case, the editors Paul Winfield and Chuck Strum seem to have lost their news sense. The man said it!What was newsworthy was the context and the entire quotation: the Rev. Jesse Jackson using Barack Obama's first name, leaning in sotto voce so that it appeared that Dr. Reed V. Tuckson had to struggle to hear him. Dr. Tuckson's attempt to be polite and respectful while awkwardly, it seems to me, hiding shock behind outward stoicism. Mr. Jackson's making the "talking down to black people" comment, pausing, pulling away, leaning in again and making the "nuts" comment. And Mr. Jackson's settling back, pausing again, then making the violent gesture.By the end of it all Jackson seemed to be talking to himself rather than to Dr. Tuckson.I say all this having interviewed both gentlemen more than once when I was at United Press International and The Washington Post more than 20 years ago, and in Dr. Tuckson's case, having shared a long, nonworking conversation during an airplane flight.The full quotation put in context would demonstrate all and more of what Mr. Winfield and Mr. Strum saw as being most newsworthy: the generational divide in political black leadership, the bitterness and palpable anger, the class-elitism issue, the simultaneous rejection and embrace of homogeneity. It is all there, and more. It is not all there when you leave out the "nuts" line. The Times editors neglected to consider the intelligence of their readers and the ability of those readers to process all of the pertinent information.So, I'm with my former somewhat-of-a-colleague David Remnick at The New Yorker. The Times, The Washington Post and the few crumbs that are left of my hometown Baltimore Sun need to loosen the reins.Doug StevensonBaltimore, July 17, 2008 ● I was appalled that The Times thinks it is ever all right not to give an exact quote of what someone said. The paper cannot possibly have editorial standards that deem something important enough to print and not relate the words.What would the possible importance be of a quote that cannot be given? We use words to communicate. Adults use blue words to communicate among themselves.Maybe if The Times always used exact language we would avoid more bubbles and recessions, and enough people might understand in advance of disaster and change behavior. It's possible.Stephen J. BoyleJersey City, July 14, 2008 ● When a public figure uses a "dirty" word, and it's central to the story, The Times has a duty to publish the quote. Otherwise, The Times is just not reporting the news. Citizens have a right to know what these public figures actually said because it's germane to our judgment of their character.Should The Times include audio or video clips of these incidents? No, leave that to the tabloids.Should The Times worry about these words showing up in their school circulation? Today's middle and high school kids know and use vulgar and dirty language all the time.I used to teach high school. If The Times had added a line, "Caution: coarse language," or something like that to clue me in, I would have used the article to open a discussion with my class about the quote, and about when language like that is appropriate and when it's not.Herbert N. Swearengen IIIBlytheville, Ariz., July 13, 2008 ● When a public figure uses profanity or other demeaning language, the failure to quote him precisely is to falsify the portrait of the speaker.The essence of reporting is to provide the reader with a complete picture of the event. That includes the character of the participants. That means telling the reader what the speaker really is, not want he wants the public to see him to be.In other words, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has a very low, crass opinion of Barack Obama. Mr. Jackson needs to be seen that way, not another.Elihu I. RoseLake Success, N.Y., July 13, 2008 ● This Times policy serves only its own image, not the larger public civility it claims to be protecting. When a story prints, "Cheney to senator: **** off" (or however the obscenity is disguised), few readers will not supply the missing word.A basic principle of linguistics: if you have a word in mind and display some symbols to your audience so that the audience realizes what you meant to write, then you have communicated the word to them. Not actually printing the missing letters is a trick to give the illusion of civility, while allowing the "unprintable" language to be communicated just as clearly as if it were spelled out.This fussy preservation of the appearance of civility amounts to hypocrisy.Charles J. SmithBuffalo, July 13, 2008 ● So why not draw the line between quoting those who use the "bad words" and Times writers using them in their own writing?I have been so infuriated by the news media (especially radio and TV) talking to our own soldiers, the "heroes" people like to point to, and then bleeping what they say.Soldiers have always had foul mouths, and what they're talking about is inherently offensive. People use offensive language, and they often use it for a very good reason. Let them.David BeanArlington, Mass., July 13, 2008 ●Please allow me to point out that "cut off his nuts" is not the same as "castrate." Almost all Times editors and readers should know this well. It is an informal expression used almost exclusively in spoken English that is taken to be extreme hyperbole by both speaker and listener.The Rev. Jesse Jackson has no desire to castrate Barack Obama; even to joke about it is absurd. It is an emphatic expression used to express the depth of the speaker's anger or outrage.It is also metaphorical, suggesting something like, "I'd really like to do something strong enough to get Barack Obama to pay attention and listen to what some of us are trying to tell him."By mistakenly treating Mr. Jackson's compressed, metaphorical expression as if it were literal, the Times did a disservice to readers and to Mr. Jackson by making the story confusing and shredding the coherence of what Mr. Jackson was trying to say.Wouldn't it be possible for The Times to simply use asterisks for "offensive" words? That would preserve the context of the remarks and not assign added meaning to them.As for "potty," I find it more offensive than "nuts," because it treats readers as if they were children.Chris DrakeHatoyama-machi, Japan, July 13, 2008 ●Re "Weighing the Risk" (July 6, 2008): A question you didn't raise is, Why does The New York Times publish the name of a nontorturing C.I.A. interrogator and not publish the names of those who've actually tortured people? Was it because it was easier to get Deuce Martinez's name?It seems to me that the real issue is that The Times, once again, is taking the easy route on digging deeper.Christopher CookPrague, July 6, 2008 ● In May, you defended The Times's practice of withholding the names of reporters reporting from Zimbabwe and Myanmar. Risk, you know. But now you defend The Times's disclosing of the name of the interrogator of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed. The peoples' right to know, you know.But the real basis for decisions whether to disclose is clear: Will it harm the Bush war effort (if it will, yes; if it won't no)?You say that the Times has "sometimes agreed, sometimes refused" to withhold information when asked to do so by the C.I.A. Why don't you give readers some depth and disclose how many times it has agreed and refused since Iraq was invaded?Steven K. CochranDallas, July 7, 2008●●

BOSTON -- This is how quickly things can change this time of year. In the dugout, around 6 p.m., Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said he was not optimistic about making a trade before the July 31 deadline. Asked if anything was close, he said, "It's a long way between close and done."
Andy Murray eliminated the defending champion, Novak Djokovic, from the Rogers Cup in Toronto with a 6-3, 7-6 (3) victory in the quarterfinals.
On Thursday evening, in front of a full house at St. Peter’s Church in Chelsea, the New Amsterdam Summer Orchestra offered spirited performances of works by Mozart and Schubert.

Nicolas Kiefer routed seventh-seeded James Blake, 6-1, 6-2, in advancing to the semifinals of the Rogers Cup in Toronto. Kiefer, ranked 37th in the world, will play Gilles Simon, who defeated Marin Cilic, 3-6, 6-2, 6-3. Kiefer and Simon are the unlikely victors in a bracket that featured Roger Federer, Nikolay Davydenko, Andy Roddick and Blake.

Chez Reavie, a 26-year-old PGA Tour rookie, finished the rain-delayed first round of the Canadian Open in Oakville, Ontario, with a six-under-par 65. He then shot 64 in the second round to take a two-stroke lead over Eric Axley, who was 11 under with a hole remaining when play was suspended because of darkness.
A new report by two Internet watchdog groups has identified hundreds of Web sites that illegally sell anabolic steroids without prescriptions or verifying the age of customers.
Investigators accused Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick of Detroit of berating and attacking them as they tried to serve a subpoena to a friend.
Ships began crawling up the Mississippi River at New Orleans in a tightly controlled procession, two days after an oil spill shut down a stretch of the river.
Joba Chamberlain worked seven innings, striking out nine and allowing three hits in a 1-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
The Mets have won 14 of their past 17 games, including three straight, to vault into first in the division, and their lead grew to two games over the Phillies and the Marlins.
On Sunday Dathan Ritzenhein will be racing in a strong international field and before 10,000 recreational runners at the third annual NYC Half-Marathon.
Janel McCarville’s layup with 6.4 seconds left lifted the Liberty to a 69-68 victory against the Los Angeles Sparks on Friday night at Madison Square Garden.
The explosion sent flames shooting into surrounding apartments and spread devastation, prompting the evacuation of scores of Flushing residents.
Shares of the television station owner Belo Corporation rose Friday after the company posted second-quarter earnings that, excluding results from the company it spun off, beat analysts’ expectations.
Antitrust regulators for the European Union have approved Hewlett-Packard’s proposed $13.2 billion purchase of the technology services provider Electronic Data Systems.
American Axle and Manufacturing posted a $644.3 million second-quarter loss, citing a nearly three-month strike that crippled production as well as charges related to a new labor agreement.
Honda Motor reported record profit for its first quarter as sales growth in new markets offset the damage from a stronger yen and soaring material costs.
AOL is shutting three data-storage services, including one of the Internet’s earliest photo-sharing sites, as it seeks to cut costs and focus resources on its advertising opportunities.

The former world-record holder Asafa Powell collected his second pre-Olympics victory in the 100 meters in three days, winning at the London Grand Prix in 9.94 seconds. The race had been promoted as a clash with Tyson Gay, the world champion. Gay pulled out because he has not yet recovered from a hamstring injury sustained last month at the United States Olympic Trials.

Iraq’s Olympic Committee has opened negotiations to try to regain its place in next month’s Beijing Games after being banned for political interference in Olympic affairs. Jazair al-Sahlani, a spokesman for the Iraqi Olympic committee, said that high-level talks had begun with I.O.C. envoys and mediators from Germany and China. But Basil Abdul Mahdi, an adviser to the government’s Ministry of Youth and Sport, said there would be “no retreat” in its decision to replace its Olympic committee.

Kenny Kelly, a former quarterback for the University of Miami, was arrested Wednesday on three felony drug counts in Plant City, Fla. Kelly, 29, turned himself in. The police said he was charged with possession of marijuana, and purchase and solicitation to deliver marijuana. Kelly, who led the Hurricanes to a Gator Bowl victory in 1999, was working as the quarterbacks coach at Plant City High School.

The longtime boxing judge Melvina Lathan was named by Gov. David A. Paterson to lead the New York State Athletic Commission, which regulates professional boxing in the state. Lathan has judged 83 world championship fights and was confirmed by the State Senate last year as the first female African-American commissioner.

Helen Alfredsson shot a course-record nine-under-par 63 to pull one shot behind the leader, Angela Park, after the second round of the Evian Masters in Evian-les-Bains, France. Park shot a 68 for a 10-under 134 total. Lorena Ochoa (73) is at six under.

Bruce Vaughan shot par 71 to take a one-shot lead after the second round of the Senior British Open at Troon, Scotland. He led John Cook (71) by one stroke, and Tom Watson (71), Bernhard Langer (71) and Eduardo Romero (73) by two.

Venus Williams, the Wimbledon champion, has withdrawn from next week’s Rogers Cup women’s tournament in Montreal with a knee injury. The tournament director, Eugène Lapierre, said Williams did not want to risk aggravating the tendinitis in her knee ahead of the Olympics.
SPORTS.
A court in Istanbul said it would hear a politically delicate case in which 86 people are accused of forming a network that plotted to overthrow the Turkish government.
The explosions, which appeared to be intended to create panic, were set off in crowded middle-class neighborhoods.
The authorities did not immediately place responsibility for the explosion, which occurred at an intersection outside Gaza City.
The Turkish and Greek leaders of Cyprus will convene for reunification talks on Sept. 3 for the first time since a referendum to unite the divided island was voted down in 2004.
With the market down and fuel costs way up, the M.T.A. is being crushed by its debt. More than any other reason, that is why the authority wants to raise fares again.
City lawyers trying to force a group to turn over videotapes from the 2004 Republican National Convention claim that it may have copies of tapes possibly lost by the D.A.’s office.
President Bush’s move to consider a “time horizon” for Iraq troop withdrawals put John McCain on the defensive.
While Ralph Fiennes performed Samuel Beckett inside a Midtown theater, a Beckett-like crowd filled the midsummer streets of Manhattan.
A federal judge’s ruling to restore federal protections to Rocky Mountain gray wolves ends the slaughter, at least for now.
In Albany, official records and other details of the state’s business should be quickly and automatically made public.
Congress should pass a bill this year that would give the Food and Drug Administration oversight of tobacco products.
A growing number of children are taking drugs for a wide range of chronic conditions related to childhood obesity.
The mythical John McCain is an affable, straight-talking, moderately conservative war hero. But how much do voters really know about him?
Radovan Karadzic’s lawyer maintains that Mr. Karadzic was apprehended last week and held incommunicado by unknown kidnappers for three days.
Brandon Knight will pitch Saturday for the Mets, and next week he may be working out with the Olympic baseball team that will compete next month in Beijing.
As David Ortiz prepared to oppose Joba Chamberlain, Manny Ramírez continued to sit with a mysterious knee injury.
The buyout of XM Satellite Radio Holdings by Sirius Satellite Radio will translate into a group of 18 million subscribers at a cost of about $3.5 billion.
Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman would not say unequivocally that the Yankees will not pursue Bonds, the career home run leader who is dogged by legal issues.
A minor league pitcher accused of throwing a ball that hit a fan during a bench-clearing brawl was charged with felonious assault.
Jeremy Hermida came in for catcher Paul Hoover and hit a pitch over the right field wall off Bobby Howry, helping the Florida Marlins to a 3-2 win over the cubs.
Sleep-away camps are having to spend time catering to increasingly high-maintenance parents, experts say.
On a housing bill, most House Republicans decided in the end to align with their conservative base.
Plans to build a $260 million wholesale merchandise mart cater-corner from the Air Train station in Jamaica were scuttled when the co-developer pulled out.
NBC will announce on Monday its plan to stream its N.F.L. games online this season and allow users to choose extra camera angles and multiple streams.
Dr. Pausch was the Carnegie Mellon University professor whose “last lecture” made him a Lou-Gehrig-like symbol of the beauty and briefness of life.
This week, the charmed young life of the Brooklyn Flea in Fort Greene, which draws thousands of visitors on Sundays, encountered its first wave of organized antipathy.
Bayer’s experimental anticoagulant Xarelto, its biggest new drug hope, has been recommended for approval by the European Medicines Agency.
Some countries voiced concerns that prosecuting Omar Hassan al-Bashir could hamper efforts to achieve peace in the region through diplomacy.
General Electric announced that it would reduce its divisions to four from six, reflecting the company’s efforts to shed slow-growing businesses as its stock trades near a five-year low.
The Yankees landed outfielder Xavier Nady and the reliever Damaso Marte from Pittsburgh in exchange for four minor leaguers. The trade is expected to be completed before Saturday’s game.
Family members of miners killed after a huge collapse at a Utah mine last year expressed outrage after two federal reports showed that the mine had long been dangerous.
Federal regulators filed insider trading charges on Friday against unidentified individuals who are accused of making suspiciously well-timed purchases of call options in two companies.
Mayor Michael Bloomberg suggested a revolution of sorts on Friday: He challenged independents to vote as a bloc in November.
Bonuses for financial employees based in New York could shrink by $10 billion or more this year, officials and experts said.
An American agency monitoring reconstruction in Iraq cited a sharp drop in attacks on the pipeline and new infrastructure built to protect it.

POWELL--Sally, (nee Deutsch), 95 years old, died July 24, 2008. From THEATRE Arts to Business Week, a superlative editor. Survived by her daughter Joan Thayer Yazmir, her son-in-law Martin Yazmir, her grandchildren Colette, Andrew and Leslie Thayer and Keith Yazmir, and her great - grandchildren Casey and Zak Thayer. Funeral services Sunday, July 27 at 1pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan.

FIELDS--Bernard R Esq., on July 25, 2008 at age 73. Loving son of the late Joseph and Mary Fields. Beloved father of Shana, David and Edina (Gregory). Dear brother of Arlene Sher. Companion of Laura Sockoloff. He had a zest for life and a love for traveling. Funeral Service: Sunday, July 27, 10am at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 Second Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Shiva to follow through Friday, August 1. Contributions in his memory may be made to Israeli Cancer Research Fund, 1290 Avenue of the Americas, Suite 550 , NY, NY 10104.

TEMPIO--James, 60, gifted artist who brought joy and laughter to many died at his home Sunday in NYC after a long illness. Survived by his mother Josephine, sisters Kathy and Maria, brother Richard, nephews Marco, Sandro, Joe, niece Chelsea and beloved pets Vincent and Toby and countless friends. He will be missed.

FERRIS--Lesley Herman, 93, of Harrison died July 24. Mrs. Ferris born April 4, 1915 in NYC, NY is predeceased by her son Neal Ferris (San Francisco) and her beloved husband of 66 years Louis Ferris. A member of Quaker Ridge Country Club, Mrs. Ferris is survived by daughters Lynn Ferris (Rye) and Pamela Ferris-Olson (Ohio), six grandchildren, three greatgrandchildren. Private memorial planned. In lieu of flowers, donate to charity of your choice. FERRIS--Lesley. The Board of Directors and the members of Quaker Ridge Golf Club are saddened by the passing of our beloved friend and longest standing member of over 80 years, Lesley Ferris. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her entire family in their time of sorrow. Her many years of friendship, kindness and enthusiastic spirit will be remembered. Philip Laskawy, President

The Norwegian police and immigration authorities have raised security at a refugee center after a 15-minute attack on Thursday by dozens of men, armed with steel rods, knives and other weapons, that wounded more than 20 asylum seekers. A police superintendent, Per Tore Fremstad, said 40 to 50 men had climbed a fence around the center in Vaaler, about 30 miles south of Oslo. The police arrested five Chechen men suspected of taking part in the attack.

TAIT--Joan Schneider, of New Rochelle, beloved mother and friend, passed away Thursday of heart failure. She was 79. Artist, teacher, world traveler and lover of people. She will be missed by many. She is survived by a daughter, Leslie.

REITER--Bertie, age 93, widow of Louis Reiter. Mother of Sheldon, Peter, and Barbara Reiter. Grandmother of Lowell (Tzivy), Russell (Susan) and Richard (Andrea) Reiter. Great-grandmother of Yehudis, Fraydi, Chaya, Lily, Samuel, Sara and Anna, and sister of Marilyn Seltzer. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., 9:30am, Sunday, July 27th.

ROSENBERG--Miriam. The loving daughter of William and Bessie Nierenberg. Born May 27, 1916, passed away peacefully July 25, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin B. Rosenberg for 54 years, devoted and proud mother of Alan D. Rosenberg and Wendy, the late Leonard Rosenberg and Arlene. Adored grandmother of Kerri and Rich Schnapper, Joshua, Brian and Stacy. Loving great-grandmother of Lexi and Mackenzie. Survived by brothers Moe and Ralph Nierenberg, and preceded by sister Pauline Jacobs. One of the first woman to be Bas mitzvahed in 1928. Volunteered at YHMA in Mt. Vernon and knitted for Israeli charity. She will always be remembered.
LIPMAN--Edward, on July 18, 2008. Graveside service Monday, July 28th at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY at 1pm with Rabbi Posner officiating.

DUDIN--Helene. The School of American Ballet family notes with sadness the death of Helene Dudin, one of the extraordinary Russian teachers who gave a sound classical base to many generations of SAB dancers. She taught at the School for nearly half a century and affected the lives of thousands of young students.

ABRAMSON--Robert. The Juilliard School mourns the death of Robert Abramson, who was a member of the faculty from 1986 until the time of his death. A dedicated teacher of great creativity and energy, he allowed the young artists of our School to understand the beauty and intricacies of music with a sparkle in his eye and a determination that permeated his classroom. He will be deeply missed by us all. Joseph W. Polisi, President Karen Wagner, VP and Dean of Academic Affairs Katherine Gertson, Registrar

PEOPLES--Don (Donald Krakaur), 77, of New York and Naples, Florida passed on July 24, 2008, from complications after a courageous battle against Multiple Myeloma. Cherished husband of Marcia Savella, loving father of Keith (Nancy), Peter (Anita) and their mother Eugenie Rosen, proud grandfather of Matthew, Daniel, Jonathan, David and Sammy. All will miss this special man. To know Don was to know laughter. Service 2pm Sunday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Joseph Michaeli Multiple Myeloma Research Fund, 525 East 68th St., New York, NY 10065 or Doctors Without Borders, Diabetes Association, World Wildlife Fund or St. Judes Children's Hospital.

GOLDSTEIN--Walter C. The staff and faculty of the School of American Ballet mourn the death of Walter Goldstein, stepfather of our Executive Director, Marjorie Van Dercook. He was funny and generous, firm of purpose, and clearly loved his family. Peter Martins, Kay Mazzo, and the entire SAB family send condolences to his wife Doris, his children and grandchildren.

HINCKLEY--Samuel Neilson Jr., died at age 92 on July 11, 2008 at Villa Marin, San Rafael, CA. Born in NYC on September 14, 1915, he was a direct descendent of Samuel Hinckley who sailed on the Hercules arriving in Scituate, MA, March, 1634, later moving to the town of Barnstable, and his son Thomas Hinckley, Governor of Plymouth Colony. Mr. Hinckley attended the Aiken Preparatory School, and graduated from Groton School and Harvard University where he was President of the Harvard Advocate. For 40 years he was a stock broker in San Francisco and divided his time between Menlo Park and Inverness, CA. His marriage to the former Helen Pettit ended in divorce in 1991. He was predeceased by his longtime and beloved companion, Mary Elizabeth Lyman in 2003. He leaves behind his wonderful and loving soulmate, Gabriele Horton, and his adoring children Samuel H. Hinckley and Helen H. Beekman. He is also survived by his four grandchildren Samuel N. Hinckley, Suzanne S. Hinckley, Izaak B. Beekman and Hugo H.L. Beekman as well as his daughter-in-law Frances D. Hinckley and son-in-law William B. Beekman. Not only will Sam be deeply missed by his devoted family but his ever joyful, witty, kind, loving, intelligent friendship will be missed by many friends of all ages from California to the East Coast. A memorial celebration of his life will be held in Inverness, CA in September. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Mr. Hinckley may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, ATTN: Tribute Gifts, Church Street Station, P.O. Box 780, New York, NY 10008-0780 or to The Inverness Foundation, P.O. Box 382, Inverness, CA 94937.

GOLDSTEIN--Walter. The Board of Directors of the School of American Ballet is deeply saddened by the death of Walter Goldstein, stepfather of Marjorie Van Dercook, Executive Director of the School. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Robert Fribourg, Chairman

CATTANACH--Melissa Bedolis. The employees of The Estee Lauder Companies are very saddened by the death of our dear colleague and beloved friend, Melissa Bedolis Cattanach. Known for her joie de vivre, she will also be remembered for her fabulous enthusiasm, extraordinary professionalism, and most of all, her kindness. She will be deeply missed. Melissa first joined The Estee Lauder Companies as Vice President of Global Communications for Aveda, and in 2002, became an integral part of the Corporate Global Communications team with responsibility for growing the company Intranet site. She also played a key part in The Estee Lauder Companies' Breast Cancer Awareness program, lending her professionalism and creativity. Prior to joining The Estee Lauder Companies, she worked at Harper's Bazaar, Mademoiselle, Women's Wear Daily, and Salon News as a journalist and editor, and as a creative director at Redken, a division of L'Oreal USA. Our hearts and thoughts are with her husband, Evan Cattanach; son, Robert and her brother, John Bedolis. Her spirit will continue to live on at The Estee Lauder Companies. Donations in her memory can be made to The Robert Evan Cattanach College Fund. Mail donations to Kathleen Longo, The Estee Lauder Companies, 767 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10153.

(Starz) HANNAH MONTANA/MILEY CYRUS: BEST OF BOTH WORLDS CONCERT TOUR (2008) Not only did this movie catapult to the No. 1 spot after it had its theatrical premiere this winter, it also made public that Ms. Cyrus, left, uses a body double in concert -- to ''help speed the star's transition from Hannah to Miley,'' according to her public relations firm. In this 3-D documentary, filmed during a concert tour last summer, Ms. Cyrus plays her alter ego half the time, in songs like ''Rock Star,'' ''Life's What You Make It'' and ''Just Like You,'' and herself the rest of the time, performing ''Start All Over,'' ''See You Again'' and ''G.N.O.,'' as in ''Girl's Night Out.'' The Jonas Brothers, that boy band du jour, provide the interlude. Ms. Cyrus's father, Billy Ray Cyrus, guest stars as himself, soul patch intact. Rafael Nadal beat Andy Murray, 7-6 (2), 6-3, to reach the final of the Rogers Cup in Toronto and put himself in line for his seventh title of the year. Nadal will face Nicolas Kiefer, who advanced to the championship with a 6-7 (4), 6-3, 7-6 (5) win over Gilles Simon.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the storied private equity firm, is preparing to finally become a public company on the New York Stock Exchange, people briefed on the plan said Sunday.

The N.C.A.A. has accused Texas A&M-Corpus Christi of nine rules violations, including use of ineligible players, recruiting violations in men’s basketball and lack of institutional control. It said that the violations, eight of them major, occurred mainly from 2004 to 2008 in men’s basketball, women’s volleyball and men’s tennis.

Howard Schultz, the former owner of the Seattle SuperSonics, said he was warned by N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern that it would be “very expensive” to pursue a lawsuit seeking to return the team to Seattle from Oklahoma City. Schultz made the claim in a declaration filed Thursday in United States District Court in Seattle. He has sued to try to reverse his sale of the franchise to Clay Bennett, an Oklahoma City businessman, asserting that Bennett failed to negotiate in good faith to keep the team in Seattle.

Girls had their most dominant showing in the history of the All-American Soap Box Derby on Saturday, winning five of six individual titles for the first time and sweeping the three major divisions for only the second time. The performances came during the 71st year of the grand prix of gravity-powered racing in Akron, Ohio. A record 606 finalists from 160 cities and 6 nations competed.

Flavia Pennetta won the biggest semifinal of her career at the East West Bank Classic in Carson, Calif., defeating the wild card Bethanie Mattek, 3-6, 6-2, 7-5. She will face top-seeded Jelena Jankovic or No. 4 Dinara Safina in the final Sunday. Jankovic can take over the No. 1 world ranking if she wins the tournament.

The Detroit Shock signed center Kelly Schumacher to a contract for the rest of the W.N.B.A. season. Terms were not disclosed. The 6-5 Schumacher came off the bench in all 34 games last season with the Phoenix Mercury, the league champion, averaging 4.4 points and 4.3 rebounds in 16 minutes.
Manager Jerry Manuel said he was worried about the Mets’ pitcher Duaner Sánchez’s velocity, which has rarely exceeded 91 miles an hour recently.

Regena Jackson, who averaged 8.7 points for the Louisiana-Monroe women’s team last season, was arrested early Saturday for firing a gun from an apartment balcony, a university spokeswoman, Laura Harris, said. Harris said that no one was hurt, and that Jackson was expelled from the college.

The United States upset the five-time defending champion Brazil, 25-23, 25-22, 27-25, to advance to the World League volleyball final Sunday against Serbia in Rio de Janeiro. Clayton Stanley had three aces to lead the United States. Serbia advanced by beating Russia, 25-19, 25-19, 25-23.

The Philadelphia Soul will play the San Jose SaberCats, the defending champions, in the Arena Bowl on Sunday in New Orleans. Philadelphia, a fifth-year franchise, is in its first championship game. San Jose is 3-0 in the Arena Bowl, also winning in 2002 and ’04.

University of Richmond center Dan Geriot is expected to miss the coming season after injuring his right knee during summer-league competition in Philadelphia, said Richmond Coach Chris Mooney. Geriot, a 6-foot-9 junior, averaged a team-leading 14.3 points and 5.5 rebounds last season. He will be examined by team doctors, but Mooney said that he believed there was only “a hair of a chance” that he would play this season. Geriot is likely to receive a medical redshirt for the coming season, leaving him with two seasons of eligibility.
About 90 men and 10 women on Saturday tried to qualify for the Empire State Golden Arm Tournament of Champions to be held at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in November.
After a brief holdout, Glenn Dorsey signed a five-year, $51 million deal with the Kansas City Chiefs that includes more than $22 million in guaranteed money.

Howard Schultz, the former owner of the Seattle SuperSonics, said he was warned by N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern that it would be “very expensive” to pursue a lawsuit seeking to return the team to Seattle from Oklahoma City. Schultz made the claim in a declaration filed Thursday in United States District Court in Seattle. He has sued to try to reverse his sale of the franchise to Clay Bennett, an Oklahoma City businessman, asserting that Bennett failed to negotiate in good faith to keep the team in Seattle.
Commentator scored a dominant, front-running victory in the $750,000 Whitney Handicap on Saturday at Saratoga Race Course in New York.
Major League Baseball on Saturday reiterated its decision to discontinue the annual Hall of Fame game in Cooperstown, N.Y., a tradition that began in 1940.
The unions representing 65,000 Verizon workers on Saturday resounded a pledge to strike if demands for higher wages, caps on health care payments and limits on outsourcing jobs are not honored.
Federal regulators on Friday closed two banks operating in Arizona, California and Nevada: First National Bank of Nevada and First Heritage Bank, N.A.
After finalizing their trade for outfielder Xavier Nady and reliever Dámaso Marte, the Yankees may not be done dealing and are discussing a possible trade with Seattle for starter Jarrod Washburn.
Con Edison employees had finished work and signed off on the safety of gas lines a mere 11 minutes before an explosion at a Queens apartment building on Friday.

A caption last Sunday for a picture in some editions, with an article about the history of Jamaica’s world-class track program, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of Dr. Herb Elliott, the public health officer in charge of athletic drug testing during competitions on the island, was taken by Ross Sheil — not by Peter Dean Rickards, who also supplied pictures for the article.

The N.F.L. training camp outlook last Sunday referred incorrectly to the 2007 season for the Denver Broncos. It was the team’s second losing season under Coach Mike Shanahan — not its first, which was in 1999.
SPORTS.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the W.N.B.A. game between the Liberty and the Indiana Fever included several errors. The surname of the league president is Donna Orender — not Ordener, as it was misspelled in some copies. Ms. Orender said the W.N.B.A.’s attendance, relevance and excitement were on an upward “trending,” not “training.” And the league goes on hiatus for the Beijing Olympics on Monday, not on Aug. 28.
Wide receiver Donnie Avery, a second-round draft pick, signed with the St. Louis Rams. He was expected on the field for the day’s second practice.

Philadelphia Eagles cornerback Asante Samuel left Saturday morning’s practice with a strained hamstring. He was hurt while working in seven-on-seven drills during the team’s first practice in full pads this summer.

The Cleveland Indians traded the versatile third baseman Casey Blake and cash to the Los Angeles Dodgers for two minor leaguers. The Indians got catcher Carlos Santana and the right-hander Jonathan Meloan.

Usain Bolt of Jamaica pulled away from the pack Saturday at the London Grand Prix, winning the 200 meters in 19.76 seconds. Bolt, who holds the world record in the 100, got a fast start and led for about the final 100 meters, winning by a half-second despite easing up at the end.

The Tennessee Titans have wrapped up only unsigned draft pick, agreeing to terms with the first-round selection Chris Johnson. Johnson, a running back out of East Carolina, was the 24th pick in the draft.
Tight end John Carlson and the Seattle Seahawks agreed to terms on a multiyear contract, putting him the practice field for the second day of training camp.
The Toronto right-hander Dustin McGowan will have season-ending surgery Thursday to repair fraying of the labrum in his shoulder.
A 43-year-old homeless man was stabbed to death on the sidewalk a few feet from a Midtown church early Saturday, the police said.
Anthony Kim made nine birdies and an eagle in 21 holes Saturday in the Canadian Open for a share of the lead with Chez Reavie.
A day after the Jets emerged as a possible partner in the Brett Favre retired-unretired dance, the training camp buzz at team headquarters went from intense speculation to almost none at all.
All across the country, cappuccino and latte drinkers are bemoaning the closing of their neighborhood coffee shops, including about 600 named Starbucks.
Following a raid at an Iowa meatpacking plant, immigrants have described pervasive labor violations that experts say could result in criminal charges.
Black radio hosts’ efforts to support Barack Obama could help increase voter turnout in a vital part of his coalition.
Colombia’s four-decade war fueled by the drug trade is proving immune to American-financed efforts to stop it.
The legislation is the latest in a series of extraordinary economic interventions by the federal government.
For the second time in two days, low-intensity explosions rocked an Indian city. Officials said 45 people were killed.
The country’s president said Iran is running more than 5,000 centrifuges for enriching uranium, suggesting a continued expansion of the country’s nuclear program.
Barack Obama’s overseas trip has fueled the questions his critics have used to try to undercut him: whether he is arrogant and taking his election for granted.
Mr. Dello Joio achieved wide popularity in the mid-20th century by composing a proliferation of essentially tonal, lyrical works.
Carlos Sastre put in a strong ride and finished close enough behind Cadel Evans in the 33-mile time trial to remain in the yellow jersey by 1 minute 5 seconds over Evans.
Negotiators are confronting a seemingly unbridgeable divide over executive power in a unity government.
Real estate developers active in Harlem have been prodigious donors to Representative Charles B. Rangel.
Gov. David A. Paterson signed a measure on Wednesday essentially ushering in a new era of energy production upstate. But he did so with a cautionary yellow light.
Hamas police officers in Gaza rounded up scores of supporters of Fatah and raided its offices after five Hamas militants and a girl were killed in a bomb blast.
After a rare Saturday vote in the Senate, the measure now goes to President Bush, who has said he will sign it, perhaps early next week.
An explosion in the cargo hold or metal fatigue were being explored as possible causes of a hole in the jet’s fuselage.
Jacques Rogge, the president of the International Olympic Committee, has said that he expects up to 40 athletes to be caught doping at the Beijing Olympics.
Registered lobbyists have donated large amounts of money to Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign, even as he denounces their profession.
Barack Obama’s high-profile trip has fueled the suggestions his critics have used to try to undercut him: that he is arrogant and taking his election for granted.
Manchester United will sign the Argentine Carlos Tévez for a British transfer record fee of $63.52 million, according to news media reports on Saturday.
Bowie Kuhn cannot escape his enduring connection to Walter O’Malley as they enter the National Baseball Hall of Fame together on Sunday.
The Mahdi Army has been profoundly weakened in a number of neighborhoods, in an important, if tentative, milestone for stability in Iraq.
Even for hipsters, life in one of New York City’s frontier neighborhoods can be anything but smooth, particularly in these uncertain economic times.
Officials at a new racing club scheduled to open on Sunday in Monticello, N.Y., said the sputtering economy has not deterred the big-bucks, big-horsepower types they are looking for.
The Atlanta Dream has left its 0-17 start behind, and is focusing on improving steadily through the rest of its inaugural season.
Experts say land seizures for logging, agriculture, mining, tourism and fisheries have become the most serious human rights abuse in Cambodia.
As long as they do not threaten the Kremlin or its friends, it seems, Russian newspapers can say what they like.
Davis Love III, who considers the British Open one of his favorite tournaments, said he did not hold grudges against those who are eligible but did not play.

Rockies Manager Clint Hurdle anointed Jeff Baker as his second baseman last week. And why not? Baker hit .380 over a three-week period and, Hurdle said, his defense improved, pushing Clint Barmes to the bench. But Baker is the epitome of a Coors Field creation. Through Friday, he had hit .341 at home with six homers but just .229 on the road with two homers. Barmes had hit nearly 30 points higher on the road.
After posting two of the three fastest 800-meter times by a woman in 11 years, Pamela Jelimo is a favorite to win Olympic middle-distance gold next month in Beijing.
Britain’s courts say celebrities have a right to cavort in privacy.

After 27 years, a memorial may be built for the 114 people killed in a collapse at a hotel in Kansas City, Mo.

Travel agents in South Florida filed a lawsuit against the state challenging a new law requiring them to post a one-time $250,000 bond and disclose the names of clients in order to continue their business with Cuba.
Over the past few years, Cubs fans have shown up in such large numbers in Milwaukee that they have begun referring to Miller Park as Wrigley Field North.

Peppers Pride, a New 5-year-old thoroughbred, is expected to be heavily favored to win her 17th race in a row, a feat no horse has achieved in modern times.
Yankees outfielder Jake Powell’s racist comment 70 years ago broke the conspiracy of silence that protected segregated baseball.
Readers sound off on the Jeremy Shockey trade.
An online emporium of handmade goods based in Brooklyn decides to forgo the startup status and hire professional management.

Because of an editing error, an article on July 20 about Erin Burnett, whom CNBC has made a prominent anchor, misidentified the location where she attended high school. She went to the St. Andrew’s boarding school in Delaware. She did not attend high school in her hometown, Mardela Springs, Md.

An article on July 13 in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section, about target-date funds misstated the percentage of equities and real estate investment trust shares that a 65-year-old investor in J.& W. Seligman & Company’s target-date funds would hold. The total would be 65 percent of the portfolio, with an additional 35 percent in fixed-income investments. Such an investor’s portfolio would not be 75 percent equities and real estate investment trusts.
Am I a genius, or what? The past two seasons, my teams of 7- and 8-year-olds have dominated the basketball competition in the St. Joseph Elementary School league in Keyport, N.J.

A philosopher aims to clarify the meaning of virtue, freedom and heroism and to take the measure of villainy.
Paperback books of particular interest.
Food labels, bottle caps, envelope linings: if it was ephemeral detritus, William Davies King cherished and collected it.
For all of Larry McMurtry’s critical and filmic success, he didn’t place a book on the best-seller list until 1985, when “Lonesome Dove” had a 24-week run.
Listening to a loved one during his final days.
Everyone’s a critic.
Is the Internet the enemy of reading, or has it created a new kind of reading, one that society should not discount?
Mr. Brieant, a former chief judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, presided over a raft of controversial cases.
Steven Spielberg’s recently announced partnership with an Indian group to form a new movie company contains an element of shock: that Hollywood could not come up with a rich enough deal for him.
The Nobel Prize winner talks about writing about her mother, why Gordon Brown isn’t as bad as Tony Blair and the trouble with Yum-Yum.
Straits Atlanta is the epicurean brainchild of the hairstylist-turned-chef Chris Yeo and the Grammy-winning rapper and actor Chris Bridges (best known as Ludacris).
Sarah Neale Fayen and Timothy James Scarlett were married on Saturday evening in Shorewood, Wis.
Esperanza Spalding is a jazz singer and bassist who, at 23, has played with the likes of Herbie Hancock and Pat Metheny.
The collapse of the Salander-O’Reilly Galleries last year has caused the magnificent town house that it rented on East 71st Street to be put on the market.
With their eclectic sensibility, Sugarland is forcing listeners to rethink any lingering stereotype of country music as pop’s most conservative format.
Drug-related corruption pervades the government in Afghanistan, a former U.S. counternarcotics official says.
He’s the next big thing in Formula One auto racing. But can he hang on to his innocence in the revved-up whirl of Grand Prix?
The young women — willing wives? abuse victims? — of the polygamist Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
Why the government should not be in the bailout business.
Bartending may look simple, but it isn’t. A bartender has to know hundreds of recipes by heart. And that takes education.

What ever happened to the names of taxi companies?
Who owns the note on a home when it is forced into foreclosure, often a murky question, is among the factors that have helped homeowners facing foreclosures to fight back.
Ronan Tynan, a 48-year-old Irish tenor, has become stitched into the fabric of New York by his singing “God Bless America” at Yankee Stadium for most of its recent major events.
In the midst of another Red-Sox Yankees blood feud, the electrifying story line in sports is the possibility that Barry Bonds may become a Yankee and Brett Favre a Jet.
Along with reports that the Jets have received permission to speak with Brett Favre comes the smell of desperation from their newly opened training camp, an S O S, the acronym for Save Our Season.
As the Giants open camp as the defending Super Bowl champions, we can all learn a lesson from the major attitude adjustment by Coach Tom Coughlin that led directly to that championship.
Jenna Didier and Oliver Hess, Los Angeles artists who specialize in transforming public spaces, both agreed that their wedding should be a public spectacle.

In Karin Fossum’s “Black Seconds,” the loss of a child implies something awful about the future of an entire village. Also reviewed: James Lee Burke’s “Swan Peak”; Jincy Willett’s “Writing Class”; and Will Thomas’s “Black Hand.”
Identity thieves are scheming to defraud people with good credit by tapping into their home equity.
With its abundant nature and tight sense of community, Breezy Point, Queens, seems much farther in spirit from Manhattan than actual distance would suggest.
After decades of postwar neglect, the Sicilian capital is poised for a comeback. Crumbling roads are being repaved, landmarks scrubbed clean and a newfound pride can be felt.
Craig Hansen’s fastball hummed inside and drilled Alex Rodriguez’s left arm in the eighth inning Saturday.
A conversation between Barack Obama and the Tory leader, David Cameron, at the Houses of Parliament was picked up on a live microphone.
Their passports say Jiang Yuyuan and He Kexin are 16, but other sources say they are only 14.
Investigators sought Saturday to determine why a section of the fuselage of a Boeing jumbo jet burst open in fight, forcing an emergency landing.
How much chess is too much? Players have long held varying opinions about how often they should compete to maintain an edge.
“In 1899, Appa’s grandfather sailed across the Bay of Bengal to seek his fortune under familiar masters in a strange land, leaving behind an emerald of a village on the east coast of India.”
“ ‘Three obituaries!’ a fierce old relation wrote after my father died. ‘What on earth for! What did he ever do?’ ”
“It’s a month after my mother has died, October 2002. My father and I have just pulled into the Mount Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, on the flat south shore of Long Island.”
How the talent agency Endeavor, founded in 1995, goes about proving it has staying power offers a window onto the shifting landscape of talent brokering in Hollywood.
When Hebrew National meets Barmès-Buecher’s 2006 Crémant d’Alsace, a sparkling white, a rewarding marriage occurs.
Once limited to dense urban environments, bike commuting has found a small but devoted following in the New York City suburbs.
Jonathan Tisch, the head of Loews Hotels, closed this month on the purchase of a 14-room co-op facing Central Park, for $48 million.
N. Anthony Rolfe’s advice for developers who paid high prices on rental buildings for conversion to condominiums is, “Good things happen to those who wait.”
IT’S tough to estimate the cost of renovating, because it varies enormously depending on the quality of the labor and the price of materials selected — appliances, tiles, flooring and the like.
Carrie Fisher’s one-woman show, “Wishful Drinking,” covers her experience as Princess Leia in “Star Wars” and her ongoing bouts with drugs, but it is more than a tart memoir.
Melissa and Jason white found a 1,400-square-foot home in a Brooklyn neighborhood full of the camaraderie and neighborhood feel they craved.
After a career of secondary parts in indie films, Melissa Leo gets a star turn in “Frozen River.”
Tomi Ungerer, an artist equally at home with political art, children’s books and dark erotica, returns to American bookstores.
In this humanist story collection, Uwem Akpan drives home the miseries that afflict Africa.
Miranda Seymour’s odd and oddly affecting memoir instantly catapults her father into the front rank of impossible and eccentric English parents.
When the author’s mother dies, his father promptly begins dating again.
A growing number of writers have hit the rubber-chicken circuit. A midlist novelist might get $2,500 an appearance, while superstar historians can command as much as $40,000.

A picture caption on Page 7 this weekend with an article about three inns with excellent restaurants in the Highlands of Scotland misidentifies the inn where a scallop dish with vermouth and Greek basil is served. It is the Summer Isles Hotel, not the Three Chimneys.
I had a habit of getting a tattoo after a breakup, believing a tattoo was sexy because everyone could see that you opted for pain.
A construction boom tied to the Olympics is threatening two types of housing in China’s capital.
Contemporary Chinese art is as hot as Beijing in August, and new galleries are opening nearly every week in its arts district, Dashanzi.
Faced with the increasing cost and unpredictability of travel today, vacationers are using Web sites that connect them with traditional travel agents.
The writer takes a wild, wet ride down the Owyhee River, snaking between sheer rock walls and camping out in gigantic caverns.

A report in the Comings & Goings column on July 13 about the Redondo Beach, Calif., Chalk Art Festival and Live Music on the Redondo Beach Pier on Aug. 23 misstated the time the music would be performed. It follows the awards ceremony, from 4 to 8 p.m.; it does not take place during the ceremony.
Events in Chicago, San Francisco and Singapore worth getting on a plane for.

To the Editor: I was very disappointed that your article “Where River Views Are From the River” (July 13) failed to mention the historic vessels of the South Street Seaport Museum — a 123-year-old schooner, the Pioneer, and a 1930s era tugboat, the W. O. Decker — which offer both public tours and great river views.

Starwood Hotels and Resorts is offering a $25 gas credit and reduced room rates to travelers who stay for at least two nights at select properties.

JACOBS--Louis, on July 24, of Oceanside, L.I. His family and friends mourn his passing. He is survived by his beloved wife of 58 years, Lucille, his sons Steven (Bonnie), Howard (Nanette), and Robert, along with his grandchildren Jared, Brett, Michael, Eric, and Benjamin. FOR BETTER OR WORSE, our culture relies on quotations -- literary passages, Bible verses, movie lines, song lyrics, catchphrases, proverbs -- to transmit the wit and wisdom of the past and the present and to lend resonance to our everyday discourse. Perhaps the most important are the political quotes, the sound bites, slogans, zingers and bloopers that can win or lose elections and shape our arguments and opinions.

An illustration with the Up Front column last Sunday was published in error. The Howard Hampton it depicts is the leader of the New Democratic Party of Ontario, not the reviewer with the same name who was profiled in the column.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended July 12, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
ZANKEL--Arthur. We miss your warmth, love, wisdom and wit. You made this world better. Love, Kenny and Anna

China never ceases to interest, or to perplex. After a century and a half of reinventing itself, trying on various new modern guises, China has become a place with opposites often in jarring juxtapositions. Its economic boom, rapidly expanding middle class and high-gear global quest for resources and markets contrast sharply with the continuing authoritarianism of its official politics. What China will look like in a decade or so is hard to say, but wherever it is headed, it is going there with enormous energy. With demonstrations in ethnic Tibetan areas, an earthquake in Sichuan Province and the Summer Olympic Games about to open in Beijing, the world's fascination with China has only intensified. Below, 32 questions designed to shed some light. ORIGINS TO OLYMPICS

Rosenberg for 54 years, devoted and proud mother of Alan D. Rosenberg and Wendy, the late Leonard Rosenberg and Arlene. Adored grandmother of Kerri and Rich Schnapper, Joshua, Brian and Stacy. Loving great-grandmother of Lexi and Mackenzie. Survived by brothers Moe and Ralph Nierenberg, and preceded by sister Pauline Jacobs. One of the first woman to be Bas mitzvahed in 1928. Volunteered at YHMA in Mt. Vernon and knitted for Israeli charity. She will always be remembered.
Wave 25 East Broadway

IN May, the South Carolina Legislature passed a bill that approved a Christian license plate design featuring the image of a cross over a stained-glass window, along with the slogan ''I Believe.'' If Gov. Mark Sanford signs the bill into law, South Carolina would become the first state to offer a religious-themed plate. But before that happens it might have to survive court challenges.
LOONEY--Dell, 92, on July 21 in Santa Monica, CA. Predeceased by husband Tim, survived by daughter Karen, niece Anne, nephew David.

To the Editor: In ''The Long Amen'' (July 20), about the decision by the Presbyterian Church of Astoria to sell its property to a developer, a church member is quoted as saying: ''They want to give us a community room. I'm sorry, but a community room is not a holy place.''

KOEHLER--Audrey, 81, on Saturday, July 19th at her home in Southampton, NY. The daughter of Walter L. Carey and Frances McKeever, Audrey was born June 4th, 1927 in New York City and grew up in Southampton and Santa Barbara, CA, where she went to Santa Barbara High School. A graduate of the New York School of Interior Design, she set up her own decorating firm in the 1960s, which she ran for more than thirty years. Among many charitable activities, she helped organize Les Boutiques de Noel, the holiday shopping bazaar that benefited Cancer Care and co-founded Parrish Presents, the annual holiday bazaar that benefits the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton. She is survived by her husband of 44 years, the artist Henry Koehler; her two sons, Alexander Mason (of Owings Mills, MD and Southampton) and Anthony Mason (of Rye, NY); and five grandchildren: Taylor, Christopher, Emily, Olivia and Nicholas. A private memorial service will be held later this summer in Southampton. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Parrish Art Museum, 25 Jobs Lane, Southampton, NY 11968 or East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978-7048.

McLEAN--William E., 86, of Pawling, NY, passed away July 24, 2008. Survived by his wife Molly, children Shelagh, Douglas, and Alison, and granddaughter, Dara. A memorial service will be held Saturday, July 26th at 2pm at Christ Church, Pawling, NY. Horn & Thomes Funeral Home 845-855-3550.

Two months ago, Michele Martin ditched her 10-mile commute from Stamford to Greenwich in favor of riding Metro-North. Gasoline prices were the main reason, she said, but not the only one. ''I would see a billboard once in a while saying, 'Do one thing.' That cinched it for me,'' she said. Now, she doubts that she would ever go back to driving.

''So you say you're selling your house?'' The Wall Street Journal asked on July 14. ''Hey, it could be worse. You could be selling a Hummer.'' Some people are selling a Hummer. And to get a sense of how bad it is when you're selling a big S.U.V. in the era of high gas prices, I went on Craigslist and surveyed the plaintive listings. The bottom line seems to be that if you have a Hummer H2 or even a more fuel-efficient H3 for sale, you're very negotiable. Let's talk, the ads say, but sometimes even that isn't possible.

WHO says the phone booth is dead? The two in the library on the University of North Carolina's Greensboro campus are very popular -- as private nooks for cellphone users. That's just one symptom of a much larger change: the elimination of telephone land lines in dorms. More institutions are acknowledging what has been obvious to students and parents for years: nobody uses them.

DUDIN--Helene. The School of American Ballet family notes with sadness the death of Helene Dudin, one of the extraordinary Russian teachers who gave a sound classical base to many generations of SAB dancers. She taught at the School for nearly half a century and affected the lives of thousands of young students.
BRESKIN--Daniel, on July 21, 2008 in Cheshire, CT. Beloved husband of Myrna, father of Peter and Andrew, brother of Lisa.

WEBER--Antoinette Marie (Toni), 64, passed away peacefully at home in Jacksonville, FL on July 17, 2008. Toni was born January 9, 1944 in The Bronx (Go Yankees!). She was the daughter of Lawrence and Lucretia Gwendolyn Hazel Celentano. Toni is survived by her loving husband, Jonathan, and her adoring doggies, Zach and Zoe. Toni touched the lives of so many people with her kindness, compassion, fabulous sense of humor, and a genuine lave for all her friends. She will be remembered in our hearts forever. Her husband would like to thank the staff at Regional Consultants Oncology and Community Hospice of Northeast Florida for their kindness and caring. In lieu of flowers, donations may he made to Community Hospice Foundation, 4266 Sunbeam Road, Jacksonville, FL 32257, or The Jacksonville Humane Society, 8464 Beach Blvd, Jacksonville, FL 32216. Also, Toni would love you to bring your used books to your local library. Let us all remember and celebrate Toni's life with as much passion as she lived it. WEBER--Toni, an unusually special friend who was always there for me with sincere and honest advice, as well as for every other friend she had. She was my rock, my confidante, my sounding board, my book source and much more. She had a quick wit, said it like it is and always made me laugh when I needed it. I will miss her beyond words and still cannot imagine life without her. Toni, you will always be in my heart. My deepest sympathies to her husband Jon. Susan

GMAT officials are analyzing the site's data and threatening to cancel the scores of students who supplied, or just studied, those questions and to notify the business schools that accepted them.
