HOLLANDER--Ralph, violinist, composer and inventor of the DAMPIT, died peacefully on July 23, 2008 at age 91 at his home in NYC. Born in Mount Vernon, NY on November 9, 1916. Preceded in death by his wife Ingrid in 1990. Survived by his brother Norman, three nieces and one nephew. He began performing classical trios at age eight with his two brothers as The Hollander Trio. A graduate of Juilliard School of Music, he had a career as a virtuoso violinist, performing with Casals Festival Orchestra and as soloist with national and international orchestras. Among other compositions, he composed and recorded an oratorio ''Psalms of David'' with Agnes Moorehead as narrator. He invented and manufactured the DAMPIT, the first humidification device to preserve and restore dry and damaged wood of violins and other valuable stringed instruments. The DAMPIT was endorsed by Isaac Stern, Mstislav Rostropovich, Pablo Casals, Yo Yo Ma, Leopold Stokowski and Arturo Toscanini. A memorial service will be held Monday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to Juilliard School of Music for students scholarships.

FIELD--Allen, 96, died on July 20, 2008 at the Osborn Pavilion in Rye, New York. Beloved husband of Lucille for 70 years, father of Lois Kreisel and Bob Field, grandfather of four and greatgrandfather of five. Allen lived in Larchmont, NY for 52 years before moving to the Osborn seven years ago. He graduated from Ohio State University and served in the National Guard. In 1945 he established the Allen Field Company that still manufactures plastic display items for the garment industry. He was a founding member of the Larchmont Temple and longtime member of Beach Point Club. He loved woodworking and photography, leaving many gorgeous nature photos to family, friends and the Osborn. A person of great dignity and self-reliance, he will be greatly missed.

SIEGEL--Jerrad, of NYC, died on July 21st in his home at the age of 80 after a courageous battle with cancer. He is a WWII Navy veteran and a graduate of Brooklyn Law School. He worked for Nassau County as a Deputy County Attorney and New York State as an Administrative Law Judge. He served as the President of the Oceanside Democratic Club. He is survived by his beloved wife, Sandra, two children, Todd Siegel and Lynda Edwards, and four grandchildren. Donations in his memory can be made to Continuum/Jacob Perlow Hospice, 39 Broadway Suite 200, New York, NY 10006 attn Development.

To the Editor: Re ''Echoes of Gaudí in a Place That Honors Grant'' (July 20), about an effort to restore mosaic benches around Grant's Tomb:

WULFSON--Harris Joshua, composer and musician, Harris Wulfson died suddenly on July 23rd. He was deeply loved by friends and family, and his passing is an indescribable loss. Harris, a cum laude graduate of Amherst College, will forever be remembered as a gentle soul with tremendous humor, a keen and unconventional intellect and an incredible, gifted musician. He is survived by his parents Howard and Carol of Boca Raton, his sister and brother-in-law Michelle and William Jaeger, his grandmother Thelma Gordon and his music. Funeral services today, 11:30am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

When is a fledgling company no longer a start-up? Once the skateboard ramp disappears, says Rob Kalin, the founder of Etsy Inc., an online emporium of handmade goods based in Brooklyn. And while Etsy is only three years old, Mr. Kalin got rid of the ramp six months ago. But that wasn't the only change: he knew he needed professional management. ''We hit a point in growth that we needed people who have done this before,'' he said.

VISITING THE TAJ MAHAL, MAY 3, 2008 Anne Engedal, 20, a student from Silkeborg, Denmark, leaps into the air as her friends snap her photo. ''I prefer to see a place for a longer period of time than just seeing the sights and moving on, because otherwise you don't get a feel for what's really going on. It's really the main kick of traveling for me -- that you can meet people in such different circumstances, and really, it's the same things that make people happy and it's the same things that you can bond over. I had been in India for about three months doing volunteer work for lower-class children in Rajasthan when this picture was taken, and we had just left the project to go on a monthlong trip. You meet a lot of people in India who have traveled there for a long time, and they say 'Oh, Taj Mahal, it's just another tourist attraction, don't go there, it's boring.' So we came with mixed expectations. But when you get there, it's even more beautiful than you thought. This incredibly big stone structure, it seems so light because it's white marble. You get the feeling that the person who created this must have been really, really developed and civilized.'' As told to Austin Considine

A breeze always seems to be blowing in from the Hudson, even on the steamiest days, and Henry's on the Hudson, in Peekskill, is a good place to catch one. Perched on a cliff overlooking the river, Henry's has a deck where, if you time it right, you can sit beneath the flapping awning and watch a kaleidoscopic sunset. The deck lies beyond an indoor bar and a dining room with long windows and a mirrored wall. The décor is plain, but the mirror brings in that view, which is what Henry's is all about.

RESSMEYER--Rev. Henry Francis, 90, Greenport. New York on July 24, 2008 at Greenport's Peconic Landing surrounded by his family. Loving husband of 64 years of Ruth Marie (Bretscher); beloved father of Christa Ruth Klein Ph.D. (Rev. Leonard), Georgia Jo Ressmeyer JD, The Rev. Canon Victoria Grace Sirota DMA (Dr. Robert) and renowned photojournalist Roger Henry Ressmeyer, loving grandfather of Maria Hollenbeck, Nicholas Strauss-Klein, Renate Klein, Jonah and Nadia Sirota, Ryan and Rachel Ressmeyer, and great-grandfather of five; dear brother of the Rev. Dr. Rudolph P.F. Ressmeyer and brother-inlaw of Rev. George Hoyer. Educated at Concordia Seminary, St. Louis (BD and MDiv); Adelphi University (MA); New York Theological Seminary (STM); Columbia University Teachers College (MA). Ordained 65 years ago, he was Pastor at Grace Lutheran Church, Malverne. NY (1945-68), Dean of Chapel and Head of Religion Department, Long Island Lutheran High School (1968-1972), Senior Pastor, St. Paul's Lutheran Church, East Northport, NY (1972-1984); Vacancy Pastor, St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Greenport, NY (198587; 1995-96); and Chaplain, San Simeon By the Sound nursing home, Greenport, NY (198804). Pastor Ressmeyer is known particularly for his pastoral ministry and family counseling, his faithfulness during the time of the split in the Missouri Synod-Lutheran Church that contributed to the formation of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, and his community leadership in racial justice in Malverne, LI during the 60's. ''Uncle Joe'' sailed Lightning class sailboats for 50 years in Orient Harbor and is remembered for his affection and good humor. Family to receive friends on Sunday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Horton-Mathie Funeral Home, 735 First Street, Greenport Village, NY. Liturgy of the Resurrection, Monday 11am at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Greenport NY. Committal to follow at East Marion Cemetery.

Four years after the closings of La Côte Basque and La Caravelle, two classic French restaurants on West 55th Street, the neighborhood's Gallic influence is alive and well and living in these bistros and brasseries. Benoit Rating: 1 star

HINCKLEY--Samuel Neilson Jr., died at age 92 on July 11, 2008 at Villa Marin, San Rafael, CA. Born in NYC on September 14, 1915, he was a direct descendent of Samuel Hinckley who sailed on the Hercules arriving in Scituate, MA, March, 1634, later moving to the town of Barnstable, and his son Thomas Hinckley, Governor of Plymouth Colony. Mr. Hinckley attended the Aiken Preparatory School, and graduated from Groton School and Harvard University where he was President of the Harvard Advocate. For 40 years he was a stock broker in San Francisco and divided his time between Menlo Park and Inverness, CA. His marriage to the former Helen Pettit ended in divorce in 1991. He was predeceased by his longtime and beloved companion, Mary Elizabeth Lyman in 2003. He leaves behind his wonderful and loving soulmate, Gabriele Horton, and his adoring children Samuel H. Hinckley and Helen H. Beekman. He is also survived by his four grandchildren Samuel N. Hinckley, Suzanne S. Hinckley, Izaak B. Beekman and Hugo H.L. Beekman as well as his daughter-in-law Frances D. Hinckley and son-in-law William B. Beekman. Not only will Sam be deeply missed by his devoted family but his ever joyful, witty, kind, loving, intelligent friendship will be missed by many friends of all ages from California to the East Coast. A memorial celebration of his life will be held in Inverness, CA in September. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Mr. Hinckley may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, ATTN: Tribute Gifts, Church Street Station, P.O. Box 780, New York, NY 10008-0780 or to The Inverness Foundation, P.O. Box 382, Inverness, CA 94937.

WEISS--Leonard A. ''Lenny''. Brother of Muriel, beloved father of Jeff, Bill and Richard, father-in-law of Robin and Tammie, grandfather of Bari, Richard and Perri, companion of Inky. Leonard practiced law in Mount Vernon New York since 1953, originally with the firm Avstreih Martino & Weiss and in recent years at the firm of Martino & Weiss. He was the patriarch of the family who was always available for his guidance and wisdom. He was happily married to his wife Betty, who passed away December 15, 1990 for 37 years. He will be greatly missed, always be kept in our hearts and never forgotten. BACK IN BUSINESS Remember Peter R. Dolan? Two years ago, he was ousted as chief of Bristol-Myers Squibb over the handling of a patent dispute regarding the blood thinner Plavix. Now, Mr. Dolan has finally resurfaced in the industry, joining the board of Gemin X Pharmaceuticals, a private company in Malvern, Pa., that specializes in developing therapies for leukemia, small-cell lung cancer and lymphoma.

FOSTER--Jane Boone, of Redding, CT. 100 years old. 1930 Graduate of Vassar College. Wife of the late Herbert Hastings Foster, Jr. Long time resident of Wilton, CT and Block Island, RI. Exceptional gardener, artist, author. Survived by four children: Grace Watkins, Joanne Carlisle, Lillian Ketchum, Herbert H. Foster III; seven grandchildren, eight greatgrandchildren. Memorial service will be held on Block Island. Contributions to the Block Island Conservancy, Box 84, Block Island, RI 02807.

As a companion-animal veterinarian of 24-plus years, I can assure you that ''humanization'' at times taints our own clinical perspectives. I'm reminded of a behavioral seminar I recently attended where the lecturer, a very prominent veterinary behaviorist, drew a critical analogy between ''discriminatory'' civic laws against pit-bull ownership and the persecution of Jews in Nazi Germany. I nearly walked out in disgust, but I digress. In my own practice experience, and consistent with the animals described in the article by James Vlahos (July 13), all types of neurotic behaviors are far more prevalent in single-pet households. If it can be managed, two or more pooches or cats are easier to live with than one. Friendship and vigorous activity go a long way in preventing nutty behavior. Just like us.

With neutrals the predominant hue on campus, bold colors make a nonconformist statement. Art majors in particular like a bright palette. ''Everything in my life revolves around color,'' says L. August Salazar (bottom center), a U.C.L.A. double major in art and philosophy. Hair, she adds, is ''another canvas'': even as a girl she used her Sharpies to paint it. Justin Edwards (top left), a senior, is less fanciful: ''I don't think I can get away with having a purple mohawk any other time in my life.''

WAVE says summer, from its waterfront location to its airy décor to its outdoor deck jutting into Port Jefferson Harbor. Diners inside and out have panoramic views of the water and the Port Jefferson-Bridgeport ferry next door. Wave, at Danfords Hotel and Marina, is the product of a multimillion-dollar renovation that transformed the hotel's forgettable 25 East American Bistro into this destination restaurant.

FRATERNITIES and sororities have long kept files of old tests to show housemates what to expect. At Virginia Polytechnic Institute, they're known as koofers, from ''coffers,'' the strongboxes where old exams were stored in the '40s. ''I thought it was unfair,'' says Michael Rihani, who wasn't in a frat.
TARQUIN--H. E. Ebker, Fashion Designer died July 21st, 2008. Survived by his wife Cho.

THE NEWS Venezuela's president, Hugo Chávez, and King Juan Carlos of Spain shook hands and made up in their first meeting since the king told Mr. Chavez to ''shut up'' at a summit last November. BEHIND THE NEWS Relations plummeted between the countries following the outburst, which lived on at YouTube, as well as on cellphone ringtones and T-shirts. Mr. Chávez, who was interrupting a speech by the Spanish prime minister when the furious king let loose, threatened to review diplomatic and business ties with Spain. Now all appears to be forgiven -- though Mr. Chávez, visiting the king, did not hug the monarch, as he said he would do.

It was 7:30 a.m. on a humid Monday, and David Muller, a doctor and a suburban bike commuter, was sweating his way to work. As he rode along the George Washington Bridge and into Manhattan, Dr. Muller, 44, seemed indifferent to the low roar of rush-hour traffic. He was halfway from Teaneck, N.J. -- where he lives -- to Mount Sinai Medical Center -- where he works -- and was happy to be on his bicycle. ''It's free, it's good for the environment, good for your health,'' he said, beads of sweat collecting under his helmet and underneath his backpack, about 5 miles into his 12-mile ride. ''And it's a little dangerous, so you get a little thrill at the beginning and the end of each day.'' He also gets satisfaction from beating cars across the bridge. ''I love it,'' he said.

MEYER--Andrew C., April 2, 1917--July 16, 2008. Passed away peacefully at age 91, at home, four months to the day after the death of his beloved wife, Myra, his soul mate of 65 years. Theirs was a true love story. Andy will be remembered as a wonderful mentor with tremendous warmth and unending devotion to his family. His positive attitude, strength, perseverance and generosity of spirit touched all who knew him. His spirit and memory is kept alive by his loving children, daughter Constance Buerger, son Andrew, son-in-law Alan Buerger, daughter - in - law Kathy Meyer, his adoring grandchildren, Reid Buerger, Grant Buerger, Joshua Meyer, Daniel Meyer, Jessica Meyer and granddaughter-in-law Krista Buerger. He was a huge part of all of their lives. He is survived by his twin brother, Wallace Meyer. Donations to the Andrew C. Meyer Initiative for Education and Clinical Progress, established in his memory, would be appreciated. Donations to the order of: Johns Hopkins University, Dept. of Psychiatry. Please note: In Memory of Andrew C. Meyer. Send to: Fund for Johns Hopkins Medicine, Dept. of Psychiatry, One Charles Center, 100 North Charles Street, Suite 410, Baltimore, MD 21201.

As he rode along the George Washington Bridge and into Manhattan, Dr. Muller, 44, seemed indifferent to the low roar of rush-hour traffic. EDITH BOUVIER BEALE, best known as Little Edie in the 1975 documentary ''Grey Gardens,'' died in 2002, but the public's fascination with her endures: ''Grey Gardens,'' the Broadway musical, earned 10 Tony nominations in 2007; John Galliano cited her as an inspiration for his spring collection; HBO is amid production on a biopic starring Jessica Lange and Drew Barrymore; and now comes the release of ''Edith Bouvier Beale of Grey Gardens: A Life in Pictures.'' Conceived by Eva Marie Beale (the wife of Edie's nephew, Bouvier Beale Jr.), the book is filled with photographs, letters, drawings and sundry scrapbook items (J.F.K. and Jackie's wedding invitation, a letter from Macy's encouraging her to model) culled from Edie's overstuffed and truly inspiring archives. ''Should one try to sum up all this phantasmagoria -- the full bouquet of Edie's memories and everything else,'' Peter Beard, a family friend, wrote in the book's foreword, ''it would have to be called something like BEYOND WORDS.''

THE first thing to say about Half Moon, the new restaurant that has taken over the old Chart House space in Dobbs Ferry, is also the first thing you'll notice when you enter: The Hudson River views are spectacular. Built partly out over the water, and with two outdoor dining areas, the restaurant has a half dozen different angles on the river, and all of them -- from the Manhattan skyline to the Tappan Zee Bridge -- are transporting. Visit on a misty evening as the sun goes down or on a clear summer night when you can sit outside, and the effect is magical. Here's some equally good news: You'll want to go for more than the views.

CORBIN--Tanya, (nee Jacobs) born June 8th, 1920, died on July 24th in NYC. Devoted wife for over forty years of Sol Neil Corbin, loving mother of David, beloved sister of Irwin Jacobs. Tanya attended the University of Wisconsin and graduated from the Tobe Coburn School for Fashion Careers. She had a distinguished career in advertising during WWII in Washington, DC. She was a descendant of Mattityahu Strashun, whose library in Vilnius was the largest library of Jewish learning in this center of the Jewish Enlightenment Movement. She helped underwrite the computerization of the Yivo Institute's catalog, which contains the books from the Strashun Library. Tanya was a Patron of The New York Festival of Song, a supporter of The New York Public Library, and a member of JINSA and CAMERA. Tanya's integrity and sense of justice were intrinsic to her personality. Her style, warmth, charm and intelligence will be missed by all who knew her. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 Eighth Ave., NYC 10011 or The New York Botanical Gardens. The family will be receiving at the home of Ann and Irwin Jacobs from 5-7:30pm, Monday, July 28 through Thursday, July 31.

LUBLIN--Jerome Turkewitz (Jerry), died peacefully at home, July 25, 2008. Wonderful father of Nina, favorite uncle of Steve and Judy, Marci, George, Marla, Howard and Don. Loving husband of the late Frances, brother of Marty, Paul and Leonore Yoss, who predeceased him. WWII veteran, USMC. Friend to so many. Thanks to his caregivers Norma, Catherine, Sylvia, Bev and Abel. Funeral service 11am Sunday, July 27, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

TALK SHOW Johnny Carson would always have me on the show whenever the latest incarnation of ''The Dick Cavett Show'' ... um ... completed its current tenure. Often on the following Monday and always with a version of the same joke in the monologue: ''Our good friend Dick Cavett is here tonight. Dick's had another show shot out from under him. I'm always afraid that if the next one doesn't take, it's going to be Armed Forces Radio for Dick.'' One time, with about a minute remaining, Carson began asking each guest what was coming up for him. And each had a big movie, big Broadway show, big something to plug. I didn't. I hoped the clock would run out before my fellow Nebraskan got to me.

EHRENREICH--Dolores Vanetti, died at her New York home on July 13, 2008. She was 96. World traveler, bird watcher, mushroom hunter, art collector, amateur anthropologist, chain-smoker and lifelong chef -among so much else -she played an important part in the life of Jean Paul Sartre, and never lost her French accent. She was a singular woman, and she will be sincerely missed.

SCHALLER--Joseph, 1926-2008. Beloved husband and best friend of Gertrude for 59 years. Loving father of Howard and Arthur and father-in-law of Margaret and Karen, cherished grandfather of Rebecca Neil, Bianca and Elizabeth, a great brother to Emanuel and Bernard. Joe loved his family, friends and all people he met.

ARRIVING at a party this summer in a clingy American Apparel dress roughly the color of her own skin, Theodora Richards (right) looked, at first glance, as if she had forgone getting dressed. And, surely, that was the intention. Nude, as the hue is called in the beauty and fashion industry, ''is one of the sexiest colors there is, if not the sexiest,'' said Alexander Wang, who worked it into his fall collection. Clearly what began last spring as a mere shoe fetish has evolved into a full-body trend. The French Vogue editor Carine Roitfeld (above), who could create a fervor for fundoshis if she cared to, attended the recent couture shows in a nude Azzedine Alaïa dress, with matching Alaïa shoes. For fall, Valentino, Nina Ricci, Christopher Kane (far left) and Chanel all showed strong looks in the delicate shade. Karl Lagerfeld even upped the erotic factor by putting bondage straps on one of his dresses.

TURNOVER AT THE TOP The Downey Financial Corporation, a California savings and loan, announced a change in its top management last week as the sour housing market continues to take a toll on banks. Downey said its chief executive, Daniel D. Rosenthal, 55, and Maurice L. McAlister, 83, its founder and largest shareholder, were retiring. The bank, based in Newport Beach, selected Thomas E. Prince, 61, its current chief operating officer, as interim chief executive while it searches for a permanent replacement. Michael D. Bozarth, an independent director, was named the new chairman.

To the Editor: Re. the article ''Wall Street Blues'' (July 20), I would feel more sympathy for Andrew Slutzky's having lost his job in residential finance if he had expressed some regret or insight about the questionable institutional practices that have led hundreds of thousands of home-buyers into unsustainable mortgages. But he wants to get back into the game.

HARTNEY--Robert J., husband, dad, poppa, skier and wordsmith, on July 14. Bob passed peacefully at his home outside San Diego surrounded by his family after a vigorous fight with cancer. He was 80. Born in Chicago, always his home town, he served in the army, earned a degree in journalism from the University of Missouri, and then migrated to New York City. He enjoyed the bachelor life during the City's Golden Years in the 1950s, until fate introduced him to his wife and life long partner Patricia. Bob spent his career in public relations, working first under the tutelage of Harold Burson at Burson-Marsteller. He later worked for several large corporations, ending his career with Household International. No major family event went by without a few or more appropriate words and commentary, crafted as only Dad could. Pat and Bob started their family in Chicago then moved back to the New York area, then back again to Chicago. A new chapter began when the family moved to San Diego in 1979. Business interrupted and brought Bob and Pat back to his roots in Chicago but they retired in San Diego for good in 1997. There he played tennis almost until his death, enjoyed the beach and served as a sheriff volunteer in Poway. Aside from Pat and his family, his great love was skiing. His extended family gathered every year in Park City, and he skied on his 80th birthday this past January. He never quite mastered the Stem Christie but he loved trying. Bob is survived by Patricia, his daughter Meghan, sons Michael (Chrissa), Mark (Tina), David (Michelle) and Christopher (Molly), and grandkids Cait, Jack, Ryan, Nick, Riley and Finnian. He will be missed always and greatly. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Elizabeth Hospice: www.elizabethhospice.org.

Michael was an assistant director for ''The Sopranos'' and many movies. He was a proud Florida Gator with a deep passion for music, sports, and politics. Michael is survived by his wife and best friend of 26 years, Amy Lauritsen, parents Linda and Dennis Beynon, sister Mary DeCasper, brother-inlaw Matt Dobbins, in-laws Sally and Paul DeMartini, Linda Jesberg, Scott Lauritsen, Marcia Cowin and Rick Lauritsen, nieces, nephews and countless friends. He was a special man who will be missed by all. A memorial service will be planned at a later date. The family is requesting donations in Michael's name to: Dr. Allyson Ocean Research Fund, c/o Allyn Rose, Weill Cornell Development Office, Box 123, 525 East 68 St. NY, NY 10065.

To get athletes to hunker down, the National Collegiate Athletic Association in 2005 developed the Academic Progress Rate, a gauge of how Division I athletes do in the classroom over four years. Penalties are levied if rates fall below 925, about equal to a 60 percent graduation rate (the N.C.A.A.'s method considers freshmen graduating within six years and includes transfer students). Until this year, A.P.R. calculations were adjusted to avoid unfairly penalizing teams on the basis of limited data. Now that four years of data are available, adjustments have been eliminated and the number of sanctioned teams has about doubled:174 teams lose scholarships or practice time; 44 more are on notice (among mitigating circumstances: showing improvement or outperforming the student body). In the graphic above is a list of teams in some major sports that have been penalized.

HARRIS--Elaine A. passed away on June 20, 2008 in Hanover, NH. Born in 1918, she was raised in Spokane, WA and graduated from the University of Washington with a degree in Far Eastern Studies. In 1941 she wed George L. Harris and entered an extraordinarily happy marriage lasting 67 years. During George's active World War II military service, Elaine worked in the Far Eastern Division of the Office of War Information in Washington D.C. After the war the couple lived in Nanjing, China, where Elaine worked to develop the original Fulbright International Exchange Program. They returned to Washington in 1949. Throughout her professional life, Elaine had administrative responsibilities for the Fulbright program and later held an acting directorship of the International Exchange of Scholars, until her retirement in 1981. Thereafter the couple moved to Craftsbury, VT, where they were involved with the Craftsbury Chamber Players and St. Johns Episcopal Church. In 2003 they moved to Kendal at Hanover. Elaine is survived by George and two goddaughters.

VALDES-RODRIGUEZ-Jorge, 78, of Surfside, FL, beloved husband for 50 years of Rosa (Crucet) Valdes-Rodriguez, died Saturday, July 19, 2008 surrounded by his family. Born in Havana, Cuba, he was the son of the late Dr. Antonio and Josefina (Unanue) Valdes-Rodriguez. He received a doctorate of law degree from the University of Havana and was an attorney in his native Cuba. Following the Communist take over of that country, in 1961, his family escaped from Cuba to immigrate to the U.S. After originally settling in New York City, NY, he lived in Manhasset, NY, where he raised his four children. As a Senior Master Agent for Equitable Life Insurance, where he was employed since 1961, Jorge retired with his wife, Rosa to Surfside, FL where he could enjoy the beach and ocean. Jorge was the first hispanic agent to be inducted into the Equitable Life Insurance Hall of Fame and was a life qualifying member of the Million Dollar Roundtable. Our husband, father, and Papi was devoted to his family, loved to dance and had an incredible zest for life. Besides his loving wife, Rosa, he leaves his children, Rose Ponte of Harwinton, CT; Jorge A. ValdesRodriguez and his wife Julie of Norwalk, CT; Alina Douglass and her husband Mark of Avon, CT; Robert J. Valdes-Rodriguez and his wife Regina of New York City, NY; his brother, Dr. Antonio Valdes-Rodriguez of Atlanta, GA, and 14 grandchildren; John Thomas, Rosie, Ashley, Tommy, Paul, Luke, Ryan, Conor, Britt, Gavin, Suzy, Robert, Casey and Linda. Besides his mother-in-law, Rosa Alcalde, who was an integral part of his life for many years, he was predeceased by his son-in-law, John Ponte. Family services and Mass will be private at the request of the family, and there will be no calling hours. Donations can be made to the Wilder Penfield Chair at the Montreal Neurological Institute, Attn: Giovanna Caraffa, 3801 University Street, Montreal, Quebec H3A 2B4. The Carmon Funeral Home & Family Center of Avon is caring for the services. For online condolences, please visit carmonfuneralhome.com.

MEDIA ADVICE Carmen Wong Ulrich, the host of a new personal finance program called ''On the Money'' on CNBC, won't mind if you watch her show while surfing the Internet on a laptop with one hand and sending text messages on a cellphone with the other. DALY--Michael J., 83, of Fairfield, CT, died at home of cancer, July 25. Medal of Honor recipient WWII. Longtime trustee St. Vincent's Medical Center of Bridgeport. Funeral service Tuesday, July 29, St. Pius X Church, Fairfield.

Rosalyn Johnson, a registered nurse from Westbury, is so convinced high gasoline prices are here to stay that she recently opted to take a job in Manhattan over one in Central Islip, closer to home. ''It was more economical to take the job in the city,'' she said, while waiting for an eastbound Long Island Rail Road train at Pennsylvania Station. ''It would cost me more to drive to Central Islip than to buy a $211 monthly train pass.''

MASSI--Norberto, died at home in Providence, RI on July 20. Beloved husband of Mary Bergstein Massi, devoted brother to Giuseppina, Italy. Adored uncle to nieces and nephews here and in Italy. Born in Bergamo on 25 August 1940, he received a Ph.D. from Columbia University in the department of Art and Archaeology in 1987. Norberto Massi was a recognized scholar of Venetian and Lombard Renaissance art, an inspiring teacher to hundreds of students at Rhode Island School of Design. MASSI--Norberto, died at home in Providence, RI on July 20. Beloved husband of Mary Bergstein Massi, devoted brother to Giuseppina Giovanzana of Mantua and Maria-Luisa Zucchinelli of Bergamo, Italy. Adored uncle to nieces and nephews here and in Italy. Born in Bergamo on 25 August 1940, he received a Ph.D. from Columbia University in the Department of Art and Archaeology in 1987. Massi was a recognized scholar of Venetian and Lombard Renaissance art, an authority on the Renaissance painter Lorenzo Lotto, and an inspiring teacher to hundreds of students at Rhode Island School of Design. GOLDSTEIN--Walter C. The staff and faculty of the School of American Ballet mourn the death of Walter Goldstein, stepfather of our Executive Director, Marjorie Van Dercook. He was funny and generous, firm of purpose, and clearly loved his family. Peter Martins, Kay Mazzo, and the entire SAB family send condolences to his wife Doris, his children and grandchildren. GOLDSTEIN--Walter C., 85, passed away on July 24, 2008 at home in Westhampton Beach. Beloved husband of Doris, cherished father of Steven, Laurie and Bruce, devoted stepfather of Carol and Marjorie and adored grandfather of nine grandchildren. His brother Emmanuel Goldstein predeceased him. Walter was born in Montreal, Canada and moved to Brooklyn, New York at the age of 12. He was a proud graduate of Penn State University with a degree in civil engineering and an Air Force bombardier navigator during WWII. Walter Goldstein was the founder and President of Underhill Industries, Inc. which became one of the largest concrete construction companies in New York, and with its joint venture partner, DIC Construction Corporation, completed the concrete structures for many of the largest developments in New York City, including the World Trade Center, Coop City, Starrett City Housing and numerous other projects. In 1972, Walter initiated the purchase of Certified Industries, a supplier of transit mix concrete, from U.S. Steel. Certified Industries became one of the largest suppliers of concrete in New York City. Walter loved food, friends, France, his boats and life. He told a good story and had a great sense of humor. He was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend. Services will be held on Tuesday, July 29, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978; gifts@eeh.org. GOLDSTEIN--Walter. The Board of Directors of the School of American Ballet is deeply saddened by the death of Walter Goldstein, stepfather of Marjorie Van Dercook, Executive Director of the School. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Robert Fribourg, Chairman GOLDSTEIN--Walter C. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Walter C. Goldstein, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary GOLDSTEIN--Walter C. Our dear friend Walter C. Goldstein was an exceptional man whom we loved, respected and admired. He influenced our lives in many ways. He always made us feel that we were part of his family. He did everything in life and did it all with great style. His passing creates a tremendous void in our lives. Our deepest love and sympathy to Doris, their children and families . Stephen, Anne Marie, Starr, Evan, and Regina Haymes GOLDSTEIN--Walter. The Associated Builders and Owners of Greater NY, marks with great sadness the passing of Walter Goldstein, member of the Board of Directors. Walter spent many years shaping the skyline of New York City through his association with Underhill Construction. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his wife Doris and their family. Jerome Belson, President Nicholas LaPorte, Jr., Executive Director GOLDSTEIN--Walter. An enduring friendship of over 65 years with never a cross word between us. Walter, you will be sorely missed. Our condolences to Doris and all members of the family. Love always, Hal, Steven, Loren, Richard, Julia, Robert and Erica

MCMAHON--Donald A. Mr. Donald A. McMahon died peacefully at home July 23, 2008 after a long illness. Born February 20, 1931 in Brooklyn, New York, Mr. McMahon made his home in Atlanta since 1975. From 1975-1985, Mr. McMahon was President and CEO of Royal Crown Companies, Inc. From 1970-1975, he was President of Baker Industries in New Jersey. He began his business career in 1952 as a salesman with the Monroe Calculating Machine Co. In New York. At the age of 35, McMahon became the youngest President in the company's history. As President of Monroe, he also served as Vice President of the parent company, Litton Industries of Beverly Hills, CA. Mr. McMahon was a member of the following boards: Roper Corp., Richton International, Norrell Corp., Kidde, Inc., Intelligent Systems, Inc., and Colorocs Corp. In addition, he was the past chairman of the Board of Visitors of Emory University, member of the board for Georgetown University and St. Elizabeth's College. Mr. McMahon was active with many Atlanta charities, including the Boys and Girls Clubs of Metro Atlanta where he served as Chairman in 1990 and was instrumental in the combining of the Boys Clubs and Girls Clubs into a single organization. He held a Master's degree in Business Administration from Emory University. In 1985, McMahon became a member of the Sovereign Military Order of The Knights of Malta. He was predeceased by his parents, William and Anne McMahon, his sister Barbara Carroll, and his grandson Ryan Conaway. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, the former Nancy Lantz, his sister Carol Young of Bronxville, NY, his children Gail Connell of Alpharetta, GA, Brian McMahon of Birmingham, AL, Lisa McMahon of Atlanta, GA, Glenn McMahon of Newport, CA, Anne McMahon of Atlanta, Carol Lucas of Greensboro, NC, Bill McMahon of Wellesley, MA, and Douglas McMahon of Orlando, FL and his 18 grandchildren and three stepgrandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Donald A. McMahon 1991 Scholarship Fund, c/o Boys & Girls Clubs of Metro Atlanta, Resource Development Department, 100 Edgewood Avenue NE, Suite 700, Atlanta, GA 30303 or online at http://www.bgcma.org/view/ donate. A vigil will be held Monday, July 28th, at 7:30pm at Holy Spirit Catholic Church, 4465 Northside Drive NW, Atlanta, 404-252-4513, with the family receiving friends one hour prior to the service. Funeral services will be Tuesday, July 29th, at 11:00am at Holy Spirit Catholic Church, with family receiving friends following at McDonough Hall adjacent to the church. Interment will follow at Arlington Memorial Park, 201 Mount Vernon Highway NW, 404255-0750.

CURRENT/ELLIOTT, a new denim brand designed by two stylists in Los Angeles, has worked a small army of fashion editors into a major frenzy. Specifically, their Boyfriend jeans, a higher-waisted, well-washed, slouchy style based on a pair of Levi's 501 XX from the 1950s. The allure? They are the antithesis of the dark, skinny jeans that have saturated the denim market. ''All I can say is that every time we send samples out for a shoot, the editor sends an e-mail asking to place a personal order,'' a spokeswoman for the brand said. More-brazen stylists have even offered to cut a check for the samples themselves. But most (which is to say, about 30) placed personal orders at the press preview in April, well before the pants had gone into production. The jeans hit Barneys New York this week, but, then, there's already a lengthy wait list.

OVERSETH--Oliver E. Overseth, 80, died peacefully in his sleep at his home in Key West, FL on July 17, 2008, of prostate cancer. Born in New York, NY in 1928 to Oliver E. Overseth, Sr. and Ione Johnson, Oliver grew up in Canton, SD and attended WashingtonLee High School in Arlington, VA. After graduating with a BS from the University of Chicago, he earned his Ph.D. at Brown University, and spentfour years as an Instructor and Research Associate at Princeton University. He and his former wife, Anneke deBruyn Overseth, moved to Ann Arbor in 1961, where Oliver joined the Physics Department at the University of Michigan. Oliver was a highenergy experimental physicist, involved in experiments at Berkeley, Brookhaven, Fermilab, and CERN. His major research interest and accomplishments were in the physics of hyperons, their polarization, decay parameters, and magnetic moments which were the subject of several experiments at the Fermilab accelerator and later at CERN. At Michigan, he chaired the doctoral thesis committees of 12 students, served on many College and University committees, and was a highly regarded lecturer. Since retiring from the University in 1992, Oliver split his time between homes in Geneva, Switzerland and Key West, FL, as well as traveling throughout the world. He married his longtime love, Ludy van Bruggen, in September 2007. Throughout his life, Oliver loved jazz, and was a noted collector of Sidney Bechet. He adored sports cars and could usually be seen driving a Porsche. He will be remembered for his keen observations on people and events, his extraordinary knowledge of facts important and trivial, his generous love for his family and his wry sense of humor. He is survived by his wife, Ludy van Bruggen Overseth, his daughters Alison Overseth (Alan Bozian) of New York and Tenley Le Sann (Bernard) of Geneva; grandchildren Hannah, Peter and Emily Bozian and Brandon and Clayton Le Sann. There will be a memorial service for Oliver in Key West this coming winter. In lieu of flowers, Oliver hoped his friends would put on some great jazz, have a martini and whoop it up.

The city’s Administration for Children’s Services has recruited 60 former police investigators in the past year and a half to bolster the agency’s 1,300 caseworkers. They help locate hard-to-find parents. They give safety tips to caseworkers for volatile domestic situations. They tweak interview techniques. And they serve as a bridge to active law enforcement when child welfare and crime overlap. In addition to having special access to databases like domestic incident reports, the former investigators have much more expertise in interpreting records that are sometimes written in arcane code.

Ferapontovo Monastery, in the Vologda region 300 miles north of Moscow, is way off the beaten track for most tourists. But for those curious about the luminous 15th-century frescoes in the monastery's Cathedral of the Nativity of the Virgin, there is an exhibition of remarkable photographs on display in Moscow's Shchusev State Museum of Architecture through the end of August. Profoundly theological in their content and execution, the frescoes depicting biblical prophets, saints, New Testament parables, Jesus and the Last Judgment, were painted by Dionisy the Wise, widely regarded as one of the greatest Russian iconographers. The frescoes, along with the monastery itself, are on Unesco's World Heritage list, and are especially notable for their terracotta and blue hues that seem more Mediterranean in style than northern Russian. Which makes it all the more amazing that the 300 or so images in "The Light of Dionisy's Frescoes" exhibition at the Shchusev Museum are photographs, the work of Yuri Kholdin, a photographer who spent over 10 years studying and capturing the frescoes, using analog cameras and shooting at specific times of day, with as little artificial light as possible. The result is a collection of images that are so detailed and true to the originals that they look like the real thing.  The fact that they are hung in the museum's Aptekarsky Prikaz wing, which looks and feels like a monastic chamber, only enhances the effect. Several times, I wanted to reach out and touch them, to feel the texture I could so clearly see.   Kholdin died a year ago at age 52, in an accident while photographing the skyscrapers of Moscow City, the Russian capital's new business district. His widow, Yekaterina Danilova, an art historian with theological training who wrote the texts that accompany the images, has continued his work promoting the frescoes.  Kholdin's love of the art form was reflected in his creation of a foundation called Frescoes of Russia. In an interview about his work, which was distributed at the exhibition, Danilova discusses Kholdin's time studying Renaissance art in Italy and his interest in Kazimir Malevich's Suprematism, which was influenced by icons. It's possible to see the influence of both in Kholdin's approach to photographing the frescoes. One American visitor at the exhibition's July 22 opening compared the photographs of the frescoes to the work of the Italian Renaissance painter Giotto. The close-ups of fresco details - an angel's face, a pitcher on a table - are reminiscent of Suprematist compositions. For more information on Kholdin's work see his Web site, www.dionisy.ru, for now in Russian only.

From the Department of Random Observations: In an era when libraries have become "media centers" and card catalogs have gone the way of parchment and vellum, it seems passing strange that the 19th-century Dewey decimal system should retain its tenacious hold on the stacks. Bookstores, after all, do just fine with large signs dividing their titles by subject and smaller signs marking internal subdivisions. Isn't that more user friendly? If I want to know what's eating my hosta leaves (slugs or deer, most likely), intuition tells me I'll find the answer more quickly at a Barnes & Noble, where I can head straight to "Gardening, Disease and Pest Control," than at a library, where I have to consult a computer database before tracking down 635.049 and its neighbors.

More than a dozen years ago, my late mother was considered a fashionista among the limited mobility set because her walker was customized with tennis balls on its back legs. The fuzzy yellow balls, scored with a utility knife for a snug fit, were intended to work rather like shock absorbers, smoothing her ride and eliminating the annoying tap-tap-tap of the walker's legs hitting the floor. She carried her possessions in a wicker basket secured to the handlebars with shoe laces.

International TWO BOMBS KILL 16 AND WOUND

LAS VEGAS -- The winners of the Wagar Women's Knockout Teams final at the Summer North American Bridge Championships here in the early hours of Saturday morning were Lynn Baker of Austin, Tex.; Karen McCallum of Exeter, N.H.; Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y.; Beth Palmer of Silver Spring, Md.; Irina Levitina of Hackensack, N.J.; and Kerri Sanborn of Stony Point, N.Y. Down by 64 international match points after 32 of the 64 boards, they surged back to win by 30 imps over Valerie Westheimer of New York; Hjordis Eythorsdottir of Huntsville, Ala.; and Marion Michielsen and Meike Wortel from the Netherlands.

DEVINE--Gerald Thomas, a longtime Rye, NY resident, died on July 25, 2008 with his wife, Louise of 44 years by his side. GT as he was known by all, was born in Plainfield, New Jersey to Christopher J. Devine and Bonaventura Kirby on January 11, 1937. He was the sixth of nine siblings. Jerry graduated Croydon Hall Academy in New Jersey in 1955. He then attended St. Edwards College in Austin, Texas. Jerry had great admiration for his father, C.J. Devine, a very successful government bond broker with an active brokerage firm named after him (C.J. Devine and Co.). Jerry began his career at the brokerage firm, Nugent Igo located in East Orange, New Jersey. He worked there until 1962 and was then hired by his father at his offices in Manhattan. He went on to manage his father's Boston office, which he did until 1964. Jerry married Louise Davino on September 26, 1964 and then settled in Rye, NY. Between 1964 and 1980, Jerry worked for a variety of different government bond firms, eventually going into business for himself starting the firm, G.T. Devine and Co. He later changed the name of his firm to Devine International. He worked tirelessly there until the day of his death. G.T. will always be remembered for his love of the market, sports (most especially golf and the football Giants), and above all else, his love of people. He absolutely adored his family and his grandchildren. He was witty, generous, charming and gracious. He was always the life of the party. He made anyone he spoke to feel special, and he was always genuine and sincere. Over the years he helped countless friends and acquaintances to find work, see a ball game, connect with one another, or get through a tough time. G.T. Devine is survived by his beloved wife Louise, his son Jerry Jr., his daughter Holly and her husband, Garth Melville, and two grandchildren, Sean and Jack. A wake will be held on Tuesday, August 29th at Grahams Funeral Home in Rye; hours: 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, August 30th at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, kindly send a donation to Abbot House located at 100 North Broadway, Irvington, NY 10533.

PARDRIDGE--Barney, 90, formerly of Palm Beach, FL, Litchfield, CT, Portsmouth, NH, and Kitzbuhel, Austria died July 23. We miss her indomitable spirit!

GOLDSTEIN--Walter C., 85, passed away on July 24, 2008 at home in Westhampton Beach. Beloved husband of Doris, cherished father of Steven, Laurie and Bruce, devoted stepfather of Carol and Marjorie and adored grandfather of nine grandchildren. His brother Emmanuel Goldstein predeceased him. Walter was born in Montreal, Canada and moved to Brooklyn, New York at the age of 12. He was a proud graduate of Penn State University with a degree in civil engineering and an Air Force bombardier navigator during WWII. Walter Goldstein was the founder and President of Underhill Industries, Inc. which became one of the largest concrete construction companies in New York, and with its joint venture partner, DIC Construction Corporation, completed the concrete structures for many of the largest developments in New York City, including the World Trade Center, Coop City, Starrett City Housing and numerous other projects. In 1972, Walter initiated the purchase of Certified Industries, a supplier of transit mix concrete, from U.S. Steel. Certified Industries became one of the largest suppliers of concrete in New York City. Walter loved food, friends, France, his boats and life. He told a good story and had a great sense of humor. He was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend. Services will be held on Tuesday, July 29, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978; gifts@eeh.org. GOLDSTEIN--Walter C. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Walter Goldstein. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Services will be held July 29th at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. Jerry Lewis, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Michael Gyure, Executive Director GOLDSTEIN--Walter C. Our dear friend Walter C. Goldstein was an exceptional man whom we loved, respected and admired. He influenced our lives in many ways. He always made us feel that we were part of his family. He did everything in life and did it all with great style. His passing creates a tremendous void in our lives. Our deepest love and sympathy to Doris, their children and families . Stephen, Anne Marie, Starr, Evan, and Regina Haymes GOLDSTEIN--Walter. An enduring friendship of over 65 years with never a cross word between us. Walter, you will be sorely missed. Our condolences to Doris and all members of the family. Love always, Hal, Steven, Loren, Richard, Julia, Robert and Erica GOLDSTEIN--Walter C. Our heartfelt condolences to Doris and Walter's extended family. We join them in mourning this exceptional and generous man, whose partnership and friendship for 23 years enriched our lives. Joe and Shirley Gleich GOLDSTEIN--Walter C. We will miss you! Our condolences and love to Doris and family. Bonnie and Bernie

SANTOGOLD ''Top Ranking: A Diplo Dub'' (Mad Decent) In late 2004, a few months before M.I.A. released ''Arular,'' her debut album, she put out ''Piracy Funds Terrorism,'' a mixtape she made with the genre-scavenging Philadelphia D.J. Diplo. The mixtape was, in some ways, a greater accomplishment than her album, transforming M.I.A. from a relative unknown, Sri Lankan Briton with a couple of ineffable singles into an avatar of a global urban music continuum that spanned hip-hop, dancehall, baile funk and more.

ZANKEL--Arthur. We miss your warmth, love, wisdom and wit. You made this world better. Love, Kenny and Anna ZANKEL--Arthur. You fill my dreams and my waking thoughts. I miss you every day and will love you forever. Judy

MELLIN--Gloria Rivers, 82, of Orleans, MA, died Sunday, July 6. Born in Boston on June 11, 1926, she was orphaned at the age of twelve and raised by family friends. Gloria attended Newton High School and graduated from Smith College in 1948. She married The Rev. John O. Mellin in 1947 and moved to Manhattan where he became pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York. She was a founding member of the Association of Mentally Ill Children School, earned an M.A. in education at NYU, and taught in New York City's public elementary schools for 20 years. She and Rev. Mellin retired in Orleans, MA in 1989. She is survived by her sons James of Wilton, CT, Timothy of Lexington, KY, and four grandchildren. She was predeceased by sons Peter and John of Orleans and her husband Jack. A memorial service will be held at noon Thursday, July 31 at the Federated Church of Orleans, MA.

ROGERS--Charles A., longtime Bay Shore resident, on July 26, 2008, in his 89th year. Beloved husband of Natalie Rogers. Loving father of John Rogers, Margaret Johnson, and Susan Rogers. Cherished grandfather of of eight and great-grandfather of six. Mr. Rogers was a real estate broker and appraiser for 50 years. He was a graduate of Hofstra University School of Business and Columbia Law School. Mr. Rogers represented his country in World War II, serving the Unites States Navy. He was a retired USN Captain for the Naval Reserve. Visiting, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at the Overton Funeral Home, Inc. 172 Main St. Islip, NY. Requiem Mass, Wednesday, 11am, St. Peter-by-theSea Episcopal Church. Bay Shore, NY. Cremation Private.

REUBEN--David Ainsworth, It has been 20 years since your beautiful, loving soul walked this earth. You left us too young. We hold you in our hearts with strength and joy. For one day your happy eyes will greet us and welcome us to our new home, where we will be at last, together with you. SWIFT--Louise Ann, on July 26, 2008 at the age of 56, of Albertson, NY. Cherished mother of Matthew, Shawn, Jessa and Zachary Swift. Loving daughter of Seymour and the late Seena Schneiderman. Caring sister of Lori and Jan. Life companion of Warren Schuster. Services Monday, 1pm at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

KIMMEL--Lucille, 96, July 26, 2008. Wife of the late Edward A. Kimmel. Mother of Joan Eigen and the late Alan Kimmel. Mother-in-law of Robert Eigen. Grandmother of Debbie, Julie, Vicki, David, Wendy and David. Great-grandmother of Sam, Nathan, Torey, Emily, Lexi, Zach, Erin, Max, Jack and Sam. Our sweet Luci, a lady who always thought of others first; who dedicated her life to her husband, and her children and then to making everyone around her happy. A wonderful woman who taught her grandchildren to love fried eggs on an English muffin, ice cream and a milk shake but most of all how to be kind to others. A true matriarch and spiritual ''glue.'' She will be missed by all whose lives she touched. After all, everybody loves Luci. Eddie and Luci -back together again dancing, playing duets and making beautiful music as they did for 67 years. On the back of every letter he sent to Luci, he wrote: IICBWYOHT -from the song: If I Could Be With You One Hour Tonight. Sweet dreams to both of you. Love the Kimmel and Eigen Families.

KAPLAN--Irwin, 71, died peacefully on July 26, 2008, at his beloved country home surrounded by family and friends, after a long courageous battle with PSP, a rare neurological disease. Survived by Marion, his wife of 48 years; children Rachel (Adam) and Daniel (Karen)l three grandchildren, Anna, Jacob, and Esme; nieces and nephews; and a multitude of friends. Founding partner of Datronics, Inc., he retired early to happily pursue many new interests, including learning piano, construction, wood working, and, as always, travel, philanthropy, theatre, music and literature. He loved life and lived with integrity, charm, humor and commitment to his family and friends. He was widely recognized as the ''reincarnation of Fred Astaire'' and lived with style and grace until the very end. Burial will be private and the family will receive visitors at their country home from Sunday, July 27 through Tuesday, July 29. A concert in celebration of his life will be held in New York City in early fall, time and place to be announced. Contributions in his honor can be made to Community Works, 38 West 70th Street, New York, NY 10023; Time and Space Limited, P.O. Box 343, Hudson, NY 12534; or to CurePSP at psp.org

PARIS -- Carlos Sastre has been a contender in the Tour de France for so long that few people thought he would ever actually win it. Despite five top-10 finishes in the last six years, Sastre was widely considered the always-a-bridesmaid rider who could not get far enough ahead in the mountains to fend off the superior time-trialing abilities of other, more well-rounded riders.

CORBIN--Tanya, (nee Jacobs) born June 8th, 1920, died on July 24th in NYC. Devoted wife for over forty years of Sol Neil Corbin, loving mother of David, beloved sister of Irwin Jacobs. Tanya attended the University of Wisconsin and graduated from the Tobe Coburn School for Fashion Careers. She had a distinguished career in advertising during WWII in Washington, DC. She was a descendant of Mattityahu Strashun, whose library in Vilnius was the largest library of Jewish learning in this center of the Jewish Enlightenment Movement. She helped underwrite the computerization of the Yivo Institute's catalog, which contains the books from the Strashun Library. Tanya was a Patron of The New York Festival of Song, a supporter of The New York Public Library, and a member of JINSA and CAMERA. Tanya's integrity and sense of justice were intrinsic to her personality. Her style, warmth, charm and intelligence will be missed by all who knew her. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 Eighth Ave., NYC 10011 or The New York Botanical Gardens. The family will be receiving at the home of Ann and Irwin Jacobs from 5-7:30pm, Monday, July 28 through Thursday, July 31.

CORBIN--Tanya, (nee Jacobs) born June 8th, 1920, died on July 24th in NYC. Devoted wife for over forty years of Sol Neil Corbin, loving mother of David, beloved sister of Irwin Jacobs. Tanya attended the University of Wisconsin and graduated from the Tobe Coburn School for Fashion Careers. She had a distinguished career in advertising during WWII in Washington, DC. She was a descendant of Mattityahu Strashun, whose library in Vilnius was the largest library of Jewish learning in this center of the Jewish Enlightenment Movement. She helped underwrite the computerization of the Yivo Institute's catalog, which contains the books from the Strashun Library. Tanya was a Patron of The New York Festival of Song, a supporter of The New York Public Library, and a member of JINSA and CAMERA. Tanya's integrity and sense of justice were intrinsic to her personality. Her style, warmth, charm and intelligence will be missed by all who knew her. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 Eighth Ave., NYC 10011 or The New York Botanical Gardens. The family will be receiving at the home of Ann and Irwin Jacobs from 5-7:30pm, Monday, July 28 through Thursday, July 31.

Jesse Jackson on July 6 quickly rose to the top of the search heap. In the four weeks that ended July 19, 6,180 search terms included the word ''obama,'' compared with 2,095 that included ''mccain.'' OLD 97'S ''Blame It on Gravity'' (New West) ''The easy way gets harder all the time,'' Rhett Miller moans on the seventh studio album by his band, Old 97's. The line sums up both his targeted wordplay and the tenacity of his characters. Through the band's 15-year career Mr. Miller has come up with countless ways to detail how love goes wrong, especially when it's the singer's own fault.

KIMMEL--Lucille, 96, July 26, 2008. Wife of the late Edward A. Kimmel. Mother of Joan Eigen and the late Alan Kimmel. Mother-in-law of Robert Eigen. Grandmother of Debbie, Julie, Vicki, David, Wendy and David. Great-grandmother of Sam, Nathan, Torey, Emily, Lexi, Zach, Erin, Max, Jack and Sam. Our sweet Luci, a lady who always thought of others first; who dedicated her life to her husband, and her children and then to making everyone around her happy. A wonderful woman who taught her grandchildren to love fried eggs on an English muffin, ice cream and a milk shake but most of all how to be kind to others. A true matriarch and spiritual ''glue.'' She will be missed by all whose lives she touched. After all, everybody loves Luci. Eddie and Luci -back together again dancing, playing duets and making beautiful music as they did for 67 years. On the back of every letter he sent to Luci, he wrote: IICBWYOHT -from the song: If I Could Be With You One Hour Tonight. Sweet dreams to both of you. Love the Kimmel and Eigen Families.

FOSTER--Jane Boone, of Redding, CT. 100 years old. 1930 Graduate of Vassar College. Wife of the late Herbert Hastings Foster, Jr. Long time resident of Wilton, CT and Block Island, RI. Exceptional gardener, artist, author. Survived by four children: Grace Watkins, Joanne Carlisle, Lillian Ketchum, Herbert H. Foster III; seven grandchildren, eight greatgrandchildren. Memorial service will be held on Block Island. Contributions to the Block Island Conservancy, Box 84, Block Island, RI 02807.
MONTI--Lily, on July 26, 2008, of Floral Park, NY. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Randi and Don. Loving grandmother. Services were held Sunday, July 27, 2008.

REUBEN--David Ainsworth, It has been 20 years since your beautiful, loving soul walked this earth. You left us too young. We hold you in our hearts with strength and joy. For one day your happy eyes will greet us and welcome us to our new home, where we will be at last, together with you. Your mother Pearl, Your sisters Rosemarie, Kathleen and Gloria, Your brothers, Denis and Lennox, Your sister-in-law Julie ...We love you eternally.

MELLIN--Gloria Rivers, 82, of Orleans, MA, died Sunday, July 6. Born in Boston on June 11, 1926, she was orphaned at the age of twelve and raised by family friends. Gloria attended Newton High School and graduated from Smith College in 1948. She married The Rev. John O. Mellin in 1947 and moved to Manhattan where he became pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York. She was a founding member of the Association of Mentally Ill Children School, earned an M.A. in education at NYU, and taught in New York City's public elementary schools for 20 years. She and Rev. Mellin retired in Orleans, MA in 1989. She is survived by her sons James of Wilton, CT, Timothy of Lexington, KY, and four grandchildren. She was predeceased by sons Peter and John of Orleans and her husband Jack. A memorial service will be held at noon Thursday, July 31 at the Federated Church of Orleans, MA.

SUPERGRASS ''Diamond Hoo Ha'' (Astralwerks) Supergrass has been a Top 10 band in Britain ever since it arrived in the heyday of Britpop with its 1995 debut album, ''I Should Coco.'' But Britpop's blend of glam and new wave rock with parochially English lyrics didn't gain traction in the United States and has been largely supplanted by later trends in Britain. And Supergrass, now one of the last Britpop holdouts, takes some trans-Atlantic swerves on its sixth album, ''Diamond Hoo Ha.''

ROGERS--Charles A., longtime Bay Shore resident, on July 26, 2008, in his 89th year. Beloved husband of Natalie Rogers. Loving father of John Rogers, Margaret Johnson, and Susan Rogers. Cherished grandfather of of eight and great-grandfather of six. Mr. Rogers was a real estate broker and appraiser for 50 years. He was a graduate of Hofstra University School of Business and Columbia Law School. Mr. Rogers represented his country in World War II, serving the Unites States Navy. He was a retired USN Captain for the Naval Reserve. Visiting, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at the Overton Funeral Home, Inc. 172 Main St. Islip, NY. Requiem Mass, Wednesday, 11am, St. Peter-by-theSea Episcopal Church. Bay Shore, NY. Cremation Private.
WOLF--Anthony Lewis (Tony). 26 years -love and sorrow. Mom and Sasha

9 P.M. (HBO) THE RECRUITER As it strives to maintain troop levels in Iraq and Afghanistan, the United States Army is encountering a dramatic recruiting crisis. This documentary by Edet Belzberg follows the fervently patriotic Sgt. First Class Clay Usie as he works closely with four recruits in Houma, La., a small Cajun town of shrimpers and oil riggers near New Orleans, finishing their senior year of high school and preparing for basic training. Lauren, above, a 17-year-old from a poor background, sees the military as the best way to pay for college and become an artist. Bobby, 18, an honor student with a bright future, decides to join the Army despite the disapproval of his father, a veteran. ''He's made the decision,'' his father says. ''I don't know that any 18-year-old can really understand that the end of his life could be around the corner in Iraq.'' 7 A.M. NEWPORT, R.I. -- The 24 members of the news media who voted in the league's preseason media poll agreed on one thing -- Syracuse will be the worst team in the Big East in 2008. All 24 of them voted the Orange last, the latest in a flurry of signs that Syracuse football has bottomed out.Under the fourth-year coach Greg Robinson, the Orange is mired in the worst stretch in team history. Things are so bleak in Central New York that the Vegas over-under for victories for the Orange this is season is 2.5, and Syracuse has already been installed as a double-digit underdog in its opening game at Northwestern.Unless a miraculous turnaround comes, this will be Robinson's last year on the Hill. It's the most obvious looming story line for the Orange as it gets ready for the season. (And as evidence by this blog post, some Syracuse fans appear tired of Robinson's rhetoric by now.)Syracuse guard Ryan Durand acknowledged that Robinson was "on the hot seat."He said: "Obviously we know about it. Everyone on the team knows about it. But it's not a dark cloud, it's not a motivation. Our motivator is to win games, for us. Coach Robinson is one of us. But I want to win for the tackle and center next to me. I just want to win. That's the name of the game."He added: "It's never been addressed on the team. It's one of those things that doesn't need to be said. Everyone knows what's going on and what our mission is. It's one of those things we don't need to talk about. It's really silly to talk about it."Durand was more than happy to talk about the new offensive coordinator Mitch Bronwing, a coup of a hire by Robinson considering the slim chances of the Orange retaining him next season. Browning sat out last season after working for Glen Mason at Minnesota, and his resume includes tailbacks Laurence Maroney and Marion Barber III. His main focus will be to overhaul one of the country's consistently bad units during Robinson's tenure. The Orange gave up 54 sacks last season and 45 the previous year. Browning is regarded as an great molder of offensive linemen, and he's had all of the Orange linemen slim down, including having the tackles lose as many as 30 pounds.Durand, who has had four offensive coordinators in five years, called him a "breath of fresh air."But breathing life into the corpse that is the Syracuse football program may be too much of a task for Browning.

Alcatel-Lucent, one of the world's largest suppliers of telecommunications equipment, on Tuesday posted a second-quarter net loss of 1.1 billion euros and said its chief executive, Patricia F. Russo, and its chairman, Serge Tchuruk, would step down by the end of the year.
Sign at Princeton airport: "Plane rides -- 20 cents per pound."

I.B.M. said on Monday that it has agreed to buy Ilog, a French software maker, for 215 million euros ($340 million), as the technology giant seeks to strike deals for intellectual companies that it can give scale.

Sirius Satellite Radio may have won its 18-month battle to convince regulators to approve its merger with XM Satellite Radio, but investors seemed wary that the deal would be a panacea for what ails the company.

British Airways and Spain's Iberia said on Tuesday that they are in negotiations to strike an all-stock merger, months after British Airways dropped a bid to buy the Spanish airline.

Private equity investors who have ponied up for retailers may well wish to wipe 2008 from their memory. That may apply especially to Sun Capital Partners, whose Mervyn's retail chain is reportedly on the verge of bankruptcy.
Raining on the Giants' parade and other items from the Interwebs:
After his mortgage company nearly crashed a decade ago, Michael W. Perry set a new course. He bought a bank so the company, soon rechristened IndyMac Bank, would never run short of money again.

Tesco on Monday inked a 950 million pound ($1.9 billion) deal to buy Royal Bank of Scotland Group's 50 percent stake in their joint venture, Tesco Personal Finance, as the British supermarket chain moves agressively into the British banking market.

A New York judge ruled Monday that bankrupt Delphi can move forward with its suit against a group of investors led by hedge fund Appaloosa Management that pulled out of an agreement to help finance the auto parts maker's reorganization plan.

Sony is in talks to buy the 50 percent stake it does not own in Sony BMG Music Entertainment from Germany's Bertelsmann for more than 100 billion yen ($931 million), the Nikkei business daily reported on Tuesday.

Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain's stock, according to a filing Monday.

Dave Hermansen did not own a bird or a cage when he bought bird-cage.com, an online store, for $1,800 three years ago. He simply saw a Web site that was "very, very poorly done," and begged the owners to sell it to him. He then redesigned the site, added advertising and drove up traffic. Last December, he sold it for $173,000.
Biovail founder Eugene Melnyk said on Monday he was abandoning his plan to oust the Canadian drugmaker's board of directors and elect his own team at Biovail's shareholders meeting next month.

A sell-off of stocks accelerated in late trading Monday as investors moved out of shares of investment and commercial banks, many of which have given back all of their gains from last week.
XL Capital, a large insurer based in Bermuda, said Monday that it would raise $2.5 billion to help recapitalize Security Capital Assurance, a bond insurance company it spun off in 2006.

A Russian court heard testimony on Monday from the author of an American anti-racketeering law, who argued in support of a novel legal theory that would allow the Russian government to apply the law in a $22 billion suit against the Bank of New York for its role in a money laundering scandal in the late 1990s.

The financial establishment came together Monday in search of a new way for banks to come up with cash for home mortgages. Regulators, bankers and traders, led by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., all pledged to do their best to get a "covered bond market" going in the United States.

Loews posted a second-quarter profit of $4.96 billion on Monday, reflecting the spinoff of its Lorillard cigarette unit.

Anyone hoping for signs the market in Spain is leveling off will be disappointed by the latest round of numbers. The number of house sales dropped by 34 percent in May compared to a year earlier and mortgage borrowing dropped by more than 40 percent, according to the National Statistics Institute.

After 14 years, the world’s largest physics experiment seems to be getting close enough to becoming a reality for its participants to plan the opening parties.
Beach closings and health warnings were down in 2007, but were still the second highest on record, a study found.
Gina Trapani, an expert on navigating the demands and complexities of modern technology, discusses how to be more productive at work.
A. J. Burnett matched a career high by earning his 12th victory and Matt Stairs hit a two-run homer Monday night for the Toronto Blue Jays in a 3-1 victory over the visiting Tampa Bay Rays.

A brief art review on Friday about “History Keeps Me Awake at Night: A Genealogy of Wojnarowicz,” at the P.P.O.W. gallery on West 25th Street, in Chelsea, misstated the connection of Photi Giovanis to the exhibition. He was curator of readings held in conjunction with it, not of the exhibition itself. (The curators of the exhibition were Wendy Olsoff, and, as noted in the review, Jamie Sterns; artists in the show also made suggestions.).
A music review on July 14 about Damon Albarn & The Honest Jon’s Revue, at Avery Fisher Hall, misstated the given name of a guitarist who performed. He is Simon Tong, not Peter Tong.

Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Sunday about the Mets’ 10-8 extra-innings loss to the Cardinals misstated the surname of the Mets’ starting pitcher in the game. He is Brandon Knight, not Wright.

A television review on July 12 about “Foyle’s War,” part of “Masterpiece Mystery!” on PBS, misspelled the surname of the detective played by Helen Mirren in “Prime Suspect,” to whom Detective Christopher Foyle of “Foyle’s War” was compared. She is Jane Tennison, not Tennyson.

An article on Thursday that previewed an article in The New York Times Magazine on Sunday about Afghanistan’s thriving opium trade misstated the background of Thomas Schweich, who wrote the magazine article. He is a former senior counternarcotics official in the State Department who was based in Washington and made several visits to Afghanistan. He was not based in Kabul.

An article on Thursday about the budding industry to turn waste products into motor fuels misspelled the name of a New Hampshire company that aims to turn crop waste into ethanol. It is Mascoma, not Macoma.

A Man in the News article last Tuesday about Radovan Karadzic, the former leader of Bosnian Serbs arrested on July 21 on longstanding war-crimes charges for atrocities committed in the Balkans conflict of the early 1990s, referred incorrectly to a British statesman who had helped draft the 1995 Dayton agreement that ended the conflict. At the time he worked on the agreement, he was Lord Owen, a former foreign secretary; he had been known as David Owen when he held that post.

An article on Monday about the dedication of a bench on Sullivan’s Island, S.C., to commemorate slaves and their history — an action inspired by a remark by the writer Toni Morrison — misidentified the location of Fort Sumter. It is in Charleston Harbor near Sullivan’s Island; it is not on Sullivan’s Island.

An art review on Friday about two exhibitions of Icelandic art, using information provided by Scandinavia House, the site of “From Another Shore: Recent Icelandic Art,” misstated the title of a work by Katrin Sigurdardottir that is on display there. It is “Haul,” not “Cargo.”.

An article on Friday about the IntercontinentalExchange misstated part of the name of the regulator of the company’s London futures market. It is the Financial Services Authority, not the Financial Securities Authority.
An article on July 14 about Western magazines in India erroneously included a magazine among those introduced in India in the last 12 months. Marie Claire was introduced earlier, in June 2006.
INTERNATIONAL.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on July 18 about Katherine Heigl’s remaining on “Grey’s Anatomy” next season despite speculation that she wanted to leave the ABC medical drama included an outdated reference to her character, Izzie. She is now a resident; she is no longer an intern.

Greg Norman turned down an invitation Monday to play in the P.G.A. Championship, deciding to stick to a previous commitment instead of competing for a fourth straight week. The P.G.A. of America offered Norman an exemption after he had the 54-hole lead in the British Open and finished third. Norman tied for fifth last week at the Senior British Open, and will play this week in the United States Senior Open at the Broadmoor in Colorado.

The Indy Racing League will not return to Nashville Superspeedway after efforts to negotiate an agreement for a 2009 race failed. The IndyCar Series had raced at the track the past eight years, including July 12, when Scott Dixon won a rain-shortened race. The Edmonton Sun reported Sunday that Toronto would replace Nashville in an 18-race schedule in 2009. Nashville had been the only concrete track on the I.R.L. circuit, and drivers had been unhappy with the difficulty of passing on the 1.33-mile oval.

The California State Athletic Commission changed its original decision on the James Toney-Hasim Rahman fight from a technical knockout to a no decision. Toney stopped Rahman in the third round on July 16 in Temecula after Rahman told the ringside doctor that he could not continue because of a cut over his left eye.

Tony Stewart was fined $10,000 for what the United States Auto Club deemed unsportsmanlike conduct during a midget race last week at O’Reilly Raceway Park in Indianapolis. Tony Stewart Racing also was placed on probation for the remainder of the U.S.A.C. season. Stewart reportedly knocked a radio headset off the head of one U.S.A.C. official and shoved another after a ruling Thursday involving Stewart’s car, which was driven by Tracy Hines. Hines scraped the wall and pitted for a tire change, but his car was not deemed ready to re-enter the race in time for the restart.

PARIS -- Ryanair, Europe's biggest low-fare carrier, said on Monday that 2008 was stacking up to be a dismal year for airlines and warned that it might post its first annual loss as a public company. Shares of Ryanair Holdings closed down 25 percent on the Nasdaq. ''The outlook for the remainder of the fiscal year, which is entirely dependent on fares and fuel prices, remains poor,'' Michael O'Leary, the Ryanair chief executive, said in a statement.

KIMMEL--Lucille. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Lucille Kimmel. Lucille was a leader in the Jewish community, who shared her commitment to generosity and philanthropy with her late husband, Edward, her late son, Alan, her late brother-in-law, Martin, and her grandson, David Eigen. Together their dedication to UJA-Federation strengthens our ability to care for those in need. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her daughter, Joan Eigen, and her husband, Robert; to her grandchildren, David, Debbie, Julie, Vicki, David, and Wendy; to her greatgrandchildren; and to the entire Kimmel and Eigen families. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO KIMMEL--Lucille. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with deep sorrow the passing of a dear friend and devoted supporter, Lucille Kimmel. Together with her beloved late husband Edward, a longtime distinguished member of Einstein's Board of Overseers, Lucille was a Benefactor of the College. The couple named a floor for cancer research at Einstein in memory of their beloved son, Alan, and established a scholarship fund for M.D.-Ph.D. students. Lucille was the loving mother of Einstein Overseer Joan Eigen, who also serves on Einstein's Cancer Research Advisory Board and is an honorary President of the Westchester/Fairfield Chapter of its Women's Division. To Joan and her husband Robert, a past Chairman of the College's Men's Division, and to the entire family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. Yeshiva University Richard M. The foreign ministers of Thailand and Cambodia began what they said would be protracted talks over a disputed mountaintop temple where soldiers from the two nations have confronted each other this month. ''The situation is not easing,'' a spokesman for Cambodia, Khieu Kanharith, said in Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital. Cambodia has 800 soldiers at the temple and Thailand about 3,000, he said. The Thai Foreign Ministry insisted that 400 Thai troops were facing up to 1,700 Cambodians. While both sides have moved artillery into the area, their soldiers are said to be mingling in a friendly atmosphere.
