GOLDSTEIN--Walter C., 85, passed away on July 24, 2008 at home in Westhampton Beach. Beloved husband of Doris, cherished father of Steven, Laurie and Bruce, devoted stepfather of Carol and Marjorie and adored grandfather of nine grandchildren. His brother Emmanuel Goldstein predeceased him. Walter was born in Montreal, Canada and moved to Brooklyn, New York at the age of 12. He was a proud graduate of Penn State University with a degree in civil engineering and an Air Force bombardier navigator during WWII. Walter Goldstein was the founder and President of Underhill Industries, Inc. which became one of the largest concrete construction companies in New York, and with its joint venture partner, DIC Construction Corporation, completed the concrete structures for many of the largest developments in New York City, including the World Trade Center, Coop City, Starrett City Housing and numerous other projects. In 1972, Walter initiated the purchase of Certified Industries, a supplier of transit mix concrete, from U.S. Steel. Certified Industries became one of the largest suppliers of concrete in New York City. Walter loved food, friends, France, his boats and life. He told a good story and had a great sense of humor. He was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend. Services will be held on Tuesday, July 29, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978; gifts@eeh.org. GOLDSTEIN--Walter. A man of unlimited passion, generosity and energy. His spirit and love of life inspired us all. Our sympathy to Doris, Margie, Laurie and the entire family. Susan Dragone and Bonnie Levison

Predeceased by her husband Irving Reichenthal, siblings Phil, Estelle, Mary and Ruth. Services Tuesday 1pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

RICHMOND--Julius B., M.D. It is with profound sadness that the members of the Board of Trustees of the Flight Attendant Medical Research Institute (FAMRI) note the passing of our beloved friend, mentor and educator --Julius B. Richmond, M.D. --formerly Surgeon General of the United States. Dr. Richmond over his long, diversified and splendid career did as much as anyone to protect and improve the health of his fellow citizens, and in particular children and adolescents. From 1953 to 1965 Dr. Richmond was chairman and professor of the Department of Pediatrics at the State University of New York, SUN Y College of Medicine and became dean in 1965, serving in that capacity until 1970. In 1965 Dr. Richmond was appointed by President Johnson as the first national director of Project Head Start in the Office of Economic Opportunity. Head Start became a year-round program after the first summer; approximately 750,000 children are enrolled in Project Head Start each year in approximately 1,500 centers across the United States. Head Start is a comprehensive child development program. In 1971 Dr. Richmond was recruited by the Harvard Medical School where he became a professor of psychiatry and human development and chairman and professor of the Department of Social and Preventative Medicine. Simultaneously, he was appointed professor of public health in the School of Public Health at Harvard. While at Harvard, Dr. Richmond was honored to receive a presidential dual appointment as both Surgeon General and Assistant Secretary for Health. Both positions required senate confirmation. Dr. Richmond was the first individual ever selected to occupy both positions. He had the responsibility in the federal public health sector for some 50,000 employees. During his tenure as Surgeon General, Dr. Richmond focused on tobacco control efforts through the publication of the 1979 Surgeon Generals Report, presenting overwhelming scientific evidence of the multiple harms caused by smoking. Dr. Richmond has received a number of honorary degrees including ones from Yale and Harvard. He continued his professional activities as the John D. McCarthy Professor of Health Policy Emeritus, monitoring students and colleagues, right up until the last couple of months. He continued to teach and write, striving to shape health policies for health promotion and disease prevention, with a special emphasis on children and families as well as the low income population. Dr. Richmond was a brilliant, caring, hands-on pediatrician for nearly 70 years. In later years he took on the onerous task of continuing to educate the public by testifying in open court about the dangers of tobacco and how the industry had for decades manipulated scientific data. In doing so Dr. Richmond voluntarily subjected himself to many days of grueling cross-examination, and he did this while refusing to accept compensation as a skilled expert witness. As Chairman of FA MRI's Medical Advisory Board, Dr. Richmond was vital to the Board of Trustees in helping to direct over $200,000,000 in grants to some of the finest medical schools and research institutions in America and the world --including five Centers of Excellence. The scientific research is aimed at eradicating the diseases caused by exposure to second hand tobacco smoke, the money having resulted from a class action lawsuit filed on behalf of nonsmoking flight attendants against the tobacco industry. Dr. Richmond had one of the most extraordinary and productive careers in the history of American monitoring science and public education. His professional accomplishments were mirrored by his sterling character traits. His sense of humor was legendary as was his refusal to acknowledge his own importance. He was endlessly patient, civil, tolerant, incredibly well-informed and a true pleasure to be around. The members of the Board of Trustees of FA MRI are eternally grateful for the guidance of Dr. Richmond over the past decade as well as for the pure pleasure of his company and insights. Board of Trustees Flight Attendant Medical Research Institute Miami, Florida

LAMB--Susan B., died quietly at her summer home on Shelter Island on Sunday, July 27th, after a two year struggle with lung and brain cancer. She was 72 years old. A New Yorker by birth and inclination, she was raised in Brooklyn and attended Cornell University, and graduated from Columbia Law School at the age of 21. She was the first female associate at Proskauer, Rose before marrying and moving to London where she and her husband owned a public relations firm, and where Lamb was an onair correspondent for the BBC. Upon returning to the United states, Lamb devoted nearly 40 years to raising funds for non-profit institutions, including New York University, the New York Public Library, the American Ballet Theater, Montefiore Medical Center and Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc. She was responsible for raising funds for many of the important educational and medical buildings built in New York during the 1970's-1980's. An avid reader, an accomplished raconteur and a skilled speaker, Lamb will be remembered for her sense of humor, her honesty, her innate sense of fairness and her mischievous smile. Everyone who knew her will miss her. She is survived by her daughter Fiona Lamb, and by her friend of many years, Carole Potter. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The New York Public Library. Services will be held on Wednesday, July 30th, at 1:00 pm, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 90th St., New York.

WASHINGTON -- A bill to advance dozens of federal programs stalled in the Senate on Monday afternoon as a narrow majority was unable to free it from the legislative grip of Senator Tom Coburn, the Oklahoma Republican who takes pride in being stubborn. The vote was 52 to 40 in favor of the Advancing America's Priorities Act, but 60 ''yes'' votes were required under Senate rules. The act embraces dozens of programs costing an estimated $10 billion and covering health care, crime prevention, aid to victims of paralysis and other items.

BERK--Henrietta: 101, died July 28, 2008 at the Jewish Home in Rockleigh, New Jersey. Loving wife of the late D. Theodore Berk, and mother of the late Gloria Berk Steinfeld. Mrs. Berk is survived by grandchildren Caryn and Richard Swanson, Jeffrey and Karen Steinfeld, and Roberta and Jonathan Jacobson, and great-grandchildren Douglas and Joel Swanson, Gabrielle and Serena Steinfeld, and Gil and Daniel Jacobson. Henrietta Berk dedicated her life to the care of children. She joined other young women in the Godmothers' League of New York who provided a day nursery program for children of working mothers, which eventually became the Children's Day Treatment Center and School, and in 1985, the West End Day School. POCZIK--Evan. In loving memory, on Saturday July 26, 2008. A bright sunny day, a jagged arrow forever pierced our hearts and tragically took the young life of one of our own, Evan Poczik. All of us will remember him for his warmth and smile and how he would always ask, ''How have you been?'', ''How are the kids?'' His zest for life and the love of his family always shown through. To his father, Donald and his beloved wife, Brenda, and his adoring mother, Regina (deceased), his wife, Lisa and his children, Carly and Jenna, his sister, Susie and brother-in-law, Keith. RUBIN--Ronald. Son of David Rubin and Dena (nee Goodman) and brother to the late Kenneth Rubin. He was a brilliant and dedicated business leader, former President of William Allen & Company which was founded by his father. Ronald built the printing business to become a major force in the hospitality industry. He was a longtime member of Engineers Country Club where he enjoyed many rounds of golf. He brought joy and laughter to all those who knew and loved him. He passed away on July 27th, 2008 at the age of 73. He will be remembered for his remarkable energy and dedication to those he loved and who loved him. He is survived by his loving wife of 26 years Bernie, his children Deborah and Bruce, three grandchildren, his brother Steven and his beloved Gizmo (daddy's little boy). In addition, he leaves nieces and nephews and countless numbers of friends and business associates. He will be immensely missed by all. Visitation will be on Tuesday, July 29, 1-4 and 6-8pm. Funeral service will be on Wednesday July 30, 11:30am, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Donations can be made to American Action Fund for Blind Children and Adults.

GOLDEN--Elliott. The staff of The Kings County District Attorney's Office mourns with deep sorrow the passing of Elliott Golden, retired Supreme Court Justice, former Chief Assistant District Attorney and Interim District Attorney. He served the People of Kings County with distinction in his long and illustrious career in public service. We send our heartfelt condolences to his entire family and know that he will be missed by all who knew him. Charles J. Hynes, District Attorney and the staff of the Kings County District Attorney's Office GOLDEN--Elliott. Retired Justice of the Supreme Court, State of NY, died on July 25th, 2008 at age 82. Beloved husband of Ana, cherished father of Marjorie, Jeffrey and predeceased by son Peter, devoted stepfather of Robert, Elizabeth, William and John, brother of Alvin and adored grandfather of Melissa, Zachary, Karina, Veronica and William, Jr. Brooklyn born, Elliott was a graduate of the New York State Maritime Academy, Class of October, 1946 and subsequently Brooklyn Law School. A lifelong public servant, he started in the Brooklyn District Attorneys office and quickly became confidential assistant to then D.A., Edward S. Silver. He was appointed Chief Assistant District Attorney under Aaron Koota and served in that position until first being elected as a Judge of the Civil Court in 1976 and then as a Justice of the Supreme Court in Kings County, NY. He served on the bench until 1999 and then channeled his energies as a mediator. His reputation in the legal field was beyond reproach and was held in high regard by his colleagues across the nation. A former eagle scout, he was very active as a fundraiser for the Boy Scouts of America and was a recipient of their coveted Silver Beaver Award. He devoted much of his life to the Knights of Pythias, having joined at age 17 and remained active until his untimely death. He had served as Grand Chancellor of the State of New York and chairman of the Supreme Lodge law committee and was recently bestowed with the rarely awarded Supreme Lodge Medal. His dedication to his fellow citizens, fraternalism and his family was only matched by his love of golf, food and humor. He will be deeply missed by all those he touched but lives on in their memories.

RICHMOND--Julius B., M.D. It is with profound sadness that the members of the Board of Trustees of the Flight Attendant Medical Research Institute (FAMRI) note the passing of our beloved friend, mentor and educator --Julius B. Richmond, M.D. --formerly Surgeon General of the United States. Dr. Richmond over his long, diversified and splendid career did as much as anyone to protect and improve the health of his fellow citizens, and in particular children and adolescents. From 1953 to 1965 Dr. Richmond was chairman and professor of the Department of Pediatrics at the State University of New York, SUN Y College of Medicine and became dean in 1965, serving in that capacity until 1970. In 1965 Dr. Richmond was appointed by President Johnson as the first national director of Project Head Start in the Office of Economic Opportunity. Head Start became a year-round program after the first summer; approximately 750,000 children are enrolled in Project Head Start each year in approximately 1,500 centers across the United States. Head Start is a comprehensive child development program. In 1971 Dr. Richmond was recruited by the Harvard Medical School where he became a professor of psychiatry and human development and chairman and professor of the Department of Social and Preventative Medicine. Simultaneously, he was appointed professor of public health in the School of Public Health at Harvard. While at Harvard, Dr. Richmond was honored to receive a presidential dual appointment as both Surgeon General and Assistant Secretary for Health. Both positions required senate confirmation. Dr. Richmond was the first individual ever selected to occupy both positions. He had the responsibility in the federal public health sector for some 50,000 employees. During his tenure as Surgeon General, Dr. Richmond focused on tobacco control efforts through the publication of the 1979 Surgeon Generals Report, presenting overwhelming scientific evidence of the multiple harms caused by smoking. Dr. Richmond has received a number of honorary degrees including ones from Yale and Harvard. He continued his professional activities as the John D. McCarthy Professor of Health Policy Emeritus, monitoring students and colleagues, right up until the last couple of months. He continued to teach and write, striving to shape health policies for health promotion and disease prevention, with a special emphasis on children and families as well as the low income population. Dr. Richmond was a brilliant, caring, hands-on pediatrician for nearly 70 years. In later years he took on the onerous task of continuing to educate the public by testifying in open court about the dangers of tobacco and how the industry had for decades manipulated scientific data. In doing so Dr. Richmond voluntarily subjected himself to many days of grueling cross-examination, and he did this while refusing to accept compensation as a skilled expert witness. As Chairman of FA MRI's Medical Advisory Board, Dr. Richmond was vital to the Board of Trustees in helping to direct over $200,000,000 in grants to some of the finest medical schools and research institutions in America and the world --including five Centers of Excellence. The scientific research is aimed at eradicating the diseases caused by exposure to second hand tobacco smoke, the money having resulted from a class action lawsuit filed on behalf of nonsmoking flight attendants against the tobacco industry. Dr. Richmond had one of the most extraordinary and productive careers in the history of American monitoring science and public education. His professional accomplishments were mirrored by his sterling character traits. His sense of humor was legendary as was his refusal to acknowledge his own importance. He was endlessly patient, civil, tolerant, incredibly well-informed and a true pleasure to be around. The members of the Board of Trustees of FA MRI are eternally grateful for the guidance of Dr. Richmond over the past decade as well as for the pure pleasure of his company and insights. Board of Trustees Flight Attendant Medical Research Institute Miami, Florida

LAMB--Susan B., died quietly at her summer home on Shelter Island on Sunday, July 27th, after a two year struggle with lung and brain cancer. She was 72 years old. A New Yorker by birth and inclination, she was raised in Brooklyn and attended Cornell University, and graduated from Columbia Law School at the age of 21. She was the first female associate at Proskauer, Rose before marrying and moving to London where she and her husband owned a public relations firm, and where Lamb was an onair correspondent for the BBC. Upon returning to the United states, Lamb devoted nearly 40 years to raising funds for non-profit institutions, including New York University, the New York Public Library, the American Ballet Theater, Montefiore Medical Center and Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc. She was responsible for raising funds for many of the important educational and medical buildings built in New York during the 1970's-1980's. An avid reader, an accomplished raconteur and a skilled speaker, Lamb will be remembered for her sense of humor, her honesty, her innate sense of fairness and her mischievous smile. Everyone who knew her will miss her. She is survived by her daughter Fiona Lamb, and by her friend of many years, Carole Potter. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The New York Public Library. Services will be held on Wednesday, July 30th, at 1:00 pm, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 90th St., New York.

Deep in the forests of Germany's Harz Mountains, twilight is a time of magic. The light turns gray and ambient, and the colors - the green of moss, the brassy gold of pine needles, the violet of the wild blueberry bushes - pop out against the tall, brown, branchless trunks of pine trees. There's a stillness. The daytime hikers have returned to their villages, and the nocturnal animals have not yet woken. This is when you can almost believe the legends about Harz - that witches fly to the 3,747-foot-tall peak of Brocken, the tallest mountain in northern Germany, and that a strange creature called the Brocken Spectre patrols the misty trails.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- Indicative of his classy nature, Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese refrained from talking about this being his final season in the job during his remarks at the league's media day Tuesday.But one of the main questions here was who would replace Tranghese, one of the most respected leaders in college sports. The early consensus is that there is no consensus, unlike the Pac-10, which appears to be leaning toward hiring the former Stanford athletic director Ted Leland.The best list I could scrape together includes the senior associate commissioner John Marinatto, the associate commissioner Nick Carparelli, the associate commissioner Dan Gavitt, Louisville Athletic Director Tom Jurich and Connecticut Athletic Director Jeff Hathaway. Don't be surprised if a dark horse emerges, though. Marinatto would be considered the favorite, but there's a lot of golf left to play.The co-chairmen in charge of the search are the Pittsburgh president, Mark A. Nordenberg, and the Georgetown president, John J. DeGioia. Nordenberg checked in by phone to talk about the process. Here are a few highlights.He called it a "critical hire" because of all the hard work Tranghese had done to position the Big East among the B.C.S. conferences after the defections to the A.C.C. Nordenberg played down the notion of whether the candidate would be a football or basketball guy; the league has eight football-playing members and 16 in basketball."In terms of the general functioning of the conference today, I don't really sense that tension as a constant part of life," Nordenberg said. "Clearly both sports are very important to us. It would be hard to imagine that we would recommend someone not committed to both and a capable leader in terms of pushing both sports forward."Football is generally given priority in college sports because it generates more television and ticket revenue.Nordenberg didn't give a whole lot of hints as to what type of candidate the Big East would be looking for. Tranghese said in his teleconference to announce his impending retirement that he'd prefer his replacement to be someone familiar with the Big East. Nordenberg said that he understood that thinking but that the league would be open to outside candidates as well.Nordenberg said the league would begin a "deliberate" search once the school year begins and said that Tranghese had shown flexibility in moving forward."Mike has been totally himself," Nordenberg said, "indicating that his own personal plans can be adjusted to the needs of the conference. That is, if we find someone early, he'll leave early. If it takes long, and that means extending his time, he can adjust to that as well. We're not locked into any time frame."Stay tuned to what will surely be one of the most intriguing hires in college sports this year.

The Knicks waived Taurean Green and Bobby Jones, one day after acquiring the seldom-used players in a trade with the Denver Nuggets. The moves were expected as the Knicks overhaul their roster under Donnie Walsh, the team’s president for basketball operations, and the new coach, Mike D’Antoni.

Nevada’s athletic commission and attorney general filed a complaint against the U.F.C. fighter James (The Sandman) Irvin, contending he tested positive for two unapproved painkillers after his July 19 fight against Anderson Silva. A urine test conducted the night of the fight in Las Vegas showed methadone and oxymorphone in Irvin’s system, the complaint said. Irvin was knocked out in the first round against the smaller Silva.

Deweycheatumnhowe will put a 14-race winning streak on the line from the rail Saturday in the $1.5 million Hambletonian at Meadowlands Racetrack. Deweycheatumnhowe, the dominant 3-year-old trotter, was made the 2-5 favorite to capture the Hambletonian, harness racing’s biggest prize. He is the first unbeaten horse to reach the final.
INTERNATIONAL.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on July 11 about an inquiry into the Denver Art Museum by two committees of the Association of Art Museum Directors, citing information in The Denver Post, omitted The Post’s mention of the first report about the inquiry. The Post said it was revealed on Tyler Green’s Modern Art Notes blog.
The Books column on Tuesday, about “The Best Practice,” by Charles Kenney, misstated the name of the publisher. It is PublicAffairs, not Public Affairs Books.

The Sports Business column on Tuesday, about the treasures stored beneath the National Baseball Hall of Fame, misstated the title of Tom Shieber, a Hall employee. He is the senior curator — not the chief curator, the position held by Ted Spencer.

An obituary on Monday about Donald G. Stokes, chairman of the British Leyland Motor Corporation, misstated the year that Leyland Motor Corporation and British Motor Holdings merged. It was 1968, not 1986.

An art review on Friday about “Pretty Ugly,” a group exhibition at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise and the Maccarone gallery, both on Greenwich Street in the West Village, misidentified the current position of the organizer, Alison Gingeras. She is chief curator of the François Pinault Collection, which is based in Venice; she is no longer an adjunct curator at the Guggenheim Museum. The review also misstated the date of an exhibition she produced at the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris, “Dear Painter, Paint Me: Painting the Figure Since Late Picabia.” It was in 2002, not 2003.

An article on July 21 about issues confronting the worldwide Anglican Communion during its gathering in Canterbury, England, misstated the background of Katharine Jefferts Schori, the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States, who is attending the gathering. She was born in Florida, grew up in the Seattle area and had been the bishop of the Diocese of Nevada before she was elected to her current position in 2006. She is not “of Boston.”.

An article in some editions on Monday about Verizon’s entrance into the television programming market in New York City misstated the number of high-definition channels offered in its $94.99 promotional package. Fifty-four are included — not 100, or “nearly double what rivals are offering.”.

An article on Monday about the outcome of the Tour de France misstated the given name of the Austrian rider who finished in third place and won the polka-dot jersey as the best mountain climber. He is Bernhard Kohl, not Bernard.

A film review last Wednesday about “Boy A” misstated the manner in which the character Jack takes the drug Ecstasy while out drinking with co-workers. One of them gives him a pill and he swallows it without knowing what it is; a co-worker does not slip it into his beer.

A picture caption on Monday with a theater review of “Around the World in 80 Days” at the Irish Repertory Theater, using information provided by the theater, reversed the identities of two actors. John Keating was at the left, and Jay Russell was in the center. (The actor at the right, Daniel Stewart, was correctly identified.).

Massachusetts moved closer on Tuesday to erasing a hurdle that blocked most out-of-state gay men and lesbians from marrying here. Following a vote by the State Senate two weeks ago, the House voted on Tuesday to repeal a 1913 law that prevented Massachusetts from marrying out-of-state couples if their marriages would not be legal in their home states.

The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with deep sadness the passing of Rubin Schieren, beloved father of George Schieren and fatherin-law of Ellen Schieren. HAGGERTY--John F. ''Jack'', on July 28, at age 71. Husband of the late Elizabeth Ann (nee Jones). Father of John Jr., Marianne Zidar (Thomas), and Bart. Beloved brother of Bert (Eileen), Noreen, the late Msgr. James J. and Mary. Devoted grandfather of Declan, Elizabeth, Owen and Liam. Graduate of Brooklyn Prep, Fordham College and Fordham Law School. He was an attorney who served as a Lt. in the JAG Corps in the United States Navy at Pensacola Naval Air Station. He was the Chief Counsel to late New York State Senate Majority leader Warren Anderson and the Majority Conference. He also served as the Queens County Republican Chairman and as President of the Forest Hills Gardens Corporation. He was a former board member of the Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens and most recently served on the NYS Commission on Health Care in the 21st century. He was retired from the practice of law where he had been a partner in the law firm of Haggerty and Rinaldi in Garden City. Visiting hours Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 98-07 Ascan Ave., Forest Hills 11375, Thursday and Friday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Our Lady of Mercy Church Saturday 10:30am. Interment St. John Cemetery Middle Village. Donations in Lieu of flowers, may be made in his memory to Fordham Univ. Endowment Fund Bronx, NY.

We shall all miss her. Nat Yalowitz, President & CEO David Smith, Chairman

YAZIGI--Monique. Died on July 22nd at home after a long illness. She was 45 years old. Her memorable articles for the NY Times on fashion and society (all preserved on the Times website) illumined the Sunday Styles and City Weekly sections. With sparkling wit and savvy style, disarming charm and generosity of spirit, she proved that one can wield a scalpel-sharp pen without inflicting wounds. She is survived by cousins and countless friends who dearly miss her in life, as in print.

BERK--Henrietta: 101, died July 28, 2008 at the Jewish Home in Rockleigh, New Jersey. Loving wife of the late D. Theodore Berk, and mother of the late Gloria Berk Steinfeld. Mrs. Berk is survived by grandchildren Caryn and Richard Swanson, Jeffrey and Karen Steinfeld, and Roberta and Jonathan Jacobson, and great-grandchildren Douglas and Joel Swanson, Gabrielle and Serena Steinfeld, and Gil and Daniel Jacobson. Henrietta Berk dedicated her life to the care of children. She joined other young women in the Godmothers' League of New York who provided a day nursery program for children of working mothers, which eventually became the Children's Day Treatment Center and School, and in 1985, the West End Day School. Mrs. Berk joined the board of the School in 1965 and served as its President from 1971 until 1998. She and her husband were also active members of Temple Emanuel in New York. Funeral services are private. Contributions can be made to the West End Day School, 225 W. 71st St., New York, NY 10023.

POCZIK--Evan. In loving memory, on Saturday July 26, 2008. A bright sunny day, a jagged arrow forever pierced our hearts and tragically took the young life of one of our own, Evan Poczik. All of us will remember him for his warmth and smile and how he would always ask, ''How have you been?'', ''How are the kids?'' His zest for life and the love of his family always shone through. To his father, Donald and his beloved wife, Brenda, and his adoring mother, Regina (deceased), his wife, Lisa and his children, Carly and Jenna, his sister, Susie and brother-in-law, Keith. There are no words from within that can adequately express what we feel. We offer you our condolences and prayers, our love and friendship and as many shoulders to lean on for as long as you need them. We are the partners, friends, associates and employees

TRADE TALKS FALL APART World trade talks collapsed in Geneva after seven years of negotiations, indicating that the ability of the United States to dictate policy is coming to an end. Some analysts say they believe the price of oil will continue to decline. [A1.]

A Sudanese court sentenced to death eight rebels from Darfur who were convicted on Tuesday of participating in a bold attack on the capital, Khartoum, in May. The rebels were part of a force that sped across the desert from Darfur, in western Sudan, and came within a few miles of the presidential palace. After fierce house-to-house fighting, Sudanese police officers and paramilitary forces defeated them. Rebel leaders criticized the sentences, saying the men who had been captured were prisoners of war, not criminals.
